The Taiyuan incident occurred in Taitung. In New York City, Huang Wenxiang and Zheng Zhifei attempted to shoot the Vice President of the Executive Council, Chiang Ching-guo. In 1971, United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758 expelled the People's Republic of China from the United Nations, replacing it with the People's Republic of China. Zhang Shunhong and Chen Guo were oppressed by the Communist Party of China when they promoted the conservation of fishing in the University magazine. The government of the Republic of China feared that Chinese nationalism would make Taiwanese identify with the People's Republic of China, deliberately suppressing Taiwanese "Chinese Identity" began to loosen. In 1972, President Chiang Kai-shek was appointed to the Executive Council, and began selecting Taiwanese elites as cabinet members, a policy popularly known as "blowing Taiwan blue." Of the 16 cabinet ministers, six were Honduran, three were from the Political Affairs Committee, and the rest were foreign ministers. In addition, the government has banned the broadcasting of more than one hour of Chinese language programming each day, and has suppressed the use of Taiwanese (also known as Hokkien) and Mandarin (also known as Mandarin) as the official languages of Taiwan. In 1973, Lin Wei-min founded the Yunmen Dance Collection, hoping that "Chinese compose, Chinese arrange, Chinese dance to Chinese," emphasizing the country's identity. The director of the newspaper, Mr. Qianfu, demanded that the television station's puppet show be translated into Chinese. In June 1974, the Taiwanese-language puppet show "Unzhou Dajuang" (雲州大儒侠), which was broadcast on Taiwanese television, was banned because the Kuomintang considered it to be a violation of the national language movement, and the director of the news bureau, Qian Yuan, agreed to cooperate with the policy. In the same year, the philosophy faculty of Taiwan University was attacked by Feng Huxiang, and many professors who were opposed to the Kuomintang were deposed. In 1976, Wang was wounded by a mailbag bomb.

Yoshiyuki 单田芳 (December 17, 1934 – September 11, 2018) was a member of this roster. On 11 September 2018, at 3:30 pm, he died of illness at the Sino-Japanese Friendship Hospital. In the 1950s, Fang's father was wrongfully imprisoned, and his mother and father divorced. He enrolled in Northeast University in 1953, but dropped out of school for physical and family reasons to pursue the art of commentary, studying under Li Qinghai. In 1955, Yoshida joined Kurayama Kugyo, and was recommended by Saikawa Taiko master Zhao Yufeng and commentator Yang Tianrong. Twenty-four years old, officially on the podium. Not only do they perform traditional commentaries, but there's a lot of new writing. During the revolution, they were convicted, persecuted, even kicked in the teeth by the rebels. He had fractures on both sides of his body. After the end of the Cultural Revolution, Yoshida was able to return to the stage to preach. From Anshan People's Radio, it was gradually accepted by critics all over the country, and became one of the best people in mainland China. According to statistics, at the peak of the day, 1.2 billion listeners listened to Fang's reviews. 单田芳 continues to develop the art of commentary, founded Beijing 单田芳艺术传播有限公司, serving as the chairman. On September 11, 2018, at 3:30 p.m., Yoshida passed away at the China-Japan Friendship Hospital at the age of 84. "Three Kingdoms" (三國演義), "The Journey to the West" (西遊記), "Hoshin Engi" (封神演義), "Suikoden" (水 Margden), "Daimyo Genryo" (大明英烈), "Kokuin Genryo" (國英烈), "Zong Guo Han" (曾國藩), "Ranzei Owl" (乱世梟雄), tells the life of Zhang Shulin and Zhang Xue Liang's father. "Three Grandmasters and Five Grandmasters" tells the story of three Grandmasters (Northern Grandmaster Oyang Chun, Southern Grandmaster Xing Zhao, Ding Clan Two Grandmasters Ding Zhao Lan, Ding Zhao Hui (the two being one Grandmaster)) and five Grandmasters (Dragon Rat Lufang, Chetchi Rat Han Zheng, Dragon Mountain Rat Xu Qing, Jiangping River Rat Jiangping, Kam Mao Rat Bai Yutang, the Five Brothers) who assisted Qing Tian Bao in the justice and justice case during the reign of Emperor Ninzong in the Northern Song Dynasty.

The Battle of Nanjing (Chinese: 明武宗南巡之争), also known as the Battle of Zhengde Nanjing (正德南巡之争), was a political event in March 1519 in the Zhengde dynasty of the Ming Dynasty. The emperor, under the influence of Jiang Bing, issued the Southern Rescript, which was opposed by a group of hundred officials of the Ming Dynasty, and was eventually executed or degraded by more than 100 officials, and the emperor was restored to life. In June of the same year, Ning Wang Zhu Shiho Rebellion, historically called "Shiho Rebellion". Although the rebellion was pacified at the end of July, Emperor Wu continued to conceal his military achievements, and in August of the same year, he began a southern crusade to suppress the rebellion. After the ascension of Ming Emperor Wuzong, he liked to play, favored eunuchs and traitors, and revolted against the "eight tigers" led by Liu Jin. Ten years later, Emperor Wuzong again favored Jiang Bing and others, the Imperial Court fell by the wayside, the Mongols invaded the territory of the Da'yan Khan, and the Ning Dynasty attempted a rebellion. In the meantime, the emperor continued to build imperial palaces in Xuanfu, and traveled to Taiyuan, Yulin, etc., spending large amounts of money. In the spring of 1519, Emperor Wuzong returned to Juntianfu. In March of the same year, the imperial edict was issued to prepare for the southern expedition. When the decree was issued, there was an uproar inside and outside the court. It is said that the kings of ancient times went on hunting expeditions in order to coordinate the measure of sound, the measure of unity, to seek the elders, to inquire about the suffering of the people, to depose officials, to promote the intelligence, to examine the achievements of various officials, to give them promotions, to make them fit for a position, so that the lords were afraid, but the people lived in peace. It is not uncommon to find that, in the case of the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty, the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were similar to each other, and that the emperors of the Han dynasty and the Qin dynasty were

Most of these mountains are located in Luanchuan, Song County, Luoning, Ruyang, Xin'an, Yiyang, Enshi, Ichuan, and Mengjin. It is divided into three major river systems: the Yellow River, the Huai River, and the Yangtze River. The Yellow River, the Luo River, the I River, the Qing River, the Magnet River, the Iron Luan River, the Jian River, and the Xian River wind among them. In ancient times, Luoyang was known as "Four sides of the mountains, six rivers flowing together, eight county towns, ten provinces." In terms of biological resources, the forest plants of Luoyang City have 173 higher plant families, 830 genera, 2308 species and 198 variants, 6 variants, there are precious rhododendron trees, cedar, incense, ginkgo, mountain white peony, etc., there are Huashan pine, rhododendron, birch, oil birch and other forest trees. Luoyang City is rich in wildlife resources, the city has 342 species of terrestrial vertebrates, of which there are over 190 rare animals, mainly minnows, minnows, otters, ospreys and a variety of precious birds. The remaining 480 species of natural medicines, spices, tannins, windbreakers, flaxseed and other precious medicines; in terms of mineral resources, Luoyang is rich in mineral resources, and the prospects for development are broad. Twenty-six kinds of molybdenum, aluminum, gold, silver, tungsten, coal, iron, zinc, crystal, lead and other minerals have been discovered. It is one of the world's three largest molybdenum mines; in terms of water resources, the largest hydropower hub in the middle and lower reaches of the Yellow River is the Small Wave Basin Hydropower Hub Project located on the main Yellow River drainage channel at the intersection of Mengjin County, Luoyang City and Jiyuan City, Henan Province. Luoyang is located on the southern edge of the warm temperate zone to the northern subtropical transition zone, abundant light, continental monsoon climate, four distinct seasons, drought in the spring, hot and rainy in the summer, mild in the autumn, cold in the winter.

In the 1990s, Ashton served as a policy advisor to several institutions, including as chairman of the Hartford County Hospital Authority from 1998 to 2001, as chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Home School of the Akron Grammar School, and as vice-chairman of the National Council of Single Parents. In 1999, Ashton was made a life peer by the Labour government in Berkeley, and became Baroness Ashton of Upholland. In June 2001, she was appointed to the position of Undersecretary of State in the Ministry of Education and Skills, where from 2002 to 2004 she was responsible for coordinating the Ministry's "Sure Start" program, which promoted reforms to improve the government's policies in the areas of early childhood education and the family. In September 2004, he was appointed Under Secretary of State for Constitutional Affairs, with responsibility for policy on the National Archives and the Public Defender's Office. Ashton was appointed to the Privy Council in May 2006, and moved to the newly created Department of Justice in May 2007 as Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. In 2005, he was named "Officer of the Year" by The House Magazine and "Nobleman of the Year" by the Fourth Estate. In 2006, she was awarded the "Politician of the Year" at the annual Stonewall Awards in recognition of her work in advancing the cause of gay rights in the United Kingdom. When Ashton was initially nominated as EU Trade Commissioner, she was criticised for her lack of experience in dealing with trade matters, with British Conservative MEP Daniel Hannan criticising her for having "no trade experience, but the EU is going to have tough negotiations with Canada, South Korea and the World Trade Organisation".

The Chinese People's Liberation Army Press (Chinese: 中国人民解放军军出版社), located in Beijing, is a comprehensive publishing house under the Chinese People's Liberation Army Press Communication Center. In June 1948, the CPC approved the establishment of the Fourth Bureau of the CPC Military Commission. In January 1950, the four bureaus of the War Department of the Central Military Commission were transformed into the Military Publishing Bureau of the Military Training Department of the People's Revolutionary Military Commission of the Central People's Government. In July 1952, it was transferred to the General Staff of the People's Revolutionary Military Committee of the Central People's Government, and was renamed the Military Publishing Bureau of the People's Revolutionary Military Committee of the Central People's Government. On April 21, 1955, the Military Publishing Bureau of the Military Commission was renamed the Military Publishing Department of the Directorate of Training of the People's Liberation Army. On December 11, 1958, the People's Liberation Army's Directorate of Training was abolished, and the Ministry of Military Publication was transferred to the Ministry of General Staff of the People's Liberation Army, known as the Ministry of Military Publication of the General Staff of the People's Liberation Army. On January 18, 1963, the Ministry of Military Publication was renamed the People's Liberation Army General Staff Publication Bureau (Chinese: 中国人民解放军总参谋部出版局), and was subordinated to the Military Training Department of the General Staff of the People's Liberation Army. In July 1965, the General Political Department of the People's Liberation Army requested the CPC Central Committee and the Central Military Commission to approve the establishment of the People's Liberation Army Soldiers' Publishing House on the basis of the Publication Bureau of the General Staff, which was incorporated into the General Political Department. In December 1966, the People's Liberation Army Soldiers' Publishing House was officially founded by combining the Publication Bureau of the General Staff Department, the Editorial Department of Starbursts of the General Political Department, and the editors of a series of books by the People's Liberation Army Literary Society. In December 1983, with the approval of the Central Military Commission, the People's Liberation Army Soldiers' Publishing House was renamed the People's Liberation Army Publishing House. In June 1951, the "Liberation Army Literature" was founded.

In addition to the development of its power, the emperor constantly launched an invasion of the Ming Dynasty. In 1635, King Jin conquered Chahar and defeated the Mongol Grand Khan Rindan Khan, and in 1636, he was given a copy of the "Treasury of Letters" by the son of Rindan Khan, thus seizing control of the Mongolian region as a symbol of the power of the Khan; in the same year, he submitted to the Southern Mongolian tribe, convened in Shenyang Khuliltai was honored as "Bogda Chechin Khan", and personally changed the new empire to the Great Qing Dynasty, the year of the ascension of the Emperor Sudha as the successor to the Great Yuan Dynasty, formally establishing the second imperial dynasty in Chinese history — the Qing Dynasty. In 1643, the Emperor died. His younger brother Dorgon fought for the throne with his eldest son Gog, and was eventually succeeded by his ninth son Fulin, who was regent of Dorgon and Jirgalang. The temple's name, Taizong (太宗, 号, 号, 天兴国弘德彰武宽温仁圣睿孝敬敏昭定隆道显功文皇帝, ᠠ   ᠠ, Ming: ᠠ   ᠠ, Murind: taidzung genggiyen šu hūwangdi), is buried in the Shingjing Three Mausoleums. The emperor is also referred to as the emperor of Hong, the emperor of Huangtai, the emperor of Taiji. And the real names of the kingdoms are disputed. The Russian anthropologist G.V. Gorsky believed that the real name of the "Imperial Crown" was "Abakhai". This was once widely accepted by Western scholars, but the name did not appear in the Chinese and Manchu texts of the time, and was therefore considered erroneous. In the Ming Dynasty chronicles of Chen Renxi, the emperor appeared under the name of "Drinking stick". He was born on October 25, 1592, the eighth son of Nurhachi.

Pluto's orbital periods are close to 247.3 years (1.5 times Neptune's orbital period), with variations of only a few years. Comparatively special Pluto minor planets exist: they can also be compared to QB1 objects. Due to Pluto's small mass, gravitational effects are usually negligible. However, the width of the resonance (the range of the semi-axis that produces the resonance) is very narrow, only a few times the size of Pluto's helix. Of course, depending on the original eccentricity, some Pluto asteroids may have left the resonance region due to interactions with Pluto. Numerical simulations suggest that the eccentricity of Pluto's small objects differs from that of Pluto by between 10% and 30%, and that it is unstable on a trillion-year scale. Built by international artist Wang Wenzhi, Moonshade Lake is fully integrated with Lantan Lake, creating nearly 90,000 visitors each year for the Chinese New Year, and was awarded the National Award for Excellence in Construction in 2015. There are 28 historic buildings in the park (including a forestry club and a forestry club built around 1914), divided into one building for senior managers, two buildings for managers and family members, four buildings for family members' dormitories, and a series of single-person dormitories. Not only are the buildings well-planned, spacious and elegant, but throughout the complex there are public bathhouses and guesthouses, fulfilling the dual functions of living and business. On October 26, 2005, the Cultural Bureau of Chiayi City Government declared it a historic building of Chiayi City. After four years of extensive renovation in 2008 and a cost of over 400 million yuan, the opening ceremony was held on 29 September 2012 together with the Song of the Forest. Using wood, railroad tracks, maple trees and stone provided by the Forestry Department, the Song of the Forest creates this large-scale installation, which is 14 meters high and about 55 meters long, with the theme of the towering tree and the railroad tracks of the Alishan Railway. The forestry tourism zone of Chiayi City along the East Forest Road and Chunghwa Road has been created to recreate the unique scenic beauty of Chiayi 'wood capital'. Before Huang Minhui became mayor of Chiayi, Chiayi City had a debt of 3.9 billion yuan. After Huang Min-hui took office, he initiated a process of opening up resources, cutting special expenses, all chiefs' special expenses were reduced by 75 percent; then Chiayi City through the Central Social Welfare, Education, Infrastructure and Finance four-pronged assessment, nearly five years increased the general subsidy of 134.8 million, until before Huang Min-hui left office, Chiayi City reduced the public debt by 28.5 billion yuan.

The Yuan dynasty, one of the southern factions of the early Republic of China, was represented by Tang Jiyao and Longyun, whose power extended to Yunnan and parts of Guizhou and Sichuan. One of the warlord factions in the Southwest. The Yunnan army, led by Tang Jiyao, occupied Yunnan and Guizhou provinces. The Yunnan army originated in the 19th town of the new army at the end of the Qing Dynasty, and after the Xinhai Revolution, it became a force for the maintenance of the republic, and the military power was held by Cai Zhao, Tang Jiyao, and so on. In October 1913, Cai was transferred to Beijing by Yuan Shikai, and Tang Jiyao succeeded him as governor and civil governor of Yunnan, gradually seizing control of the Yunnan army and the province. Later in the war, Tang expanded his army, besides controlling Yunnan and Guizhou, and sent Yunnan troops into Sichuan to seize territory and plunder wealth. Between April and August 1917, he fought several battles with Liu Zhenhao's troops in Chengdu, Shiyang, and the Inner River. In July 1917, after his return to the post of Prime Minister, he refused to restore parliament and the Provisional Treaty of the Republic of China. Sun Yat-sen unveiled the flag of Protectorate, Tang Jiyao used the name "Protectorate", implemented expansion, reorganized the Yunnan army into the "Yasukuni Army", and assumed the position of commander-in-chief. In December, he joined forces with Yuanzo Ming's Guizhou army and Xuan Ke's Guangxi army, and was appointed commander-in-chief of the "Joint Army of Guangxi and Yunnan". In February of the following year, his troops entered Chengdu, again controlling Sichuan. At the same time, some military leaders of Shaanxi, Hunan, Fujian and other provinces, also called "Yasukuni," Tang Jiyao Ichuan, Yunnan, Guizhou, Hubei, Yunnan, Shaanxi, Xiangxiang, Min eight provinces joint army commander, the Yunnan warlord's reputation reached its peak. In 1918, the Yuan and former Gui factions colluded to sabotage the Northern Expeditionary Forces, and reorganized the Guangdong Military Guards Government, forcing Sun Yat-sen to leave Guangdong.

In 1999, the following regulations were issued: a seal with a diameter of 5 cm, a centrally issued national emblem, issued by the State Council. The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs of the People's Republic of China, also known as the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, is one of the constituent departments of the State Council of the People's Republic of China. The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs is mainly responsible for coordinating research and organizing the implementation of the strategy, planning and policy of the "three farms", supervising and managing cultivation, animal husbandry, fisheries, agricultural reclamation, agricultural mechanization, agricultural product quality and safety, and managing agricultural investment. The Office of the Central Leading Group for Rural Work is located in the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs. In October 1949, the Ministry of Agriculture of the Central People's Government was established. It was renamed the Ministry of Agriculture of the People's Republic of China in 1954. On June 22, 1970, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China decided to abolish the Ministry of Agriculture, the Ministry of Forestry and the Ministry of Fisheries and to establish the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry. On February 23, 1979, the Sixth Session of the Standing Committee of the Fifth National People's Congress decided to abolish the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry and split the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry. On May 4, 1982, the Ministry of Agriculture, the Ministry of Agricultural Reclamation and the State Administration of Fisheries were merged to form the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries. In April 1988, the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries was abolished in accordance with the State Council's institutional reform program. On March 17, 2018, the First Session of the Thirteenth National People's Congress adopted the Decision of the First Session of the Thirteenth National People's Congress on the Institutional Reform Programme of the State Council, and ratified the Institutional Reform Programme of the State Council. The program stipulates: "Formation of the Ministry of Agriculture Rural. The Ministry of Agriculture, together with the State Development and Reform Commission's agricultural investment projects, the Ministry of Finance's integrated agricultural development projects, the Ministry of Land and Resources' agricultural land rehabilitation projects, and the Ministry of Water Resources' agricultural land water conservancy construction projects, will be integrated into the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, which will be a constituent department of the State Council.

Another 2,000-strong Burmese army attacked the crossing at Wan Hsala, just south of Raposa, closer to Raposa, and ambushed Raposa. On the side of the Saratoga crossing, due to the remoteness of the isolated military units, it was difficult to reinforce the crossing in a short time, so they had to temporarily mobilize the anti-communist university students who were being trained, led by the head of education, Lieutenant General Li Zhenfeng Unified Command, and reinforced the crossing by troops from three directions. On the 21st, Lieutenant General Li Zhenfeng's reinforcements arrived, and after a fierce battle with the Burmese, they won a decisive victory, bloodied the Salweng River, killed 403 Burmese, captured 71 prisoners, captured one field gun, 21 small guns, 81 mortars, 42 machine guns, rifles, carbines, submachine guns, 542 handguns, 15 telescopes, 21 rubber boats. Forty-one soldiers were killed and 54 wounded. In the Mengbu area, the Burmese army, under the command of General Zasu, the Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the Army, surrounded and attacked Li Guohui's quarters, and on the 17th, the relief troops arrived, clashed on both sides, finally crushed the Burmese army, killed 111 Burmese soldiers, captured 49 prisoners, captured 81 mortars, 21 machine guns, 201 rifles, 33 submachine guns, 300 Burmese swords, and numerous ammunition. Twenty-one soldiers were wounded, and the head of the anti-communist university student corps, Sun Yat-sen, sacrificed himself bravely. On 23 April 1953, when the United Nations adopted Resolution 707 by a 59–0 vote (the Republic of China abstained), General Li Mia, the commander of the Burmese army, was recalled to Taiwan, the Republic of China government declared to the international community that the troops that had not withdrawn from Taiwan were no longer related to the Republic of China government.

In June, the occupation of Chongqing, Ming Rui King Zhu Changhao, Sichuan governor Chen Shiqi, Chongqing governor Wang Zhongjun, etc. were executed. On 9 August, he defeated Chengdu, and the governor Long Wenguang, general Liu Jiaying, Shu King Zhu Yishu, and his concubines all committed suicide. Zhang Chengzhong called it the 600,000th army, and soon took control of most of Sichuan's provinces and counties. On August 16, Zhang Xianzhong accepted the throne of Qin from Li Zhengfeng. On December 4, he ascended the throne as Emperor Taizei, changing the yuan to Taishun, and renaming Chengdu as the capital of the west. In 1646, when the Qing army came to the north of the river, Zhang sent an army from Chengdu to fight against the Qing army, killing all of his concubines and children, and avoiding his defeat, his relatives were captured by the Qing army. Liu Zhenchuan surrendered to the Qing army. On January 2, 1647, Zhang Xianzhong was shot and killed by Liu Jinzhong, a forward of Prince Hog of Qingsu, during a reconnaissance of the Sun River in front of Dobong-ji Temple on Mt. Phoenix (15 km southeast of Dobong-jo Castle, at the junction of Saichong County and Salt Pavilion County). After Zhang's death, his four sons-in-law (李定國,孫可望,劉文秀,艾能奇) joined forces against Qing, and fought in Guizhou and Yunnan. According to legend, Zhao Zhenzhong's way of life was that Zhitong Emperor (who was also Zhao Zhenzhong's surname, i.e. Wenchang Emperor) promised not to kill the villagers, so Zhao Zhenzhong regarded Zhitong as his brother, so Zhitong's inhabitants were not slaughtered completely, and later Pei and Jia people worshipped the statue of Zhang Liping Temple, which was destroyed by the Qing Dynasty, and rebuilt to this day. According to the author of the book, "The Last Days of the Ming Dynasty" (明史纪事本末), Zhang Chengzhong committed the following acts of slaughter: Yan Bai was born with an ancient poem "The Seven Deadly Monument" (七殺碑), which was strongly written and often mistakenly thought to be the handwriting of Zhang Chengzhong.

He Xiangtang (Chinese: 何香凝; 27 June 1878 – 1 September 1972) was a Hong Kong-born Chinese revolutionary, politician, pioneer of the women's movement, nationalist painter, and elder of the Kuomintang reform party. She was the wife of Liao Zhongkai, and both were early members of the Sun Yat-sen-led Chinese League. He advocated equality between men and women, and organized China's first celebration of International Women's Day. The assassination of Liao Zhongkai in 1925 kept Ho away from party politics for the next 20 years, but he remained active in organizing support for the anti-Japanese war. In 1948, he co-founded the Revolutionary Committee of the Kuomintang of China, and served in numerous high-ranking government positions after the founding of the People's Republic of China. He Xiangtang is a famous painter of the Lingnan Painting School, whose works were used in the special stamps issued by China Post. The collection, exhibition and study of works of art by He Xiangziu. In June 2017, the Academic Committee of the Centennial Exhibition of Cantonal Art announced the specially selected 21 Cantonal artists in the history of Cantonal Art Centennial, including Ho Xiangtang, Li Tiefu, Luo Guo Liu, Gao Jianfu, Chen Shujin, Lin Fengming, Gao Qifeng, Zhao Shaoxing, Guanshan Yue, and so on. He was born on 27 June 1878 to a merchant family in Hong Kong. As a child, Ho displayed a strong feminist ideology, and her father, in accordance with traditional Chinese customs, demanded that she be entangled in prostitution, which she vehemently resisted. In 1904, he returned to Hong Kong, gave birth to his daughter, Liao Mengsheng, left her to her family to look after, and then returned to Tokyo. While in Tokyo, Ho and Liao met the Chinese revolutionary Sun Yat-sen and joined the Sun Yat-sen-led Chinese League.

Due to starvation in the mountains, they had to go downhill to attack the city, and encountered Spanish ambushes, killing around 25,000 people. Later, the Spanish deceived the Ming court into saying that the Chinese would riot and kill the Chinese. In 1604, the Emperor issued the Emperor's decree: Lu Song He (呂宋酋) should kill the merchants, and punish the officials for their crimes. It is believed that the death penalty was imposed on him, and that he was sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of his wife and children, but he did not commit the crime. The Chinese then went to Lu Song again, and the barbarians profited from the Chinese market, but they did not reject it, and they were reunited for a long time. In 1609, more than 20,000 Chinese were murdered because Chinese merchants protested overtaxation. Six years after the massacre, 50,000 Chinese merchants were massacred by Spaniards in Luzon, Philippines. There's some controversy about how this will be handled in the morning. In 1639, the Spaniards forced the Chinese to pay high-value identification taxes and rents, which were resisted, and the Spaniards again massacred the Chinese, and the Ming Dynasty was deeply engulfed in warfare: the Ming army gathered 300,000 men from nine sides and defeated the eight flags of Manchuria, resulting in the overthrow of the entire army; locusts, droughts, famine, and starvation occurred in Shaanxi, Henan, Shandong, etc.; Li Jianzheng led 17 cavalry across the central plain, gathered 500,000 troops; Zhang Zhenzhong rebelled in Hubei Valley City against the Ming, inflicted havoc on two lakes, and destroyed the Yueyang Tower in the fire. Chiang Zhongling (Chinese: 蒋仲玲; September 21, 1922 – March 18, 2015) was a retired General of the Republic of China Army, who served as Commander of the Sixth Army, Commander-in-Chief of the Kinmen Defense Command, Commander-in-Chief of the Army, Chief of the Presidential Staff, Minister of Defense, Political Affairs Commissioner of the Executive Yuan, Cultural Construction Commissioner of the Executive Yuan, Chairman of the Presidential Administration and Vice President of the Kuomintang. In January 1967, he was promoted to Major General, and in July 1967, he was appointed Director of the Military Training Department and Commander of the Student Corps of the Army Military Academy. In August 1968, he was appointed commander of the 4th Reserve Division. In December 1969, he was appointed commander of the 6th Reserve Division. In November 1970, he was reassigned as the commander of the 26th Infantry Division, where he participated in anti-tank exercises. In July 1972, he was appointed Chief of Staff of the Kinmen Defense Command. In April 1973, he was appointed commander of the Third Army, and in November, he was appointed commander of the Ninth Army. He was promoted to lieutenant general in January 1974. In July 1975, he was appointed deputy commander of the Kinmen Defense Command. In April 1976, he enrolled in the War College, where he was promoted to the rank of general officer. In April 1977, he was appointed commander of the 6th Army Corps, and during his tenure, he participated in the 1978 "Han Wei Exercise" National Military Examination, and also served as a military review commander. In December 1979, he was appointed Commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, and was also a member of the Kinmen Political Affairs Committee.He was keen to operate the battlefield, cultivate the fighting force, do his utmost to prepare for the war, and strive for local construction for the well-being of the people.

After the Sino-Soviet War, both the Soviet Union and the People's Republic of China declared that they were the only ones to inherit Marxism-Leninism. In the People's Republic of China, Mao Zedong was officially proclaimed to have "combined Marxism with concrete Chinese practices," and then proclaimed Mao Zedong to have renewed Marxism as a whole on the basis that Mao Zedong Thought was a more advanced stage of Marxism. The Maoist parties of the Communist Party of China and the pro-CCP described their ideological foundations as "Marxist Leninism, Maoist Thought". After Mao's death, the Communist Party of Peru (Guanghui Road) coined the term "Maoist Marxism-Leninism" to replace the term "Maoist Marxism-Leninism-Maoist Thought". Since 1977, North Korea has gradually replaced Marxism-Leninism with subjective ideology as its guiding ideology. However, the government of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, due to its political and economic structure, is sometimes described as "Stalinist". The other three remaining socialist countries (Cuba, Vietnam, and Laos) also adopted Marxism-Leninism as their official ideology, although they gave it a different name for practical reasons. Some officially anti-communist countries have also used the term "Marxism" extensively. For example, the Republic of China (particularly after the removal of the Taiwanese throne, before the lifting of martial law) put forward a nationalist slogan, "Expel the Poles, restore China," and strictly restricted its citizens' access to so-called "Marxist books." However, what is known as "Marxism" has not been explained by the Republic of China officials, and is generally assumed to refer to the entire communist theory, including Marxism, Leninism, Marxism-Leninism, and Maoism.

During his tenure at the National Academy of Sciences, Wong planned and organized a series of Science and Humanities Dialogue Forums, and organized the first National Conference of the Humanities and Social Sciences. In 2000, he was appointed as a full-time member of the Executive Council of the Executive Yuan, responsible for the reconstruction of 921 after the earthquake disaster, and at the end of July 2001, as the Executive Chairman of the Executive Council of the Executive Yuan after the earthquake disaster reconstruction promoted as the commander of the fifth operational disaster relief zone in the central part of the Motegi windstorm disaster. In 2002, he transferred to the Ministry of Education, where he assumed the post of Minister under the Education Reform Measures Man Arashi, took charge of all aspects of the so-called Decade of Education Reform, nine-year integrated curriculum and multi-faceted university admission issues, and responded to the needs of society and learners to make significant adjustments and reinforcements; in addition, with universities directly involved, he promoted the development of seven research-oriented universities and the World-Class University Project (later 12), promoted the general university evaluation, and planned to establish the Higher Education Evaluation Center Foundation. The Judiciary, also known as the Judiciary, is one of the branches of government whose job is to uphold the law, enforce the law correctly, and resolve disputes; however, the specific definition of "justice" and the powers of the Judiciary vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. Judiciary refers to a court or a specific body that, in accordance with its statutory powers and procedures, specifically applies the law to the hearing and trial of civil and criminal cases. The common law holds that justice is trial and judgment. In the ordinary legal system, only the judiciary has the power to interpret the law (including the Constitution). In continental law, the court conducts a specific inquiry into the case; the judge summons witnesses, question witnesses, defendants, and so on. The court has the power to interpret the law, but does not necessarily have the final power to interpret the law. In addition, prosecutors are often part of the judicial system. Under ordinary law, the court does not conduct a specific inquiry into the case. The role of a judge or magistrate is merely to ensure that the plaintiff (or, in criminal cases, the government's lawyer) and the defendant are able to present their case fairly and reach a decision. If the defendant is charged with a serious crime (such as murder, rape, etc.), in some jurisdictions (such as Hong Kong, the United Kingdom, and the United States) it is the jury that decides whether the defendant is guilty, and the judge is solely responsible for determining the punishment. In common law, only the court has the power to interpret the law, and the court's interpretation and judgment of the law are binding on subsequent similar actions, becoming case law. In addition, prosecutors are often part of the administrative system. The primary function of the judiciary is the exercise of judicial power, i.e., the maintenance of social order through public coercion, the arbitration of interests and, in some countries, the interpretation of constitutions and laws.

Wang Faqin (Chinese: 王法勤; 1870 – 28 May 1941) was a Chinese political figure. Wang Faqin went to Japan to study abroad in the early years, and then dropped out of school and returned to his home country. He was elected to the House of Representatives in 1907. He was also a member of the League of Nations, and served as the Minister of Corrections of the League of Nations in Kyoto. After the establishment of the Republic of China, he served as Deputy Minister of the Kuomintang, and was elected as a member of the Provisional Provincial Assembly and a member of the First National Assembly of the Republic of China. After the Second Sino-Japanese War, he joined the Communist Party of China and participated in the Second Sino-Japanese War. In 1924, he joined the Kuomintang and was elected to the Kuomintang Central Executive Committee and the Northern Executive Committee. In the same year, he was appointed Commander-in-Chief of the Marine Corps of the Republic of China. In 1926, he continued to serve on the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang at the Second National Congress. The following year, he was elected a member of the Central Political Committee at the Second Third Plenary Session of the Kuomintang. He was later appointed a member of the Wuhan National Government, Minister of Commerce and Industry of the Kuomintang, and Minister of Labour. In 1928, he was appointed a member of the Beiping Political Subcommittee of the Central Political Conference of the Kuomintang. After that, he joined Wang's reformist faction, and together with Chen Gubo, Gu Mengyu and others formed the Chinese Kuomintang Reformed Comrades' Association. In 1930, he was appointed a permanent member of the Beiping Enlargement Conference, which was dominated by restructuring factions. At the end of 1931, Ning was elected to the 4th Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang after the Guangdong Kuomintang compromise. In 1935, he was elected a member of the 5th Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang and chairman of the Pension Committee. In 1939, he became a member of the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang. On May 28, 1941, Wang Faqin died in Chengdu at the age of 71.

Wu Yingzhuang (Chinese: 吴蕴初; September 29, 1891 – October 15, 1953) was a Chinese chemist, founder of the Chinese chlorine industry and an industrialist. He founded China's first perfume factory, chlorine factory, acid-resistant pottery factory, synthetic ammonia and nitric acid factory. In 1911, he graduated from Shanghai Military Academy, majoring in chemistry. In 1913, he became a chemical engineer at Hanyang Iron Works in Hankou, China. In 1916, he became the director of Hanyang Iron Works brick factory. Hanyang Military Factory was the head of science and chemistry and the head of pharmaceuticals. In 1919, he was appointed as an engineer and director of the Hankou Xiechang Fireworks Factory. In 1920, Wu founded the Incheon Beef Leather Factory in Shanghai. In the 1920s, following Japan's invention of taste buds, young Wu Yinchuan developed his own taste buds from grains in his lab. But Wu Yingzhuang, who had come out of the laboratory, encountered many obstacles, until he met Zhang Yiyun, the great soybean king of Zhejiang. It was Zhang's unique insight and hard work that led to the creation of the perfect combination of national industrial capital and technology, as well as the chemist Wu Yingzhuang, who had originally worn a long grey cloth and buried his head in the laboratory to invent, creating the taste of the great king known to all adults. (1) In 1923, the word "" flavor "" appeared on the front door of Zhang Yiyun's chain store, Zhang Jiaoyuan, and advertisements for "" Buddha Hand "" ran all over Shanghai's main thoroughfares. Tianqiao flavor factory is booming in the market, and the real boss, Zhang Yiyun, is always behind the scenes. In the list of shares of that year, Wu had 10 percent of the shares, and in fact, the 5,000 yuan he had invested was all donated by Zhang Yiyun. At the same time, all the flavor packs in the kitchen were labeled "Mr. Wu Ying-chuan's creation."

On July 7, 1937, the Sino-Japanese War broke out. The outbreak of World War II, however, is generally regarded as the beginning of the German invasion of Poland on 1 September 1939, which led to the declaration of war by Britain and France against Germany. However, after the invasion of Poland, Germany began to attempt to establish an empire in Europe, starting a series of wars from 1939 to 1941 that resulted in Germany occupying most of Europe and signing the Tripartite Pact with Italy and Japan. The declaration of neutrality was followed by the signing of the Treaty of Non-Aggression between the Soviet Union and Germany, which led to the invasion and subsequent occupation or annexation of six countries on Europe's borders, including Poland, which had been occupied at the outbreak of World War II. The British and Commonwealth nations continued to fight the Axis powers, and numerous military conflicts broke out in North Africa and the Atlantic Ocean, making Britain one of the few major European powers still resisting German invasion. In June 1941, Europe's Axis powers decided to tear up their co-operation with the Soviet Union and invade the Soviet Union in a joint offensive that resulted in the largest ground operation in human history, Operation Barbarossa. By December 1941, the Axis powers in Asia had been weakening for many years in the Battle of China, in order to gain leadership in Asia and the Pacific, launched the Pearl Harbor Incident, attacked the British and American colonies in the Pacific to seize Southern Ocean resources, led the United States to declare war on the Axis powers, and the pattern of the Eurasian War clearly emerged.

The Allied forces also focused on the Mariana Islands, and once they had captured several of the islands' airfields, the B-29s could attack the Japanese Seika region of Guangdong, especially Tokyo, directly, thus destroying Japanese industry and civilian morale. At the time, the B-29 was only capable of flying from mainland China to the southwest of the Republic of China via airfields along the continental shelves, attacking Japan's Kyushu region, and was insufficiently capable of surviving. Further to Honshu, the B-29's limited range prevented further attacks on Japan's industrial core. To capture the islands, Nimitz, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, assigned Raymond Ames Spruance of the Fifth Fleet to cover the landings in Marianas, and Lieutenant General Richard Kelly Turner, commander of the 51st Fleet, entered the Marianas in mid-June, blockading and suppressing aircraft and ships from nearby airports and ports, and preparing to attack Saipan to capture the air base. At the time of the U.S. invasion of Saipan, Japan had dispatched its newly formed main fleet, the First Motor Fleet, under the command of Osamu Ozawa, to intercept the Fifth Fleet. When the Japanese realized that the U.S. was attempting to capture Mariana, Operation Hwang, which had been launched to counter the MacArthur Line, was halted, the battleships supported Ozawa's fleet northwards, and Operation A, which the Imperial Japanese Navy headquarters had been trying to plan, was launched—a sea battle involving ground-based aircraft and aircraft carrier motor fleets, with the aim of defeating the main Allied fleet to reverse the defeat.

Their eccentricity is very low, so their orbits are similar to Earth's. The semi-major axis of Amoor II lies between Mars and the main belt, between 1.52 and 2.12 AU, about one-third of the size of Amoor, and Amoor II is also a member of Amoor II. They have a mean eccentricity of 0.17–0.52, all exceeding the orbit of Mars. Amorphous III asteroids comprise half of the Amorphous type, all of which come from the asteroid belt, with a semi-major axis between 2.12 and 3.57 AU. They have a high eccentricity (0.4–0.6), and can travel close to Earth's orbit. Because of their high eccentricity, nearly one-third of Type III asteroids orbit within 1 AU of Jupiter, such as 719 Albert and 1036 Ganymed, and even more extreme, pass through the orbit of Jupiter, such as 5370. Since they are all within the asteroid belt, many Type III objects belong to the subfamily Asteroid Belt. For example, (887) Alinda is also divided into the Alinda family. Amorphous IV asteroids have a semi-major axis of more than 3.57 AU, very few in number. They have a high eccentricity (0.65–0.75), and are able to traverse Jupiter's orbit altogether, but do not have a "Damock" or cometary elliptical orbit (e–0.9). The only known Type IV object is 3552 Don Quixote. Some asteroids usually orbit after the Earth, but their perihelion is between the Earth's perihelion (0.9833 AU) and the distant sun's perihelion (1.0167 AU).

On July 30, 2010, Zhuang Sheng Company and Shinda North Branch, Shinda Leasing, Shinda Investment signed the Supplementary Agreement for the Implementation of the Settlement Agreement. In 2011, the company was listed on the Beijing Financial Asset Exchange to transfer its stake in the company, and on October 31, 2012, it was publicly acquired by China Shin Guoan Group. On October 31, 2012, Sino-Shin Guoan Investment Co., Ltd. took a float on the Beijing Financial Asset Exchange to acquire a stake in Shinda Leasing Co., Ltd., to acquire the Zhuangsheng Phase II A-G land reclamation project. In November 2012, China Trust Co., Ltd. obtained transaction certificates such as confirmation of the acquisition of Xinda, and completed the registration of industrial and commercial change. In early 2017, the company completed the demolition of the remaining six enterprises, nearly 500 households, and obtained a land certificate on March 22, 2017. In 2013, Beijing Zhuangsheng sued Xinda Investment, Xinda North Branch, and Xinda Leasing, demanding the cancellation of the relevant agreements, the return of the A-G block's interests, and payment of a billion yuan for breach of contract. On December 18, 2014, the Beijing Higher People's Court issued a civil judgment, dismissing Zhuang's entire lawsuit, and upholding Xinda's objection. On March 24, 2017, the Supreme People's Court of the People's Republic of China overturned the first-instance verdict, holding that the sale of the company's equity to China Credit Union was a malicious breach of contract, and Beijing Zhuangsheng had the right to rescind the agreement.

The University of Chicago (UChicago) is one of the 12 founding members of the Association of American Universities and ranks among the top ten universities in the world. The University of Chicago was founded in 1890 by John Rockefeller, King of Oil, and consists of a university academy and various graduate programs and interdisciplinary committees composed of four academic departments, six vocational colleges, and one continuing education college. Scholars and researchers at the University of Chicago founded the Chicago School in many fields, including the famous Chicago School of Economics and the Chicago School of Social Sciences. As of October 2020, of the University of Chicago's alumni, professors and researchers, there are 100 Nobel laureates (fourth in the world), 10 Fields laureates, and four Turing laureates. In sports, the University of Chicago is a member of the University Athletic Association (UAA). The University of Chicago is one of the cradles and assemblies of the Chinese elite. It has trained three Chinese Nobel Prize winners (including Lee and Yang Zhenning, the first Chinese to win the Nobel Prize), prominent Chinese politicians, former Vice President of the Republic of China, former Chairman of the Communist Party of China, prominent jurist Mei Ruyi, prominent medical doctor Wu Chaoping, prominent physicist Ye Pingsun, prominent meteorologist Guo Xiaolan, prominent economist Zou Jiaozhuang, former senior vice president of the World Bank Lin Yifu, and others who also graduated from the University of Chicago or studied at the University of Chicago.

On August 15, 1945, Japan declared its unconditional surrender to the Allies, and the remaining Japanese forces in Shanxi Province of the People's Republic of China were formed to participate in the Second Sino-Japanese War. After Japan declared its unconditional surrender, the vast majority of Japanese troops were disarmed, surrendered to Chinese troops and repatriated to Japan. However, the top of the Japanese North China Front's 1st Army and Yan Xishan secretly agreed to keep some of the 1st Army's troops in Shanxi under the name of the Railway Maintenance Team, and to join Yan Xishan's Shanxi Army in the battle against the CCP's forces, "preventing the redistricting of Shanxi". In 1949, with the Chinese Communist Army's assault on Shanxi, the remaining Japanese forces in Shanxi were also defeated. After the liberation of Taiyuan in 1949, the last remaining Japanese troops were defeated, most of them captured. The former commander of the 1st army, Sumiharu Sumida, sneaked into Japan under the cover of Mt. Yanxi. Most of the POWs were repatriated to Japan after 1954. On 15 August 1945, Emperor Showa issued a decree of unconditional surrender. On September 9, Ninji Okamura, the commander-in-chief of the Japanese-Chinese Expeditionary Force, handed over the surrender letter to General Ho Se-chin, the commander-in-chief of the Chinese Army. In accordance with the Potsdam Declaration and international law, Japan must permanently abolish militarism, completely disarm its army, expel it from the territory of the aggressor state, and repatriate it to Japan. The Japanese North China Front's 1st Army Commander, Sumiharu Sumida, the 1st Army Chief of Staff, Dotake Yamaoka, the 1st Army Chief of Staff, Kiyoichi Iwata, the Shanxi Provincial Government's Counsellor, Hiroshi Shirono, the 114th Division's Division Commander, Saburo Miura, and the Shanxi Industrial Co., Ltd.'s Chief of Staff, Daisaku Kawamoto, secretly planned to keep a portion of the Japanese forces in China.

Military organization refers to the organization of armed forces according to categories or functions, making them a hierarchical, well-defined, flexible, and operationally useful team. Or an organization that has a military nature, possesses an armed force, and uses that force to advance its objectives can be called a military organization, such as al-Qaeda. Form (sometimes called method) is often used to describe how ancient armies were deployed in action or in battle. Fish scales, geese's bills, etc. During the Warring States period, the Sun Yat-sen Law referred to "eight battles" and "ten battles". The eight groups are unknown, and the ten groups are: 方陣,円陣,疏陣,数陣,椎形陣,雁形陣,鉤形陣,玄襄之陣,水陣 and火陣. Military units are primarily used to refer to an internally homogeneous organization, often from the same army, under a single command and control. In this sense, a battalion can be seen as a formal military unit, while smaller organizations such as regiments and platoons can be seen as sub-military units below the battalion. On the other hand, in a broader sense, the term military unit can also be used in relation to non-military units, whereby all units that exist for military purposes are also referred to as military units. The following table lists some of the organizations that apply to the modern army, many of whose names can be traced back to military theories in European history. In general, the military structures of different countries vary greatly, many of which are modeled after the United Kingdom, the United States, or a combination of the two. The hierarchy of brigade, regiment, and battalion ranks may be merged, omitted, or adjusted as necessary, for example, NATO troops may merge battalion-level units into brigades; the U.S. Marine Corps, Russian Army, and Airborne Corps omitted brigades; the U.S. Army, German Army, and French Army omitted regiments; and the Japanese Ground Self-Defense Forces omitted battalions.

Chen Yu-yan (Chinese: 簡余晏; born February 5, 1967) is a Taiwanese politician, a member of the Democratic Progressive Party, and a native of Nantou, Taiwan. He is a former member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembl He graduated from the University of North Carolina, where he earned a bachelor's degree, a master's degree, and a master's degree in journalism. He served as a deputy editor-in-chief of the Toson Shimbun, a reporter for the China Times, and a reporter for the Yonhap Evening News, a political program hosted by Zhao Shaokang at the time, and later joined the Taiwan Solidarity League. In 2006, he was elected to the Taipei Legislative Assembly on behalf of the Taiwan Solidarity League (Taiwan Union), and in the Taipei Legislative Assembly election of that year, he and Chen Jianming won the first Taipei Legislative Assembly seat for the Taiwan Union. On November 8, 2007, the party's policies caused controversy, with both Chen and Simpuan resigning from the party and becoming non-party members. A few days later, he was invited by several members of the Communist Party of China (CPC) to join the Communist Party of China (CPC) as a member of the city parliamentary group, or to join the CPC, but he declined on several occasions due to "inappropriate timing", and did not join the CPC until February 27, 2008. In the 2010 municipal elections, he was re-elected to the Taipei City Council as a member of the Communist Party of China. Initial polls of the 8th Taipei Provincial People's Congress (PPC) in the Zhongshan and Matsuyama districts were completed, and it was initially understood that in the poll, the current city councillor Simp Yuan defeated the former deputy Guo Zhengliang on behalf of the PPC against the current non-district deputy Luo Shulai of the upper Kuomintang. On January 14, 2012, Chen was elected to the Legislative Council of Zhongshanshanshan District, winning 89,417 votes and losing by 29,086 votes to Luo Shulai, who was nominated by the Nationalist Party of China (NPC).

In the People's Republic of China, municipal districts are administrative subdivisions designated by the People's Republic of China as directly administered municipalities and larger city districts, and the "districts" of larger cities are at the same county and county-level city levels. However, the "districts" of the municipalities directly under the Central Government are at the same level as the municipalities, districts, unions and autonomous prefectures, while the Pudong New Area of Shanghai and the Binhai New Area of Tianjin City are sub-provincial municipalities. The area under the jurisdiction of the municipality is dominated by streets, and also includes towns and villages, and due to the expansion of the municipality in recent years, some municipalities are dominated by towns and villages, such as the northern district of Chinzhou City in Guangxi. In general, the functions of the people's governments of municipal districts are less than those of the people's governments of counties and cities at the county level, because many government functions are transferred to the municipalities at the district level. For example, a public security sub-office of a municipality may be managed by a public security sub-office under the vertical leadership of the municipality. In particular, the traffic police battalions of the municipalities, basically led by the traffic police branch of the Public Security Bureau, implement vertical management in order to unify the traffic management powers and responsibilities within the city. In addition, land resources, planning, industry and commerce, quality control, tobacco monopoly, inspection and quarantine, etc., are mostly under the direct control of the city bureau. Four of them. It is also known as the "Street Street" or "Street Street", which is a street in the downtown area of the city. Note: excludes cities listed above that are all under municipal jurisdiction.

Saint Petersburg (Russian: Санкт-Петербург) is one of the cultural, economic, scientific and transportation centers of Russia. The city is home to a number of important Russian government institutions, including the Constitutional Court of the Russian Federation, the Heraldic Council of the President of the Russian Federation, the Government of Leningrad Oblast, the Interparliamentary Assembly of the Commonwealth of Independent States, the Russian Navy Command and the Western Military District Command. Saint Petersburg was the capital of the Russian Empire from 1712 to 1918, and the center of the three Russian Revolutions: the First Russian Revolution, the February Revolution, and the October Revolution. After the outbreak of World War I in 1914, St. Petersburg changed its name to Petrograd (Russian: Петрогра́д) due to the "de-Germanization" of the city, and after Lenin's death it was renamed Leningrad (Russian: Ленингра́д). During World War II, Leningrad was besieged by the Germans for 872 days, resulting in the starvation of 1.5 million people.

In 1885, a 76-centimetre refractive telescope was built at the Pulkovo Observatory, which was the largest telescope in the world at the time, and its main mirror was milled by the famous telescope maker Clark. In 1894, the observatory began astronomical photography, and in 1920 it began broadcasting accurate timekeeping services over the radio. In terms of geodesy, the meridian across the center of the main building of the Pulkovo Observatory is the starting point on all the maps published in Russia in the past. Due to the geographical northern latitude of the observatory, it was impossible to observe the stars to the south, so two observatories were established in present-day Ukraine, located in Sims and Nikolayev, respectively, on the Crimean peninsula. During World War II, the Pulkovo Observatory was heavily bombed by the Germans, almost all of its buildings were destroyed, and some important equipment, library materials, etc. were transferred to St. Petersburg to be properly preserved. By the time the war was over, the Soviet government had decided to rebuild the Pulkovo Observatory. Reconstruction began in 1946 on the ruins of the site, was completed in May 1954 and officially opened, both equipment, personnel and research areas were greatly expanded than before, and new departments such as radio astronomy and instrument manufacturing were established. The original instrumentation was restored, and new equipment was installed, including a 65 cm refractive telescope, an interferometer, a solar telescope, a coronal instrument, and a radio telescope. In 1945, the station was incorporated into the Simis Astronomical Observatory of the USSR Academy of Sciences, which now belongs to Ukraine. In honor of Pulkovo Observatory, asteroid 762 Pulkovo was named.

In January 1980, the four villages of Guangyang, Takarao River, Azhuang, Xiaojiabo and Yao County of Bucheng County were subdivided into the city of Cunchuan, and in May of the same year, urban and suburban areas were established. In October 1983, Yijun County was transferred to the city of Tongchuan. In July 1992, the Tongchuan New Zone was established, and in 1993, it was upgraded to a provincial economic and technological development zone. In March 2000, the urban area of the city was renamed Wang Yi District, and the suburb of the city was renamed Intai District. In 2002, Yao County was abolished, and Yao Prefecture was created. In 2003, the city government officially relocated to Zhengyang Road in the new district of Tongchuan. In March 2009, it was declared a resource-depleted city by the State Council. It is located in the Guanzhong Economic Zone, between 108°34′E to 109°29′E and 34°50′N to 35°34′N. About 68 kilometers from the city of Xi'an, the Xi'an to Huangling Expressway crosses, there are two branch lines of the Xi'an Copper Railway, Meiji Railway. It has a temperate monsoon climate, January average temperature -2.8 °C, average annual temperature 10.8 °C, average annual rainfall of 594 mm. It has 244.45 million acres of forest, 152.07 million acres of pasture. It is rich in mineral resources, with more than three billion tons of coal reserves, and coal production accounts for one-third of the province's total output. In terms of agriculture, apples are the most productive, and they grow on 400,000 acres. It has two tributaries, the Ishikawa River and the Luo River, and it has a total of 2.242 million cubic meters of water, of which 12.077 million cubic meters is groundwater, and 44.94 million cubic meters is groundwater that has been discovered. The municipality is divided into three districts and one county.

United Nations Security Council Resolution 87, also known as the U.S. Invasion of Taiwan, was a resolution adopted by the United Nations Security Council at its 506th meeting on 29 September 1950. At that time, the People's Republic of China submitted a statement to the United Nations entitled "Prosecution of the Armed Violation of Taiwan". Following the outbreak of the Korean War in 1950, the U.S. entered Taiwan, indicating that Taiwan's status was uncertain. On August 24, 1950, Zhou Enlai, the Foreign Minister of the People's Republic of China, filed a petition with the United Nations Security Council, accusing the United States of interfering in China's internal affairs, violating Chinese sovereignty, and demanding the withdrawal of U.S. military forces from Taiwan. Having noted the statement of the People's Republic of China on the armed aggression against the island of Taiwan (Formosa), Resolution: (a) To defer consideration of this question until the first meeting of the Council after 15 November 1950; (b) To invite the above-mentioned representatives of the Government of the People's Republic of China to participate in the Council's discussion of the statement of the Government of the People's Republic of China on the armed aggression against the island of Taiwan (Formosa) after 15 November 1950. Egypt abstained, and then-Council President-in-Office Gladwyn Jebb announced that the resolution had been adopted by seven votes to three. The People's Republic of China insisted that its own votes of no-confidence gave it the right to veto, and argued that the case was a substantive one, resulting in controversy. On October 7, 1950, the United Nations General Assembly passed Resolution 376, calling for the unification of the Korean Peninsula, authorizing the United Nations military to cross the 38th parallel. On 30 November 1950, the United Nations Security Council held its 530th meeting to discuss (a) the allegations of armed aggression against Taiwan and (b) the allegations of aggression against the Republic of Korea.

As of October 2020, 26 Nobel Prize winners, six Turing Prize winners, two Fields Prize winners, two Abel Prize winners have been born among the alumni and faculty of the University of Michigan. The University of Michigan is one of the cradles and assemblies of excellent Chinese scholars. Famous alumni include eight heads of state or government at home and abroad, 47 U.S. senators, 218 members of the United States House of Representatives, 42 U.S. cabinet secretaries, 41 U.S. governors, and 26 living billionaires. Michigan has nurtured Chinese Nobel laureate Ding Zhaozhong, the first president of the Chinese Academy of Engineering Zhu Guangya, physicist Wu Daiyu, chemist Zhang Zhengho, astronaut and rocket engine expert Ren Xinmin, overseas fellow of the American National Academy of Sciences Zhu Keiichi, historian Huang Renyu, and others. The University of Michigan was founded in 1817 as the "Catholepistemiad", later renamed the "University of Michigania", and began to use the name "University of Michigan" in 1838. The university's Latin name is University of Michigania, and the abbreviation "Mic" appears in honors, such as LLD Mic, a doctorate in law awarded by the University of Michigan. The University of Michigan administers two smaller regional universities — the University of Michigan — Dearborn and the University of Michigan — Flint. The University of Michigan and the two regional universities it administers are the three separate degree-granting institutions of the University of Michigan Board of Trustees, similar to the University of Virginia's College at Wise, which is governed by the University of Virginia but is academically and degree-grantingly separate from the University of Virginia.

There is a four-sided courtyard behind the front gate, the main hall is a devotional shrine, and in the middle there is a plaque with the words "Sin Zhao Tianzhi" and "Ye Jian Ying Handbook," which are the four words from Yue Fei's exclamation, "Sin Zhao Tianzhi." Inside the Great Hall is a colorful seated statue of Yue Fei, standing four and a half meters tall. On both sides there are plaques of the Ming Dynasty people's book "Sheng Zhong报国", the Chinese Buddhist Association president Zhao Pak-chu's book "Bright Blood Heart", and the Xi Ling Inshasha Changsha Menghai's book "Great Longevity". On the right side of the Great Hall is Yue Fei's tomb, built in 1979 in the style of Southern Song Dynasty architecture, the tomb is circular, and the tombstone has the words "Song Yue E Wang Tomb" written on it. On the opposite side of the tomb are four kneeling statues of Qin Hin (秦檜), Wang Clan (王氏), Wan Gao (万俟), and Zhang Shun (张俊) associated with Yue Fei's murder, which were cast of white iron. In the garden there is a stone gallery, displaying Yue Fei's handwriting and the works of various generations of celebrities. At the beginning of the 20th century, the Republic of China implemented "private ownership, public governance, public enjoyment" and implemented a free economic society; and at the beginning of the founding of the People's Republic of China, initially as a planned economic society under public ownership, from 1978 onwards, the direction of governing the country was adjusted to reform and openness, gradually towards the transition to a market economy society under private ownership and capitalism, this form is called the Chinese characteristic socialist market economy under macroeconomic control, at the same time industrialization and urbanization developed rapidly, hundreds of millions of people in just over 20 years from farmers to urban workers and entrepreneurs employed. In the early 21st century, China became the world's second largest economy. He who follows things should know the place where they happen; and he who follows people should know the family life and surnames of the people. The earliest known high primate, the Chinese dawn monkey, lived in southern China about 45 million years ago. Archaeological evidence suggests that China was inhabited by upright people between 22.4 million and 2.25 million years ago, and the earliest archaeological finds of primitive humans include the Wushan people, the Yuanlu people, the Lantian people, the Nanjing upright people, and the Beijing upright people. The various cultures of prehistoric China passed through several stages: the Early Middle Paleolithic (more than 50,000–400,000 years ago), which was dominated by upright apes, followed by the Late Middle Paleolithic (more than 200,000–100,000 years ago), which was dominated by mountaintop cave dwellers. Archaeological findings from the Ancient Cave and the Hanging Barrel Ring suggest that pottery was made in China as early as 18,000 years ago. The appearance of pottery marks China's first entry into the Paleolithic era. Ancient caves and burial mounds have also revealed semi-wild and semi-domesticated man-made rice, archaeological evidence that China is the world's earliest rice-growing region.

In the 1997 election, Zhang was defeated by 3,000 votes, defeating the then-Chinese Communist Party (CCP) Governor of Yunnan, Su Wenxiang. In 1998, he was elected to the United States House of Representatives from the 3rd congressional district of Yunlin County with the highest number of votes.
