Longnan City, anciently known as Wutou, is a city in Gansu Province of the People's Republic of China, located in the southeastern part of Gansu Province, at the junction of the three provinces of Shaanxi and Gansu. It borders Tianshui City to the north, Dingxi City to the west, Xipinggan South Province to the south, Aba Province to the south, Mianyang City to the south, Guangyuan City to the east, Hanzhong City to the west, Baoji City to the east. It lies between the southern, northern Qinling Mountains and Minshan Mountains, and in the middle is the Huicheng Basin. The main rivers are Jialing River and its tributaries Xihansui, Bailong River, Baishui River, etc. The city has a total area of 27.839 square kilometers, a population of 25.909 million, and the city's people's government is located in Wutou District. Due to its favorable climate, high forest cover, it is called Longshang Jiangnan. Qin Dynasty put up a stronghold. In the year 111 BC, Emperor Wu of Han (汉武帝元鼎六年(前111年)置武都郡, belonged to the History Department of Liangzhou. At the end of the Han dynasty, Cao Cao divided the provinces into three divisions: Liangzhou, Liangzhou and Yongzhou, and Wutou County was transferred to Yongzhou. During the Three Kingdoms period, Wudu County was the border between Wei and Shu. In 219, Liu Bei captured the Hanzhong County of Cao Cao's army, blocking the connection between Wutou and Yongzhou, so Cao abandoned Wutou County and moved to Ufufeng Xiaokairi. After that, Wei and Shu fought many wars in Wutou, the most famous of which was the "six out of Qishan" invasion of Wei, and in 229, they captured Wutou and Yinping two counties, from which Wutou County became the seat of Shu, until the state of Shu was destroyed by Cao Wei. During the period of the Eastern Jin Dynasty and the Northern and Southern Dynasties, five Hu dynasties were established in Longnan: Yuchi, Tangchang, Wudu, Wuxing and Yinping, and they were called the "Longnan Five Kingdoms". During the Sui and Tang dynasties, the political and economic situation in Longnan region was relatively calm, and the Tang dynasties settled in Longnan, Wu, Cheng, Tei, Tang, Min and other provinces. In 762, Toba invaded Longnan. During the Xiantong years, the Tang recaptured Wuzhou, renamed the state, Xiantong seven years (866) recaptured into a state.

Lucas Papadímos (Greek:Λ aboveas Papadímos; born 11 October 1947) is the former Vice-President of the European Central Bank (ECB) and the 181st Prime Minister of Greece. He earned a degree in physics from MIT in 1970, a master's degree in electrical engineering from MIT in 1972, and a Ph.D. in economics from MIT in 1978. He taught economics at Columbia University from 1975 to 1984 and at the University of Athens from 1988 to 1993. In 1980, he became a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. He was Chief Economist of the Bank of Greece in 1985, and was promoted to Deputy Governor and Governor in 1993 and 1994, respectively, and served as Governor until Greece joined the eurozone on 1 January 2001. From 2002 to 2010, he served as Vice-President of the European Central Bank. After leaving office in 2010, he became the economic adviser to Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou. Since 1998, he has been a member of the Tripartite Commission (a non-governmental social group coordinating economic cooperation between Europe, the United States and Japan). He's a member of the Athens Academy of Sciences. On 11 November 2011, a coalition government was formed under his leadership. The new government’s main task is to enable the European Union’s solution to the Greek debt crisis to be adopted by parliament, and to prepare for the upcoming parliamentary elections on February 19, 2012.

Caesar (Latin: Caesar) was a title in the Roman Empire. After the death of Gaius Julius Caesar (102–44 BC) as dictator, several ancient Roman leaders claimed to have inherited the name of the Caesar family (and its legitimate rule). Thus the word Caesar became one of the many titles of the Roman Emperor. During the reign of the Four Emperors, Descartes formally repositioned the word "Caesar" as "Deputy Emperor", as the deputy and designated heir to the title of "Prince" of Augustus. Caesar's original meaning of "hairy" can be traced back to the early Roman branch of the Iulia clan, the Iulii Caesares, possibly because of his distinctive long hair (or, in other words, the fact that he had no hair on his head). Julius Caesar, a political figure of the late Roman Republic, was assassinated and, in his will, designated his young niece Gaius Jadwiga as his heir. In Roman custom, Octavian was legally adopted by Caesar, and named Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus. For political and personal reasons, Octavian, after acquiring the sole political authority, emphasized his relationship with Caesar, and adopted the title "Imperator Caesar" in self-proclaimed terms with care and humility—the general representing the actual military power, Caesar representing his legitimate inheritance, the rest of the titles being rejected in public.

The Republic of Mali withdrew from the French Community on 22 September. From its independence to 1991, a series of dictators ruled Mali. Anti-government protests in 1991 led to a coup d'état, a transitional government and a new constitution. In 1992, Alfa Omar Konare was elected President of Mali in the first multi-party, democratic elections, and was re-elected in 1997. He strengthened political and economic reforms and the fight against corruption. In 2002, when Amadou Toumani Touré became President of Mali, Touré was a key figure in the 1991 democracy movement. Presidential elections were held on April 29, 2007. In January 2012, the Tuvaluan rebels launched an armed rebellion in the north, sparking the conflict in northern Mali. On March 21, 2012, a group of soldiers staged a coup d'état in the capital, Bamako, overthrowing the Duel, suspending the constitution, and dissolving state institutions. Under pressure from the international community, the coup plotters signed an agreement with the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) on 6 April, agreeing to cede power and appointing the Speaker of the National Assembly as interim president. On April 8, Duel resigned. At a time of uncertainty in the south, Tuareg separatists, aided by Islamic militants, took advantage of the situation to take control of northern Mali. Later, hardline Islamic militants defeated the Tuareg separatists and took control of northern Mali. In January 2013, the Islamic Republic of Iran launched an armed offensive in the south, France launched Operation Bumblebee, sent troops to assist the Malian government in the war, and quickly recaptured all major cities in the north. On 18 August 2020, a military coup d'état took place in Mali, in which President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita and Prime Minister Bubu Sese were detained by rebels.

On 23 September, Hitler rejected the plan and Czechoslovakia was mobilized. Shu Ting (Chinese: 舒婷; born May 25, 1952) is a Chinese poet. She rose to prominence in the Chinese poetry scene in the late 1970s, and along with her contemporaries Kitajima, Gucheng, and Liang Xiaobin, she set off a wave of "shadow poetry" in Chinese poetry. On May 25, 1952, he joined the Xiangxian Internment Corps, returned to the city in 1972 as a worker, began publishing poetry works in 1979, worked for the Fujian Provincial Literature Union from 1980, engaged in professional writing. He is the current Chairman of the Xiamen City Council and Vice-Chairman of the Fujian Province Council of Culture. Husband: Chen Zhongyi (born 1948 in Xiamen), professor at Xiamen City College. Son: Chen Xi (born in Xiamen in 1982), Ph.D. in Modern Chinese Literature, Department of Chinese Studies, Peking University, Research Fellow, Contemporary Room, Institute of Literature, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. His major works include a collection of poems, "The mast ship", "The iris that sings", "The first ancestor bird", and a collection of essays, "The heart smoke". "To the Oak" is one of the representative works of the wave of obscure poetry. It expresses the spirit and thinking of the women of the time in the unique way of female life experience calligraphy. Shuting excels in introspection of self-emotional rhythms, capturing complex and subtle emotional experiences. Emotional complexity and richness are often expressed through the twists and turns of particular syntactic expressions such as assumptions and concessions. It builds a whole new lyrical image with the self at its core. To express a sweet melancholy, a sad hope, to convey a sad and beautiful feeling. The self-value of human beings — the affirmation and affirmation of dignity, the promotion of personality independence and the pursuit of the ideal of life — constitutes the core idea of all of Shuting's poetry. It has obvious modernist characteristics.

The Chinese Revolutionary League (Chinese: 中國革命同盟会; pinyin: Zhōngxīng Jīngjīng) was the predecessor of the Nationalist Party of China. It was founded in 1905 in Tokyo, Japan, as a revolutionary organization formed in the late Qing Dynasty by a number of groups such as the Xingchu Kai and the Huaxing Kai. Its organization spread across Chinese communities in China and around the world, and launched several attempts to overthrow the Qing dynasty, including the successful overthrow of the Qing dynasty and the establishment of the Republic of China's Xinhai Revolution. The alliance was led by Sun Yat-sen, Song Kyo-jin, Huang Xing, Huang Yuan-hui, and Cai Yuan-pei, among others, and as a result of its membership, internal strife has continued since 1906, including personal conflicts, differences of theory, and differences of revolutionary leanings, especially due to a series of failed armed uprisings. After the success of the Xinhai Revolution, the alliance was reorganized into the Kuomintang. After the dissolution of the Kuomintang, some members formed the Chinese Revolutionary Party, which was reorganized into the Kuomintang in 1919. Under the leadership of the Japanese leader Ryohei Uchida, he was elected Prime Minister of the People's Republic of China on the basis of the following organizations: the People's Republic of China Association, the People's Republic of China Association of Huang Hing and Song Kyo-jin, the People's Republic of China Association of Shanghai Cai Yuan-pei, the People's Republic of China Association of Zhang Binglin and Wu Kei-hung, and the People's Republic of China Association of Zhang Jie. The alliance vowed to "eradicate the Tatar POWs, restore China, establish a national state, and establish equal land rights", and the following year issued a "Military Government Declaration", which was listed as the "Four Principles of Revolutionary State-building": 167. The League of China agrees with Sun Yat-sen's idea of a Republic of China government structure: with the Prime Minister as head of the executive, legislative, and judicial branches, which is in fact a principle of separation of powers. On November 26, 1905, the League's organ newspaper, the Minpo, was founded in Tokyo, publishing the words "Promoting the Nation, Civil Rights and Civil Liberties": 169.

Some of the gaps are segments of tiny moons that have been cleared, such as Pan, probably many of which have not yet been discovered, and some of the rings are bound by gravity waves of some Shepherd Dog moons (such as the F-rings maintained by Prometheus and Pandora). Other gaps may be caused by resonance with the orbital periods of the larger moons, the presence of the Cassini node bound to the Milky Way, and more circular structures that produce spiral waves due to periodic perturbations by other moons. Data from the Cassini spacecraft show that Saturn's ring has its own atmosphere, independent of the planet itself. The atmosphere contains oxygen molecules (O2), which are produced by the Sun's ultraviolet rays interacting with the ice in the ring. The bonds between the water molecules are stimulated by ultraviolet light to produce chemical reactions that release and eject gases, especially O2. According to these atmospheric models, there are also H2, O2, and H2 atmospheres that are very sparse, but are strangely condensed around the ring, its thickness being only one atom. Saturn has a complex pattern in its brightness. In 1980, when Voyager 1 flew over Saturn, it was shown that the F-rings were composed of three braided rings with complex structures; it is now known that the outer two rings had protruding tumors, causing the illusion of weaving and clustering, while the third, less luminous, was inside them. The rings of Saturn may be very old, dating back to the formation of Saturn itself, and there are two main theories about the formation of Saturn's rings. One theory, which originated in the 19th century at the Roche limit, suggests that the ring was originally a Saturnian moon that fell into the Roche limit due to a decay in its orbit and was torn apart by tidal forces because it was not tight enough (see Roche limit), and this theory evolved into the theory that the moon collapsed when it was struck by an asteroid or comet.

On 29 April, the 44th Division of the Imperial Japanese Army attacked Wuyang, facing the Japanese. After World War II, Truman was appointed Chief of the Army Staff (1945–1948), President of Columbia University (1948–1953), and the first Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (1951–1952). In 1952, at the age of 62, Eisenhower ran as a Republican candidate in the 1952 United States presidential election. His primary aim was to prevent his party's rival, Republican Senator Robert A. Taft, from pursuing an isolationist policy after his election; Taft had publicly opposed the establishment of NATO because he did not want the post-war United States to fall back into "external strife". Eisenhower won both the election and the 1956 re-election by an overwhelming margin, defeating his Democratic opponent, Adele Stevenson II, twice in a row. Eisenhower's main domestic and foreign goals were to reduce the federal deficit and contain the expansion of Soviet communism. In 1953, at the end of the Korean War, he spoke to the military of the People's Republic of China about the use of nuclear weapons and eventually agreed to sign a Korean Armistice Agreement with the Chinese government. He gave priority to the development of low-cost nuclear weapons as part of his nuclear deterrence policy, while also reducing spending on U.S. Army divisions. On the diplomatic front, he continued the policy of his predecessor, Harry Truman, by continuing to recognize the Republic of China as the only legitimate government representing the whole of China, by signing the Common Defense Treaty with the Republic of China in 1954, and by signing the "Formosa Resolution" passed by Congress, which authorized the President of the United States to dispatch U.S. forces to Taiwan and Penghu Island when he deemed it necessary, to assist the Government of the Republic of China in defending the First Island Chain, and the number of U.S. troops stationed in Taiwan peaked in 1958 at 20,000.

Wu Qiwei (Chinese: 吴奇伟; 8 January 1891 – 11 July 1953) was a military commander of the People's Republic of China. Wu Chiwei was educated at Huangpu Army Primary School and Wuchang Army Secondary School. In 1919, he graduated from the sixth class of the Baoding Military Officers' School. I've been with Ye Ting for seven years. Since then, he has been working under the chairmanship of Chen Jiangming. During the Northern Expeditionary War, he was the Chief of Staff of the 36th Regiment of the 4th National Revolutionary Army, Commander of the 34th Regiment, Deputy Commander of the 12th Division and Commander of the 30th Regiment, Commander of the 4th Division, Commander of the 4th Army, and Commander of the 9th Army Group. In the Battle of Shidu Red Water, in the war to blockade the Central Red Army into Guizhou, the main force was lost, Wang Jiawei led only the remaining one regiment from the southern gate of Zunyi escaped, halfway met the first column commander of the Central Army to reinforce Wu Qiwei, as a result of the headquarters was attacked by the long-distance bypassing Red Army, the two divisions of Wu Qiwei's well-armed were defeated by the Central Red Army. Wu Chiwei fled to the mouth of the Wu River all night long, crossing the bridge to the northern bank of the Wu River, ordering the soldiers to immediately cut the cables of the bridge to block the Red Army's pursuit, as a result of which the national soldiers who were crossing the bridge fell into the river, and the soldiers who had not crossed the river were overtaken by the Red Army and surrendered. At the beginning of the war, he led the 4th Army in the Battle of Songhai. He was promoted to commander-in-chief of the Ninth Army, and served as the former commander-in-chief of the enemy at the Battle of Wanjialing, where he made outstanding contributions to the Great Patriotic War. In the autumn of 1938, he was appointed deputy commander of the 4th War Area, and the following autumn he was promoted to deputy commander of the 6th War Area and commander-in-chief of the defense of the upper Yangtze River. After the end of the war, he became the chairman of the Hunan Provincial Government. Subsequently, he was appointed Deputy Director of Wuhan Camp, Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the North China Anti-Banditry Command, Deputy Director of Suijing Public Administration in Xuzhou and Deputy Director of Suijing Public Administration in Guangdong.

Masuren (Chinese: 马叙伦; April 27, 1884 – May 4, 1970) was a Chinese linguist, philosopher, educator, calligrapher, and politician. In 1905, he and Deng Shi, Huang Jie, and others organized the Kuomintang Gazette, which promoted the Kuomintang and the Revolution of Exclusion. In 1909, he was elected chairman of the Zhejiang Advisory Council. In 1910, Masuryan joined the Nansha (Southern Society) founded by Yanako. In the summer of 1911, he accompanied his friend Tom and his friends to Tokyo to organize a specialized medical school in Zhejiang. In Japan, he was introduced to the Chinese League (unknown whether he joined or not). In 1913, he became a professor at the Beijing Medical School and Peking University. In 1915, he resigned and returned to Zhejiang to protest against Yuan Shikai's appointment as Emperor. After Yuan Shikai claimed that the Emperor had failed, he was invited by the president of Peking University, Cai Yuanpei, to become a professor at Peking University. In 1919, during the May Fourth Movement, he was secretary and president of the Beijing University Teachers' Union and the Beijing Teachers' Union of Secondary and Higher Schools. In 1920, during the Salary Campaign of elementary and secondary school teachers at Peking University against the military government, Masuren was elected as its leader. In June 1921, he became the headmaster of Zhejiang's First Normal School and the director of the Zhejiang Department of Education. After the reorganization of the Beijing government, he returned to Beijing, serving twice as deputy minister of education, and once as deputy minister of education. Meanwhile, he was covering up for Li Dazhao. In 1923, he joined the Nationalist Party of China and became the Minister of Propaganda of the Beijing Special Party Department of the Nationalist Party of China.

Kim Sin (Hangul: 김신; September 21, 1922 – May 19, 2016) was a retired Lieutenant General of the Republic of Korea Air Force, diplomat, and politician. He served as Chief of Staff of the Air Force, Ambassador to the Republic of China, and Minister of Transportation. Mr. Kim speaks Shanghainese fluently, and has sent his daughter to Taipei to study at the Northeast Girls' High School. In February 2016, he donated US$2 million to the National Taiwan University to promote bilateral academic exchanges between Korea and Taiwan. He was born in Shanghai in September 1922. He then attended Tuenxi Secondary School in Anhui Province, and Chongqing National Central University Experimental School (now Nanshi Normal School). In May 1945, he graduated from the 24th class of the Taiwan Air Force Military Academy (橋). In June 1947, he graduated from the Randolph Aviation School in Randolph, Texas. In May 1950, he graduated from the Korean Military Academy. During the Korean War, he served as Director of Operations at the Air Force Headquarters, Commander of the 101st Base Battalion, 1st Fighter Squadron, and Commander of the 15th Aviation Training Battalion of the 1st Fighter Squadron. In 1952, as a colonel of the 1st Regiment, he led the aerial bombardment of North Korea's strategic facility, the Seohori Iron Bridge, which was successfully bombed on 15 January. In July 1953, he enrolled in the SOC/FOC program at the United States Air Force University in Alabama. In September 1953, he became commander of the 10th Fighter Squadron. In September 1956, he was appointed Chief of the Administrative Staff of the Air Force Headquarters. In July 1959, he became deputy chief of staff of the Air Force.

In the middle of the 17th century, the power of the federal state declined. In 1791, the Four-Year-Old Congress of the Union passed the Fifty-Three Constitution, the second written constitution in the world. In 1831 and 1863, both Polish and Lithuanian uprisings against Russian rule were unsuccessful, Russia implemented a policy of Russification, abolished the laws of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in 1840, banned Lithuanian publications from 1865, and closed several educational institutions and Catholic churches. After the Russo-Turkish War of 1877–78 and the deterioration of relations between Russia and Germany, Alexander II accepted the proposal of his generals to build the Kaunas Fortress on the western border (within Lithuania) as a major defence for the front line. During World War I, Lithuania was occupied by the German Empire after the Russian army withdrew from the war, but the German army remained in control and the National Assembly had no power. In March 1918, the German occupation of Lithuania recognized its independence and its existence as a German dependency. In June, the Kingdom of Lithuania was established. After the end of World War I, the Kingdom of Lithuania was abolished, followed by the promulgation of the Provisional Constitution by Augustas Valdemaras, who became the first Prime Minister of Lithuania, organized the government and army, and began a three-year war of independence against the Soviet-backed Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (Lithuanian–Soviet War), the Volunteer Army of Western Russia, and Poland (Polish–Lithuanian War).

Coordinates: 29°33′N 106°33′E / 29.550°N 106.550°E / 29.550; 106.550 (Chongqing) Chongqing (Chinese: 重庆市; pinyin: Chóngqìng, pronounced ) is a city under the direct administration of the People's Republic of China, a national center city, a super-large city, a financial center in China, an economic center in the upper Yangtze River region, an important modern manufacturing base in China, and an inland open highland. Chongqing is a test area for the comprehensive reform of urban and rural areas, is a famous historical and cultural city of the country, the hot spring capital of the world, one of the three most famous hot spring cities in China, and the starting point of the "Yuxian-New Europe" international railway connection. With a written history of more than 2,000 years, it belongs to the Ba Shu culture. The name of the river is derived from the ancient name of Chongqing, hence Chongqing is also known as Chongqing. In the Northern Song Dynasty (1102), Yuzhou was renamed to Kyozhou. In January 1189, the son of Emperor Xiaozong, Zhao Atsun, became King of Chongqing, and in February, Emperor Guangzong assumed the throne, and Chongqing was renamed Chongqing Prefecture. In 1891, Chongqing became the first port in Sichuan and western China to open to the outside world. In 1929, Chongqing was officially founded. Chongqing, along with Washington, London, and Moscow, was listed as one of the world's four anti-fascist command centers, making an enormous contribution to the Allied camp. In the early days of the People's Republic of China, Chongqing was a city directly under the Central Government, the headquarters of the Southwest Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the headquarters of the Southwest Military and Political Committee, and the political, economic, and cultural center of the Southwest region.

The Wei Dynasty (220–589), also known as the Three Kingdoms and the Northern and Southern Dynasties, was a period in Chinese history that lasted more than three hundred years. This period began with Cao Pi's usurpation of the Eastern Han throne in 220, followed by Cao Wei's independence in 589, and finally ended with the reunification of Southern Chen in 369. It can be divided into three periods: the period of the Three Kingdoms (in which Cao Wei, Shu Han, and Sun Wu were united), the period of the Western Jin (in which Eastern Jin was called the Jin Dynasty), the period of the Eastern Jin and the Sixteen Kingdoms (in which Jean Wei and Western Yan were not counted), and the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties (in which Southern and Northern Dynasties were opposed, totaling 150 years). In the southern part of the Yangtze River, the six dynasties of the Song, Qi, Liang, and Chen dynasties are known as the Six Dynasties (Chinese: 六朝; pinyin: Xīngzhīn; pinyin: Xīngzhīn; pinyin: Xīngzhīn; modern-day Nanjing: 建康; pinyin: Zīngzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzhīn; pinyin: Zīnzh Historian Yoshio Kawakatsu once described the Three Kingdoms Period and the Northern and Southern Wei Dynasties as "the glorious dark ages" because of the chaos of the world, which allowed the heroes to become great figures and culture to blossom. After the death of Emperor Hanling in 189 AD, the Middle Plains was in a state of prolonged turmoil. The three kingdoms of Cao Wei, Shu Han, and Dongwu were founded by Cao Cao's sons Cao Pi, Liu Bei, and Sun Quan respectively. After the Wei Ming Dynasty, the Cao Wei regime was gradually seized by the Sima clan, led by Sima Yi; in 263, the Sima Zhao Bing Kingdom of Cao Wei, launched the War of Destruction of Shu, in 266, the Sima Yan Dynasty of Wei called the emperor, Jian Xi Jin; in 280, the Eastern Wu regime was defeated in the War of Destruction of Wu, and in nearly a century, the Three Kingdoms period was finally briefly unified by the West Jin. After the completion of the unification, the Jin dynasty was rapidly corrupted, and the short-lived unification broke up after the rebellion of the eight kings and the Wu Hu rebellion, and the political situation was again in turmoil.

The Containment Policy (Chinese: 圍堵政策; pinyin: Zhōngxīng Guóqīng; pinyin: Zhōngxīng Guóqīng) was a diplomatic strategy of the United States against Communism during the Cold War, aimed at limiting the domino effect. The policy began with George Kennan's "long telegram" to the U.S. ambassador to the Soviet Union. After the end of World War II, relations between the Allies and the Soviet Union were strained, and Stalin established a number of pro-Soviet states around the Soviet Union to secure his own territorial dominance, such as the seizure of Poland. President Truman of the United States decided to take political countermeasures, limiting the socialist system of the Soviet Union. On March 12, 1947, Truman delivered a State of the Union address to the U.S. Congress, hoping that Congress would support democratic governments in Greece and Turkey. The U.S. began to provide military and economic assistance to countries that opposed socialist politics, a policy that formally proclaimed the U.S. foreign policy. The newly appointed U.S. Secretary of State, George Carter, Jr., adopted John F. Kennedy's "X" blockade plan, which was defined by Kennedy as a "blockade of Soviet imperialism," and published in the July 1947 issue of Foreign Affairs. In his signature essay On the Causes of Soviet Behavior, Kanan proved the defectiveness of the socialist system, and argued that when the United States truly saw its own strength and accepted a dominant position, it was perfectly capable of limiting Russia's expansion back. Subsequently, the United States provided military and economic assistance to Turkey and Greece, owing to their geographical importance, jointly holding the Black Sea to the Mediterranean at the mouth of the Danube: if the Soviets controlled the area, the Soviet Black Sea fleet could sail freely into the Mediterranean, and the military threat would reach the entire Mediterranean region, threatening Italy, Spain, France, and the British-French North African colonies.

The Second Sino-Japanese War, fought in 202 BC, was the last major battle of the war. About 100,000 Chinese troops under the command of Han Yu were defeated in the Battle of Qixia (according to various accounts, in present-day Henan or Anhui Province), and the entire army was overthrown. After Liu Bang's victory, the Han dynasty was established. After the Treaty of the Danube, Penghue attacked more than twenty towns in the vicinity of Kechang-eup (in present-day Heze City, Shandong Province) and Jinxiang County, Jining City, and seized more than 100,000 tons of grain for the Chinese army's food, while Liu Bang led the Chinese army in the retreat of the Han troops in Yangxia (present-day Taikang County, Zhoukou City, Henan Province) and captured the Chu army, General Zhou and 5,000 Chu troops, Liu Bang went to Guling (present-day southern Taikang County, Zhoukou City, Henan Province), ordered Liu Jia to cross the Huai River, attacked Jiao Shun (present-day Huainan City, Anhui Province), and dispatched troops against the Chu army's commander, General Zhou Yin. At this time, Jin Xi also attacked and defeated Qiyang (present-day Jiyang District, Jinan City, Shandong Province), and then clashed with Liu Bang-hui in Chen County (present-day Huaiyang County, Zhoukou City, Henan Province) to capture Han Yu, and after attacking Qu Pengcheng (present-day Xuzhou City, Jiangsu Province) in the vicinity of Pingding Pengcheng, defeated Zhou Lan. Xuanqu Hou Dingyi, Fenyang Hou Jinqiang and the surrendering Chu general Lingzheng took the lead in defeating the Guling garrison of the Great Defeat of Zhongjiao, Kwang Yu fled to the south to Chen County, Liu Bang and Guan Yin met in Summer Township (in the Luoyi County, Zhoukou City, Henan Province), Liu Bang led the Han army to attack actively (there were Zhou Bo, Fan Yu, Guan Yin, Jin Xi, Xia Hou Yin, Jian Feng, Ding Yi, Jin Qiang, Lingzheng and other generals), and killed dozens of Chu generals in Chen Shi (now in the Huaiyang County, Zhoukou City, Henan Province). He was defeated in the Battle of Chenshui, and the Han forces occupied Chen County. After the victory of the Chinese forces in the Battle of Chencheng, Hanyu was in absolute disadvantage.

The ancient Greeks believed that man could not be governed by others, only by the gods that the city-states believed in. Adult males with certain property qualify as citizens and can participate in the political life of the city-state. Public life in cities is an obligation, not a reward. Only by participating in the management of things in cities can you become a real person. The political activity of the city-state is the discussion of matters in the public assembly of the square, each citizen has an equal right to speak. This assembly is also the only legislature in the state. At rallies, citizens complete the functioning of power through speeches. But it can be manipulated by politicians, and it can lead to majority tyranny. Municipal offices were created either through direct elections or by drawing lots. The distribution of public office is achieved through rotating governments. Most ancient societies were monarchy-dominated states, usually subject to the doctrine of monarchy, but the nature and circumstance of their power varied from time to time and from place to place. The Roman Empire was the most representative of authoritarian states, and its central idea of government was the authority of the Roman Emperor, emphasizing the interests of the emperor and the government over the interests of the individual. Any decision on political matters must go back to the source of authority. The Senate represents this authority, used to give legitimacy to the government, but has a People's Chamber to represent male Roman citizens. The emperor's authority remains unchanged, and the system of power, led by the emperor, is constantly changing. China, at the time of the Western Zhou, was already a feudal monarchy, the head of state called Tianzi. Since the establishment of a unified centralized state in the Qin Dynasty, the emperor's monarchs have concentrated more power. This political system prevailed in China from then until today and in the Chinese-speaking countries that were influenced by the Chinese civilization.

It is considered to be the earliest policy document of the Communist Party of China and the Government of the People's Republic of China on relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. On January 1, 1979, the day of the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the United States, the most famous of which was issued by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, the impact of which continues to this day, the contents of which are mainly to discuss the end of the military confrontation on both sides of the Straits, and propose three cross-Straits communications and expand cross-Straits exchanges. The Taiwan Compatriots' Letter was first published on February 28, 1950, by the Taiwanese Democratic Autonomous League (Taiwan Democratic Autonomous League) and proposed the completion of the task of liberating Taiwan. The second was published on October 6, 1958, the day after the end of WWII, by Mao Zedong, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, and later by Peng Dewei, Minister of Defense of the People's Republic of China. On October 25, 1958, the Ministry of Defense of the People's Republic of China issued a letter to the Taiwan compatriots demanding unity with the United States. It was published for the fourth time on November 1, 1958, as the Third Letter of the Ministry of Defense of the People's Republic of China to the Taiwan Compatriots, but never published. The fifth issue was published on January 1, 1979, and was adopted by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, preceded by the session of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress chaired by Ye Jianying.

Each soldier had a house, a field, a fixed monthly allowance, and weapons were produced by state-employed craftsmen; however, the actual distribution was often inadequate; food was provided only during the march, and clothing was still required. The soldiers were stationed in camps, divided into two duties: garrison and field duty, which varied in proportion and rotated from time to time, and field duty, which required fixed provisions to supply the garrison and officials, with the aim of recruiting soldiers without wasting state funds. Since the end of the Civil War, there has been a steady increase in the number of civilian refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) living in the camps. In the first year of the Han Dynasty, there were many defectors, but by November of the third year of the Han Dynasty, the total number of defectors was 47,986, during the period of appeasement, the frontier was severe, the army was in urgent need of strength, and the Imperial Court adopted the recruitment system, so that the guard system was abolished. The recruitment was different from the Wehrmacht, it was not hereditary, it was relatively free. However, because the recruitment system destroyed the idea of the "soldiers' separation" of the early guard system, the cabinet had to subordinate the military power to the general, and the Ming Dynasty could not fully control the military power under the recruitment system, especially the relatively well-known "relative family army", which contributed to the consolidation of centralized power. Additionally, as a result of the enforced recruitment system, military expenditures rose steeply, leading to the end of the Ming Dynasty due to inadequate rates of pay, and even frequent mutiny, ultimately resulting in the death of the Ming dynasty. Contemporary literature usually ranks the 13 colonies of British North America by geographical location from north to south. According to the present-day administrative division of the United States, the thirteen colonies comprised all or part of the twenty states of the United States, seven of which came from: Maine: then part of the Bay of Massachusetts Vermont: then part of New York West Virginia and Kentucky: then part of the Virginia Colony and Territorial Territory Tennessee: then part of North Carolina Alabama and Mississippi: then part of Georgia By decree of James II in 1685, Maine, New Hampshire, the Bay of Massachusetts, Plymouth, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New York, and East and West Jersey were combined into one large colony. After the Glorious Revolution, the plan was abolished, and the nine colonies regained their independence in 1689. It was founded in 1630 by the English Puritans. The colonial charter was abolished in 1684, and the Massachusetts Bay Department was established in 1691. It was founded in 1622. In the 1850s, the Massachusetts Bay Colony annexed the Maine Territory (now the southern tip of Maine). In the second half of the 17th century, the Maine area east of the Kennebec River was also part of New York. In 1691, the charter formally incorporated these areas into the Province of Massachusetts Bay. It was built in 1620. In 1691, it was incorporated into the Province of Massachusetts Bay. It was built in 1635. It was incorporated into the Connecticut Colony in 1644. It was founded in 1637. As a punishment, Charles II issued the Connecticut Charter in 1622, which ceded New Haven to the Connecticut Colony.

As of June 2014, Neptune is known to have 14 natural satellites, all named after Greek and Roman mythological water gods. The largest of these is still Neptune I, discovered by William Russell on October 10, 1846, 17 days after the discovery of Neptune; the second moon, Neptune II (Lead), was discovered more than a century later. Neptune is the only irregular satellite with a planetary mass, i.e., it orbits in the opposite direction of Neptune's rotation and is inclined relative to the equator. This suggests that it was not formed at the same time as Neptune, but was captured by Neptune's gravitational pull. The second largest irregular moon in the Solar System is Phoebe, but it has only three tenths of the mass of Neptune. The capture of Neptune, which may have occurred some time after the formation of Neptune and its satellite system, was a devastating disaster for Neptune's primitive satellite system. Disturbing their original orbits, they collide with each other to form a rubble disk. Neptune's mass is large enough to reach a state of fluid static equilibrium, and it is able to retain a sparse atmosphere, forming clouds and haze. There are also seven regular moons in the orbit of Neptune, orbiting in the same orbit as Neptune and close to the equatorial plane; there are also some moons in the rings of Neptune, the largest of which is Proxima 8, which captures Neptune and regenerates from the previous debris disk after the orbit of Neptune has been rounded. In the outer layer of Neptune, Neptune also has six irregular moons, of which Neptune II is one, whose orbits are much further away and tilted: three of which are in transit, and the remainder are in retrograde orbits.

In order to invade Greece, Hitler reached Hungary, Romania, and Bulgaria within a short period of time to sign the Treaty of Tripartite Pact, joining the Axis powers through a series of co-operation agreements. Yugoslavia signed a friendship agreement with Hungary on 27 February to counter some of the German pressure, and the latter government also wanted to suppress the growing pro-German forces in the capital, Budapest. However, since the summer of 1940, the Hungarian High Command has been willing to support any plans for military action against Yugoslavia, despite the opposition of Prime Minister Ferencvárosi Pál (who further strengthened relations with Yugoslavia in October 1940, with Hitler's approval). On 5 March, the British Embassy in Belgrade began advising expatriates to leave Yugoslavia. At 8:30 p.m. on 25 March, the Kingdom of Yugoslavia formally signed the Treaty of Tripoli. The next day, a coup d'état took place in Belgrade, in which a group led by Dušan Šimović overthrew the existing government and formed a new cabinet. For this sudden coup, which swept away all German influence and diplomatic achievements, despite Yugoslavia's declaration of "faithfulness", the most German-friendly leader of the South was kicked out of political power. Military cooperation agreements between Germany and the Axis allies were concluded as early as October last year, which provided a great deal of facilitation for this operation. On 31 March, the German Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued three demands to Yugoslavia: first, compensation for the loss of German property following the coup d'état; second, public ratification of the Tripartite Pact; and third, demobilization of the army. At the same time, the German overseas population in the southern part of the country began to withdraw. On 2 April, the Germans ordered the South Korean embassy to be reduced to five, leaving only staff and general staff, but the next morning Belgrade was bombed by the Luftwaffe and the Germans launched a full-scale offensive against Yugoslavia.

The asteroid belt is a dense region of the Solar System between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter. Of the 120,437 asteroids that have been numbered, 98.5% have been discovered here. Asteroids are small bodies of rock or metal that orbit the Sun. Because this is the most densely populated region of asteroids, estimated at as many as 500,000, the region is known as the main asteroid belt. The asteroid belt is formed by a group of stars in the primordial solar nebula — precursors of planets that are smaller than planets. Jupiter's enormous gravity hindered these stars from forming planets, and caused many of them to collide with each other at high energies, causing many debris and fragments. The asteroid's orbit around the Sun continued to be perturbed by Jupiter, forming an orbital resonance with Jupiter. The asteroids at these orbital distances (i.e., the Kirkwood Gap) are quickly swept into other orbits. The first three asteroids discovered in the main belt were Chitose, Mars, and Vesta, while the largest three were Chitose, Kenshin, and Vesta, with an average diameter of over 400 km; only one dwarf planet, Ceres, was found in the main belt, with a diameter of about 950 km; and the remaining asteroids were not large, some as large as dust. The material in the asteroid belt is very sparse, and several spacecraft have passed safely without incident. The asteroids in the main belt are divided into three classes according to their colors and major forms: carbonate, silicate, and metal. Collisions between asteroids may form a family of asteroids with similar orbital characteristics and coloration, and these collisions are also a major source of dust that produces ecliptic light.

Ni Ni (1916-2012), from Teng County, Shandong Province (present-day Tengzhou City). He was a statesman, calligrapher, adviser to the President of the Republic, and was awarded the Order of the Second Star by the President himself. For many years, he served as an anti-Japanese commander-in-chief, and later wrote plaques and awards for the President's Office (e.g., Deng Lijun, Tani Shosho). He's the oldest civil servant in history, often referred to as a national treasure. Ni graduated from the Law and Politics Department of the Central Political School (now Taiwan National Political University) in 1946, and studied under Mr. Wang Zhongyu, an early political activist of the Kuomintang. Between 1946 and 1948, he served as the director and secretary of the Mongolian Tibetan Committee of the Executive Yuan in Nanjing. From 1948 to 1967, he served as the head of the Legislative Yuan, secretary, brief secretary and head of the group. He was a member of the National Construction Planning Committee of the National Security Council from 1967 to 1973. He served in the legislature for 25 years, until the senior legislator stepped down. When he was ready to retire, former President Lee Teng-hui sent a special train to pick him up at the presidential palace, where he was hired as a state policy adviser. Between 1973 and 1991, he served as Deputy Secretary-General and Advisor to the Constitutional Review Committee of the National University of Japan. Since 1991, he has been appointed as an advisor to the President of the Republic of China. In 2000, when the party was re-elected, Ni Ni packed up his belongings and prepared to leave, but remained in office again for President Chen Shui-bian. In 2002, he was promoted to the position of President of the Republic of China. From 1999 to 2006, he was a consultant to the Chinese Calligraphy Society of Taiwan. Nine years later, he helped the president write plaques, headlines, praise letters, and articles for his country's Joint Communiqué and Spring and Autumn Festivals. He excelled in ancient Chinese literature, poetry, and was deeply involved in Peking Opera and Kunqu.

Thomas Hardy OM (2 June 1840 – 11 January 1928) was an English writer. Hardy studied architecture in Dorchester, England, and then travelled to London in 1862, where he became a student of King's College London, studying architectural engineering while pursuing studies in literature, philosophy, and theology. Hardy worked as an architect for several years, receiving awards from the Royal Society of Architects and the College of Architects, before devoting himself to literary creation. He wrote many works throughout his life, his novels mostly set against the backdrop of rural life, his early works long novels "Under the shade", "Away from the dust", idealizing rural life under the rule of law, opposing industrialized urban civilization. The realistic elements of the work were gradually strengthened. The long novels Return to the Countryside, Mayor of Castlebridge, and Residents in the Woods, through the tragic encounters of the characters in the book, reflect the enormous changes in England's legal countryside after the industrialized forces penetrated the countryside. Tess of the Derby and Jude the Unknown are two of his representative novels, the former depicting the tragedy of the persecution and destruction of rural girls by the rich, and the latter a story of the destruction of the ideals of rural youth in industrial society. In his later years, he turned to poetry, writing the play The Ruler, denouncing the tyrant who brought misery to the people. His works are full of sympathy for the poor and unhappy lives of the people, profound revelations and criticisms of industrial civilization and morality, but his works also have some pessimistic and fatalistic themes. Hardy had a dual status as a poet and novelist, with the exception of short stories, novels, short stories, poems, and plays, all of which were of high quality, and published one novel every 12 years since 1871, with a total of 14 novels, seven of which are considered to be great works of English fiction.

The Institute of International Relations (later renamed the Institute of Diplomacy, now known as the Master's Degree Program in Diplomacy) was established in Taiwan, and the Department of Diplomacy was reinstated the following year. In 1989, the State approved the establishment of a doctoral program and a master's program in strategic and international affairs. The Institute of East Asian Studies was founded in 57 years of the Republic of China, was the first institute in the country, with mainland China as the core, and awarded master's degrees, in 70 years of the Republic of China was authorized to establish a doctoral course, became an academic center of domestic and overseas research on mainland China issues, has a network of overseas and domestic universities, and is deeply influential. Established in 1983, the Institute of Russian Studies (Russian: Институт России) is the only institute in Russia dedicated to the study of political and economic issues in Russia, Central and Eastern Europe, and the Commonwealth of Independent States. Since 1992, the institute has conducted a distinctive "Master's Course in National Security and Continental Studies" for relevant public officials and social professionals. The Faculty of International Affairs, together with the Center for International Relations, the Faculty of Foreign Languages, the Faculty of Social Sciences, the Faculty of Law, and the Faculty of Commerce, established the Master's Degree Program in Japan in the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of Japan. The Master's Degree in International Studies in English was established in the year 101 of the People's Republic of China, with the main goal of inviting international students to Taiwan to receive regular education in international relations and cultivate professional leaders in international affairs. In January 1999, the National Assembly of the Republic of China passed the Program for the Integration of Resources and Development of the Institute of International Affairs, with the Institute as the unit, coordination of funding, human resources, admission, curriculum, space, work and evaluation, while respecting the existing interaction patterns.

From then until 1767, the island was under the administration of the French East India Company. In 1735, the newly appointed governor, Bertrand-François Maé de Labradorne, began to develop sugar plantations on the island of France, and developed the port of Louis as a center for shipping and shipbuilding. In addition, many of the existing Mauritian buildings were also constructed in Labrador. From 1767 to 1810, except during the French Revolution, during which the colonists of the island established a de facto independent government, administrative officials on the island were appointed by the French government. From 1803 to 1810, the governors of France and Réunion were Charles Mathieu Isidore Decaen, a famous general during the Revolution and Napoleon's opponent. He had arrested the famous British explorer and mapmaker Matthew Flinders as a "prisoner of war", and although Napoleon ordered the release of the British, Degas did not hesitate to keep Flinders in long-term custody in order to oppose him. During the Napoleonic Wars, the island became a base for French pirates attacking British merchant ships, which continued until 1810, when the Royal Navy under Brigadier General Josias Rowley captured the island. During the Anglo-Mauritian War, the French won only the Battle of Port-au-Prince, and surrendered three months after being besieged by the British at Cape Malheureux.

Uranus (minor planet designation 38628, 2000 EB173) is an exoplanet discovered on March 10, 2000 by Ignacio Ferrin. It has an orbital resonance of 3:2 with Neptune, and is thus classified as a Pluto minor planet. It was not until the founding of the Four Emperors that the empire was fully restored to stability, during which time all four emperors co-ruled the Roman Empire. This system could not be sustained, and soon led to civil war. The Civil War was finally won by Constantine I, the sole ruler of the empire. Later, Constantine I moved the capital to Byzantium and named it New Rome, but historians prefer to call it Constantinople. Constantinople remained the capital of the empire until its end. Constantine I also legalized Christianity in 313, and Diocese I declared Christianity a national religion, making Christianity the dominant religion in the Western world. The Roman Empire remained the dominant power in the world, and a century-long conflict with its eastern heirs, the Persian Third Empire, continued. Emperor Theodosius I was the last emperor to rule a complete Roman empire, whose territory was increasingly eroded by adverse factors such as abuses of power, civil wars, barbarian invasions, military reforms, and economic decline. In 410 and 455, the western Roman city was invaded by Germanic tribes such as the Visigoths and Vandals. In 476, Roman Emperor Romulus Augustus was deposed by the Ottomans, marking the end of the Roman Empire. However, since Romulus Augustus was never recognized by the Eastern Roman Empire, strictly speaking, the last emperor of the Western Roman Empire, Emperor Nebuchadnezzar, died in 480 AD, marking the end of the Roman Empire's rule in Western Europe.

Prunus subgen. Padus Plants are not called cherry blossoms in Chinese, but they are often called cherry trees in Japanese, such as ash-leaved plums are called cherry trees in Japanese, and cypresses are called dog cherry trees in Japanese. Most of the wild and cultivated varieties of cherry blossoms bloom in the Northern Hemisphere between March and April. For wild varieties, even the same fat, each tree has different genes, so even if they're planted in the same place, there are some differences in when they bloom. On the other hand, for cultivars, they are often planted to admire cherries, and because they are clones propagated by grafting or cutting, they are genetically homogeneous, so that every tree of the same cultivar blooms and withers in the same place. In addition, some wild varieties, such as the Greater Sakura, and the cultivars that they breed, are already blooming before the leaves open, giving a spectacular impression to those who appreciate them. Yoshino cherry blossom is one of the most popular cherry trees for viewing cherry blossoms, because in addition to these characteristics of simultaneous flowering and blooming before the leaves open, it can also produce large numbers of flowers, and quickly grow into a large tree. Many cultivars of mountain cherry blossoms are derived from complex interspecies hybridization on the basis of Oshima cherry, which is commonly used for ornamental purposes, usually reaching blooming status within a few days to two weeks after the blooming of Yoshino cherry blossoms. Cherry blossom time is thought to be influenced by global warming and urban heat island effects. According to a 1200-year-old Japanese cherry blossom record in Kyoto City, Japan, from 812 to the 19th century, the cherry blossoms were relatively stable, but after that, the cherry blossoms began to bloom faster, and in 2021, the earliest record of a 1200-year-old cherry blossom appeared.

Some landowners felt that no slaves could sustain production, so they left Seychelles. Freed slaves had no land of their own and lacked the skills and willingness to work, leading to economic stagnation in the islands. Soon, when the coconut industry developed, things changed. With the British government sending slaves found on slave ships south of the equator to the liberation of Seychelles, Seychelles soon prospered. In 1879, Victoria officially became a city, with its own parliament. In 1903, Seychelles gained its independence from Mauritius and became a British colony. For a long time, Seychelles was a place of deportation for political prisoners in Britain. A Sudanese from Perak wrote the tune of today's Malaysian national anthem here, and Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus blessed it with eternal blessings. After the start of World War I, local supplies were affected, wages fell, prices soared, and the Seychelles' labor force was badly wounded in East Africa. The Seychelles felt neglected, and after the war began to protest against British rule. In 1939, Seychelles' first political party was formed. Soon, the British government was forced to open up the right to vote, but only 2,000 people in Seychelles enjoyed that right. In 1964, the Seychelles People's United Party, led by François-Albert Lené, and the Seychelles Democratic Party, led by James Mancum, were formed. In 1970, an autonomous government headed by Mankam was established. Following the 1974 general election, the newly formed two-party coalition government actively negotiated independence with the United Kingdom. In 1976, Seychelles gained independence from the Commonwealth.

The New Literary Movement originated in 1915 with the founding of the Shanghai-based "Young People's Magazine" (referred to as "New Youth" from the second volume, and generally referred to as "New Youth" by those studying the history of the magazine). In The New Youth, Jew focuses on several essays published by Hu Shi between 1917 and 1919. In the January 1917 issue of The New Youth, Hu proposed eight propositions: first, that there must be something to say, second, that we must not imitate the ancients, third, that we must seek grammar, fourth, that we must not groan, fifth, that we must break down stereotypes, sixth, that we must not use dictionaries, seventh, that we must not fight, eighth, that we must not avoid colloquialism. Hu advocated the use of white literature, arguing that "white literature is the authenticity of Chinese literature, and a necessary tool of future literature, it can be asserted." In April 1918, he published The Construction of the Literary Revolution, which divided the eight propositions into four principles: one must speak and speak only. And the second is, what to say, what to say; how to say, how to say. And the third is to say what I say, and not what others say. The fourth is what the people of the time are, and what they say. In addition, he proposed a new historical view of literature, overturning the orthodoxy of ancient literature, and establishing vernacular literature as the canon of Chinese literature. On the other hand, to use the traditionally neglected vernacular as the only tool of all literature, to create Chinese literature. In the February 1917 issue of the New Youth, Chen published "Literature Revolution" and made three major claims: "To overthrow the carved, aristocratic literature, to build a simple, lyrical national literature," "To overthrow the obsolete, paved classical literature, to build a fresh, sincere literal literature," "To overthrow the perfunctory, arduous forest literature, to build a clear, popular social literature."

Taiwan independence, also known as "Taiwan independence" or "Taiwan independence", is a term used to refer to Taiwan as a sovereign independent state, representing Taiwan, not a territory under the control of the People's Republic of China. They argued that Taiwan should retain the national flag of the Republic of China and its status as an independent state, not pursue Taiwan's independence movement and counter-attack on the mainland, and not favor unification with the People's Republic of China. This ideology supports "Taiwan is Taiwan" and the two-state doctrine, arguing that Taiwan should follow the Republic of China's flag and constitution. The term "Taiwan Independence" was coined in 2015 by Tsai Dingqi, the general convenor of the Taiwan Alliance for the Defence of Taiwan, to distinguish it from "traditional Taiwan independence", which is a claim to establish an independent state entirely under the name of Taiwan, arguing that it does not belong to Taiwan independence. This political term is similar to the old term "independence", both of which were seen as independence by the People's Republic of China. The term was first coined in 2015 by Tsai Dingqi, and is used to distinguish between different political policies such as "Taiwan Independence" and "Taiwan Independence". In the Taiwanese independence movement, there are many different lines of argument, one of which is that Taiwan should be independent, establish its own constitution and national flag, and the national flag should be the Republic of Taiwan, which is called "Taiwan Independence" or "traditional Taiwan Independence". The term "Taiwan independence" is a euphemism for "Taiwan independence", which explicitly advocates open Taiwanese independence, the establishment of a sovereign independent "Taiwan Republic", and the abolition of the political system of the Republic of China. China's isolationism, under the banner of the Republic of China, seeks not necessarily the unification of China, but the possible need for a legitimate movement. During the reigns of Lee Teng-hui, Chen Shui-bian, and Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan was regarded as an independent nation.

In 1875, Freshwater Hall was divided into Hsinchu County, Freshwater County, and Keelung Hall, hence the name "Hsinchu" and the first county was established, and the administrative center was located in present-day Hsinchu City, which included the area south of present-day Taoyuan City Shashi Creek, Hsinchu City, Miaoli County, and the area north of Taijia Creek in present-day Taiyuan City. In 1887, Hsinchu, Miaoli, and Hsinchu counties were divided into the present-day Taoyuan City area south of Shashi Creek, Hsinchu City, and the present-day Miaoli County area north of Zhonggang Creek, and the administrative center was established in Take Tren City (present-day Old City District, Hsinchu City). After Taiwan was ceded to Japan in 1895, the initial administrative divisions changed frequently. In November 1901, the whole of Hsinchu Province was divided into 20 halls and began to stabilize, at that time Hsinchu District was established as Hsinchu Hall, under the jurisdiction of five halls, the area of today's Hsinchu Province did not include Guangxi Town, and included Miaoli District north of the China Port Creek. In October 1909, Miaoli Hall was demolished, Da'anxi was annexed to Hsinchu Hall to the north and Taichung Hall to the south; Hsinchu Hall's jurisdiction was expanded to include present-day Hsinchu City and Miaoli County (excluding Guangxi Town), and the administrative district was centered in Hsinchu District (along with present-day Hsinchu Railway Station). In September 1920, Hsinchu County was abolished and replaced by Hsinchu Prefecture, the whole territory of Hsinchu Hall was merged, Taoyuan Hall (excluding the Triangular Spring Hall) became Hsinchu Prefecture, eight counties were subdivided, and the province was established on Hsinchu Street in Hsinchu County (later elevated to Hsinchu City), and Zhongzheng Road was the axis of the city. After the end of World War II in 1945, the National Government accepted Taiwan, changed Hsinchu Province to Hsinchu County, the jurisdiction remained unchanged; the original county was changed to county district, district streets were changed to district towns and villages. On October 30 of the same year, Hsinchu City was designated as a provincial city, originally established in Hsinchu City, the county government, after the end of the war moved out of Hsinchu City, through the relevant officials and representatives of various levels of public opinion, after many studies, relocated to Taoyuan Town in Taoyuan District.

The Yantai Incident occurred on the afternoon of January 5, 1913, when the Yantai garrison in Shandong Province was involved in an armed rebellion. After the 1911 Revolution, for historical reasons, the number of Yantai garrisons was large, the quality, the equipment was uneven. In total, there were the Allied system of the Shanxi Army, the North Sea system of the Qiyunpeng Army, the Guangxi army of the Lianjiang base, the local Lu army and the navy. The North Atlantic government has repeatedly withdrawn its troops from Yantai, but for various reasons, such as soldiers being dismissed, remaining in the city of Yantai, obstructing public order, and inadequate food rations caused by the withdrawal problem, the army of all factions in Yantai is insecure. On January 3, 1913, the first and third battalions of the Guangxi army were disarmed due to a dispute over salaries, but by noon they had been disarmed. Subsequently, the 2nd Battalion followed orders to withdraw, hand over weapons, awaiting demobilization. However, the local Lu army soldiers, who had been dismissed years earlier, were at odds with the soldiers of the Guangxi army. After the soldiers of the Guangxi army were disarmed, they gathered in large numbers, besieged and beat the unarmed soldiers of the Second Battalion of the Guangxi army. The soldiers of the 2nd Battalion, angry, went to the regimental headquarters and demanded immediate payment of the demobilization expenses. At 4 p.m. on January 5th, the soldiers, having been unable to respond for a long time, started a riot, destroyed the regimental headquarters, broke through the armoury gates and looted the weapons. First, the soldiers of the Third Battalion responded, riot, looting, arson in the city of Yantai. Shang Zhen immediately sent troops to suppress the rebellion, while leading the battalion commanders to disperse and persuade, temporarily stabilizing the rebels. On January 6, the earthquake raised emergency funds, distributed demobilization funds, appeased the rebels. In the afternoon, the Shanxian armed forces seized the mutineers, boarded two ships, crossed the sea to Dalian, demobilized them in Dalian, and the mutiny subsided. The mutiny resulted in the looting of shops in the city of Yantai, the destruction of 28 shops, the burning of more than 80 houses, and the economic loss of about 50,000 yuan.

Although Taiwan was very close to Luzon, the Spaniards chose to expand south to Mindanao and the Moluccas, and did not intend to occupy Taiwan. Taiwan is referred to in Spanish literature as "Isia Hermosa", meaning "Beautiful Island", located seven hundred kilometers north of Luzon. In the late 16th century, Spanish officials always regarded Taiwan as part of the Philippines, and therefore considered Taiwan to be under Spanish royal jurisdiction. In 1586, the Governor of Manila signed a petition with fifty Spaniards to King Philip II of Spain and Portugal, urging him to send troops to the islands of El Mosa and the more remote islands of the Philippines, because "their situation is becoming increasingly corrupt... for their sake and for our own safety, we must reach out to comfort them, and it will be too late." Although the king replied that he would soon conquer places such as Elmosa, there was no compelling reason for Filipino officials in Dan to establish a stronghold in Taiwan before 1596. After the death of Toyotomi Hideyoshi in 1598, the Manila authorities saw the threat lessened and no longer intended to occupy Taiwan. By the early 17th century, the threat of the Manila authorities had rapidly shifted from Japanese to Dutch. Because of the Dutch War of Independence and the enmity of the Portuguese-Western Commonwealth, the Dutch expanded into East Asia, intending to block Spanish trade: on May 5, 1656, Valdez led a fleet from Manila, Philippines, due to the Dutch occupation of southern Taiwan. Spanish troops along the northeast coast of Taiwan. The Spanish established San Salvadoe as the center of their rule, from 1701 to 1771, until the situation improved when Chinese traders came to barter chickens and food.

South African Dutch is a variant of Dutch spoken by the 17th-century colonials, with a considerable number of loanwords and grammars from Malay, Bantu, and other languages, among which the ancestors of white South Africans are known as Boers, a name derived from the Dutch wordboer (farmer). Dutch has more phonemes than German, Russian, etc. In addition to the phonemes ch, lingo also has phonemes. Dutch is a SOV language, ordered main-subject-predicate. Most sentences in Dutch follow the second-order principle of verbs, meaning that the definite verb of a clause or sentence is placed in the second place, and has a separate component before it, used as the subject of the clause. In most sentences, the main order (not inverted) is: subject-limited verb-indirect adjective-determined adjective of time and place-direct adjective-predicate-non-predicate part. In sentences, the second syllable of the verb no longer applies, occurring in reverse (as in German), reversing the SOV syntax. In Dutch grammar, the sex of a noun determines whether it is modified or assigned to its prefixes, adjectives, and pronouns. Sex in Dutch is a very complex topic, because depending on the geographical area and the speaker, there are two types of sex in Dutch: the first is universal and neutral; the second is trisexual (negative, positive and neutral). The Dutch language of the Kingdom of the Netherlands belongs to the first category, i.e. the two sexes; the Dutch language of Belgium (also known as Flemish) retains the three sexes. Traditionally, Dutch nouns were identical to German, Icelandic, and so on, and continued the three genders of the Germanic language: negative, positive, and neutral. Both the negative and the positive (or universal) nouns use the definite de, which contains more than half of the Dutch nouns; the neutral nouns use the definitehet, which contains a small part of the Dutch nouns.

Both sides claimed victory Chester Nimitz Jack Fletcher Two fleet carriers Two fleet carriers One light aircraft carrier 1941–1942 Indian Ocean in World War II Southeast Asia Burma Southwest Pacific North America Mainland Japan Manchuria and North Korea The Battle of the Coral Sea was a naval battle that took place in the Coral Sea from May 4 to May 8, 1942, and was an important battle in the Pacific War. This was the first carrier-to-carrier battle, the first naval battle in which both fleets were out of sight of each other, and the first naval battle in which the two warships did not directly engage each other. The Japanese determined to strengthen their defensive positions in the South Pacific by occupying Port Moresby in New Guinea and Tulagi in the Solomon Islands. To this end, the Japanese launched Operation MO, commanded entirely by Vice Admiral Naomi Inoue, and deployed several battle fleets of the Combined Fleet, including two fleet carriers and one light carrier to provide air cover and support for the fleet. U.S. intelligence learned of the plan and dispatched two carrier task forces and an Austro-Japanese joint fleet to intercept the Japanese. On 3 and 4 May, the Japanese successfully captured Tulagi, but several warships were attacked, sunk, or wounded by aircraft from the U.S. fleet carrier Yorktown. The Japanese, aware of the presence of U.S. carriers, dispatched their carriers to the Coral Sea, with the intention of searching for and destroying Allied naval forces.
