Southern Europe is bordered by the Mediterranean, where summers are dry and winters are rainy, where subtropical highs dominate in summer, and we have a westerly wind in winter. And the Arctic coastal region has a tundra climate. Two or three hundred years of archaeological excavations have confirmed that there was human activity in Europe, including Britain, during the Paleolithic. From 4000 B.C. to the 26th century B.C., the Celts in Western Europe developed a megalithic culture, and there are now European megalithic monuments. The Aegean Sea in the eastern Mediterranean is considered the birthplace of European civilization. Around 2000 BC, the ancestors of the ancient Greeks settled on the Aegean island of Crete, which also became the birthplace of ancient Greek civilization, and gradually developed a city-state culture. In the 5th century BC, after the Peloponnesian War, the ancient Greek mainland gradually declined, but its cultural influence continued to expand, and in the 3rd century BC, Alexander the Great conquered Egypt and Persia, established a great empire across Eurasia and Africa, spreading Greek culture to Asia and Africa. In 27 B.C., ancient Rome arose, formed the Roman Empire, became a great empire that ruled Europe, Western Asia and North Africa, and the Mediterranean became its inland sea. The Apennine Peninsula was the political and economic center of Europe at the time. After the 1st century, Christianity began to spread in Rome. In 313, Christianity was declared a Roman state, gaining dominance in Europe. In the late 3rd century, the Roman Empire gradually weakened. In 376, when the Huns defeated the Eastern Goths, the Goths were forced to cross the Danube into the Western Roman Empire. In 395, it was divided into two empires, East and West.

Wang Zhigang (Chinese: 王志剛; born 7 September 1942) is a Taiwanese politician. He graduated from the Department of Agricultural Economics, Taiwan University, and received a Ph.D. in Business Administration from the Texas Institute of Agriculture and Technology. After returning to Taiwan, he taught at the University of Taiwan, the Political University, and was the head of the Department of International Trade at the University of Taiwan. During his tenure, prominent entrepreneurs such as Guo Taiming, Yin Yanliang, Yin Kaitai, and Lin Xinyi were his students, and Taiwan University was the first university in history to have a full-time lecture in the Law School auditorium, with no seats on the floors or on the floors, and students crowded around the doors of the classrooms to listen to his lectures. In 1984, as a scholar, he was invited to serve as the executive secretary of the Investment Advisory Committee of the Ministry of Economy, cooperating with the government in implementing the policy of great openness to the outside world, actively attracting foreign investment, overseas investment and technical cooperation projects. In 1989, he was appointed Director of the Commercial Department, promoted commercial automation, promoted commercial upgrading; promoted the liberalization of commercial regulations, provided a convenient business environment, and achieved outstanding service to the public.In 1990, the Executive Council held an evaluation of service to the public of about 2,000 administrative agencies under its jurisdiction, the Commercial Department was rated as the first, by the then President Lee Hwan personally awarded the prize. In 1990, he was appointed Deputy Director General of the Ministry of Economy, which promoted Taiwanese business to invest in the continent, supplemented the registration system, and laid the foundation for bilateral trade and investment activities. From November 12 to 14, 1991, the Minister of Economy Xiao Wancheng led a delegation to Hancheng, South Korea to participate in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) ministerial meeting, which was Taiwan's first participation in APEC, Vice President Wang Zhigang accompanied as a speaker, witnessed our country under the name of Chinese Taipei, and China and Hong Kong became official members of APEC at the same time.

The Salt City (Chinese: 盐市; pinyin: Zhānfu; ancient Chinese: 盐渎; pinyin: Zhānfu) is a city in Jiangsu Province of the People's Republic of China, located along the coast of central and eastern Jiangsu Province. The coastline is 582 kilometers long, 61% of the total length of the coastline of the province. It's bordered by Nantong City to the south, Taizhou City to the west, Yangzhou City to the west, Huai'an City to the northwest, Yungang City to the northwest, and the Yellow Sea to the east. It is located in the northern part of the Yangtze River Delta, the northern part of the Subei irrigation canal is the Huang Huai Plain, the southern part is divided into two parts — the Kushan River in the west is the Lishui River Plain, in the east is the coastal plain, the terrain is flat, the canals are horizontal. Irrigation networks such as irrigation canals, waste Yellow River, Subei irrigation canals, Jiayang River, Xinyang Port, Tongyu Canal, Kushan River and others run through the city. With a total area of 16.931 square kilometers, it is the largest city in Jiangsu Province, with an area of 824.7 million inhabitants. With its long coastline and extensive coastal wetlands and beaches, Salt City is an ideal bird sanctuary, and the Yellow Sea bird sanctuary is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The area where Salt City was located was formerly Huaiyi territory; Kyushu was divided into Qingzhou at the time, Wu at the time of Spring and Autumn, and Yue at the time of Later. The warring states belonged to Chu. It belonged to the Eastern Kai County in the Qin Dynasty; the western Han Dynasty was initially the territory of the Sun Yat-sen Marquis Liu Wanfeng. In the Western Han Dynasty, Salt City was still a seaport on the coastline, and was named for its major industry, which was the smelting of seawater for salt. In the fourth year of Emperor Hanwu's reign (119 BC), the county was established, which was the beginning of the establishment of the county of Salt City, and Sun Jian was appointed as the secretary of the county of Salt City. The three provinces belonged to the Wei, abolished the county system; the West Jin again re-established the county system; the East Jin Yixi seven years (411) renamed Salt City, this is the beginning of the present name; the Northern and Southern Dynasties called Salt City County; the Sui Dynasty was still a county, belonged to Jiangdu County; at the end of the Sui Dynasty, Weiche, according to Salt King, was divided into two counties, Xin'an and An'le, the Tang Dynasty re-established Salt City County; the Song Dynasty belonged to Chu Prefecture.

Vigo, a powerful wizard and tyrant of the 16th century, suddenly resurrects his portrait in the museum and enslaves Janosz Poha, Dana's boss, ordering Janosz to find him a child so that he can escape the painting's restrictions on resurrection and conquer the world. Janos is in love with Dana, so he wants Vigo to win the Oscars. Detectives excavated at the intersection of the Oskarsplatz and found that the muck-filled river was passing through an abandoned Bietchi gas pipeline transportation system. Thunder tries to take samples from the river, but is attacked by slime, and in a panic accident causes the entire city to be blacked out. Ghostbusters also went to court for investigating supernatural phenomena and causing damage without authorization, using mucus samples as evidence. Judge Wexler argued furiously with the gang, and the mucus exploded, summoning the two brothers who had been sentenced to death. Ghostbusters help judges catch ghosts, and they overturn lawsuits and court orders that previously prohibited them from catching ghosts. Mucus sneaks into Dana's apartment in the evening and attacks both mothers and sons, and she again turns to Peter for help. Ghostbusters found mucus to be emotionally responsive, suspecting it was a build-up of New Yorkers' negative emotions. Peter and Dana have dinner together, and Egan, Ray, and Winston are dragged down the river as they explore the underground slime stream. The three of them huddled together until Egan realized they were mucussed. The three then determined that the river would eventually flow into the museum. The mayor thought the Ghostbusters' reporting was nonsensical, and the mayor's assistant, Jack Hardemeyer, put them in a mental hospital to protect the mayor's political fortunes.

The Battle of Handan (also known as the Battle of Pinghan) was fought between October and November 1945, when the Chinese National Army surrendered to the Japanese along Pinghan Road, south of Handan, Hebei Province, in a clash with the forces of the 8th Army of the Jinhe-Luyuan Military District, and the 8th Army called it "the self-defense counterattack against the National Revolutionary Army". In September 1945, the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) accepted the surrender of the Japanese army and dispatched troops to the Communist Party of China (CPC) liberated areas, but the Eighth Route Army did not allow the NRA to enter the liberated areas, believing that this was an invasion of them; at the same time, the Eighth Route Army actively accepted the surrender of the Japanese army to expand the liberated areas. On the Shanxi side, the Eighth Route Army launched a counterattack to prevent the surrender of the National Army. On 10 October, the two sides signed the Bi-Ten Agreement in Chongqing, but the substantive issues remained unresolved. The battle was nearing its end, but by the time it was fully over, most of the main army of the 8th Route was in southeastern Jin, and it was difficult to reach Handan at once. Liu Beisheng and Deng Xiaoping, during the Battle of Shanghai, deliberately left the Jilu Yu column, which had been stationed near Handan, to monitor the northern section of the Pyongyang Railway, and took on the task of blockading it. On October 10, Liu Beisheng and Deng Xiaoping sent a telegram: "He Lu Yu and He Nan should relax the secondary direction, pull out the army used in the decisive direction of the Pyongyang Line, no worries, dispersed troops, everywhere powerless. In mid-October, the First Ladder of the 30th Army, 40th Army and the newly formed 8th Army, composed of seven divisions and 40,000 men under the command of General Sun Lianzhong, the commander of the 11th Army, started from Xinxiang and moved northeast along the Pinghan Line under the command of Deputy Commander of the 11th Army, General Takashi Kōshū; the 32nd Army and the newly formed 4th Route Army, commanded by General Sun Daebu, continued to follow the First Ladder as the Second Ladder.

At the age of 24, he enrolled at Beiping Chinese University, where he taught political science, English and American law, as well as German and French, and The New York Times described him as "a living encyclopedia". In 1911, the Guangdong Provincial Assembly held a banquet in Hongkou Hongyuan Garden in Shanghai for Sun Yat-sen's upcoming visit to Beijing as the Provisional President, Wang Yun-fi's speech on behalf of the Assembly was praised by Sun Yat-sen, and in 1912 he was appointed Secretary of the Office of the Provisional President of Sun Yat-sen, and joined the Kuomintang. In 1921, on the recommendation of Hu Shi, Wang Yun-fi was appointed Director of the Compilation Department of the Commercial Printing House and later General Manager. During Wang's tenure, he published a variety of dictionaries, encyclopedias, and collections, with the aim of promoting education and academic independence, and was instrumental in the spread of knowledge in China. Wang also studied the invention of the square number retrieval method, known as Wang Yuan Five, and printed the Five Dictionaries of Wang Yuan using this method. Wang also reformed commerce with scientific management methods, increasing the number of publications. In 1932, during the Second Sino-Japanese War, the Commercial Printing House and the Oriental Library were almost completely destroyed by the Japanese, and more than 3,700 employees were made redundant and unemployed. After two years of struggle, he not only completely restored the operation of the building, but also doubled the original capacity by half. Under the auspices of Emperor Wu, Commerce was able to continue publishing during the Sino-Japanese War, and continued to do so for 40 years. After the war, Wang retired from the Nationalist Party in 1927, but became an active outsider as a senator.

Hispanic Americans, Latin Americans, Latin Americans, or Latinos are immigrants from Latin America to the United States, many of whom speak Spanish as their mother tongue and English as a second language. Americans referred to as "Hispanic" or "Latino" are, in fact, often European whites, or mixed-race people whose ancestors were married to Native Americans (the Mestizos), not true Spaniards, and sometimes include immigrants and ethnic groups who actually emigrated from Spain to the United States. As a result of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexican immigrants (including illegal immigrants) migrated to the United States in the 1980s and 1990s, becoming the largest ethnic minority in the country, surpassing African Americans. Latin Americans are generally settled in the southwestern United States, near the Mexican–American border, so in American schools, although the traditional middle school foreign language instruction is to learn French, in many states, the middle school foreign language instruction is to learn Spanish. The emergence of the Latinos, beginning with the Spanish conquest of the Americas in the Age of the Navigator, and the large number of Western conquerors who began to marry indigenous women, led to the birth of a mixed-blooded Latin population known as the Mestizos, which spread from southern Argentina to northern New Spain to California, and became the dominant ethnic group in Latin America. After the American Revolution of 1789, the United States emerged as the only nation in North America capable of competing with British North America, Canada, and Mexico, which had just gained independence from the Spanish Empire.

In addition, in Hong Kong and Macau, except in cases involving history, the term "Three Domains City" is commonly used, as opposed to Mainland China and Taiwan. The Chinese-language media in the area are generally referred to as "San Francisco" (Cantonese) and "San Francisco" (Chinese/Putonghua) depending on the dialect habits of the readers, viewers or listeners. The Chinese version of the official website of the City of San Francisco and its subordinate municipal units uses the two different translations of "San Francisco" respectively, without unifying them into a single translation. Older Chinese Americans often refer to San Francisco as the "Big Harbor" (whereas the "Second Harbor" and "Three Harbors" refer to the California capitals of Sacramento and Stackton, respectively), but this name has been used less frequently by new immigrants in recent years. Native Americans arrived in Northern California 3,000 years ago. Evidence suggests that the indigenous Ohlone people inhabited the San Francisco Bay Area as early as the sixth century, and that "Ohlone" means "Western" in their own language. Europeans arrived in the San Francisco Bay Area in 1542, and the San Francisco area became part of Spain's Upper California Territory in the 16th century. The Spanish general Don Gaspar de Portola led his men to explore the San Francisco Bay Area in 1769. On 28 March 1776, the Spanish explorer Juan Bautista de Anza selected two building sites, one for military purposes and the other for missionary purposes, but the actual construction was supervised by two of Anza's companions, Lieutenant José Joaquin Moraga and Francisco Palóu, a Franciscan priest.

Initially, volunteers temporarily recruited by the government and volunteers enrolled on a voluntary basis were separated from the regular United States Army, separately known as the "History of the United States Army", but in 1918 (within a year of entering the war), the Department of War abolished this division, declaring all former National Army units to be part of the United States Army. After the end of World War I, the isolationist United States began to reduce the size of its federal army. Congress passed the National Defense Act of 1920, which reorganized the U.S. Army, defining its three components: the Regular Army (the Army's reserve force), the Army National Guard, and the Army Reserve. The United States began using aircraft after 1910, initially under the command of the Army. In 1947, after World War II, the United States Army Air Forces formally separated from the United States Army and became the independent United States Air Force. The U.S. Army also participated in the Korean War and the Vietnam War. With U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War no longer supported by the people, the Volunteer Army Project (VOLAR) began in the late 1970s, seeking to abolish the compulsory military service. After the end of the Vietnam War, the U.S. Army became a fully volunteer army, consisting entirely of volunteers. In the early 1990s, the end of the Cold War prompted the United States to pursue a policy of disarmament.

Buddhism in Japan was introduced in the Asuka period, and began to develop in the Nara and Heian periods, as one of the Han Buddhist traditions, with Mahayana Buddhism as the mainstream. Chinese Buddhist sects that have disappeared, such as Shingon Buddhism and Hosso Buddhism, have been handed down to this day in Japan. According to the United States Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), Buddhism accounts for 70.4% of Japan's population and Buddhism for 69.8%. According to the Religion Statistics Survey conducted annually by the Japan Agency for Cultural Affairs, as of December 31, 2016, there are 84.74 million believers in Shinto (about 68 percent of the population) and 87.70 million Buddhists (about 70 percent of the population), i.e. most Japanese believe in both Shinto and Buddhism. Many Japanese do not participate in any religious organizations, only participate in traditional religious ceremonies such as weddings and funerals; and many young people even participate in religious ceremonies, but consider themselves agnostic or atheist. There are about 75,000 Japanese Buddhist temples and over 300,000 Buddha statues in Japan. According to the Japanese Buddhist calendar compiled by the Ministry of Culture, the majority of Buddhists in Japan today belong to the Taishu-Kamakura period sect. According to a 2010 survey of Eastern Hongan-ji Buddhist monks, the majority of sects in the Pure Land Sect (including Pure Land Shintoism) comprise about 47%; the Nichiren Sect (including Confucianism) comprises about 21%; the Zen Sect comprises about 16%; and the Esoteric Sect (including Taoism and Eastern Buddhism) comprises about 12%, with the remaining 4%. Eastern (continental) Scandinavian: Western (island) Scandinavian: The Scandinavian or Northern Germanic branch is a branch of the Indo-Germanic language family, including languages spoken in Scandinavia, parts of Finland, and the Faroe Islands and Iceland. The North Germanic languages are more widely used in comparative linguistics, while the Scandinavian languages are mainly used in the study of contemporary dialect continuum on the peninsula. The language is spoken by about 20 million native speakers, of whom about 5% live as a minority in the non-Northern Germanic-speaking country of Finland. There are also a number of speakers of the language in Greenland and North America. North Germanic is the official language of Denmark, Iceland, Norway and Sweden. Within the Nordic Council, written material is usually translated into three versions: Finnish, Icelandic, and one of three: Danish, Norwegian, and Swedish. In Northern Europe, apart from Finland, Greenland also uses a non-Northern Germanic language, Greenlandic, which is the only official language of Greenland. There are some German minorities (also known as North Schleswig Germans) in the southern part of Denmark's Jutland Peninsula, and German is the official minority language of the region. Conversely, in the German state of Schleswig-Holstein, a group of German-speaking Danish minorities settled in the Ruhr. Both groups are highly Danish-Lower German bilingual. Traditionally, German and Danish are the official languages of the United Kingdom of Denmark and Norway. Written languages in Denmark and Norway use Danish, while the Duchy of Schleswig and Holstein use German.

Pingliang is a city in Gansu Province, China, located in the eastern part of Gansu Province, at the intersection of the three provinces of Shaanxi and Ganning. It's bordered by Baiyin City to the northwest, Xilinding City to the west, Da Tianshui City to the southwest, Baoji City to the southeast, Xianyang City to the east, Linqingyang City to the northeast, Guyuan City to the northeast of Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region. It's in the western Longdong Loess Plateau, high in the middle, low on both sides. To the east are the loess plateau gullies, to the middle are the hexagonal mountain ranges, and to the west are the Liangshan Hills. The western two counties belong to the Weihe River system, the eastern five counties belong to the Jinghe River system, the Jinghe flows from the west to the east across the middle. It has a total area of 11,171 square kilometers, a population of 209,800, and the city's people's government is located in Dongdong District. Plain is an ancient Silk Road must-visit town, called "dry dock" and "the first city west of Chang'an." The Buddhist name Mt. Dongdong is located in the precinct. In 572, he was appointed governor of Pingliang County, Longcheng County, Liyuan Province. In 742, the county was reorganized into a county, and the original county was reorganized into Pingliang County. In 788, Pingliang County was re-established. In 803, the exiles from Gyeongwon Province, located in Baili-jo Castle in Lingtai County, moved to Pingli-jo Castle. In 809, Wei was established in Pingliang, Pingliang County. In 880, the Tibetans occupied Pingliang Castle. After the Tang Dynasty of Qingtai II (935), Pingliang County was re-established, first belonged to Jingzhou, then to Weizhou. In the Northern Song Dynasty (1117), Weizhou was elevated to the rank of Pingliang army commander. In 1331, he changed Weizhou to Pingliang Prefecture. It was renamed Weizhou in 1139. In 1787, he was appointed governor of Liangliang (平凉府) in Liangliang Province.

On January 12, 1946, the Republic of China changed the Japanese nationality of Taiwanese to the nationality of the Republic of China in the absence of a peace treaty. In August of the same year, the British Embassy in China sent a letter to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China objecting to the Taiwanese's unilateral change of nationality at the beginning of the year, saying: "With regard to the transfer of the island of Taiwan to China, the British Government considers that it should continue to comply with the Cairo Declaration of December 1, 1943." The Allies did not intend to transfer Taiwanese sovereignty from Japan to China, pending the conclusion of a peace treaty with Japan or other formal diplomatic procedures. Therefore, despite the fact that Taiwan has been ruled by the Chinese government, the British government regrets to agree that the Taiwanese people's industry has been restored to Chinese nationality.' In mid-February 1947, a group of Taiwanese youth went to the U.S. Consulate in Taiwan to present a petition to Secretary of State Marshall. In their petition to the United Nations, these young people bitterly stated that Taiwan was unlike anything they had seen before the disaster, that the Cairo Conference had pushed the Taiwanese into "human hell", and that the participants were responsible for the suffering of the Taiwanese at this time. The petition went on to state that Taiwanese nationality remained a matter of concern, and that Taiwan had not been returned to China before the United Nations and Japan signed a peace treaty, in which case Taiwan had a line of hope. At the end of the petition, the young people asked the United Nations for help and friendly involvement in governing Taiwan. On March 6, 1968, six days after the events, the U.S. Ambassador to Taiwan, Stephen Reid, wrote to Secretary of State Marshall, transmitting a letter from the U.S. Consulate in Taiwan, saying: "The Taiwanese emphasize the responsibility of the U.S. for the Cairo Conference and intend to appeal to the U.S. to help the United Nations intervene before the final transfer of sovereignty to China."

As a member of the House of Lords, a judge appointed as a permanent appellate judge, if not previously hereditary or life peer, would be added to the barony at the time of appointment. Thus, past British Supreme Court justices were noblemen, commonly referred to as "Judges" or "Law Lords". Following constitutional reform in the 21st century, the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom became the independent supreme court of the United Kingdom. The former "judges" automatically became judges of the Supreme Court, but the newly appointed Supreme Court judges no longer held the peerage. To avoid legal and public embarrassment, the government declared any Supreme Court justice without a noble title to be a "lord" and the actual title was announced at the time of the judge's appointment. Thus, all the judges of the Supreme Court are referred to as "My Lord" or "Your Lordship" in court. In addition, the judges of the Court of Civil Appeal under the Supreme Court also use the corresponding title ("My Lord" or "Your Lordship"), but do not hold the title of Lord. The word "Lord" was first used in the Old English wordhlaf-weard (loaf-guardian), reflecting the custom of the leaders of the ancient Germanic tribes to distribute food to their followers. The feminine equivalent of "Lady" may have come from "loaf-kneader". Late in the 13th century, the words laverd and loverd appeared, which is a variant of "Lord."

Although the introduction of the wartime economic system slowed the pace of Japan's financial bankruptcy, it was not a long-term solution, coupled with concerns about Soviet military might, and the Japanese were eager to quickly overthrow the national government in order to accumulate more resources for both northern and southern policies. As Emperor Hirohito of Japan said at a pre-war conference in Wuhan, he wanted to give the national government a final and deadly blow, to force China to surrender, and not to see another "million imperial divisions subdued in China." Therefore, Japan's war against Wuhan was also a throwing away of the nation's strength, a throwing away of its own. After the war, it was discovered in Japanese documents that "the army devoted all its efforts to the Battle of Hankou, and there was no room for maneuver," and even the only remaining Japanese Home Guard division was on standby ready to reinforce Wuhan. Wuhan was the second-largest city in China at the time, with a population of more than two million, and on December 13, 1937, the National Government Military Committee formulated a plan to defend Wuhan. After the defeat of Xuzhou, he reorganized the deployment, mobilized about 50 army 130 divisions and 200 aircraft of various types, 40 ships of various types and minelaying boats, a total of more than 1 million people, took advantage of the favorable terrain on both sides of the Dabie Mountain, Poyang Lake and Yangtze River, organized defense, defended Wuhan. Lieutenant General Li Zongren, Commander-in-Chief of the Fifth War Area (from mid-July to mid-September, acting on behalf of Bai Chong-hui), commanded 23 army divisions in charge of the defense of the North River; Lieutenant General Chen Cheng, Commander-in-Chief of the Ninth War Area (from mid-July to mid-September, acting on behalf of Bai Chong-hui), commanded 27 army divisions in charge of the defense of the South River. In addition, the 1st War Area was in the area west of the Zhengzhou to Xinyang section of the Pinghan Railway (now Beijing 1 Hankou) to defend the Japanese forces south of China; the 3rd War Area was in the area east of the Yangtze River between Anhui Wuhu, Anqing and Nanchang in Jiangxi to defend the Japanese forces bypassing the Zhejiang and Gansu Railway (Hangzhou 1 Zhuzhou) to the Guangdong and Han Railway (Guangzhou 1 Wuchang).

Battlefield is a series of first-person shooter computers, home consoles, and Mac games developed by Electronic Arts. It was first published in 1942 by Digital Illusions CE. The Battlefield series is characterized by large maps, a wide variety of vehicles, and extensive network combat, while recent Battlefield games also have environmentally damaging features. Battlefield 1942 is the first installment in the Battlefield series, released for PC on September 10, 2002, and for Mac in 2004. The game recreates the battlefield of World War II, with an abundance of land, sea and airborne vehicles, and supports up to 64 simultaneous online battles. DICE's self-developed Refractor engine was first used in Battlefield 1942. The game has sold over three million copies. Battlefield: Vietnam is the second installment in the Battlefield series, released for PC on March 15, 2004. The game recreates the Vietnam War, adding jets and helicopters. The game incorporates nearly 20 1960s pop songs to give it a sense of the times. Battlefield 2, the third installment in the Battlefield series, was released for PC on June 21, 2005, and is set against the backdrop of a fictitious modern military war. The game uses a much improved Refractor 2 engine, which makes great improvements in graphics and sound effects.

According to the Constitution of the People's Republic of China, the People's Republic of China is the supervisory organ of the People's Republic of China, is the state organ that performs the functions of state supervision, was established from 2017 to 2018 successively, is elected and appointed by the people's congress at the same level, accepts the supervision of the people's congress at the same level and the state supervisory organ at the higher level, is a parallel state organ other than "one government and two courts", and co-operates with the CCP's disciplinary and inspection organs at the same level. This system is a reorganization and optimization of the disciplinary inspection organs, administrative supervision organs and anti-corruption departments at the four levels of the state, province, city, and county, and is regarded as a major reform of the system of disciplinary inspection and supervision of the Party and the State under the leadership of President Xi Jinping. The thirteenth session of the National People's Congress, held in March 2018, adopted the Constitutional Amendment and the Law of the People's Republic of China on Supervision, and elected the first members of the National Supervisory Commission of the People's Republic of China. On October 27, 2016, the Communist Party of China's Sixth Plenary Meeting of the Eighteenth Central Committee of the Communist Party of China merged the "supervisory organ" with power organs (the People's Congress and its Standing Committee), administrative organs (the People's Government), judicial organs (the People's Court and the People's Procuratorate) for the first time, and upgraded it from a constituent department of the People's Government to a parallel state organ. For this reason, the CPC Central Committee decided to establish the Leading Group for the Pilot Work on the Deepening of the National Supervisory System Reform, and Wang Qishan, Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, served as the head of the group. On November 7, 2016, the General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued "On the Pilot Program for the Development of the State Supervisory System Reform in Beijing, Shanxi and Zhejiang Provinces", which determined the thinking of the supervisory system reform.

Since taking office in 2017, US President Donald Trump has repeatedly criticized the North American Free Trade Agreement for the loss of manufacturing jobs in the United States. The North American Free Trade Agreement reopened negotiations, and the first round of negotiations officially kicked off in August 2017. On August 27, 2018, the United States and Mexico reached a preliminary agreement in principle to renew the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA): On September 30, 2018, the United States and Canada announced that they had reached a consensus on a new agreement: Agriculture has been a contentious issue since the original NAFTA negotiations, and any free trade agreement signed under the World Trade Organization framework raises similar issues. Agriculture is the only part not to have been negotiated in tripartite consultations, with three separate agreements being negotiated bilaterally. Agreements between Canada and the United States contained restrictions on agricultural products and tariff quotas, mainly sugar, dairy products, and poultry; agreements between Mexico and the United States allowed phased trade liberalization. The overall effect of the Mexico–Mexico Agricultural Agreement is controversial, as Mexico does not have the infrastructure investment needed to compete, such as a complete rail and road transportation system, which puts the country's poor in a more difficult environment. In fact, Mexico's agricultural exports increased by an average of 9.4 percentage points annually from 1994 to 2001, compared to imports which increased by only 6.9 percent. Mexico's corn production increased after the NATFA was implemented, but the domestic demand for corn exceeded what was available, making imports more urgent than Mexico's initially agreed agricultural quotas.

The first Chinese People's Liberation Army naval fleet to cross the Taiwan Strait occurred in late January 1974, after the outbreak of the war in the Western Sahara, the Chinese People's Liberation Army Navy Eastern Sea Fleet escort ships of the 18th Battalion South Division in the Fuzhou Military District fully counterattacked, from the evening of 21 to the morning of 22 smoothly sailing through the Taiwan Strait, supporting the South China Sea Fleet. The Chinese People's Liberation Army Navy used the voyage to break the military blockade of the Republic of China — the policy of closure, to restore the fleet to the Taiwan Strait. Tens of thousands of soldiers in Fuzhou Military District. In October 1949, the People's Republic of China was founded, divided on both sides. To oppose the new government of the People's Republic of China, the Republic of China imposed a military blockade of China's territorial waters — a policy of closure. Although the People's Republic of China gradually broke through the military blockade in other areas of the Taiwan Strait, the Republic of China was able to maintain its closure policy for a long time because of US support and the Republic of China's military superiority over the People's Republic of China. PLA surface ships, like civilian ships, didn't cross the Taiwan Strait until 1974. When small ships — torpedo boats — are moved north and south of mainland China, they are usually transported by train. The Southern Submarine Group, the 18th Battalion, 6th Marine Guards Squadron of the Eastern Sea Fleet of the People's Liberation Army in Zhejiang Province, was the main fighting force at the time. The 18th Battalion was originally composed of four Type 6601 frigates of the Riga class, namely the Kunming (505), Chengdu (506), Guiyang (507) and Hengyang (508). On 19 January 1974, the Battle of the Western Sahara broke out. Prior to this, Zhang Yuanpei, commander of the South China Sea Fleet, had asked the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the People's Liberation Army Navy for support for the East China Sea Fleet.

The French Liberation of Paris (French: Liberation de Paris) was a battle fought by the Allies to regain control of Paris from the Germans during World War II. The battle lasted from 19 August 1944 until the surrender of the German garrison on 25 August 1944. After the Battle of France in 1940, France fell into Nazi Germany's military occupation, and Western Europe fell into Nazi Germany's rule. The Allied forces launched a counterattack on Western Europe in 1944, and on 6 June 1944 the Allied forces successfully landed in Normandy. Allied military operations in Normandy progressed smoothly, and by early August they had achieved the objectives of the Grand Duchy's campaign, gaining control of much of the Normandy region. Following the fall of Normandy to the Allies, Allied troops approached the original French capital, Paris. On 19 August, the French Resistance in Paris responded by launching an uprising to drive out German troops stationed in Paris. Among them, the former Vichy France, which had a police force of 10,000, also joined the uprising under the banner of the Resistance. The Germans, on the other hand, had about 20,000 regular troops stationed in Paris, 5,000 of whom were in the city. The two armies fought fiercely in the streets. Due to the heavy casualties of the French resistance, the insurgents' fighting power and weaponry were far inferior to those of the trained regular German forces, as well as inadequate supplies and ammunition, the insurgents sent envoys to the regular Allied forces to seek help. However, according to the Allied plan, the Allied forces intended to bypass Paris after the Normandy landings and attack Germany directly, avoiding entering the city for street fighting, so the Allied generals in command of the front refused to seek the help of the French guerrillas. However, under the influence of Charles de Gaulle, the supreme decision-maker of the Allied forces, the plan was changed, and the French 2nd Armoured Division was sent to attack Paris; on 24 April, the leading elements of the L'Aquilae Division entered Paris and engaged the Germans; on 25 April, the French issued an ultimatum to the German commander of the garrison, Lieutenant General Dietrich von Kurtitz.

Plastics can also be classified according to their physical properties, such as density, tensile strength, and glass conversion temperature. There are also specialty plastics for special purposes, like medical plastics, conductive plastics, high-temperature plastics, etc. Biodegradable plastics degrade naturally when exposed to certain environmental or biological conditions in nature. Specific conditions may include exposure to the sun, exposure to water or moisture, bacteria, enzymes, wind abrasion and other environmental conditions (environmental decomposition), or biological conditions such as predators, pests or insect attacks. Some types of plastic decomposition require that the plastic be exposed to sunlight, and some decompose in landfills or compost. Starch particles have been added to plastics to accelerate their decomposition, but they are still unable to completely decompose the plastic. Some researchers have used genetic engineering to modify a bacterium to make plastics that are completely biodegradable, but this material (polyhydroxybutyrate) is still very expensive by 2013. There are also companies that have developed biodegradable additives to accelerate the decomposition of plastics. Natural plastics include natural rubber, latex (which can be used to make gum), insecticides, and nitrified fibers, but most of today's plastics are produced by the petrochemical industry. The limited availability of oil and the problem of global warming have led to the development of bioplastics, plastics made from renewable sources of biomass, such as vegetable oil, corn starch, peas starch, etc. The world's annual consumption of soft packaging is estimated at 12.3 million tons, of which 32.7 million tons are bio-based. Some plastics are semi-crystalline polymers with half crystalline and half amorphous chemical structures, so they have both melting points (the temperature at which intermolecular forces are overcome) and one or more glass conversion temperatures (the temperature at which local molecular elasticity is significantly increased).

The court-martial jurisdiction of military courts differs from court-martial jurisdiction to court-martial jurisdiction: some incorporate military criminal law into court-martial jurisdiction, some retain military courts only during wartime, some distinguish between court-martial jurisdiction and court-martial jurisdiction on the basis of crimes committed by military personnel, and some make court-martial jurisdiction independent of court-martial jurisdiction; and some include members of the military family or civilians who may be transferred to court-martial jurisdiction if they violate military law. Some military courts, based on confidentiality requirements, may choose not to hold public hearings, or not to appoint a jury; in some cases, military convictions are preceded by discharge, discharge orders, and deprivation of liberty. Western military law originated in Roman law, when it was common law and there was no clear distinction between civilian and military crimes; after the conquest of England by William I in 1066, the establishment of the Constable's Court provided an independent tribunal to deal with crimes committed by non-citizens, separate from the civilian population; in 1523, the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V enacted the Military Penal Code, which was pushed to Europe as the military expanded; in 1642, the British formally established a military court to replace the constable's court; and in 1689, the British Parliament passed the Rebellion Act, which later became the basis of the U.S. military law.

The southern expedition of the Golden Soldiers, Huai'an often suffered from war, people fainted, so the Huai'an army was changed to Huai'an State, the Yuan Dynasty was changed to Huai'an Road, the capital was still Xianyang. During the Ming and Qing dynasties, Huai'an was the hub of the three great powers of the southeast: the river, the paddle and the salt; the imperial court appointed two governors of the southern river and the paddle; the city flourished at its peak; Fucheng, Kawashima, Banzhao, and Qingjiangpu formed dozens of miles of huge belt cities; along with Yangzhou, Suzhou, and Hangzhou, they were called the "four great cities" along the Beijing-Hangzhou Grand Canal. Huai'an Prefecture was one of only two prefectures north of the Yangtze River in present-day Jiangsu Province, and its jurisdiction extended to the four cities of Huai'an, Salt City, Shuqian, Lianyungang, and the eastern part of Xuzhou. In the Qing Dynasty, Huai'an Province was divided into Haizhou and Jilin Province, and Xu'an Province was divided into the newly established Xu'an Province, the scope of which was reduced, and six counties were under its jurisdiction: Shanyang (now Huai'an District), Qinghe (now Huaiyin District), Andong (now Lishui), Moyuan (now Sabian), Salt City, and Funing (division of Shanyang County east of the newly established Xu'an Province). In 1761, when the city of Qinghe was destroyed by a flood, the town of Qingjiangpu in Shanyang County was transferred to Qinghe as a new county seat. In 1914, several counties in the area were renamed because of their importance: Shanyang County was renamed Huai'an County, Qinghe County was renamed Huaiyin County, Andong County was renamed Lishui County, and Taoyuan County was renamed Sabian County. After the establishment of the Republic, the prefectural administration was abolished, and the road was retained. It was the seat of Huaiyang Road, and from then on it officially replaced Huai'an Prefecture as the administrative center. Huaiyang Road includes the former Huai'an Prefecture and Yangzhou Prefecture, and is administered by 13 counties: Huaiyin County, Huai'an County (now Huai'an District), Liansu County, Yancheng County, Funing County, Sabian County, Jiangdu County, Dongtai County, Gaopu County, Yixi County, Baoxiang County, Tai County, and Xinghua County.

The Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous-Shoemaker is a NASA spacecraft named in honor of astronomer Eugene M. Shoemaker. The main objective of the Soyuz-Shumek program was to study the inner structure, composition, mineralogy, mass distribution, and magnetic field of the star for more than a year. The secondary objectives include studying the characteristics of the weathering layer, the interaction between asteroids and solar winds, possible geological activity (e.g. dust or gas) on the surface of the asteroid, and the state of rotation of the asteroid. These data will help scientists understand the general characteristics of asteroids, the relationship between meteorites and comets, and the early history of the Solar System. To achieve these objectives, the spacecraft was equipped with an X-ray/gamma ray spectrometer, a near-infrared imaging spectrometer, a multispectral camera with a CCD imaging detector, a laser rangefinder, and a magnetometer. Scientists have also used the Near Field Tracking System to conduct radio science experiments to estimate the asteroid's gravitational field. The instrument weighs 56 kilograms and requires 81 watts of power to operate. The Soyuz-Shumek was also the first spacecraft to land on an asteroid. The main mission of the Soyuz-Shumek spacecraft was to study the structure of Uranus by orbiting it for nearly a year. Aishin is an S-type asteroid, 13 × 13 × 33 km in size, the second-largest of the near-Earth asteroids. Its initial orbital radius was 200 km, then gradually reduced to 50 × 50 km on April 30, 2000, and then to 35 × 35 km on July 14, 2000.

Swedish (Swedish: svenska 帮助·信息) is a North Germanic language (also known as Scandinavian) spoken mainly in Sweden and Finland (especially the Åland Islands) by more than nine million people. It communicates with two other Scandinavian languages, Danish and Norwegian. Like other North Germanic languages, Swedish is derived from Old Norse. Old Norse was a common language in Scandinavia during the Viking Age. Adult literacy in Sweden is 99 percent. Standard Swedish is the official language of Sweden, derived from the dialect of central Sweden in the 19th century, and established in the early 20th century. Standard Swedish spoken and written is unified and standardized. Other language variants that have evolved from older, more remote dialects still exist, some of which differ greatly in grammar and vocabulary from Standard Swedish and cannot be called the same language. These dialects are spoken only in very remote areas, in very small numbers, and these people have very little social mobility. Although there are no signs that these languages are going to be dead, many scholars are studying these dialects seriously, and local governments are encouraging people to use them, but the number of people using them has been decreasing since the last century. Swedish Standard Grammar is a predicate structure, sometimes changing the order to emphasize certain words. Swedish is similar in construction to English, with relatively little variation in word form; there are two types of lexical lattice, no grammatical lattice (previous studies have suggested that there are two types of lattice, main and subordinate); and there are differences between singular and plural. Adjectives vary according to their lexical, quantitative, and restrictive categories.

On March 15, 2017, the Fifth Session of the Twelfth National People's Congress adopted the General Provisions of the Civil Law of the People's Republic of China, which entered into force on October 1, 2017. However, the Civil Code has not been repealed and may continue to be applied. If the provisions of the Civil Code are inconsistent with the provisions of the Civil Code, the provisions of the Civil Code shall be applied in accordance with the principle that the new law is superior to the old law. In February 2019, Xi Jinping, General Secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC), said at the first meeting of the CPC's Central Committee for the Comprehensive Rule of Law, "We must start from China's national situation and reality, take the road of the rule of law that suits us, never copy the models and practices of other countries, never follow the path of the West's 'constitutional government', 'three powers' and 'independence of the judiciary'." The law of the People's Republic of China includes the basic laws formulated and amended by the National People's Congress and other laws formulated and amended by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress. In some cases, "law" is broadly equivalent to "constitution and law", but the Constitution is outside the scope of this article. The laws of the People's Republic of China must comply with the Constitution of the People's Republic of China, and the legal effect of the Constitution is superior to administrative regulations, local regulations, autonomy regulations and unilateral regulations, the regulations of the departments under the State Council of the People's Republic of China, the regulations of local governments, and judicial interpretations. The legal system of the People's Republic of China has changed over the centuries, but since the founding of the country, it has adopted the written legal system, with legal origins expressed as enacted laws, not including case law. In accordance with the Constitution of the Communist Party of China, the Regulations on the Work of the Basic Organization of the Communist Party and Party Organs of the Communist Party of China, and other regulations, the Political and Law Committee of the Communist Party of China has been established from the central to the local Party Committees at the county level, and exercises leadership over the judicial, procuratorial, public security and national security organs.

As a historical term, it usually refers to the introduction of Western ideas into Europe and parts of the pre-British colonies during the late Ming and early Qing dynasties and the late Qing dynasties. During this period, Chinese attitudes toward Western studies ranged from initial rejection and resistance to gradual acceptance, and even calls for "comprehensive Westernization." Western philosophy, astronomy, physics, chemistry, medicine, biology, applied sciences, technology, geography, politics, sociology, economics, law, history, literature, and the arts were introduced to China in large numbers through the media of Chinese immigrants, Chinese emigrants, various newspapers, books, and modern education, with Macau, Hong Kong, other trading ports, and Japan as important windows. The evolution of Western scholarship discussed in this article can be roughly divided into two phases: the Ming and Wan eras, with the arrival of Jesuit missionaries, touched upon the academic thought of China. By this time, Western science and technology was beginning to develop rapidly, while the development of science and technology in China was relatively slow, falling somewhat behind that of Europe at the same time. At the same time as spreading Catholic doctrine, missionaries also introduced a great deal of Western science and technology. Some Chinese physicians and emperors accepted scientific and technological knowledge, but were largely unaffected by it. This phase of Western studies was interrupted by a change in the Roman Church's missionary policy towards China (abolition of the Rima rule, prohibition of priests), which provoked antipathy from the Yongzheng dynasty and the people, but the smaller-scale introduction of Western studies was not completely stopped.

On the Korean Peninsula, discrimination against legitimate and illegitimate children during the Joseon Dynasty was severe, with men and women of different classes not allowed to marry, and lower-ranking men who married higher-ranking women were guilty of kidnapping and the marriage was null and void. Females of lower ranks, if married to males of higher ranks, are generally only concubines, not wives, and are not legally assisted after the death of their husbands, with very few exceptions. After the death of her elder brother, Yoon Yuan-hyun's concubine, Cheng Lan-jeong, she was permitted to be raised to the status of a legitimate wife, and she was given the title of Join Join-jeong-woman. At that time, there was a "mother-law" in which children inherited their mother's social class, with the exception of royalty or the children of the royal family. If a child is born out of wedlock to a non-royal family, his or her father, his or her lawful wife, and his or her legitimate brothers or sisters shall be regarded as servants of the Lord, and if his or her mother is of noble birth, he or she shall be regarded as servants of the Lord. The king's heirs are called princes, his daughters are called princes, his daughters are called princesses, and his sons are called princesses. The king's daughter-in-law is called the countess, and the daughter-in-law is called the countess. The legal spouse other than a legitimate wife is an illegitimate wife, often called a concubine or concubine. In the Zhou Dynasty, noblewomen married, requiring sisters or nieces of the same family to marry, called  (正妻的同族陪嫁女子), rarely seen in later times. A concubine is usually a man who marries a woman who is inferior to him, without going through the rites of Sanskrit, and takes her as his concubine in a simpler ceremony known as a concubineship.

Taiyuan City (Chinese: 太原市; pinyin: bīng; pinyin: zhōng; Nanjing dialect:bin1; Chinese: 中古擬音:pjeng; pinyin: zhōng; pinyin: zhōng; pinyin: zhōng) is a city in central Shanxi Province, China. The city borders on the northeast with Yangquan, on the southeast with Jinzhong, on the west with Lüliang, and on the north with Xinzhou. It lies in the northern part of the Taiyuan Basin, on the three sides of the Ring Mountains, on the east of the Taiyuan Mountains, on the west of the Lüliang Mountains, on the north of the Kaizhou Mountains and Yunshan Mountains. The Fen River enters from the northwest, flows through the city and exits from the south. By 2021, the city is divided into six districts, three counties, one county-level city, and the city's people's government is located in the Anhualing District. Taiyuan is an important central city in the North China region, an important new materials and advanced manufacturing base in the country, a political, economic, cultural and international exchange center of Shanxi province, as well as a decision-making and management center of Shanxi's economic and financial affairs, the core region of Taiyuan metropolitan area. Taiyuan is a long-standing cultural ancient city, with more than 2,500 years of history, has the honor of "Embroidered Taiyuan City" since ancient times. The southwestern corner of the city, Jinyang Ancient City, is the capital of several dynasties in Chinese history, so the Taiyuan is also known as the "dragon city". It is one of the cities with the largest number of cultural heritage projects in China, and has a certain international influence. It is also an excellent tourist city, a national garden city, a national historic and cultural city. It has successfully hosted the 2nd Youth Olympic Games, the Central China Expo and the China Television Awards. "" Taiyuan "" first appeared in the spring and autumn. In British units used in the United States, burning the equivalent of one cubic foot of natural gas produces 1031 British Units of Heat (BTUs). In the U.S., natural gas is often retailed as "" sam "" (Therm, abbreviated as th,1 Therm = 100,000 BTU). Wholesale transactions typically use "Decatherms" (Dth) or "Thousand decatherms" (MDth) or "Million decatherms" (MMDth) as units. One million tenths of a gram is roughly equivalent to one billion cubic feet of natural gas. As the main fuel for gas turbine engines and steam turbine power generation, natural gas is very important. In the gas turbine, steam turbine, combined cycle model of power generation, energy efficiency is particularly high. In terms of the natural environment, burning natural gas is cleaner and produces fewer greenhouse gases than fossil fuels like oil and coal. To get the same amount of heat, burning natural gas produces 30 percent less carbon dioxide than burning oil, 45 percent less than burning coal. Combined cycle electricity using natural gas is the cleanest fossil fuel energy available. This technology is being widely adopted where gas can be obtained at a reasonable cost. Fuel cell technology may eventually provide a cleaner alternative to converting natural gas into electricity, but it is not yet price-competitive. Similarly, natural gas is said to peak around 2030, 20 years later than oil. Global gas supplies will run out in the mid-1980s.

Hirofumi Ito (伊藤博文, Ito Hirofumi, October 16, 1841 – October 26, 1909) was a Japanese nobleman who lived from October 16, 1841 to October 26, 1909. Japan's modern politician, the Meiji Restoration Emperor, was one of the five great leaders of Choshu who went to the United Kingdom to study, led Japan to the completion of the Westernization, became the first prime minister of Japan's cabinet, plotted the Sino-Japanese War at noon, and was Japan's first Korean governor-general. In 1853, he lodged in a temple, and later worked as a servant in the family of feudal retainers such as Fukuhara, usually doing miscellaneous duties, leisurely studying literature and reading.

A prime minister (Chief Minister, Chancellor, etc.) is the head of government of a country or region who is responsible for the administration of the government. Most modern parliamentary, bicameral, monarchical, and other quasi-presidential governments have prime ministers or similar positions, and some prime ministers are formally called presidents of the Council of Ministers, but in some presidential countries (such as the United States, Brazil, and Indonesia), the head of state is also the head of government, so there is no need to create a separate government headquarters. The term "Prime Minister" is used in Chinese to refer to the head of government of a monarchy, such as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, but there are many exceptions to this usage. The titles of heads of state in Chinese are more often based on traditional translations, and can sometimes be used interchangeably. For example, the Prime Minister of Thailand under the Constitution of Thailand is often referred to as the "Prime Minister of Thailand" in Chinese; the Prime Minister of Japan under the Constitution of Japan may also be referred to as the "Prime Minister" or "Prime Minister" in Japanese; and the "Prime Minister" (head of government under the Constitution of Thailand) may also be referred to as the "Prime Minister" in Chinese. Both prime ministers and prime ministers can use the term "uprising" broadly, this usage comes from the ancient Chinese to distinguish the prime minister from the "uprising", the Ming Dynasty also called the cabinet chief "uprising", "Ming Dynasty Zhaofu calendar 1": "In Zhaofu, especially the uprising is important.

Zhang Zongchang (張宗昌; February 13, 1881 – September 3, 1932) was a provincial governor of Shandong Province. He was a military commander in the government of the Republic of China in Beijing. Zhang Zongchang broke through Guandong as a teenager, as a lumberjack, as a railroad worker, and in Russia, as a butcher, and later organized as a laborer's friend, became a bandit. In 1911, during the Revolution of 1911, he led the Green Line brothers into the hands of Huei, the governor of the Shandong Revolutionary Army, and then moved to Shanghai, where he became the commander of the Guangfu Army under Chen Qimei, the governor of the Shanghai Military Governorate. In 1913, he was appointed commander of the 3rd Division of the Jiangsu Army. In the same year, during the Second Revolution, Zhang Zongchang was ordered to Xuzhou to resist the attack of Yuan Shikai's North Korean army, and fell before the battle, becoming a subordinate of Feng Guozhang's North Korean army. In the spring of 1916, during the Shanghai Uprising, Chen Qimei was assassinated by Zhang Zongchang. As a result of his efforts, he was promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel. In November of the same year, he was appointed deputy commander-in-chief, and Zhang Zongchang was appointed military commander. After the outbreak of the Civil War in 1918, Zhang Zongchang was appointed as the commander of the 6th mixed brigade brigade of the Soviet army (Jiangsu army), along with Zhang Huaizhi went to Hunan to participate in the battle with the Southern government forces, but was defeated. In 1921, Zhang Zongchang's headquarters in Ji'an, Jiangxi, was disbanded by Jiangxi Governor Chen Guangyuan. Zhang Zongchang fled to the north. Since then, the direct leader Cao Cao had hoped to appoint Zhang Zongchang, but failed due to opposition from Wu Pefu. Zhang Zongchang then relied on Zhang Shaolin, who was a vassal of Zhang. In 1922, Zhang defeated the loyalist rebels and gathered the remnants of the rebels into his own army. In the winter of the same year, Zhang absorbed the Russian White Army, which had fled from Russia to China.

Organ transplantation is the process of transferring an individual's organ, in whole or in part, to another body (or to another part of the body, such as an autologous skin graft). The aim is to replace damaged or dysfunctional organs with healthy organs from the donor. The donor is the "" donor "" of an organ transplant, whether it's a living person or a recently deceased person. The organs provided by the living are called living organs, and the organs of the deceased are called dead organs. One of the recipients of the organ is the recipient of the transplant. However, organs that have been infected or depleted cannot be transplanted. According to Auschwitz survivor Yitzhak Ganon, he had successfully removed a kidney from a concentration camp medic, Joseph Mengler, without the use of narcotics, but this was inhumane, so that under normal conditions, anesthesia was used before the organ was removed or the donor was confirmed to be brain dead. In addition to the above-mentioned technical issues, organ transplantation in some places may also raise ethical controversies because of the source of the organ donor, so as noted above, in general, if the patient is not dead or suspected to be dead, it must be performed after the legal examination has been completed, and after the prosecutor has determined that no further examination is necessary. Since the People's Republic of China has long used capital punishment organs, there is considerable possibility of using imprisoned Falun Gong practitioners' organs without prior consent.
