Wang Xuefeng (Chinese: 王雪峰; born 26 August 1964) is a Taiwanese politician. He was born in Taipei. Wang Xuefeng was the daughter of Wang Kunwa, an important member of the Outside Party Movement, and was educated in the Political Department of the National Taiwan University before transferring to the Law Department of the National Taiwan University. During his time at the university, Wang was involved in student activism, served as vice president of the Taiwan University Students' Representative Union, and was one of the founders of the Association for the Promotion of University Law Reform; Wang was also attacked and detained by the military and police in 520 incidents. He then went to Cornell University, where he earned a master's degree in law, and then went on to study law at Harvard Law School. After returning to Taiwan in 1991, Wang was elected as a representative of the Democratic Progressive Party to the Second National Assembly in Taipei, and was subsequently appointed Deputy Director of the Social Movement Department of the Central Party Department of the Democratic Progressive Party, elected to the Third Legislative Council in 1995, and re-elected in 1998 and 2001. In 2002, Wang Xuefeng married fellow student Wang Sakuryo, and left politics. In April 2009, Taiwanese media reported that Wang Xuefeng and Wang Chengliang were picking up Visheng near their mountain home in Xindian City, Taipei County; Wang Xuefeng said that there was nothing wrong with picking up Visheng, and that she didn't mind being recognized, but she also hoped that the outside world would help her find a job. On October 15, 2009, Wang Xuefeng was rushed to the hospital in an ambulance after being injured by police officers, and Wang Xuefeng's brother Wang Bo-yu claimed that Wang Xuefeng had been assaulted by Wang since 2007. On October 16, 2009, Wang said that they had only argued on the 15th, that he had not beaten Wang Xuefeng, and that Wang Xuefeng occasionally waved at him; he said that he had indeed beaten Wang Xuefeng at the end of 2007, that Wang Xuefeng had gone to the hospital for an examination and to the police station, but that Wang Xuefeng had chosen to forgive and decided not to report; he said that, based on Christian belief, he would not divorce Wang Xuefeng, and that he would also take good care of Wang Xuefeng who was in poor health.

Brandess alumni are also famous in politics, including heads of state, congressmen, governors, diplomats, and so on. Brandeis University was founded in 1948. Because of widespread discrimination and exclusion, Jews, women, and other minorities were unable to access higher education on an equal footing, and the American Jewish community funded the establishment of a non-religious university, accepting faculty from all backgrounds and faiths. Its mission is to maintain excellence in university education and research innovation. It was founded on the site of Middlesex University. Middlesex University is a medical school located in Waltham, Massachusetts, and is the only medical school in the United States that does not allocate a quota to Jews. The founder, John Smith, died in 1944, and his will provided for the establishment of a non-sectarian university. Dr. Smith's son, C. Ruggles Smith, desperately wanted to save the University of Middlesex. He learned that a New York committee led by Dr. Israel Goldstein was seeking to establish a secular university funded by Jews. Smith sought Goldstein's help and made a proposal to hand over the Middlesex campus and licensing rights to the Goldstein Commission, in the hope that his commission "would have the evident ability to rebuild the medical school on the basis of approval". Goldstein feared that his medical school vision would fail, but eventually secured a 100-acre campus. So he was very excited. It's not far from one of the world's largest Jewish communities, New York City, and it's only nine miles from one of the most important Jewish population centers, Boston.

The truth of suffering is to observe that the source of suffering comes from greed, so that when suffering is to be destroyed, it is not to destroy suffering directly, but to destroy greed afterwards, because all beings are no longer greedy of the Five Elements, so that the Five Elements will not be born in the next world. The truth of suffering and destruction is the method of suffering, to go through the so-called "medieval" life according to the principles of the Eightfold Path, and finally be able to liberate the flow of life and death. There are many different categories of suffering in Buddhism, divided into three kinds of suffering, eight kinds of suffering, and so on. In the six realms, the suffering of the lust realm is all three, the suffering of the color realm is bad and suffering, and the suffering of the colorless realm is suffering. Eight types of suffering are commonly used in Mahayana Buddhism: according to the Long Part of Southern Buddhism, the Buddha also divides "pain" into ten types (the "Eleven Methods of Suffering"): life, old age, death, sorrow, grief, pain, sorrow, anger, resentment, separation of love, unwillingness to seek, and finally, in general terms, "five are pain." The Buddha referred to these sufferings as the "five virtues of suffering," that is, the five negative virtues of suffering, the five virtues of burning, that is, the five virtues of suffering. Moreover, suffering refers to the Four Great Constellations, and once the Four Great Disorders are in place, they cause all sorts of diseases. The suffering of the six realms of reincarnation can refer to a place where one is born after one's death, or it can refer to a situation in which one's karma is suspended, or it can refer to a situation in which one's mind is awakened, and one feels the pain of a certain cycle of reincarnation. The gods of heaven want to live happily, so they don't think about Buddhism. In the seven days before their death, they will see the five signs of death (the Five Decays of the Heavenly Ones) and the gods of the Immaculate Land will feel their weakness and fall.

Tianxingyu fried liver restaurant, which was founded in 1862 in Beijing China old name restaurant, which belongs to Beijing Cheap Bo Roast Duck Group Co., Ltd., with fried liver as the business characteristics, is the origin of fried liver. Founded in 1862 at the mouth of the fresh fish in front of Beijing's front gate, the restaurant, owned by Liu Yongqiu, was originally a small liquor store serving liquor such as yellow wine and peanut rice, peeled eggs, and salted eggs. In 1894, under the management of his successor, Liu Xigui, Qing Guangxu created fried liver, which was favored by customers because of its good quality and attentive service. In 1933, a Tianxingyu snack shop, which also sold fried liver, was opened in the vicinity of Xiangxiang House, and the two shops formed a rivalry, in which the competition gradually formed a unique fried liver production technique, and the two shops were merged in 1956 in the rush for public-private partnerships. In 1997, it was awarded the title of "The First National Chinese Famous Snack" by the Chinese Cuisine Association, "Eat Ten Authentic Specialty Snack Shops in Beijing." In 2006, it was recognized by the Ministry of Commerce of the People's Republic of China as one of the first "Old Chinese characters" hotels. In 2007, Tianxingyu's fried liver production technique was included in the list of protected intangible cultural heritage of the Chongwen District of Beijing. Finally, Allied leaders decided to launch a major offensive against France in early 1944, but U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt wanted to keep Italy out of the war. As a result, the Allies decided to conduct military operations against Italy without affecting the main fronts, thereby giving the Royal Navy complete control of the Mediterranean, and greatly improving Britain's ability to communicate with Egypt, the Far East, the Middle East, and India. At the same time, the Germans forced the Soviets to withdraw their troops from the war to defend Italy and southern France, in favor of the Soviets' war against Germany. At the time, the Allies had even hoped that Italy's surrender would force the Germans to abandon Italy and retreat to the north. In September 1943, the Allies successfully landed on the Italian mainland from Sicily, and Italy surrendered to the Allies. The Allied success in capturing large numbers of German troops in Italy prevented the Germans from mobilizing additional troops to support Northwestern Europe. On July 10, 1943, a combined force of British, Canadian, and U.S. forces landed in Gela Bay and Syracuse, Sicily, with amphibious assault vehicles and paratroopers. Although the Germans were unable to stop the Allied occupation of Sicily, they managed to evacuate almost all German forces back to Italy. On 17 August, the last German troops from Sicily withdrew to Italy. Nonetheless, the Allies at least learned to land. On 3 September 1943, the Eighth Army launched Operation Bay City, landing in Calabria, Italy, and the Italian government surrendered to the British on 8 September. However, the Germans did not withdraw and decided to fight alone. On 9 September, the U.S. Fifth Army launched a major campaign of avalanches, but encountered a German heavy artillery counterattack when it landed at Salerno.

Intel Corporation was the world's second-largest semiconductor company, initially developing SRAM and DRAM memory chips, which were Intel's primary business until the 1990s. In the 1990s, Intel invested heavily in new microprocessor designs and nurtured the fast-growing PC industry. During this period, Intel became the supply leader for PC microprocessors, and market orientation was dominated by aggressive and sometimes controversial marketing strategies, much like Microsoft dominated the development of the PC industry. The main competitors are Apple, AMD, NVIDIA, Samsung Electronics and TSMC. Intel's growth history can be divided into several distinct phases, described in the following sections. In 1955, "Father of Transistors" William Shockley left Bell Labs to found the Shockley Semiconductor Laboratory, which attracted many talented young scientists to join it. Soon, however, Shockley's management methods and eccentric behavior caused employee discontent. Among them, Robert Noyes, Gordon Moore, Julius Blank, Eugene Clay, Kim Hurney, Jay Laster, Sherton Roberts, and Victor Glick resigned, and in October 1957, they co-founded Sendo Semiconductor. Hungarian Andy Grove, who later made Intel a dominant player in the 1990s, joined the company in 1963 at the invitation of Gordon Moore. Due to the rapid development of Sendo semiconductor, internal organizational management and product issues have become increasingly imbalanced.

Kyzylorda Kyrgyz Autonomous Oblast (Kyrgyz: Кызылсуу Кыргыз aвтономиялуу oбласты; Uighur: قىزىلښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښه, Latin: QizilsuÉSZhiz Aptonom Oblasti), also known as Kyzylorda Suzhou or Kyzylorda, is an autonomous prefecture of the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of the People's Republic of China, located in western Xinjiang. It's bordered on the east by the Aksu region, on the south by the Kashgar region, on the west by Tajikistan, on the north by Tajikistan. It's on the southern edge of the Tianshan Mountains, on the eastern side of the Pamir Plateau, on the northwestern side of the Tarim Basin, on the northern slope of Mount Kunlun, and it's surrounded by mountain ranges. The main rivers are the Toshgan River, the Budani River, the Chukmak River, the Kuzlesu River, the Gezi River, the Kushan River, the Yelqiang River, and other lakes, such as Lake Brenkur and Lake Karakur. It has a total area of 72,468 square kilometers, a population of 59,610,000, a Kurdish population of about 27%, a Uyghur population of about 65%, and the autonomous city of Atush. Kizilsu (Kizil Su) is a name derived from the Kizi River, which means "red water" in Kyrgyz. "Kizil" (Russian: Кири́ль, "red") can be found in the villages of Kizil, Kizil Caves, Kizilto, and the capital of the Tuva Republic of Russia, Kyzyl.

Geographers study phenomena, processes, features, and the interrelationships between humans and the natural environment, their spatial and temporal distributions. Spatial and temporal themes are ubiquitous, such as climate, ecology, and economics, so geography is a cross-disciplinary discipline. Geography can be divided into two parts: natural geography and human geography. Natural geography focuses on natural environments, such as the formation processes of landforms, phenomena related to climate, soil, water, ecology, and vegetation, and their interrelationships. Human geography focuses on man-made environments, such as how humans colonize, manage, and view space.Natural geography is a natural science that specializes in exploring patterns of change in nature (rock, atmosphere, hydrology, and biosphere), and can be classified into the following categories: Biogeography and landscape ecology Climate and prehistoric climateology Oceanography and coastal geography Environmental geography and environmental management Geodesy Landforms Paleogeography and Quaternary science Hydrology and hydrology Soil and soil geography Climate glaciology and frozen soil Chemical geography Seismology and volcanology Human geography deals with the interactions between humans and the environment, and studies the relationship between humans and communities, culture, and economics, thus falling into the category of social sciences. Although there is little mention of human geography and landforms (see natural geography), human activity is certainly mountainous and riverous, with regional climates (such as deserts unsuitable for cultivation). Therefore, when discussing human geography and not neglecting natural factors such as landforms and climate, environmental geography connects the two.

谈迁 (23 November 1594 – 14 January 1658) was a historian of the late Ming and early Qing dynasties, originally named以训, 观若; after his death, he changed his name to 迁, 孺木, 明朝诸生, and was born in Haining Zaolin, Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province (southwest of Haining, Zhejiang). Established in 1928 in Nanjing, China, the Central Academy of Sciences (Chinese: 中央研究院; pinyin: Zhongren-in) is the national academy and the highest academic hall of the Republic of China, directly subordinate to the President's Office. Members of the Central Academy of Sciences are the highest honors in the academic world of the Republic of China, many of them are elected as full-time researchers at the Central Academy of Sciences, or after being elected as full-time researchers or communications researchers, so there is a relatively large proportion of members who are also researchers in the Academy. On April 17, 1927, at the 74th session of the Central Political Conference of the Kuomintang in Nanjing, Li Shisheng proposed the establishment of the Central Academy of Sciences, and the resolution recommended that Li Shisheng, Cai Yuanpei, and Zhang Jinjie jointly draft the Law on the Organization of the Central Academy of Sciences. On May 9, the 90th meeting of the Central Political Conference of the Kuomintang established the Preparatory Office of the Central Research Institute, and appointed Cai Yuanpei, Li Yuying, Zhang Jinjie, Chu Minyi, Xu Chongqing, and Jin Xiangfan as the Preparatory Committee members. On July 4, the "Organization Ordinance of the University of the Republic of China" was promulgated, renumbering the Central Research Institute as one of the affiliated institutions of the University of the Republic of China. On November 9, the "Organization Law of the Central Research Institute" was promulgated, stating that "the Central Research Institute is directly subordinate to the National Government of the Republic of China and is the highest academic research institution of the Republic of China", establishing fourteen institutes: physics, chemistry, engineering, geology, astronomy, meteorology, historical language, national literature, archaeology, psychology, education, social sciences, animals and plants.

Judges are national judges who are elected and appointed by the people. The President of the Supreme People's Court is elected and removed by the National People's Congress. Local courts are elected and dismissed by the local people's congress. The other judges were appointed by delegation. Currently, the People's Republic of China is divided into 12 levels, the President of the Supreme People's Court is the Chief Justice, the others are the Chief Justice, the Senior Judge and the Judges. According to the Law of the People's Republic of China on Judges and the Measures for the Implementation of the State Judicial Examination, a person who has not passed the judicial qualification examination and obtained the judicial qualification shall not be appointed as a judge. Under the People's Republic of China's Law on People's Jurors, the system of People's Jurors is implemented in some trials, with the participation of people's jurors and judges. The current Constitution of the People's Republic of China and the Organization Law of the People's Procuratorate of the People's Republic of China stipulate that the People's Procuratorate is the legal supervisory organ of the state. It shall have the exclusive right to exercise public prosecution, at the same time exercise the right to approve arrests, arrests and appeals, and shall have the right to investigate on its own specific crimes involving corruption, neglect of duty and violation of the elections of the people. The Procuratorate shall be under the dual leadership of the People's Congress at the same level and the Procuratorate at the higher level. Although the Constitution does not explicitly state whether the Prosecutor's Office is a judicial organ, China has always regarded the Prosecutor's Office as a judicial organ that is independent of the government and inseparable from the courts. The People's Procuratorate shall be established in accordance with the level of comparison of the people's courts, and all levels shall be referred to as the People's Procuratorate, except for the branch of the People's Procuratorate of the Municipality directly under the Central Government, which shall be referred to as the People's Procuratorate of the Municipality directly under the Central Government, which shall be referred to as the People's Procuratorate of the Intermediate People's Court. It also established specialized prosecutor's offices, such as the Military Prosecutor's Office and the Railway Transport Prosecutor's Office. In Xinjiang, the Production and Construction Corps also set up procuratorates by regiments, divisions and regiments.

The stars in other clusters are also composed of a single constellation, but not a traditional model. Like seasonal clusters, some other clusters are composed of stars in more than one constellation. In addition to large-scale clusters, there are also small, well-adapted clusters of stars. The southern constellation is a special case. Early in his career, he was one of the largest constellations created by Ptolemy, and in his Coelum Australe Stelliferum (1763), when Lacaille reconstructed the southern constellation, he divided it into several parts of a ship: the bottom, the stern, and the sails. In 1930, the International Astronomical Union (IAU) also considered the constellation to be too large, so these old clusters were formally recognized as three constellations: Constellation Taurus, Constellation Canis Major, and Constellation Taurus Minor, while the original constellation was regarded as a single cluster. The Cross of the South is not a star cluster, but rather a real constellation: the constellation of the Southern Cross, although it is still a star cluster in the rear leg of Centaurus in Byrd's Uranometria (1603), it was not separated from Centaurus until 1930. Prior to this, the equinox had been reduced once, and Lupus was originally only part of this group, being considered a strange beast in the hands of the equinox, separated by the Iberian valley around 200 BC, and had existed independently on the list of Ptolemy. In the original design, the tail of Leo had some faint stars forming like waves after a flattened body, vividly depicting the tail. Probably before Ptolemy, Alexander the Great called the constellation "the hair of Berenice" in 243 BC in memory of his queen, and it was later accepted by Diocletian as a constellation, and Bayreuth recorded this result and re-drawn the lion's figure; the International Astronomical Union also recognized it as a constellation.

In 2008, the State Council of the People's Republic of China approved the construction of Hainan as an international tourist island, and in 2018 it approved the construction of Hainan as a free trade port. In the Western Han period, the Hanwu Emperor Yuanfeng Dynasty (110 BC) established Pearl Cliff County (now Hainan Qianshan) and Danlu County in Hainan Island. In the 5th year of Emperor Hanzong's reign (82 BC), Danlu County was annexed to Pearl Cliff County. At the end of the Western Han Dynasty, Zhuhai County was abolished. In 43 AD, Emperor Han Guangwu of the Eastern Han Dynasty dispatched the generals of Fubo (伏波將軍馬援平定交, 撫定珠崖, 設珠崖縣). During the Three Kingdoms period, between 238 and 251, Shezhu Cliff County (now Xu Wen, Guangdong). In the year 280, the western Jin Dynasty Emperor Taikang (西晋武帝太康元年), the provincial cliff county, and joined the Hyupo county. During the Southern Dynasty, Song Dynasty Yuanjia eight years (431 years) re-established Zhuhai County, Ji Xu Wen, soon abolished. During the reign of Emperor Liangwu (r. 535–546), the island of Hainan was ruled directly by the central government for the first time after the abolition of the Zhuhai County in 580. In the first year of Emperor Sui's reign, the Sui dynasty officially included Hainan in the map. It was founded in 631 by Emperor Tang Taizong in the province of Qiangcheng, hence the abbreviation "Qing" in Hainan. Five generations, ten countries, Hainan belongs to the Southern Han. In the Song Dynasty, Hainan Island, along with most of today's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, belonged to Guangxi Southwest Road. In the Yuan Dynasty, the former Guangxi Road was assigned to the province of Huanglong, and Hainan Island was also assigned to the province of Huanglong. In the Ming Dynasty, Qiangzhou was part of Guangdong Province, and Ji was located in Qiangshan County (now Jiangshan City and Town), which governed the entire island. The West and South Sands Islands are officially under the jurisdiction of the Joongju Governorate. The Qing Dynasty basically followed the Ming system, and by the end of the Qing Dynasty, Hainan had one province, two states and 11 counties.

2019 Coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated COVID-19. Common symptoms include fever, cough, fatigue, shortness of breath, and loss of sense of smell. The virus is transmitted mainly through oral and nasal secretions, including cough. Several diagnostic methods have been developed to diagnose the disease. The standard diagnostic methods are reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR), transcription-mediated amplification (RMA), or reverse transcription loop-mediated isothermal amplification (RT-LAMP) to detect viral nucleic acid. Chest CT scans can also help diagnose individuals who are highly suspected of infection based on symptoms and risk factors. Precautions include frequent hand washing, keeping social distance, quarantine, indoor ventilation, covering your nose and mouth when coughing, and avoiding touching your face with unwashed hands. Antiviral drugs are being developed for 2019 coronary artery disease, and some vaccines have been approved and are being distributed in countries that have subsequently launched large-scale vaccination campaigns. The main treatment is symptomatic therapy. On January 30, 2020, the World Health Organization declared the 2019 coronary heart disease outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC). In early January 2020, due to the unknown cause of pneumonia cases, and the preliminary investigation of the pathogen identification and traceability of the cause, the Wuhan City Health and Health Commission called it "unknown cause of pneumonia".

The inner soul is the whole body (i.e., the material part); the outer soul is the part that can leave the body. The outer soul leaves the body, and it stays on the totem pole. The subterranean world of Sumer is a cave of dark terror, where the inhabitants continue their lives on earth in the form of shadows. This dark region is called Kur. Kurt's soul only eats dust: 58. The Sumerians believed that the entrance to Kur was in the eastern part of the Zagros Mountains, and that every soul needed to pass through the seven gates of Kur. Ancient Egyptian religions believed that man was composed of various elements, some of which were physical, some of which were spiritual. There are similar ideas in the religions of Ancient Assyria and Babylon. The Kottamuwa Stele, a burial stone of 8th-century BC royal officials of the Sam'al dynasty, describes how the Kottamuwa asked his burial attendants to hold a banquet to commemorate his life and afterlife, "for the sake of my soul on this stone," so that the stone could serve as one of the earliest references to the idea that the soul could be separated from the body. It's made of basalt, three feet high, two feet wide. It was discovered during the third excavation of the Neubauer Expedition at the University of Chicago Oriental Institute. The Bahá'í Faith holds that the soul is the symbol of God, the jewel of heaven, and that the most learned cannot grasp its trueness, and that no matter how acute its mystery may be, no one can hope to unravel it.

In 1942, after graduating from the University of Inada, he sought to become a Marxist and was recommended by his university classmates. At the end of 1951, the assassination of Chiang failed due to the discovery of a gun by the Kuomintang government. On May 19, 1952, Smith's "Tenzanrin" arrived in Kobe. Despite successfully escaping from Taiwan, Shimei was arrested by patrolling Japanese police shortly after landing in Kobe, and detained by the Japanese government for several months on charges of "illegal entry". In 1952, to make a living while overseas in Japan, Shimei met a Japanese resident in Mainland China, Kyoko Pingga, who was selling noodles and dumplings at a stall in front of the Ikebukuro Station in Ikebukuro, Tokyo. At that time, he visited the National Diet Library of Japan, the Hibiya Library of Literature and Culture, and collected materials related to the history of Taiwan, and recorded and used them. In 1955, in Tokyo, Shimei established contacts with former comrades of Chiang Kai-shek's plan to assassinate Chiang on the island of Taiwan, and began building "underground operational pipelines" against the Kuomintang. In April 1967, under the leadership of representatives led by Shimei and Ho Wenshan, the Taiwan Independence Union was established in Tokyo, attempting to associate and unite the various Taiwanese independence movement factions in Japan. On June 30 of the same year, Shi continued to form the Taiwan Independence Party in Tokyo, Japan, with about 70 members; he defined the overseas organization as "a socialist party," while proposing "the main battlefield on the island," "Taiwan nationalism," and "Taiwan socialism."

Shoko Shō Kō (尚, Shoko Shō Kō; 14 July 1787 – 5 July 1834) was the 17th King of the Second Shogunate of the Ryukyu Kingdom, reigning from 1804 to 1834. His name was Satsuma Shang, and he was nicknamed Satsuma Ryokin. As the king had only one son, and only one of the sons of the king's father, Shang Mu, was still alive, the princes conspired to appoint Shang as king. He was only allowed to return to the royal family, and was still considered the son of King Shangmu. He sent messengers to demand a seal of the Qing Dynasty. In 1808, Emperor Qing Jiaqing dispatched Shusen Ziyang, and gave him the title of "Senior Viceroy" (正副冊封使) and the title of "King" (冊封尚). During his reign, Ryukyu suffered frequent disasters. Due to long-term overdevelopment, desertification and deforestation in all parts of Ryukyu gradually atrophied. The sudden onset of an unusual climate, the corruption of officials, and the exploitation of the Satsuma clan further exacerbated the difficulties of people's lives, with famine and pestilence repeatedly occurring in Ryukyu. In order to stabilize the situation, the Shang dynasty dispatched governors, prosecutors, and other officials to various areas of poverty, instructing and encouraging the cultivation of the people; and on many occasions awarded people's official positions or objects as prizes. In 1810 and 1814, he sent additional doctors to Miyako and the Yaeyama area to teach the locals how to treat diseases. In addition, Dutch and British warships also came to the Ryukyu Islands, demanding trade, but being rejected by the Ryukyu Islands. Although he hoped to restore the situation of poverty in Ryukyu, the situation did not improve.

In preparation for the opening of the mine, Tang also proposed to build a railway from Kaiping mining area to Beitang estuary, so that coal could be transported to Beitang estuary by sea to Shanghai, Tianjin, etc. At the same time as the construction of the railway, the Kaiping Mining Bureau also established the Xikouzhuang Repair Works in Fengrun County (now Fengnan County), the first railway factory in China. When the factory was first built, it belonged to the Kaiping Mining Bureau, and was very small, with only a few dozen workers and a rudimentary workshop, with a total of about a dozen small machines, most of which were hand-rolling machines, a few of which were steam-powered. In 1883, the Hu Xiaozhuang Automobile Works, imitating the European model, built a first-class passenger car for the officials of the Kaiping Mining Bureau, beginning the history of the factory's production of railway passenger cars. With the expansion of coal mining in Kailuan, the Tangxi railway continued to develop. In August 1885, Lieutenant Governor Li Hongzhang accepted the proposal of the Kaiping Bureau of Mines to "divide mining and railway" and sent a letter to the Qing government for approval, and in 1886 organized the Kaiping Railway Company, also known as the Kaiping Railway Bureau, with Wu Tingfang as the general manager, overseeing the Tangxi Railway and the Huxing-Kozhuang Railway Factory, becoming the beginning of independent railway operations in China. In February 1887, the Qing government placed railway affairs under the jurisdiction of the Prime Minister's Office of Naval Affairs, and the railway became one of the national priorities. In August 1888, the Tangxi Railway was extended to Tianjin, renamed the Tangjin Railway, and passenger trains began to run. Due to the increasing volume of transportation, the Xiqiao Zhuang workshop was no longer able to meet the needs, while, due to the establishment of the Kaiping Mining Bureau in Tangshan, many of the coal wagons needed to be repaired were in the Tangshan mining area, and the factory's coal had to be transported from Tangshan, so as to facilitate the operation of the factory, the Xiqiao Zhuang workshop was moved to No. 23 Shanxi Road in 1888, separated from the Kaiping Mining Bureau, renamed the Tangshan workshop, and the scale was expanded.

It spans 106°39′45′′E — 108°32′11′′N, 30°19′40′′N — 32°20′15′′E, has a length of 177.5 km from east to west and 223.8 km from north to south. The population aged 0-14 was 1,113,344, or 20.36%; the population aged 15-64 was 375,824, or 68.73%; and the population aged 65 and over was 596,506, or 10.91%. Between 1946 and 1948, Britain introduced a system of bread rations that it had never implemented before during the war. The Soviet Union suffered heavy losses in the war against Germany. The Soviet Union's population declined by about 27 million during the war. Of these, 8.7 million died in combat. Nineteen million non-combatants died of various causes, including starvation during the Siege of Leningrad, imprisonment in German prisons and concentration camps, mass shootings of civilians, forced labour in German industry, famine and disease, the harsh conditions in Soviet camps, and service in German or German-controlled military units fighting the Soviet Union. Soviet prisoners of war and civilians deported from abroad were suspected of collaborating with the Nazis, of whom 226,127 were sent to concentration camps under Soviet censorship. Many former prisoners of war and young civilians were also drafted into the Red Army. Others worked in labor camps to rebuild infrastructure that had been destroyed during the war.

It belongs to Han, Wei, Chu. 230 BC), Qin Yingchuan County, Jiyang Zhai (音狄, present-day Uzhou City). The county is divided into twelve counties: Xu County (present-day Xuchang County), Yang Zhai County (present-day Uzhou City), Changsha County (present-day Changge City), Xiangling County, and Xiangcheng County. It was founded in 201 B.C., and is located in Xihan Gaozu (西汉高祖六年, before 201 B.C.), Diaxu County, and Qiyingyin County (治今魏都区). The counties of Xu County, Yingyin County, Yang Zhai County, Changsha County (治今长葛市老城), Xingling County (治今陵县彭店乡古城村) and Xiangcheng County all belong to Yingchuan County. On October 7, 1906, Emperor Han relocated the capital to Xiu, and Xiu became the nominal capital of the country until 220. During the Three Kingdoms period, Wei called Yingchuan County, which belonged to Yuzhou, Xuchang County, Yingyin County, Xuling County, Changsha County, etc. all belonged to Yingchuan County. Xuchang is one of the five capitals of Wei. In 221, Emperor Wen of China changed Xu County to Xuchang County (Chinese: 许昌县; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; RR: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; RR: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎ It is located in the southern part of the county, in the county seat of Changsha, Changge and Xiangcheng counties. The palace is open to the public. In 1368, it was abolished as Changsha County, and was incorporated into Xuzhou, the four counties, Changge, and Xiangcheng. Xuzhou and Junzhou were all subordinate to Kaifeng. In 1575, Junzhou was renamed Uzhou. At the end of the month, Li Zhengcheng's insurgents changed Yuzhou to Hwangpyeongfu. In the early Qing Dynasty, Xuzhou and Uzhou belonged to Henan Province. In 1724, Xuzhou was elevated to the status of a direct vassal state, and it belonged to Chang Gu. The palace is open to the public. In 1735, Xuzhou was elevated to Xuzhou Prefecture, Linying, Xiangcheng, Xiangcheng, Changge, Mi County (now New Mi City), New Zheng Province, and in 1741, Xuzhou was restored to Zhili Province, and all of the counties belonged to it.

The United Nations General Assembly has 65 observers. It consists of two observer states, five observer entities, and 58 observer organizations. In addition to its member states, the United Nations also has an observer system, inviting international organizations, non-governmental organizations and entities to participate in United Nations affairs. Observers have the right to speak at the United Nations General Assembly, but are not allowed to vote in the Assembly. The United Nations also has a permanent observer system, which allows non-members to qualify as members of any United Nations specialized agency. The following is a list in alphabetical order. The United Nations General Assembly may invite non-member entities that are not formally members to participate in the United Nations, and this has happened many times. Such participants are described as observers, some of whom are more clearly interpreted as observers of unofficial member states. The majority of former non-member observer states accept observer status because they have applied for membership but have not been granted, either because of actual or threatened rejection by one or more permanent members of the Council. The right of observers is granted only by the United Nations General Assembly and is not vetoed by the Security Council. An observer state is a sovereign political entity that can apply for membership in the United Nations on a voluntary basis at any time; for example, Switzerland was a permanent observer from 1948 to 2002, before becoming a full member on 10 September 2002. It should be noted that the United Nations considers the Knights of Malta to be a sovereign entity, not a sovereign state. Sixteen former non-members were also granted observer status. Most former non-member observer States accepted such status when applying for membership, but were unable to obtain membership because of the veto power of one or more permanent members of the United Nations Security Council.

The Forest Brothers (Estonian: metsavennad, Latvian: mežabrāļi, Lithuanian: miško broliai) referred to the guerrilla warfare of the three Baltic States against the Soviet occupation of the Baltic States during and after World War II in Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania. Similarly to the Cold War, anti-Soviet organizations in Eastern Europe also fought against Soviet rule in Bulgaria, Poland, Romania, Croatia, and Western Ukraine. In 1940–41, the Soviet Red Army occupied the independent Baltic states, and after Germany occupied them in 1941–44, they occupied them again in 1944–45. As Stalinist oppression intensified, 50,000 people in these countries began to use rural forests as natural barriers and bases for armed resistance to Soviet rule. Resistance organizations ranged from individuals with basic self-defense capabilities to well-organized, large-scale units capable of fighting large numbers of Soviet armed forces. The name Forest Brothers first appeared in the Baltic Sea region during the Russian Revolution of 1905. The term forest brothers sometimes refers to farmers rebelling in the forest during this period. After the collapse of the Russian Empire, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania gained independence. For Estonia and Latvia, it was the first time since the 13th century that they had become independent, and so the idea of nationalism and national self-determination was gradually gaining ground. At the same time, Lithuania regained its sovereignty: it was the largest country in 14th-century Europe, but it was occupied by the Russian Empire in 1795.

The page can be divided into different chapters using the chapter title syntax. You can create chapters with titles, see the code below, see also Help: Editing Pages. Don't use a single equalizer (=Heading=), which will make the chapter title the same font size as the page name. Registered users can set parameters for automatic title numbering, so that each chapter title has its own unique tag. Chapter titles (including subtitles) should have only one in the same page, and using the same title name raises the following problem: one or more chapter content can come from a separate page (or template) that contains it, without altering the appearance of the page. Reference: Help: Template#Composite_pages. This method actually provides a chapter-independent editing history. You can also split up custody. The chapter of a template page, its chapter number depends on the position of the presentation page. For example, if the template is in the third section of the article, then the first section of the template becomes the fourth section of the article. Any text that appears in the first section of the template becomes the text of the section in which the template is located, and the text behind the article becomes the text of the last section of the template. This may be deliberate, but it is generally best to avoid it. In MediaWiki software, chapter titles written in wiki-style are defined as regular expressions, /(^={1,6}.*?={1,6}\s*?$)/m (m stands for multi-threaded mode). As long as each article has more than three chapter titles, it automatically generates a table of contents (TOC) based on those titles, except in the following cases: __FORCETOC__ or __TOC__ code can be used to force the display of a directory with fewer than four chapter titles.

Vanuatu recognizes the sovereignty of the Arab Democratic Republic of the Sahara and the sovereignty of Kosovo. Abkhazia had established diplomatic relations with Vanuatu in 2011, but in 2013, after Russia stopped providing economic assistance to Vanuatu, Vanuatu and Abkhazia broke off diplomatic relations, instead establishing relations with Georgia, and recognizing Abkhazia as part of Georgia. The majority of Vanuatu's people are engaged in primary production, mainly agriculture, whose crops provide about 65% of Vanuatu's needs; fishing and livestock farming are also one of Vanuatu's major economic activities. Tourism is also important in Vanuatu, and is a major source of revenue for the government. Due to high prices and production costs, Vanuatu's industry lacks export competitiveness, with major industrial products imported from abroad and sold domestically in Vanuatu. Vanuatu has small factories for coconut processing, food processing, timber processing, butchery, soap. Vanuatu's road system is undeveloped, with less than 100 miles of paved roads, mostly muddy and only suitable for four-wheel drive. Each island has a small harbour or wharf that allows small cargo ships and boats to dock regularly. In Vanuatu, cycling is a popular alternative. There are a number of taxis and small buses in Port Vila and Luhanville. According to the 1999 Census of Vanuatu, there were 95,682 males and 90,996 females. Official statistics show that infant mortality declined in the second half of the twentieth century, from 123 deaths per 1,000 population in 1967 to 25 deaths per 1,000 population in 1999. However, the CIA estimated in 2011 that 46.85 babies died per 1,000 live births.

Zhu De (Chinese: 朱德; pinyin: Zhu De; December 1, 1886 – July 6, 1976), also known as Zhu De (Chinese: 朱代珍; traditional Chinese: 朱代珍; pinyin: Zhu De; pinyin: Zhu De), was a citizen of Yilong County, Sichuan Province, China. He was one of the founders and leaders of the People's Liberation Army and the People's Republic of China, and one of the early leaders of the Communist Party of China. Zhu De is an important revolutionary and military figure in modern Chinese history, and the head of the Ten Commanders-in-Chief of the People's Republic of China. Zhu De graduated from Yunnan Military Academy, participated in the Xinhai Revolution, the War for the Protection of the State, the War for the Protection of the Law, and served as the head of the Yunnan Provincial Police Department. In 1922, while studying in Germany, he joined the Communist Party of China, and later studied at Zhongshan University in Moscow. On August 1, 1927, he participated in the Nanchang Uprising, after which he led the Mao Zedong faction to Jinggangshan, and successively served as the commander of the Fourth Red Army, the commander of the First Red Army Corps, the commander of the Red Army of the One Party, the commander of the Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army, and the chairman of the China Revolutionary Army Commission, participating in the Long March. During World War II, he served as Vice-Chairman of the Central Military Commission, Commander-in-Chief of the Eighteenth Army Group and Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the Second Military District. During the Second Sino-Japanese War, he served as the commander-in-chief of the Chinese People's Liberation Army, along with Mao Zedong. After the founding of the People's Republic of China, Zhu De successively served as vice-chairman of the Central People's Government, secretary of the CPC Disciplinary Inspection Committee, vice-chairman of the People's Republic of China, and vice-chairman of the CPC Central Committee. In 1959, he was elected chairman of the National People's Congress. During the Cultural Revolution, Jude was shocked. On July 6, 1976, Zhu died in Beijing. During his time in the North Sea government, Zhude was awarded the Order of the Fifth Order, the Order of the Silver Tiger, and the rank of Lieutenant General of the Army. He was awarded the title of General of the National Revolutionary Army by the National Government during the War of Resistance against Japan and the Medal of Victory in the War of Resistance after the war.

Sagittarius is a small southern constellation near the South Pole, one of the 14 constellations identified by the French astronomer Nicolas Louis Lacaille in the 18th century. The constellation's original name, Mensa, is Latin for "" table, "" originally meaning "" Mons Mensae, "" or "" Table Mountain. "" The constellation is one of 88 modern constellations designated by the International Astronomical Union (IAU), covering 153.5 square degrees of night sky. Apart from Antarctica, which is the southernmost constellation, Saturn is the southernmost constellation, and the northern hemisphere is only visible south of the 5th parallel. The constellation is at the base of 88 modern constellations, has no bright stars at all, and its brightest star, Alpha Centauri, is barely visible in the night sky of ideal weather in the suburbs. With so many clusters and quasars in the constellation Cassiopeia, at least three galaxies have discovered extrasolar planets. The French astronomer Nicolas Louis Lacaille spent two years at the Cape of Good Hope observing and cataloging 10,000 southern stars, 14 constellations in Europe's unobserved southern sky, and 13 other constellations named after scientific instruments from the Enlightenment, with the exception of the constellation Sagittarius, which represents Table Mountain. It faces Scorpio to the north, Hydra to the northwest and west, Antarctica to the south, Taurus to the east, and is adjacent to Pisces to the northeast, covering 153.5 square degrees of night sky, 0.372 percent of the total, 75th in 88 modern constellations. Lacaille allocated ten Greek letters (except κ) from α to λ for the constellation, using the Bayer nomenclature, and Benjamin Apsoop Gould later added κ, μ, ν, ξ and π. Usually these faint stars don't deserve to be named in the Greek alphabet, but Gould felt they needed to be named because they were so close to the South Pole.

On March 2, 1945, the Commander-in-Chief of the Chinese Army ordered the withdrawal of the Commander-in-Chief of the Expeditionary Force, the Commander-in-Chief of the Fourth War Area, the Commander-in-Chief of the Gui Guizhou-Guiangxiang Border Area, the Commander-in-Chief of the Yunnan-Vietnam Border Area, and the numbers of the 1st, 9th, 11th, 16th, 20th, 24th, and 35th Army Groups and the Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the 1st Army Group, appointed Wei Lihuang as the Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the Chinese Army, Lu Han, Zhang Fukui, Yun Bo, Wang Yaowu as the Commander-in-Chief of the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th Fronts, and Chiang Kai-shek ordered Cho Yuzi as the Commander-in-Chief of the 36th Army Group: 7673. In March, the Maoists opened the China-India highway, praising China and abroad. The stance of Wei Lihuang toward the problem of the Communist Party was more oriented to the problem of political negotiation, and the main war colors of Chiang Kai-shek and others were extremely unacceptable; funding allowed him to remain in the West. In November 1946, Wei Lihuang stepped down as commander of the Expeditionary Force, a four-man expedition from Shanghai to the United States via Japan. In the spring of 1947, Wei left for Europe. Upon arriving in Britain, Mrs. Han wrote to her French niece in Paris, Li Huiwen, and her nephew's son-in-law, Wang De Zhao, asking them to contact the Communist Party of China as soon as possible. Wang de Zhao contacted the Soviet embassy in France through his friend, the Communist Party of France, and reported the matter to the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union through the Northeast Bureau of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union secretly between July and August 1947. In October 1947, Chiang Kai-shek returned to China. In January 1948, Chiang Kai-shek appointed Wei Lihuang to replace Chen Cheng as the commander-in-chief of the Northeast Anti-Banditry Command: 555. In April 1948, Wang and his wife returned to their homeland after 15 years in exile, and Wang was appointed by Wei Lihuang as Deputy General Secretary and Chief of the General Staff.

In 1931, the Tibetan army again attacked the Qinghai Yushu area, was defeated by the Qinghai army of the Republic of China, the Republic of China Kawan Army also took the opportunity to launch a counterattack in Kang District, the Tibetan army had to retreat to the west of Jinsha River. In 1932, the two sides signed a ceasefire agreement, agreeing to use the Jinsha River as the boundary, pending a negotiated settlement between the Republic of China and the Tibetan authorities. On July 22, 1935, the Nanjing National Government established the West Kangding Provincial Committee in Ya'an, which was relocated to Kangding the following year. At the time, the committee nominally controlled 20 counties in the Kangding region, and 13 counties already controlled by the Tibetan Karkha. On March 14, 1938, the Nanjing National Government reorganized the Xikang Jian Provincial Committee, and on September 1, it divided the former provinces of Ning (now Xichang) and Ya (now Ya'an, except for Meishan County) into two administrative bureaus of 14 counties under the jurisdiction of the Xikang Jian Provincial Committee. With the abolition of the Sikang Provincial Committee, it was reorganized into the Sikang Provincial Government, established the Sikang Province, and implemented the Sichuan and Sikang Separation. On January 1, 1939, Xikang Provincial Government was officially established, and Liu Wenhui was appointed as the chairman of the province. The provincial government of Western Kangxi actually only manages Kang District east of Jinsha River. In 1941, the Banzen Kambu Conference Hall recognized the ninth Banzen Erdeni as a reincarnated child, but the Kakha never recognized his status, claiming that he was "a substitute child", and also recognized the tenth Banzen Erdeni as a legitimate Banzen Erdeni, allowing him to live in Lhasa, and declaring that he had been approved by the Tibetan independence state. It was not until 3 June 1949 that the Government of the Republic of China "specially authorized the succession to the tenth Panchen Dorjee Rinchen Dorjee Rinpoche," and on 10 August the ceremony was held.

In 1918, the Ottoman Empire was defeated in World War I, withdrew from the region, and Arab tribes clashed. In 1922, the League of Nations entrusted Britain with the administration. Influenced by the rise of Jewish nationalism and anti-Semitism, after World War II, large numbers of Jewish immigrants moved in. On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly adopted Resolution 181, in which it declared its support for the partition of Palestine, the establishment of an independent State of Palestine and the international administration of Jerusalem and its environs. On May 14, 1948, David Ben-Gurion, president of the World Organization for the Restoration of Judaism and the Jewish Association for Israel, declared that "a Jewish state shall be established in the homeland of Israel, called the State of Israel", and that it would begin to function at the end of the Mandate. Jordan occupied the area from the Green Line to the Jordan River, and in 1950 annexed it to the Kingdom of Jordan, recognizing all Arabs there as Jordanian nationals. Israel gradually gained control of the West Bank (1967–present), the Sinai Peninsula (1956–1957, 1967–1982), parts of Southern Lebanon (1982–2000), the Gaza Strip (1967–2005; still considered occupied after the withdrawal in 2005), and the Golan Heights. Israel extended its jurisdiction to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem. Under the Oslo Accords of 1993, Israel exercises partial or total jurisdiction over Areas B and C of the West Bank, while Area A is under full Arab autonomy.

On November 30, 1946, a demonstration of stall vendors in Shanghai ended with the release of the arrested stall vendors and an apology. In July 1946, the Shanghai Municipal Government ordered stalls to be allowed only at designated locations on the grounds that stalls obstructed public space and traffic; on August 2, it ordered stalls to be banned in Shanghai's 1st District in August, September and October; in August, the 1st District Police began arresting stall vendors and confiscating goods; as a result, 16 stall vendors headed by Wang Zhenhui, a member of the Communist Party of China, formed the 1st District stall vendors committee, wrote to the Shanghai Municipal Government, demanding that the ban on stalls be reinstated, and released the stall vendors in custody, returning the confiscated goods. The city government ignored it. On August 28, 15,000 stall vendors gathered on Hankou Road to petition the city government, stopped by the military police, turned to the city's public stadium, decided to send a separate petition representative, and then disbanded. On the 27th of November, the First District Police Department went out and arrested the vendors. On the 30th, more than 3,000 hawkers and their families gathered at the 1st District Police Station to demand the release of people and a physical confrontation. It wasn't until eight o'clock in the evening that they were all released, handcuffed, and then scattered. But the Shanghai government didn't keep its promise, and on December 1, the city went under martial law. More than 5,000 hawkers gathered again to besiege the first ward, and clashed fiercely with the army and police. On December 2, representatives of the stall vendors again petitioned the city government, the city government was forced to take back the life of the stall vendors, the police chief Xuan Tieguo publicly apologized to the injured, and promised to replace the post of the director of the first division, announced the release of the arrested stall vendors, and issued the goods that had not been collected.
