Emperor Yongle (永历帝朱由榔; November 1, 1623 – June 1, 1662), also known as Emperor Zhaozong, was the fourth and last Emperor of the Southern Ming dynasty (December 24, 1646 – June 1, 1662). In 1646, Emperor Longwu of the Southern Ming Dynasty was captured, and Emperor Gui of Guizhou named himself Qing. Shortly thereafter, Emperor Longwu's younger brother, Emperor Tang, succeeded to the throne in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province, and the following year, the year of Shaowu, was designated as "Shaowu Emperor". A few days later, Emperor Gui of Guangdong Zhaoqing also ascended the throne, the year of the eternal calendar, is called the "Eternal Calendar Emperor". In the end, the two armies were defeated, and the war was declared a war of attrition, resulting in the defeat of the Allies. The following year, the Qing army captured Guangzhou, Shaowu Emperor's troops were defeated and martyred, and Emperor Yongzheng became the sole ruler of the Southern Ming Dynasty. In 1659, after the Qing army captured Kunming, Emperor Yongzheng was exiled to Burma by the Dong Xu dynasty. In 1661, on the third day of the first month of the sixth month of the sixth month of the sixth month of the sixth month of the seventh month of the seventh month of the eighth month of the ninth month of the ninth month of the tenth month of the eleventh month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the tenth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the twelfth month of the twelfth month of the On June 1, 1662, the Emperor's father and son were hanged in Kunming. After his death, the Zheng dynasty in Taiwan continued to use the epoch-making date until 1683, when the Qing dynasty occupied Taiwan and Zheng Keqiang surrendered. Zhu Yuhao was the grandson of the Myojin sect, a disciple of the Ming Xi sect, the Myoshu sect, and the Myoan sect, and was born on November 1, 1623. He was the seventh son of Emperor Ming of the Ming Dynasty, and the seventh son of Emperor Hengyang of Hunan, and he entered the domain on September 26, 1645, and died of illness in Wuzhou on November 4, 1645.

The Bering Strait (Croatian:Эʼрвытгыр, Russian:Бе́рингов проли́в) is a strait in the Pacific Ocean between Cape Tejenev (169°43' W) at the easternmost point of Asia and Cape Prince of Wales (168°05' W) at the westernmost point of the Americas. This strait connects the Chukotka Sea (part of the Arctic Ocean) and the Bering Sea (part of the Pacific Ocean), between Russia and Alaska. It's named after the Danish explorer Vitus Berring. Right in the middle of the Bering Strait are the Aomed Islands. The narrowest point of the Bering Strait is about 82 kilometers, and the water is between 30 and 50 meters deep. The strait connects the Chukotka Sea (part of the Arctic Ocean) with the Bering Sea. The International Date Change Line is located between the islands of Grand Omid and Lesser Omid, so although the two islands are only about three kilometers apart, the time zone is not the same, so you can see "Tomorrow" Russia on the side of Lesser Omid. The Bering Strait is sparsely populated. The towns of Nome (3,788 people) and Teller Village (228 people) on the eastern coast of U.S. Alaska. The western coast is occupied by the Chukotka Autonomous Oblast in the Far Eastern region of the Russian Federation, along with the strait towns of Lorino (1,267 inhabitants) and Lavrentya (1,459 inhabitants). During the Cold War, the Bering Strait was the boundary between the Soviet Union and the United States, with the Soviet Union's Grand Omid Island only 3.9 kilometres (3.1 mi) from the United States' Grand Omid Island.

Mongolia On December 4, 2022, large-scale protests and riots broke out in the Mongolian capital Ulaanbaatar. Thousands of people gathered in Sukhbato Square in front of the National Palace, home of Mongolia's central government, to protest government corruption and high inflation, and to demand the dissolution of the parliament, as well as the government's joint investigation into coal corruption involving about 44 trillion kroons ($12.8 billion). As a neighbour and largest trading partner, Mongolia exports 86% of its total exports to China, more than half of which are coal. In the nine months to 2022, Mongolia's coal exports jumped to $4.5 billion. Even during the winter, mass protests erupted in the Mongolian capital Ulaanbaatar. Protesters gathered outside Ulaanbaatar's government palace on December 4 to ask for the names of officials who allegedly stole 44 trillion Mongolian Tugrik coal export earnings over the past two years. Several protesters held up flags and slogans such as "Working together, punishing bandits," "Don't just eat, think about my future." Hundreds of protesters decided to continue protesting on December 5th, saying they would "" go all the way. "" In the third largest city of Mongolia, Darkhan, protesters also demanded the publication of the names of the coal thieves and the confiscation of their property. On Sunday, protesters marched through the city, arguing that citizens' constitutional rights and freedoms were being increasingly curtailed, and that their lives were deteriorating every day. On December 5, protesters attempted to break into the government palace in Ulaanbaatar. Christmas trees were burned in Sukhbatar Square, and protesters blockaded the capital's Avenue of Peace. The Mongolian authorities say they have set up a working group to talk to the protesters.

λ Cusa is an optical binary star composed of λ1 and λ2, which are very distant in real time, but seen from Earth's perspective are essentially overlapping. λ1 Rhododendron is an 186-light-year-old binary star with a magnitude of 6.22 and a spectral classification of F7IV-V. The seven bills represent the left leg of the big-billed bird. Theta Tucana is an A-type star about 423 light-years from Earth. Bird bill VI is a yellow-white main sequence star with a spectral magnitude of F9.5V, 4.2, about 28 light-years from Earth. There are five known planets in the constellation Cuckoo, four of which have been discovered by Chile's high-precision radial velocity planetary search engine. HD 4308 is about 72 light-years from Earth, about 83 times the mass of the Sun, has a planet called Super-Earth, and it orbits for about 15 days. Located to the west of the Milky Way, 47 Cancri is the second-brightest globular cluster in the night sky, behind ω Centauri, about 1.47 million light-years away, and an estimated 12 billion years old, 2.77 million light-years away. NGC 362's orbit passes about 3,000 light-years from the center of the Milky Way, very rarely close to a globular cluster. James Dunlop discovered NGC 362 in the 1920s. The Milky Way lies at the southernmost tip of the constellation cuckoo, and it's a dwarf galaxy about 210,000 light years from the Milky Way, closer than most other known galaxies. The Milky Way is probably a disk, but it's distorted by the massive tidal force of the Milky Way. The Magellanic Stream is a giant gas cloud that encloses the Milky Way and the Large Magellanic Cloud.

The Red Wall is a place name, famous for the Battle of Red Wall in 208 C.E., as well as the famous phrase "Red Wall" by the great writer Su Shi. In 1998, the name was changed to the former city of Akabe in Hubei Province. The Battle of the Red Wall occurred at the end of the Three Kingdoms period, is one of the three battles, at that time basically controlled the northern China Cao Cao led a large army in the Yangtze River along the Red Wall, the Uling Line and Liu Bei, Sun Quan's coalition of the battle, resulting in the weakened Sun Liu coalition of the army launched a fire attack, Cao's army was defeated, lost the opportunity to unite in the sea, also roughly determined the situation of the Three Kingdoms era three-legged and divided the world. The battle of the Red Wall not only had a profound impact on the history of the time, the main characters of both sides of the war such as Cao Cao, Zhou Yu, Zhuge Liang and so on are known and admired by future generations, and a large number of vivid stories, such as the Anglo-Saxon League, grass boat borrowing arrows, borrowing the east wind, ring counter, etc., "Fire burned the Red Wall" became one of the most famous battles in Chinese history. For hundreds of years, historians have debated the location of the "Red Wall" war, often referred to as the "New Red Wall War" by the media. General statistics show that there are at least seven kinds of "Akabeki-Say" (赤壁說): Bugan-Say, Huangzhou-Say, Zhongxiang-Say, Wuchang-Say, Hanyang-Say, Hanchuan-Say, Jiao-Say. From a contemporary point of view, the controversy centers on the distinction between the Putonghua and Jiao dialects, while historical publications and the evidence of found artifacts are more biased towards the Putonghua dialects. In the Ancient Commentary on Chinese Literature by Yin Falu, he wrote: "That red wall is in the northwest of Pohang County, in present-day Hubei Province, on the south bank of the Yangtze River. It is also said that "Akabe Mountain lies 120 miles west of Pohang County, on the northern bank of the Linjiang River, on the northern bank of which is Urin, which is the place where Zhou Yu burned his boat and fled.

Nantou County (Chinese: Nantou  Nantou; pinyin: Lâm-tâu-kuān; Buno: Nantu; Hakka: Nàm-thèu-yen) is a county in the Taiwan Province of the People's Republic of China. It is the largest, most densely populated, and most transportation-intensive city in Nantou County. The indigenous peoples of the county include the Taiya, Sadek, Buno, Zou, and the Zou of Sun Moon Lake. Taiwan's highest peak, Mount Tama, the largest natural lake, Sun Moon Lake, the source of the longest river, and Taiwan's geographical center are all located in the county. Specialties include blue plum, banana, sugarcane, frozen oolong tea, Shaoxing wine, bamboo handicrafts, Nantou pottery, flowers. The name Nantou is derived from the Arikun word for "Ramtau", which means "Nautou" in Taiwanese. It is located in the northern part of the city of Nantou, east of Nantou Mountain, south of Nantou River, north of Nantou River and north of Nantou River, hence the name Nantou. It is located in the northern part of the township of Northumberland (formerly Northumberland Township). It is located in the northern part of the city of Nantou (modern-day Nantou County) and is adjacent to the northern part of the city of Nantou (modern-day Nantou County). In 1683, it belonged to the Zoro County of Fujian Province. In 1723, it was added to Changhua County, which belonged to the county. In 1759, he was appointed governor of Nantou County, which marked the beginning of Nantou County's political and religious life. In 1887, Fujian and Taiwan were divided into two provinces, and Taiwan was reorganized into Taiwan Province, which at that time was part of Taiwan Prefecture's Taiwan Prefecture (present-day Taichung South District).

A dirty bomb is a radioactive weapon that combines radioactive materials (usually uranium) with conventional explosives. Dirty bombs are not like nuclear weapons. The radiation cloud may extend tens to hundreds of square miles (about 26 to 259 square kilometers), and the radiation scope of a dirty bomb may be confined to a few blocks or miles from the site of the explosion. One of the simplest dirty bombs even needs to leave the radioactive material there for its radiation to spread, without having to be explosive. Sources of radioactive waste include medical isotopes and waste, radioactive drugs (iodine-131, iodine-123, yttrium-99, yttrium-201, xenon-133), nuclear power plant fuel rods (uranium 235), universities, laboratories, X-ray inspection and measurement ( cobalt-60, caesium-137, yttrium-192, radium-226), and so on. Radioactive materials can be released in a variety of ways, including destruction of facilities or containers containing radioactive materials, detonation of cargo or remotely controlled devices, placing of radioactive materials in facilities such as water treatment plants, use of aircraft, missiles, and rockets, and contamination of livestock, fish, and food crops. Most dirty bullets do not release enough radiation to cause death, which leads directly to serious disease. Depending on the circumstances, however, dirty bomb explosions can cause public fear and panic, pollute property, and require extensive clean-up costs.

A battalion is a modern army formation of about 300 to 1,000 men, composed of several companies, usually of the same type, with another battalion regiment or other combat support units. The commander of a battalion is an officer, called a "battalion commander", and is usually a lieutenant colonel or major. In modern army formations, a battalion is a battle tactical unit that belongs to a regiment, group, or brigade and has more than one supply source, allowing it to sustain more than a few days of operations. In Japanese and Korean, this unit is called a "battalion", and in some countries a "cavalry squadron" is roughly equivalent to a battalion. In addition to battalions and air squadrons, an infantry battalion usually has one battalion regiment, three infantry regiments, one artillery regiment, a mechanized infantry battalion with one battalion regiment and three mechanized infantry regiments, a tank battalion with one battalion regiment and three tank regiments, and an artillery battalion with one battalion regiment and three artillery regiments. The battalion commander is a lieutenant colonel, and there is also a deputy battalion commander and a battalion counselor. In order to increase the combat capability of the Combined Armoured Brigade, the Republic of China Army began in 2019 to subordinate each armoured brigade and mechanized infantry brigade to the "Composite Battalion", where the armoured battalion is equipped with two tank regiments, one mechanized infantry regiment, one fire support regiment, one combat support regiment, infantry battalion is equipped with two mechanized infantry regiments, one tank regiment, one fire support regiment, one combat support regiment, in order to adapt to future ground defense operations. In the early years of the Civil War, the U.S. Army did not have a fixed battalion structure, as long as it consisted of several regiments.

The term "Four Policemen" was coined by President Franklin D. Roosevelt to refer to the four major Allied powers and founding members of the United Nations: the British Empire, the United States of America, the League of Soviet Socialist Republics, and the Republic of China. The phrase symbolizes Roosevelt Jr.'s conception of the post-World War II world order. After the end of World War II, these four countries would become the "police of the world", meaning that they would need to maintain world peace together, but after Roosevelt's death, this idea was not realized until the Declaration of the United Nations was signed and the United Nations was established. In the middle of World War II, it was generally understood that there were three superpowers in the world: Britain, the United States, and the Soviet Union. China was also considered a superpower at the time, but due to its low level of economic development and instability, it was generally not recognized as a superpower. Until the end of World War II, when the Allies achieved a decisive victory, President Roosevelt proposed the concept of a "trustee of world power" to describe the four countries, later known as the "Four Policemen". He believed that the four countries would become the superpowers of the world and form an alliance. However, the Chinese Civil War continued and the Communist Party of China gained leadership. Since then, China has not become a superpower. At the same time, the widespread independence movement led to the disintegration of the British Empire and the loss of Britain's superpower status shortly after the war. This left only two superpowers in the world: the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Then came the Cold War. After the end of the Cold War, the Soviet Union, as a superpower, withdrew from the Union for various reasons, thus dissolving the Soviet Union.

The Jutland Peninsula (German: Jütland; Danish: Jylland; Low German: Jötlann) is a peninsula in northern Europe, on the northern tip of the North European Plain, between the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, that forms the bulk of Denmark's territory. To the west and north are the North Sea and the Skagerrak, and to the east are the Kattegat and the Little Belt. It's about 2.35 million people. In ancient geography, it was known as the Siberian Peninsula. Broadly speaking, it includes Schleswig-Holstein in Germany. On 31 May and 1 June 1916, the only war between the British and German navies — the Battle of Jutland — took place in the Skagerrak Strait to the north of the peninsula. The peninsula and nearby islands were completely covered by glaciers in the 4th century, leaving behind ice shelves that formed low, rolling ice shelves and ice lakes. After the end of the ice age, sea levels rose, and with the partial subsidence of the land, the original land was divided into peninsula and island. In the eastern part of the peninsula, the polygonal bay, the curved coastline, is conducive to shipping and development of fisheries. Minerals were scarce, only a small amount of lignite and kaolin. The peninsula has historically been part of Danish territory along with the Scandinavian region and the Isle of Wight. Prior to this, according to Ptolemy, it was the home of the Jodonians, the Symbri, and the Charudes. The Danes built a wall in southern Jutland that extended from the North Sea to the Baltic Sea to resist the Christian Frankish invasion. Charlemagne drove out the pagan Saxons at the southern end of the peninsula (later the Halstein region), and moved the Christian Obots (a group of Slavs who spoke German) there.

Huili City (Chinese: 会理市; Northern Yi dialect:  or  nyi ddix shyp or hop li shyp) is a county-level city in Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, China. It has a total area of 4,527 square kilometers, 440,000 inhabitants in 2004. It was designated a National Historic and Cultural Landmark in November 2011. On September 26, 2021, the county council was officially dissolved and the county council city was established. In 111 BC, the Hanwu Emperor established a government here, called Kaiwu County, belonged to Yeoshu County (present-day Xichang), belonged to the northern part of present-day Kairi County and the eastern part, Ningnan, Meiyi, etc.; in 675, the name of Kaichuan County was changed to Kaichuan County, meaning "Kawahara and Kai, the place where the chiefs listen to each other"; from 1277 to 1277, it was called Kaichuan Road, Taiwuan, Yongchang, Laixi, Kairi, Malong, Tong'an, Jiangzhou, etc., seven provinces; in 1392, the Ming Dynasty ancestor Hongwu 25th year of the Heian Dynasty, the rebellion of Ruetsumil, was changed to the commander of the people of Kaichuan Guards; in 1729, the Qing Dynasty Emperor Yongzheng, the people of Kaichuan Guards, guarded Kaichuan State, transferred to the eastern part of the Kairi State in Weizhou (the seat of present-day In May 1935, the Red Army's Long March passed through Kairi, and because of the high walls, the county seat was not attacked for a long time, becoming one of the few county seats not to be attacked on the way to the Long March. On the 12th, a famous conference was held on the outskirts of the city. It is located in southern Sichuan, the southernmost tip of Liangshan province, 184 km north of the provincial capital Xichang, adjacent to Panzhihua in the west, and bordering Yunnan in the south. The city is about 1,800 meters above sea level, surrounded by mountains.

Beijing Imperial Palace is located outside the Forbidden City of Beijing in the Ming and Qing Dynasties, inside the inner city of Beijing. It is surrounded by walls and has a gate, known as the Royal Gate. Beijing's Imperial Palace is located in what is now Beijing's Eastern and Western Districts. It extends south to Dong Cheung An Street, West Cheung An Street and Chairman Mao Memorial Hall; north to Jianmen West Street, Jianmen East Street; west to Fu Uk Street, Ling Shan Hotong, West Yellowstone South Street, West Yellowstone North Street; east to Morning Street, East Yellowstone South Street, East Yellowstone North Street. It has an area of about 6,87 square kilometers. Its predecessor was the Sui Dynasty's Sui Goryeo Gyogu (高麗行宮臨朔宫宫城) and Beiyuan (北苑), the Liao Dynasty's Yongyu Gyogu (姚嶼行宮), the Jin Dynasty's Daning Gyogu (大寧宮), and the Jin Dynasty's Dadu Gyogu (金中都離宮大寧宮). In 1368, the Ming Dynasty troops captured the capital, the Yuan Shun Emperor fled north, the capital was renamed Beiping. Due to the lack of warfare, the capital and the Yuan dynasty palace were completely preserved, but were demolished by order of Zhu Yuanzhang in 1369. In 1370, Zhu Yuanzhang placed his fourth son, Zhu Di, in the northern domain, and ordered him to build a royal palace at Longfeng Palace inside the Yuan imperial palace. In 1379, Yan's palace was completed, and in 1380, Chu Di ascended the throne. In 1399, Emperor Zhu launched the Siege of Jingning, won the throne in 1402, and changed the northern plain to Beijing in 1403. In 1406, plans were made to relocate the capital to Beijing, and it was built on the site of Yan Wang's palace in the west. In 1416, the Beijing Palace was built in imitation of the Nanjing Palace. In 1416, the expansion work moved the southern wall of Beijing to the south about 0.8 kilometers, so the Beijing palace was moved southwards on the base of the Yuan Forbidden City, while the axis of the central axis of the Yuan Forbidden City was shifted to the east about 150 meters, so that the central axis of the Yuan Forbidden City was placed on the so-called "white tiger throne" or "killing throne" of the west.

American English (abbreviated AE, AmEng, UES, en-US) is a form of English used in the United States. It's the dominant language of the United States. According to the 1990 census, 97 percent of Americans could use English "good" or "good," while only 0.8 percent did not use English at all, compared to 3.6 percent in 1890. By 2005, more than two-thirds of native English speakers were using American English. During the British colonization of North America, English was introduced to North America. The first emigration of native English speakers to the United States occurred in the 17th century. At the same time, Dutch, French, Spanish and Swedish are spoken in North America. In contrast to English, many aspects of American English tend to be phonologically conservative. Some people think that some of the North American accents are the same as Elizabethan English, which is still under discussion. Standard American English in the Midwestern and Northern United States is more pronounced than 17th-century English in comparison to contemporary English indigenous tones. The main reason for the conservative pronunciation of American English is that it is a mixture of various dialects from the British Isles. Due to its close relationship with England, the East Coast of the United States remained predominantly British at the time, and the tone of the East Coast of the United States changed with the development of English-speaking America. With relatively little contact between the interior of the United States and the United Kingdom, the original tone was largely preserved. Most contemporary North American English has a curl (also known as a curl), and the letter r is pronounced before the consonant; although English today does not have a curl, this was the case throughout England in the 17th century.

Both sides of the river are gently sloping to the northeast in the middle, and the mountains in the south are descending towards the river. The Wuling Mountains branch off from Guizhou Yunmiang Mountain into this city, and three branches. The northern branch comes from Hubei to Fenglong Mountain and enters Xianshan, Guiyingshan and Qinglong Mountains in Sangyou County in this city; the central branch along Lisui River north of there are Tianxishan, Hongxishan, Chaotianshan, Qingyanshan and Maohuakai. The southern branch runs between Lishui and Yuansui, has seven stars, Chongshan, Tianmen Mountain, extends into Jili County, Dalongshan, Tianhe Mountain. All three branches flowed east to Lake Dongting and disappeared into the plateau. The highest point is 1890.4 meters above sea level and the lowest point is 75 meters above sea level. The city has an average elevation of 183 meters, and the area has an average elevation of 1,000 meters. The municipality is divided into two districts and two counties. At present, Yongding District, Wulingyuan District and Sangfeng County enjoy the policy treatment of ethnic autonomous areas, while Jili County enjoys the treatment of more than half of the province's ethnic minorities. Preliminary results of the 6th census of 2010 showed that Zhangjiajie had a resident population of 1,476,521, 2.25% of Hunan's population, ranked 14th, population density of 155 people/km2, and gender ratio of 104.38/100. In terms of educational attainment, higher education accounted for 6.47 percent of the total population, lower education for 55.37 percent of the total population, and illiteracy for 4.74 percent. The district has 438,419 households and 1,388,420 households, accounting for 94.03 percent of the total population; the average household size is 3.17 persons. In terms of age composition, 262,085 persons aged 14 and under accounted for 17.75% of the total population; 1,049,596 persons aged 15-64 accounted for 71.09%; and 164,840 persons aged 65 and over accounted for 11.16 percent of the total population.

Shortly after the Japanese took control of Taiwan, they launched an invasion of Fujian as a base. In the early days of Japanese rule in Taiwan, the Japanese did not need a passport to travel through Taiwan to Qing. However, as Japanese rogues appeared in Fujian and engaged in illegal activities, the Governor-General of Taiwan promulgated the Foreign Travel Pass Rules in January 1897. Initially targeted at Japanese travelers to the Qing Dynasty, it expanded to Taiwanese and Taiwanese living in Taiwan and traveling to China and other countries in May of the same year. Around 1896, the then-Japanese governor of Taiwan, Yugentaro Yu, sent the then-chief priest of Yilang Lanyang Temple in Taiwan, the late Gao Su Guang, to Xiamen for missionary work. Later, the monks of the Eastern Voodoo Monastery, such as Mizutani Kaiyo, built the "Xiamen Eastern Voodoo Monastery". On August 24, 1900, the cathedral was burned down. On the 25th, the Japanese governor of Taiwan sent an army overseas to seize Xiamen. The Western powers reacted strongly, and the British, Germans, Americans, and Russians launched their warships into Xiamen harbor, and the British landed on British soil, and the Japanese were forced to retreat. "The Xiamen Incident of 1900". In February 1934, Chen Yi was appointed as the President of Fujian Province. On August 15, 1945, Japan declared its surrender. On 29 August, Chiang Kai-shek appointed Chen Yi, then President of Fujian Province, as Taiwan's Chief Executive. On October 25, the Republic of China took over Taiwan and Penghu. In 1949, the Central Committee of the Republic of China government moved to Taipei after losing the Chinese Civil War. Fujian and Taiwan faced a long-term civil war. In 1979, at the beginning of the reform and opening-up, the Mainland issued the Letter to the Taiwan Compatriots. In November 1980, the first small-scale trade transactions were concluded between Fujian and Taiwan, and the first Taiwanese-owned enterprise was established in Fuzhou in 1981.

One of the officers said: "Li Bin always hid a book of demons, saying that his brother Li Keng should have a great throne, and wanted to secretly plot revenge for Shi Heng. He was sentenced to life imprisonment, and Li Bing was convicted of treason and conspiracy to commit treason. Zhu Qian twice ordered his retainers to go to court, but they were afraid of persecution and did not dare to take revenge on him. The Li Bin brothers were executed by hanging, with twenty-eight people taken to their deaths. It is revealed that he was killed by Cao Cao and his nephew Cao Qian, and that Cao Qian and Cao Qian were very angry with him. In July 1461, Cao Qin rebelled, attacked Xiang's family, killed him, and removed him from his position. And when the rebellion was ended, the governor was appointed overseer, and his son overseer of the affairs. At the time, he was still serving as a prisoner of war. The sixty-seven soldiers of the grandfather and grandson of Shaozong's mother-in-law all pretended to have fought against Cao Chin, and the disciples revealed this. Son Shaosong was reprimanded, and the others were imprisoned.

The Manchus, the white flag bearers, the Fuchus, were descended from a prince, Major General Chengdu. Three years later, in 1799, he was promoted to the rank of captain. He spent his whole life experiencing rich, ups and downs, ranging from the post of the empress to the post of the Minister of the Interior with a red flag of the Han army and the duties of the Daijo-ji Temple and the Kono-ji Temple. At the beginning of the reign of Jiaqing, he served as a chamberlain for the Han Lin Temple, promoted the establishment of the Kuomintang, edited the National History Museum, baptised the horses of the Jing Dynasty, and participated in the writing of the Qing Dynasty Jianlong Dynasty Jiao Jiao (清実録乾隆朝実録).

According to a study by Lee Jinying, a Taiwanese university student, in 1883, a German expedition to the Nansha Islands conducted a survey, and the Qing government lodged a diplomatic protest against Germany, claiming that the Nansha Islands belonged to China. In 1887, the Qing government and France signed the Treaty of Renegotiation of the Sino-French Boundary, establishing a seaward boundary line to determine the allocation of maritime islands, and the Seychelles to the east of the line was not part of Vietnam. In 1907, a Japanese merchant named Yoshiji Kasa took up phosphate mining on the island and named it Kasa Island, after which the Qing government protested to the Japanese consul in Guangdong, and the Japanese government recognized the Qing court's sovereignty over the islands, but the Qing court offered to buy Japanese investment facilities on the island. According to a December 2011 report in the People's Political Co-operation Report, the citation reads as follows: In 1909, Admiral Li Jun of the Guangdong Naval Division of the Qing Dynasty led more than 170 men aboard three warships to patrol the Western Sha Islands, naming, building houses and flying the Yellow Dragon Flag. In April 1935, France sent troops and ships carrying 30 Vietnamese settlers to South Sandwich Island, and occupied six of the islands, including West Sandwich and the two South Sandwich Islands, and then expanded to nine reefs, known as the "French Occupation of the Nine Small Islands". At the time, the National Government was not in a position to deal with the issue, but established a "Surface Mapping Census Committee" and protested, and in 1935 published the "Chart of the Islands of the South China Sea", which delineated the South China Sea's boundaries as far as 4 degrees north. Following the outbreak of the Second Sino-Japanese War, in March 1939, the Japanese occupied the French-occupied islands of the Western Sahara, and at the end of March they occupied the islands of the South Sandwich Islands.

At the beginning of 1946, of the 38 seats in the political consultations involving the People's Coalition, the Communist Party of China, the Chinese National Party and non-partisans, the People's Coalition occupied nine seats, more than any other party at the time; combined with its alliance with other parties, the People's Coalition became an important force in balancing the two parties. In November 1946, the KMT decided to convene a constitutional national assembly, but the Communist Party of China refused to participate. Within the People's Alliance, the Chinese Youth Party and the Chinese Democratic Social Party participated separately in the Nanjing Constituent National Congress, but were expelled by the People's Alliance, leading to a rapid deterioration of the People's Alliance's relations with the Kuomintang. In October 1947, the Kuomintang government of the Republic of China declared the League an "illegal group" and imposed sanctions. In November of the same year, the National Assembly of the People's Republic of China held elections for deputies, and both the Communist Party of China and the People's Alliance boycotted the elections. The Kuomintang's suppression of the League led directly to the League's open declaration of cooperation with the Communist Party of China at its January 1948 Third Plenary Session, and the League's alliance with the Communist Party of China since then. Following the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, the Communist Party of China became the ruling party, and Mao Zedong proposed that eight other democratic parties, including the People's Alliance, remain. The Communist Party of China (CPC) exercises political leadership over the League, but promises to guarantee the organization's independence and legal equality, without interfering with the independence and day-to-day affairs of the Democratic Party. At the first plenary session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), Zhang Lan was elected Vice-Chairman of the Central People's Government, Shen Jun-ju was elected Vice-Chairman of the National People's Political Consultative Conference (NPCPCC), Zhang Beijun was elected President of the Supreme People's Court, and Zhang Beijun, Shi Liang, and Hu Yuzhi were elected Ministers of the Administrative Council, respectively.

The origin and subsequent spread of the virus led to an increase in xenophobia, phobias, prejudice, discrimination, and violent behavior and expression. Nearly Chinese, far East Asian, even other Asians were affected to varying degrees. At the same time, there has been a lot of xenophobic discrimination against people living in the affected areas, such as rejection of people from Wuhan, Hubei and Northern Italy, New York City in North America, and the Chinese virus. With the spread of the epidemic and the formation of hotspots, such as those in Asia, Europe, and the Americas, people in these hotspots have been reported to be discriminated against. In addition to the spread of discrimination against Chinese, these incidents have increased the prevalence of Islamophobia, homophobia, transgenderphobia, and anti-Semitic acts and expressions. In the past, many diseases were geographically named, such as Middle East respiratory syndrome and Zika virus, but in 2015, the World Health Organization recommended that this practice be avoided in order to reduce stigma. According to this policy, in February 2020, the WHO recommended the use of the official name "COVID-19". Among the countries affected by the epidemic, the 2019 Crohn's disease outbreak again raised fears and concerns caused by SARS in 2003 and MERS in 2012–2013. There are numerous online videos accusing Chinese people of "poisoning," Chinese people being rejected on buses, Vietnamese people being discriminated against because they are Chinese, and passers-by saying, "Be careful, there are Chinese girls passing by." They were even beaten, beaten and so on.

The talks were held on 27 April 1993 and 14 October 1998, respectively, by Wang Zhenfu (Chairman of the Taiwan Strait Exchange Foundation) and Wang Daohan (Member of the Central Working Group on Taiwan and President of the Taiwan Strait Relations Association). The first was in Singapore, the second was in Shanghai, mainland China. The First Wang Keng Meeting or First Wang Keng Meeting was a meeting between the Chairman of the Taiwan Strait Exchange Foundation (the "Sea Foundation") and the Chairman of the China-Singapore Strait Relations Association (the "Sea Association"), Wang Daohan, held in the Republic of Singapore from 27 April to 29 April 1993. The meeting was the first official contact between civilian representatives on both sides of the Strait since the 1949 partition, under official authorization. In April 1990, Zhang Shangde, a disciple of Taiwanese scholar Nan Weijin, visited the philosophy department of the East China Normal University and sought an opportunity to meet with Shanghai's leading leaders. On April 26, 1990, Zhang had a one-and-a-half-hour meeting at the Overseas Chinese Hotel with Wang Daohan and Professor Feng Chi of the East China Normal University. After this meeting in Shanghai, the two sides accelerated the pace of civilian exchanges. On 21 November 1990, the Taiwanese side established the Strait Exchange Foundation (海基會), and on 9 March 1991, the foundation was officially launched. On December 16, 1991, Wang Daohan was elected as the first chairman of the China Association for the Relationship between the Straits of China and the People's Republic of China (China Association for the Relationship between the Straits of China and the People's Republic of China) in Beijing. Between October 26 and October 30, 1992, a second working consultation was held in Hong Kong between the Strait Exchange Foundation, a Taiwanese non-governmental organization representing the Mainland Committee of the Executive Council, and the Strait Bilateral Relations Association, a Chinese non-governmental organization representing the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council.

Nanchang City (Chinese: 南昌市; pinyin: Nánchāng shì; /lan35 tshɔŋ44 s11/) is a city in Jiangxi Province, China. Nanchang is located in the northern part of Jiangxi province, on the northern border of Jiujiang City, on the western border of Yichun City, on the southern border of Dafu City, and on the eastern border of Cheng Rao City. It lies on the slopes of Poyang Lake, flat in the southeast, hilly in the northwest. The Ganjiang River, the Fuhe River, runs through the middle of the city, flowing north into Poyang Lake. There are numerous lakes in the territory, including Qing Lan Lake, Junshan Lake, Jinxi Lake, Yao Lake, Nantang Lake and so on. It has a total area of 7,195 square kilometers, a population of 643.75 million, and the city's people's government is located in the Red Valley Beach District. Nanchang is a national historic and cultural city, famous for "changing great southern frontier, southern prosperity," the construction of the city history more than 2,200 years, there are famous monuments such as the Mausoleum of Sunset Marquis, Teng Wang Pavilion, the rope gold pagoda, the Eight Great Mountain Men Memorial Museum, as well as the core city of Poyang Lake ecological economic zone, the national integrated transportation hub, the aviation industry base and the photovoltaic industry base. Nanchang is a cultural ancient city with a long history. Ancient stone artifacts dating to 500,000 years ago have been excavated in Anzhi County administered by Nanchang City. More than 5,000 years ago, people were already producing here. Until 3,000 years ago, north to Lake Aixi, south to Qingyunsheng, this arc of land formed the aggregation of the ancient Nanchang inhabitants. In 202 BC, the Han general Xuanbao was stationed in the area, in Sheyuan Zhang County. The next year, they built a castle pond, and it's located about four kilometers southeast of the present-day Nanchang railway station, at the site of the Yellow City Temple, and it stretches for 10 miles and eighty-four paces, and it's called the "" Infant City. Yang Qiu Xing (Chinese: 楊秋興; born May 15, 1956) is a Taiwanese politician who served as a member of the Legislative Council of Kaohsiung Prefecture. He was promoted to the Democratic Progressive Party (DP) by Kaohsiung County Governor Chen Yueying, and returned to his hometown to represent the blacks of Kaohsiung County, participated in the National Assembly, and ran for mayor of Fengshan City, but was unfortunately defeated. He was re-elected to the Legislative Council of Taiwan in 2001 and succeeded in becoming the governor of Kaohsiung Prefecture, where he was highly regarded as a "small giant of the South". In the 2010 municipal election, he was defeated in the first round by the Democratic Party of Kaohsiung mayor Chen Qiu, and was defeated in the second round by the Democratic Party of Kaohsiung mayor Chen Qiu. In the 2012 presidential election, he was elected as a member of the Political Affairs Committee and Director of the Southern United Service Center of the Executive Yuan, and in 2013 he joined the Kuomintang again, winning the nomination for mayor again defeated. He resigned from the National Party in 2019. After leaving politics, he worked as a construction worker. Yang Qiu Xing was born in 1956, the birthplace of the rolling water tribe (now Kaohsiung Kaohsiung's Yanzhao District's Yanzhao Village). He graduated from the National Tainan First Senior High School in 1974, and joined the National Taiwan University in March 1975. In 1979, he graduated from the Faculty of Civil Engineering of the National Taiwan University, then entered the engineering department as an engineer. He graduated from the Institute of Civil Engineering, Taiwan University in 1985, and returned to Chungding Engineering Service, where he married his wife Lin Shufeng at the beginning of the year, and his eldest daughter was born in the same year. In 1986, while serving as the governor of Kaohsiung Prefecture, he joined the government of Kaohsiung Prefecture, joined the Communist Party of China, and became one of the first members of the Communist Party of China.

The Solar System contains the Sun and other bodies bound by its gravitational pull: eight planets, 165 known moons, five confirmed dwarf planets (including Pluto) and their moons, and billions of small bodies. Small objects in the Solar System include asteroids, Kuiper belt objects, comets, meteors, and interstellar dust. Broadly speaking, the region diagram of the Solar System includes the Sun, four terrestrial planets classified as inner planets, a belt of asteroids containing some small rocky objects, four gas giants classified as exoplanets, and a second band of ice-packed objects called the Kuiper Belt. Above the Kuiper belt are the Disc, the Solar System, and the hypothesized limiting Oort cloud. The planets are arranged in order of distance from the Sun: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Six of the eight planets have natural satellites, usually named after the Earth's moon, or the Moon, and each is surrounded by a planet made up of dust and other particles. All planets except Earth are named after gods or goddesses in Greek and Roman mythology. The five confirmed dwarf planets are Pluto, Ceres (the largest object in the asteroid belt), and the largest known objects in the Kuiper belt: Orion and Haumea, and Eris, the largest object in the Disc. The Earth is home to millions of creatures, including humans, and the Earth is the only known body of life in the universe today. The Earth was born 4.54 billion years ago, and life was born within a billion years. Since then, the Earth's biosphere has altered the atmosphere and other environments, giving rise to oxygen-demanding organisms and creating the ozone layer.

Taiwanese subjectivity, also known as Taiwanese subjective consciousness, is a political and cultural discourse in Taiwan. After the democratization of Taiwan in the 1990s, it became one of the mainstream ideologies. "Taiwan's subjectivity" is based on the idea of Taiwan as the center, through the power of multiculturalism and Taiwan nationalism, to break through Chinese centralism, Chinese nationalism or Great Han nationalism, to establish Taiwan as an "independent country" democratic system and cultural identity. Taiwanese subjective consciousness, along with the concepts of promoting Taiwanese independence, anti-authority, anti-colonialism, and anti-middle class often form a collection. However, because the ethnic history of the South Islands, European heritage, Chinese traditions, and Japanese Taiwan are all part of Taiwan's history, there is actually a difference. Supporters of Taiwan's subjectivity, such as law and politics scholar Peng Mingmin (Declaration of the Taiwan Self-Defense Movement), historian Cao Yonghe (The History of Taiwan Island), Lin Mazli (The Composition of Taiwanese Blood and the Origin of Taiwanese Ethnic Groups), former president Lee Teng-hui (Special Binationalism), former vice president Lu Xiu-ren (The consensus of '96'), Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan Solidarity Alliance, Time Force, even musician Xiao Tai-ren, singer Cai Zhen-nan, director Wei De-sheng, all supported or actually participated in the Taiwanization movement, forming a subjective consciousness centered on Taiwan, and developing Taiwan's own culture. Taiwan's subjectivity emphasizes multiculturalism and democratic thought. In the view of Taiwan's subjectivity, the influences of non-Chinese Taiwanese indigenous culture, European culture, Chinese culture (Chinese culture), Japanese culture, American culture, and globalization are all part of Taiwan's historical heritage and modern civilization, hence the criticism that Taiwan's subjectivity is a de-Chineseization. In a speech at an academic conference titled "New Thinking in the Study of History and Culture", the Minister of Education of the time of the Communist Party of China, Du Zhengchuan, proposed "turning 90°", "Taiwan's view map", emphasizing "Taiwan must find its own central point".

Huizhou was an area of terrestrial marshes 70 million years ago, suitable for dinosaurs to survive, and in recent years, four sets of 38 dinosaur eggs and some dinosaur footprints have been found all over Huizhou. About 10,000 to 4,000 years ago, in the late Neolithic Age, primitive humans began to thrive in Huizhou, engaged in fishing and primitive agriculture. Today, 28 ancient sites such as hills and caves have been found throughout Huizhou, including Borohu Ling, Su Yagang, Ho Yagang and other hillside sites, excavated a large number of stone tools and pottery pieces. During the Spring and Autumn Warring States period, there was an ancient kingdom called Banlu in the Boro County of Huizhou, and it is recorded in the Lu Spring and Autumn: "Banlu, Yaoyu, Shokoku no kuni, do no kimi." In 1993, during the construction of the Guanghui Expressway, more than 300 ancient tombs were discovered in Mt. Yooling in Boro County, mostly belonging to the Zhou Dynasty. In 214 BC (Qin Shi Huang thirty-three years ago), after the Qin Shi Huang Pingding Ling southern area of Baekcheng territory, in Huizhou established Boro County, which belonged to Nanhai County. At the end of the Qin Dynasty, Zhao Tuo founded the Republic of South Vietnam, and Huizhou belonged to the territory of the Republic of South Vietnam. In 111 BC, after the death of Emperor Hanwu of South Vietnam, the county was divided into nine counties, and Huizhou belonged to Boro County, Nanhai County. During the Three Kingdoms period, Huizhou belonged to the territory of Eastern Wu. In 326, Nankai County was divided into Dongguan County and Boro County was transferred to Dongguan County. Between 326 and 334, Ge Hong, a famous Taoist monk, retired to Mount Lo Wu in Huizhou to seek medicine, refine, and create four Taoist temples on the mountain, making Mount Lo Wu one of the most famous Taoist temples in China.

In 1597 or 1598, Peter the Great collaborated with Jodocus Claudius in Amsterdam to print the Twelve Constellations on a 35-centimeter telescope. In 1603, the German astrographer Johann Bayer published the Astronomical Survey, the first astronomical atlas of the constellation. Both Francis and Bayer painted the cuckoo as a big-billed bird. The cuckoo is irregularly shaped, with Hydra to the east, Crane and Phoenix to the north, Indian to the west, and Antarctica to the south. The constellation covers 295 square degrees of the night sky, ranked 48th out of 88 modern constellations. In 1922, the International Astronomical Union (IAU) determined that the three-letter abbreviation "Tuc" represented the constellation. In 1756, the French explorer and astronomer Nicolas Louis Lacaille allocated the Greek letters "α" to "ρ", omitting the letters "ο" and "ξ", and assigned the two nearest stars to "λ" and the three stars to "β". In 1879, the American astronomer Benjamin A. Good described Lacaille as a nebula in the constellation Xi Cuckoo, which is now known as the globular cluster 47 Cuckoo. According to Francis Bailey, Cuckoo was too faint to be assigned the Greek alphabet, so the original name was dropped, and two bodies, now called κ1 and κ2, formed Cuckoo Kappa. The cuckoo's brighter stars are arranged like kites. Beak 4, Beak 2, and Kappa Cuckoo are multiple star systems, containing six, two, and four stars, respectively. The beak is around the tail of the bird.

The Original Geometry (Ancient Greek: Σλιοχεῖα, Stoicheia) is a 13-volume work by the ancient Greek mathematician Euclid. This book is the foundation of modern mathematics and is estimated to be the second most widely published book in the West after the Bible. In all four books, he was assigned to the Department of Astronomical Algorithms. Euclid's Original Geometry consists of 13 volumes. Volumes 1 through 6 deal mainly with planar geometry. The seventh to ninth chapters of the book deal mainly with number theory. Volume 10 discusses unreasonable numbers. Volumes 11 through 13 deal mainly with stereogeometry. Geometry was originally considered by many scholars to be the work of Euclid, who gathered together the principles proved by many of his predecessors and some of his own original proofs, according to an ancient Greek historian Proculus. Euclid wrote the original geometry in 300 BC. It was translated into Arabic, then re-translated into Latin. The first printed book appeared in 1482. The Greek version still exists in various places, such as the Vatican Library or the Bodleian Library at Oxford University. It is regrettable that these existing manuscripts vary in quality and are incomplete. The earliest Chinese translation was the Latin text of Origen (15 volumes), compiled in 1607 by the Italian missionary Limazzo and the Chinese scholar Xu Guangqi, and revised and supplemented by the German priest Christopher Kravius, and named Origen Geometry, from which the Chinese name of geometry is derived. They translated only the first six volumes, and the last nine volumes were translated by the Englishman Weir Yale and the Chinese scientist Li Zhenlan in 1857.

The Military Police Training Center (MPTC), formerly known as the Military Police School (MPS), is a military professional training center located in New Taipei City, Taiwan. On October 31, 1948, the 1st Regiment was transferred to the Huangpu River Shipyard in Shanghai and conducted 12 drills in Jian, Hualien County. In September 1956, the new South Battalion was formed in Taipei City as the "Constabulary Training Battalion". In 1958, the regiment was reorganized as the "New Military Training Battalion" (憲兵新兵訓練大隊). On May 16, 1961, the unit was expanded to six battalions and renamed the Military Police Training Center. In 1965, he was transferred to Taishan District, Tai'an District, Taipei Prefecture. In July 1983, he was transferred to the Linkou-Huimin camp. On November 2, 2004, it was merged into the Military Police School (憲兵学校) as the "林口校區" (林口校區). On 27 November 1924, the second phase of the Huangpu Military School was expanded to include a gendarmerie section, "Department of Administration Director Gu Zhutong organized the gendarmerie", located at the old site of the army lecture hall in the northern campus of the provincial city of Huangpu Military School "provincial branch school". The gendarmerie department opened in April 1925, ten months of training, graduating in February 1926. In February 1925, the National Government established the Military Police Training School in Huangpu, Guangzhou.

Pingjin District (Chinese: 平鎮區; pin: ziin: kiʹ; pin: zhin: kiʹ; Taiwanese: Pîng-tìn-khu) is a district of Taoyuan City in Taiwan, located in the northern Linjiang District, the western Yangmei District, the eastern Daxi District, the northeastern Linjiang District, and the southern Yuelongtan District. The core of Pingcheng District's original development was in the Anping Township, Nansei, and Shanzitop areas, and later, due to the influence of the Nine Districts of the nearby city, its development was more restricted and it was more likely to become the peripheral zone of the city. It is known for the development of a highly tight-knit Middle-Level, as well as the nationally known High School Baseball Strength Plains High School Baseball Team. Archaeologically, the early Plains Town belonged to a 3,500-year-old plough head system culture group, and three sites have been found, including the Songya site, the Futang Palace site, and the Zhuang Cuo site, but there is no clear record of it, possibly because the inhabitants moved elsewhere at the time, and the area has not been culturally preserved. During the Qing Dynasty, Pingcheng was part of the Mokan Fort, and at that time the administrative division could be divided into Yabo-zhuang, Anping-zhuang, Doulian-po-zhuang, Song-ya-zhuang, Northern-zhuang, Southern-zhuang, Shanchai-cho-zhuang, Eastern-zhuang, and Shachai-zhuang. The name of the town was originally derived from the fact that in order to protect the safety of traveling troops from the mouth of the Great Lake to Zhongli, Taoyuan, it was established Zhang Luliang (present-day Puxin District, Yangmei District), Wang Luliang (present-day Nansei District), and the area between the two places was called Xisei (present-day Pingcheng District, Pingcheng Li Area, present-day Taoyuan 72 Line, along the South Ping Road), and later the security improved, taking the meaning of protecting peace, it was renamed Anping Town.
