In 1639, the frontier defenses of Jilian were the strongest of all the fortresses of Guangxi, such as Matsuyama, Jinzhou, Ningyuan and others under the command of Grand Duke Taishou, second only to the forces stationed in the mountains. Before the Battle of Songjin, Si Liao's frontier army still had a certain amount of offensive and field capability, defeating Dorgon's soldiers in the field in 11 AD. In early December, the Qing dynasty accelerated its offensive against the Ming dynasty, and in January, the Qing army entered Shandong from the Gyeonggi region, and in February, after the Qing Prince Dorgon's army was overrun, it returned from the northeast of the mountains to Tianjin Wei and crossed the canal to the east. In early March, the Qing army left Qingshan Pass and retreated back to Liaodong. The Qing army entered Guangdong for half a year, penetrated 2,000 miles, captured one prefecture, three provinces, fifty-five counties, and two gates; killed two Ming governors, guarded more than 100 officers; captured the population of 460,000 Yuan, 42,000 Yuan of gold, and 970,000 Yuan of silver and the same characteristics as in the past, this was a large-scale purely plunder-type military attack, greatly destroyed the economic situation of the Ming Dynasty Kiev region and showed that Manchu soldiers were able to tear apart the northern defenses constructed by the Ming Dynasty government.

The red turtle (Caretta caretta), also known as the red turtle, the red sea turtle, the sun-headed turtle, the bay turtle, and the fire turtle, is the only species of turtle in the family Carettae, distributed worldwide. The average maximum length of growth for this species is 90 cm, but more than 280 cm have been found. The adult turtle weighs about 135 kg, the heaviest specimen ever found weighing more than 450 kg. The skin is yellow to brown, and the shell is usually reddish-brown. There is not much sex difference before adulthood, and the most notable sex differences among adult turtles are the coarser tail and shorter chest. Red turtles have been found in the Atlantic, Pacific, Indian Ocean and Mediterranean. Most of the turtles live in saltwater and estuarine habitats, and the mother turtles lay their eggs briefly offshore. Red turtles have a low reproductive rate, with females laying an average of four eggs, which they will not lay again for the next two to three years. Turtles are sexually mature between the ages of 17 and 33, with an average lifespan of 47 to 67 years. Red turtles are omnivorous, subsistence invertebrates. The large and powerful lower jaw of the turtle effectively supports its prey. The juvenile turtle has many natural enemies; its eggs are particularly threatened by terrestrial predators. Once adult, the large size of these turtles can cause inconvenience to large marine predators such as sharks. The red turtle is considered endangered and is protected by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). Many deaths of turtles are caused by fishing gear. The red turtle will die of suffocation after being trapped in a bottom fishing net. In order to provide turtle escape, turtle escape devices have been installed, with the hope of reducing mortality.

Hungarian, also known as Magyar (Hungarian:magyar), is a branch of the Uralic language family of the Finno-Ugric peoples. It is the official language of Hungary and one of the 24 official languages of the European Union. It is also spoken in Romania, Slovakia, Ukraine, Serbia, Croatia, Austria, and Slovenia. The Old Hungarian alphabet was once used, but was replaced by the Latin alphabet after Christianity was introduced into the Kingdom of Hungary, but the Old Hungarian alphabet was revived in the Kingdom of Hungary in the late 20th century, and used alongside the Latin alphabet. The Mazar alphabet consists of the Latin letters Q, W, X, and Y, which occur only in foreign words (W and Y, common in Hungarian names, are pronounced V and (J)I, respectively). Sometimes people use the Great Hungarian alphabet and the Small Hungarian alphabet to represent the alphabets with and without Q, W, X and Y, respectively. The language has 14 vowels. The vowels and the vowels can be combined into a number of long vowels. Most of their discrimination is only persistently long or short, but a/á and e/é differ in both opening size and length. When adding suffixes, Mazar follows the rules of vowel harmony. That is, add different suffixes according to the vowels of the word. There are 25 consonant phonemes in the Mazar language. Similar to vowels, Hungarian consonants can also be extended. For example, fireworks reading. Mazar is a sticky language, and has many similarities to Finnish, which belongs to the Finno-Ugric language family. There are many variations of the Mazar word, and there are as many as 20 variations of the Mazar word.

The Third Battle of Changsha (Japanese: 長沙会戦, Hepburn: 長沙会戦, lit. After the Battle of Wuhan in October 1938, the Japanese occupied most of the area east of the Beijing–Hanoi and Guangdong–Hanoi railroads, but failed to achieve the goal of forcing the Chongqing National Government and the Chinese military to give up their resistance. Furthermore, the heavy losses suffered by the Japanese army due to the successive attacks of the Chinese People's Revolutionary Army in the Battle of Songhua and other battles in the early stages of the offensive; the fact that the Japanese army itself had to allocate its forces to defend large areas after the occupation made its mobile forces weaker; the guerrilla warfare of the Chinese army in the Japanese-occupied areas also made it necessary for the Japanese army to increase its forces to defend the occupied areas; and Japan's economy was further weakened by the war. As a result, after the Battle of Wuhan, the Japanese army won the occupation of Yueyang and stopped the offensive, and the Chinese anti-Japanese war entered the "Strategic Compromise Phase", which Chiang Kai-shek and the Commander-in-Chief of the National Army called the beginning of the "Second Phase of the Anti-Japanese War". Since entering the co-existence phase, the area around the Two Lakes Plains has been one of the major battlefields of resistance, with the 5th and 9th Divisions being responsible for defence, respectively. However, in 1940, the Fifth War Area was rebuilt, and after the capture of Yichang and Xiangyang, its importance declined sharply; the Hunan area remained only the Ninth War Area still had defensive power, and the main force of the Chinese-Japanese Front was the 11th Army, which confronted the New Wall River at the Hunan battlefield, and fought many battles during the war. On September 14, 1939, at the outbreak of World War II in Europe, the Japanese launched the First Battle of Changsha. At the beginning of the battle, the 9th Division used the characteristics of the Hunan River and canals to defend itself, and adopted the tactics of "battling one after another to exhaust the Japanese forces; striving for the outer wing to attempt a subsequent siege; retreating afterwards to defend Changsha; while the enemy retreated to surround and annihilate" in order to kill and injure the Japanese forces in large numbers.

In 1999, regulations were issued: a 5 cm diameter stamp, a five-pointed star, issued by the State Council. The Financial Stability and Development Commission of the State Council, also known as the Financial Commission of the State Council, is a deliberative and coordinating body of the State Council established by the State Council of the People's Republic of China to promote financial stability and development. The 1997 Central Financial Working Conference established sectoral regulation of the financial sector. The Securities Regulatory Commission of China and the Insurance Regulatory Commission of China are responsible for the supervision of the securities and insurance industries respectively, and the People's Bank of China is responsible for the supervision of the banking and trust industries. In 2002, the Central Financial Working Council abolished the Central Financial Working Commission and established the Bank of China Supervisory Board. The one-size-fits-all regulatory model has become established. But the disadvantages of the fragmented regulatory model are also obvious, and it's institutionalized, and it's prone to regulatory shortcomings because of inadequate coordination. For this reason, on August 15, 2013, the State Council approved the establishment of a coordination mechanism — the "inter-ministerial joint meeting on financial supervision and coordination" system, the joint meeting is led by the People's Bank of China, the member units are the Banking Supervision Authority, the CSRC, the Insurance Supervision Authority, the Foreign Exchange Bureau, if necessary, can invite the Development and Reform Commission, the Ministry of Finance and other departments to participate, in principle, one meeting every quarter, in order to strengthen coordination of supervision and promote information communication. But the system was later viewed by the market as “flowing into form,” because without empowering the lead departments, the joint meetings effectively served only to communicate information between regulators, and were not administratively binding. From July 14 to 15, 2017, the National Financial Working Conference was held in Beijing. The General Secretary of the Communist Party of China Xi Jinping emphasized at the meeting, "Finance is an important core competitiveness of the state, financial security is an important component of national security, and the financial system is an important basic system in economic and social development.

In recent years, however, many taxonomists have argued that biological classifications should be monophyletic, that they should include all descendants of a particular species. The reptiles defined above are considered related because they do not include mammals and birds, and are all descendants of primitive reptiles. Mammals are a monophyletic group, so the parental taxonomy recognizes the traditional taxonomy of mammals; while birds are a monophyletic group, formally called birds. In fact, mammals and birds are subgenera of amphibians. However, reptiles are not an evolutionary branch of the classical taxonomy; they are part of the amphibian family, excluding mammals and birds. There is no identifiable common dimorphism in reptiles. The definition of reptiles includes amphibians with and without features: a lack of feathers and hair. In 1916, Edwin Stephen Goodrich established the lizards and theropods to distinguish between lizards, birds and their relatives, and mammals and their extinct relatives. The differences in the heart and blood vessels of the two evolutionary branches, as well as features of the prefrontal cortex, support this classification. According to Goodrich, the lizards and theropods co-evolved from an earlier protozoan evolution called "Protosauria", which also includes some ancient amphibians and early reptiles. In 1956, David Meredith Seares Watson discovered that the two groups began to separate very early in the history of reptiles, so he divided "Protosauria" into sauropods and theropods.

Zhang Chang (Chinese: 張燦; born March 1, 1936) is a Taiwanese politician and the first mayor of Tainan. Zhang's parents were often involved in inter-country public activities, including election campaigns, and gave Zhang great political inspiration. When he was in the fifth grade of elementary school, he witnessed the execution of Yude Zhang in Taisho Park (now Yude Zhang Memorial Park in Tainan City) by the Nationalist army, and was not allowed to have his wife's body collected. After graduating from Tainan Elementary School, due to his outstanding mathematical achievements, he was sent to the Department of Chemistry at National Taiwan University. In 1961, he went to the United States to study, and earned a Ph.D. from Rice University. In 1967, he was appointed to the faculty of Chemistry at the Cooper Union College in New York City. In the United States, he was involved in the Taiwanese independence movement, serving as vice-chairman of the All-American Taiwanese Independence League when it was formed in 1966, vice-chairman of the Taiwanese Independence League after it was formed on January 15, 1970, and chairman of the Taiwanese Independence League in 1973. He served as Chairman of the Taiwan Independence Party until 1987. In the aftermath of the Tiananmen Square protests, Zhang launched a campaign to support Taiwanese democracy in the United States. In 1983, the Bureau of Investigation of the Ministry of Justice announced that Zhang was the mastermind of the two newspaper bombings. He was subsequently charged with "conspiracy to commit an act of terrorism" and returned to Taiwan in 1991 under the name of "Reunification of Taiwan". Due to Taiwanese society's reaction and the 100th amendment of the Criminal Code of the Republic of China, Zhang was granted bail in October 1992 and was acquitted. He joined the Democratic Progressive Party and ran for the Legislative Council of Taiwan in 1995, but was defeated by more than 30,000 votes.

This was the first battle between China and Russia. In 1657, the Russian regular army established the towns of Yaksa and Nebuchadnezzar at the confluence of the Nebuchadnezzar and Shilka rivers. There have been several diplomatic and military conflicts between Russia and China since then. On May 22, 1685, Kangxi dispatched Peng Chun, a general of the Qing Dynasty, who raised 5,000 troops from Aihui, and on May 25, 1686, he attacked Yaksa, where the governor of Yaksa, Tolbukhin, vowed at a ceremony of surrender not to return to Yaksa, and after the retreat of the Qing army, he renewed his vows, and in 1686, the Qing army again attacked Yaksa and besieged the city for 10 months. On September 7, 1689 (July 24, Kangxi) the Treaty of Nibutsu was officially signed, the two sides reached a peace, the Russians withdrew from the city, and the city was demolished. On 7 September 1689, after the Battle of Yaksa, a border treaty was signed between the Russian army commander, Count Feodor Golovin, and the Qing government on behalf of Soetsu, the Minister of Internal Affairs, and Tong Guoxuang, their uncle, in Nebuchadnezzar (present-day Nerchinsk, Russia). During the negotiations, the Kalka Mongols launched a massive anti-Russian movement near Nibutsu, and the Jesuit priests representing the Qing government actively argued with the Russian representatives, the Russians accepted the Qing proposal and the Russians had to withdraw from the demarcation of the Yaksa River. The treaty deprived Russia for more than a hundred years of the opportunity to conquer the vast regions of the middle and lower Heilongjiang (mainly the Outer Manchuria), but established trade relations with the Qing dynasty. Outside the treaty, the Xing'an Ridge and the Gurguna River demarcated the border between the two countries, but it was not determined which regions belonged between the Xing'an Ridge and the Udai River.

Between 1884 and 1895, when Empress Dowager Ji returned to the throne and retired from politics, Emperor Ilyin used funds raised in the name of the North Sea painter to rebuild the park. Due to limited funds, he concentrated his efforts on the restoration of the forecourt buildings, and built a wall around Kunming Lake, and renamed it Summer Palace in honor of the Summer Palace. After the ascension of the Qing emperor, the Summer Palace became a private property of the Qing dynasty, and the People's Republic began selling tickets to foreign countries in 1914. In 1924, after Puyi was expelled from the palace, the Summer Palace was taken over by the Beiping Special Municipal Government, and turned into a park. In 1949, the Summer Palace was occupied by the Communist Party of China. Several prominent members of the Communist Party and Mao Zedong's close associates (such as Liu Yazi and Jiang Qing) also lived in the garden. Since 1953, the Summer Palace has been open to the public as a park, and the Summer Palace is dominated by Mt. Longevity and Lake Kunming, which account for three-quarters of the total area of the Summer Palace. In addition to the mountains, there's the Hall of Fame, there's the Maple Leaf Landscape. Important buildings are concentrated on the north-south central axis of Mt. Wanshou. The mountain is divided into two parts, the front and the back, and from the east to the west, the front has famous landscapes such as Yuyunxuan, Unfinished Yuyunxuan, Sukeju-do Hall, Yuyun-den Hall, Qinghuaxuan, Baoyun-cave, the first floor, Xianxiang Pavilion, and the middle of the painting. The north-south central axis of Houshan is a large-scale Han-Tibetan-style temple complex, including the Four Continents, Sumi Lingjiang, Xiangyan Zongyin Pavilion, etc., surrounded by a number of small mountain gardens, Suzhou Street, Tora Huichengguan, Hana Cheng Pavilion, Qian Chunyuan, Pao Fang Hall and other buildings. There are three islands in Kunming Lake, named Nanhu Island, Alokado Island, and Jizhongkou Island, respectively.

In geometry, a diameter is the length of a line that passes through the center of a circle and both ends are on the circumference of the circle, or the longest string on the circle, usually denoted by the symbol d or Ø. In general metric spaces (i.e., spaces that define distances, such as a two-dimensional plane), the diameter of a set can also be defined. Here the diameter is the smallest upper bound of the distance between two points in the set: a circle can have innumerable diameters (if it refers to the line segment itself), but on the plane, except for any point outside the center of the circle, it has only one diameter. One end of a diameter is called the opposite end of another. Every point on the circumference has one and the same radius. The diameter divides the circle into two parts of equal area (each of which becomes a semicircle), and divides the circumference into two parts of equal growth. The midpoint of diameter is the center of the circle, and the diameter is the longest string on the circle. In other words, the diameter of a circle is the maximum distance that can be reached between any two points on the circumference of the circle. In the same circle, the diameter is twice the radius of r. The ratio of the circumference to the diameter of a circle is the circumference factor. Given a circle and a diameter AB on the circle (A and B are points on the circle), then for any other point C on the circle, the angle ACB is the right angle. If point C is outside the circle, then angle ACB is sharp, and if point C is inside the circle, then angle ACB is blunt. In a rule drawing, if you know a circle and its center, you just draw a line through the center, and the line between the center and the intersection is the diameter of the circle. If the center of the circle is unknown, the diameter can be calculated as the midline of the string. Specifically, if you make a string that is arbitrarily round, and you make the midline of the string, the line segment between the midline and the intersection of the two points of the circle is the diameter of the circle.

The Battle of Ulaanbaatar was fought on the New Year's Day of 1613. The governor of Jiangsu, Nur Khattak, led 30,000 troops in a two-pronged assault on the city of Urad, Urad Belyabzate and his son, Daramu, defended the city, and he himself led 30,000 troops against the enemy, and the two sides were unable to hold each other along the Fulha River. However, due to the defence of the city of Du, the lord of Fulha surrendered to Nurhaç, and the Ula army retreated and was defeated. The monastery was demolished, its buildings demolished, and its buildings demolished and rebuilt. In September 1612, the Jiangsu ruler Nurhachi defeated the Ula army in the Battle of the Ula River, the two sides reached an oral agreement, Buxantai sent his son, a pro-Faith minister, to Jiangsu as a hostage as a condition of the withdrawal of troops, Nurhachi built a wooden castle on Mt. Imahu on the side of the Ula River to keep 1,000 people under surveillance. The Jiangsu army entered the territory of Ula and went down the river, attacked the city of Kushon Zatai from the mouth of the mountain, then joined forces with another army to attack the city of Kukudo, Ula's army shrank the defensive line, withdrew from the city of Omu, and the Jiangsu army occupied the city that evening. After three sieges, the Jiang army marched directly against the southern gate of the city of Ulaanbaatar, the city of Fulha. At this time, the sons of the lord of the city of Fulha, Ahei and Alhusu surrendered the city of Jiangsu, Jiangsu was instantly enemy, Jiangsu's army took the opportunity to kill, Ula's army fought hard, nearly 10,000 were killed, Jiangsu lost 78,000 men, and hundreds of casualties on both sides. Nurhachi stayed in Ura for ten days, and transferred the survivors of Ura to Jiangsu Province. The son of the king of Bhutan, Hong Kuan, plotted to restore Ula, but was defeated and killed by the enemy.

To go directly to Guangzhou, Widder sent Anna to explore the Pearl River waterway. When the government of Guangzhou discovered this, it dispatched officials to question the purpose of the British invasion. On July 22, 181637, Anna returned to Taiwan and reported back to Weddell. In August, the Weddell fleet set sail for Pearl Harbor. On the way, a Chinese warship warned Widder's convoy not to sail to Guangzhou, ordered it to turn to Lantau, and claimed that the Guangzhou government had blockaded the ship by sinking it in the Yangtze River. However, Weddell remained silent. On 8 August 1637, Wedel's fleet landed on the Isle of Azalea (now the Isle of Wight) near Torumen. On the 12th, the Ming army of the Yamoussoukro launched a bombardment against the Weddell fleet, but the Ming army did not defeat the British fleet's counterattack, and was defeated. Afterwards, Wilder sent a hundred sailors into the battery, tore down the Ming flag, hoisted the British and King's flags, and carried the Ming battery into the ship. Subsequently, the Weddell fleet raided civilian ships in the vicinity of Tiger Gate, and forced fishermen to bring letters of defense to the Guangzhou government's fleet, demanding free trade. On August 15, 1637, the Guangzhou government sent a black translator, Paulo Noretti (Chinese: 李叶荣), to investigate the situation. Faced with the British fleet, Paul declared himself an Ming official, and said that he would be able to trade as long as the British returned the guns and supplies they had stolen from Madame Tussauds, and paid taxes and duties like the Portuguese. : In 2016, Paul went to Guangzhou with two British merchants, and on the 19th, the two British merchants came back and told Weddell that they had been received by General Chen Qian of Guangzhou. However, at this time, Zheng Maohua, the Guangxi governor in charge of the affairs of the two provinces, and Zheng Junguang, the vice envoy of the sea, together put pressure on Chen Qianshi, demanding that Chen Qian expel the "Red Moors".

The Valleys Marineris, also known as the Mariner Canyon, Mariner Canyon, or Mariner Canyon, named after Mariner 9, is the largest canyon on Mars and the longest in the Solar System. Located to the east of the Tassis Volcanic Plateau, it is 3,767 km long and 7 km deep, forming a complex canyon system that is formed by the collapse of the crust, comparable to the East African Rift Valley on Earth. The valley extends from 267.3 degrees east to 331.1 degrees east, west of the Labyrinth of Noctites, east into a large chaotic terrain, and north to south from 2.96 degrees south to 19.09 degrees south. There have been many theories about how the Sailor's Valley formed. In the 1970s, it was thought to be caused by erosion of water or the melting of permafrost in glacial regions. Thermal castration is a relatively plausible effect, but water erosion is unlikely, as liquid water is unlikely to exist on Mars with an atmospheric pressure of less than 1% of Earth's and a temperature of only 148–310 K; however, scientists agree that liquid water may have existed on Mars in the past. The valley may have been formed in the past by the erosion of liquid water. McCauley proposed another hypothesis in 1972 that Sailor's Valley may have formed as a result of erosion of the underlying magma causing the surface to sink. Around 1989, Tanaka and Golombek proposed that it might be caused by a rupture caused by tension. Today's most accepted theory is that the formation mechanism is similar to that of the East African Rift Valley, which was later expanded by cliff avalanches and erosion.

Portuguese (Português) is a Romance language. Portuguese is the seventh most widely spoken language in the world, being spoken in Portugal, Brazil, Angola, Mozambique, Cape Verde, São Tomé and Príncipe, Guinea-Bissau, East Timor and Macao. More than 200 million people speak Portuguese as their mother tongue. Due to Portuguese colonial expansion beginning in the 15th and 16th centuries, which resulted in the colonization of Brazil in the Americas and Macau in Asia, Portuguese also became the second most widely spoken foreign language in some regions, such as the Western Indian region of the Commonwealth of the Bahamas and the Malaysian state of Malacca. The earliest Portuguese language is derived from a common Latin variant used by the Kingdom of Galicia in the Middle Ages. Today's native language population is about 200,000, with about 2,400,000 including second-language speakers, and is generally ranked as the sixth or seventh most widely spoken language in the world. Portuguese is the most widely spoken language in the Southern Hemisphere, second only to Spanish in Latin America. The Spanish writer Miguel de Cervantes called Portuguese "a sweet language", while the Brazilian poet Olávo Birac called Portuguese "última flor do Lácio, inculta e bela", meaning "Lazio's last glorious wildflower". The only Portuguese-speaking Nobel Prize winner, José Saramago, said: "There is no such language as Portuguese in the world, but there are many languages that use Portuguese.

In ancient Chinese, "占卜" means " divination", "卜" means "turtle", "占" and "龟卜" are both divination methods used in ancient China, where the turtle is more ancient, but the original method has been lost, and the In ruins skeleton is a direct archaeological evidence of the existence of the turtle; "占" because it is recorded in the Dictionary, its method has been preserved to this day. Since ancient times, China has had a philosophical idea of the unity of the heavens and the earth, and the Chinese believe that the rise and fall of human beings can be manifested through natural changes, and captured in the process of divination. On the one hand, divination is a mysticism, and on the other hand, it is the practical application of various natural scientific experiences. Although divination itself can be used to find information that has already occurred but that cannot be directly accessed due to conditional limitations, most people seem to be more interested in using it to explore the future. As the saying goes, "The one who goes to the right counts, the one who comes to the wrong counts, and so does the one who goes to the left counts." Science can measure weather phenomena that have already occurred and thus successfully predict future weather changes, such as solar eclipses, weather warnings and volcanic eruptions, but these are not prophecies at all. Strictly speaking, fortune-telling predicts the effects of some supernatural force or fate, whereas scientific prediction relies on scientific laws, unfeeling material arguments, and mechanized methods of repetition. Thus, by operational definition, all non-scientific methods of prophecy can be said to be divination. In addition to these simple explanations, there are serious theories about how divination works. One of these theories, based on empirical science, is based on subconsciousness. According to this theory, divination is a process of decoding information contained in the subconscious.

In 1932, he was appointed Secretary of the First Military Political Defence Department of the Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army and Minister of the Works Department of the Red Army. In October 1934, he participated in the Long March, where he was responsible for conducting enemy reconnaissance and protecting the security of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. After Li Keun moved to northern Shaanxi, he became the Liaison Director of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, specializing in the work of the Northeast Army. In January 1937, Li Khongnong, on behalf of the Red Army, negotiated the cessation of the civil war with Gu Zhu in Tongguan, and later led the Red Army's office in Xi'an. According to the survey, before Huangmei County introduced professional Huangmei opera performers from Anqing in the 1980s, there were no local singers of Huangmei opera, and the elderly over the age of 70 said they had never heard of Huangmei opera in Huangmei County. Anhui local scholar Liao Li Nan believes that Anhui Shuksongsai really is the origin of Huangmei opera. He said, according to the evidence, Huangmei opera originated from the early Tang Dynasty Huangmei tea poems, through the development of folk songs in the Song Dynasty, the influence of Yuan Dynasty drama, gradually formed the early form of folk drama. By the Ming Dynasty, a unique local drama had formed. "It is an artistic form of melody sung by the working people in the long-term productive labor and social life of Anhui Shuksong and Hubei Huangmei. The two counties are contiguous, there's a long border, and there's a lot that can't be separated." Mr. Liao Rinan, through the examination of the literature, found that in the history of the development of the Huangmei opera, there are more than a dozen firsts. The first performance of the Huangmei tea ceremony. From the middle of the Ming Dynasty, the Songpan people began to perform the tea ceremony of Huangmei on Songmei Ling Street; they were the first to write the Huangmei drama in the opera house. During the Qing Dynasty, the locals included several popular Huangmei dramas, such as Send Xiangcha and Xi Lou Kai, in the Liaohe Theatre's repertoire; they were the first to hold "official performances". In 1853, Sukumatsu invited Kusano to the official county town performance of the Huangmei Opera, which was recorded in the "Huangmei Opera in 1934 in the Huangmei County Performance" as early as 1881; the first officially popular folk song of the Huangmei tea ceremony was named Huangmei Opera, and the first officially recorded the name "Huangmei Opera" in the 1921 publication of the Sukumatsu County Chronicle. At this stage, Huangmei opera performance activities gradually became professional, and from the rural grasslands to the urban stage.

The Summer Palace is a royal palace and a large royal garden in the Qing Dynasty, located in the northwest of Haidian District in Beijing, China, covering an area of 297 hectares. The Summer Palace was built during the Qing Dynasty's Qianlong period (originally known as the Qing Yi Garden) and rebuilt during the Gwangxu period, and was one of the Three Mountains and Five Gardens in the western suburbs of Beijing during the Qing Dynasty. The Summer Palace is famous for its ingenious combination of artificial architecture and natural landscapes, representing the peak of Chinese landscape art. In 1998, the Summer Palace was declared a World Heritage Site. In 1153, the lord of the Jin Dynasty, Feng Yanliang, set up the Jinshan Gyogong Palace on Mt. Xiangshan and Mt. Yuquan. After the establishment of the capital of the Yuan Dynasty in Beijing, Guo Shukei opened up the upper reaches of the water, drew the springs of Jinshan in Changping and Baifu Village, and along the way poured water into the lake, increasing the water potential, and became a reservoir to protect the water of the palace and to provide water transportation. :102 In 1494, in the seventh year of the Ming Dynasty, Emperor Ming's maternal grandmother, Lady Luo, built a Buddhist temple in front of Ming's urn, but it later fell into disrepair. Since then, the number of gardens around Mt. Uranus has grown steadily. The Ming Dynasty built a palace on the lakeside, called "Good Mountain Garden", as a royal garden, and changed the name of "Ming Mountain" back to "Golden Mountain", and "Ming Mountain Pavilion" to "Golden Sea". The Ming and Wu sects and the Ming and Jin sects used to play boating here. During the reign of Emperor Ming Xi, the eunuch Wei Zhongxian claimed possession of the Garden of the Good Mountains. In the early Qing Dynasty, Uranshan became a court horse breeding pasture, the convicted jailers were assigned to this grass. :103 The Summer Palace's predecessor, the Qing Yi Garden, was built in 1750. In the northwestern suburbs of Beijing, there is Mt. Uranus, which is the Yuanshan Mountains, there is a lake below the mountain, called the Seven Li Li Li, the Great Lake, Uranus Lake, the West Lake. In the early Qing Dynasty, the number of gardens around Haidian in the western suburbs of Beijing increased, and the amount of garden water consumption increased. At that time, in addition to the less flowing Wanquan River system, most of the garden water came from the Yuquan Mountain, flowing into the West Lake, which has been the source of the Tonghui River since the Ming Dynasty. If the water from the Yuquan Mountain was cut off in large quantities, it would threaten the water level of the Tonghui River from Beijing to Tongzhou section, directly affecting rowing.

On April 8, 1940, the San Francisco News reported that "Trei's combination of exquisite art and exquisite artistry conquered audiences with her skill, her versatile, graceful and sophisticated program, and infected not only the Orientals, but also the Westerners." In the November 6, 1940, issue of the Mexican Cosmopolitan, "All of her dances allude to a certain psychological state, and closely combine spiritual values with distinctive emotions and techniques." To be precise, she's a remarkable dancer. The Argentine newspaper Buenos Aires Grafico of 25 June 1940 stated, "There is no doubt that she is a perfect artist, an artist who is both agile and harmonious, sculptural, and an actress who is proficient in the mental nature and psychology of how to perform dance. The M3 is a fully automatic, air-cooled, open bolt submachine gun that operates on the principle of recoil. The bolt is usually held open in the rear by a spring; when the trigger is pulled, the bullet is fired with the force of the spring; the bolt has a retractable clasp in front of it, which grips the shell and fires the bullet simultaneously; when fired, the bullet is ejected by high pressure gas produced by the ignition of the ammunition; when the trigger is pulled, the bullet is released by a retractable clasp; if the trigger finger is not loosened, the bullet is fired until the bullet is exhausted; if the trigger finger is loosened, the bolt is again held open in the rear. If the trigger finger is not loosened when the bullet is fired, the bolt will snap forward to the barrel. At this point, after changing the receiver, the right handle must be pulled backwards, driving the bolt backwards, compressing the recoil spring to be held by the spring, recovering the position of the ready firing. Each bolt bore one hole, each bore one guide rod, and the double spring outer guide rod contracted as the bolt moved back and forth. This design allows for the use of less sophisticated and inexpensive parts. Due to the low pressure produced by the.45 ACP cartridge and the heavy bolt, the M3 submachine gun does not require a complex chamber closure or delay mechanism. The safety of the M3 is located in a retractable case at the top right of the barrel, with a raised iron plate that holds the bolt. The M3 does not have a safety mechanism that locks the trigger, so inserting a magazine with a bullet while the bolt is pressed backwards is equivalent to inserting a bullet. The M3 magazine is a 30-round magazine with a single round of double-barreled ammunition, similar to the magazine of the Sten submachine gun. On the right side of the barrel, above the front of the trigger is the grip assembly, which consists of nine parts. After the handle is pulled backwards, the bolt is driven backwards until the spring is engaged.

The Battle of Yubei was also known as the Yubei Offensive. It happened in March 1947, and it ended on May 28, 1947. During the Second Sino-Japanese War, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) led by the Communist Party of China (CPC) launched an offensive against the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) in northern Henan Province. In early 1947, the U.S. Army switched from a full-scale offensive to a major offensive. Due to the concentration of the national army in the northern Shaanxi and Shandong battlefields, a dumbbell-like situation emerged in the war. On both sides of the east and west lines, a large number of troops were engaged in constant fighting, while in the middle zone, on the Jinzhiluyuan line, both sides took up defensive positions. Due to the large number of elite troops drawn from the national army to intensify the offensive in Shandong and northern Shaanxi, the central defenses were weak. Accordingly, Liu Beisheng, the commander of the Hunan Field Army of the Jin Jiru, and Deng Xiaoping, the political commissar, decided to launch a counterattack in the northern part of the Hunan region, a key area linking Shandong and northern Shandong battlefields, in order to fight the Liberation Army in Shandong and northern Shandong battlefields. The National Army deployed 31 regular brigades and local security teams totaling 300,000 men on the battlefield of Jinhe Luyuan, of which 6 reorganization divisions and 1 temporary reorganization column served as defenses on the northern front. Its defence centered on Xinxiang, the junction of the Pinghan Railway and the Doqing Railway, and north of it, among which: The Communist Party of China fought the PLA in response to the battlefields of northern Shaanxi and Shandong, decided to mobilize the main force of the Jilu-Yuan field army and local troops of the military district to fight, in addition to the 4th column and Taiyu military district troops to conduct the Jinnan offensive, in addition to the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 6th column and the forces of the Jinan, Taiyuan, Jilu-Yuan military district, a total of 18 brigades and 60 regiments of about 100,000 troops, with the cooperation of 100,000 militia, formed four battle groups, launched the Northern Yuan Campaign.

These parties have 3.3 million members. The Italian, French and Western Communists were seen as the three pillars of "European Communism." In the same year as the Madrid Declaration, however, as relations with the French Socialist Party deteriorated, the French Communist Party reaffirmed its allegiance to the political line of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, abandoning the "European Communism" line. Soon, the Spanish Communist Party also announced its withdrawal from the "European Communism" tripartite coalition. In 1984, Enrico Bering died suddenly, and the Italian Communist Party, the main pillar of "European Communism," plunged into a crisis of leadership within the party, splitting into factions. "" European communism "" is virtually extinct. During this period, the basic positions of the "European Communist" parties in Italy and the West were gradually eroded by the Social Democrats. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, the "European Communist" party suffered severe political shocks as a result of the Great Eastern European Upheaval and the dissolution of the Soviet Union. The Communist Party of Italy declared its renunciation of communist ideology and reorganized itself into the Left Democratic Party. The Spanish Communist Party and the French Communist Party also suffered serious ideological turmoil, with some proposing the abolition of the party, but ultimately being rejected, and in the process its power was severely weakened. The Communist Party of the Netherlands and the Communist Party of Finland dissolved themselves. The Swedish Left Party-Communists, the Communist Party of Great Britain, and the Communist Party of San Marino also chose to change their flags and abandon their communist ideology. Since then, the Communist Party of Spain and the Communist Party of France have not used the term "European Communism" again, although they have retained and developed a number of "European Communist" policies.

Emperor Guangxu (Chinese: 光緒帝; August 14, 1871 – November 14, 1908) was the 11th emperor of the Qing dynasty and the ninth emperor of China, and the last emperor of China to have an official emperor and an official mausoleum, serving from February 25, 1875 to November 14, 1908. He was the grandson of Emperor Daoguang, niece of Emperor Xianfeng, cousin of Emperor Tongzhi, and nephew of Empress Dowager Ji. When the Emperor died, he was succeeded by two empresses-daughters, so he succeeded to the throne at the age of three by Emperor Xianfeng and two empresses-daughters, thus succeeding to the throne successfully. In the first year of his reign, he was governed by Empress Dowager Jian and Empress Dowager Jian, and after the death of Empress Dowager Jian, Empress Dowager Jian continued to be regent by herself, although he later gained the opportunity to govern, but for the rest of his life, the great power remained in the hands of Empress Dowager Jian, and there was no real power. During his reign, he experienced important events such as the Sino-Japanese War, the Boshin Revolution, the Battle of Eight Kingdoms, and the end of the Qing Dynasty. In 1898, after the failure of the Boshin Revolution, she was imprisoned in Yingtai, China, by Empress Dowager Ji, and lost political power, becoming a rubber stamp. In 1908, one day before his death, Emperor Guangxu was poisoned by frostbite in Yingtai in the South China Sea. He was buried in the Chongling Mausoleum of the Qing Emperor (Ming:ᠠᠠ ᠠ, Ming:ambalinggū hūwangdi). He was born on August 14, 1871, in the imperial palace of Taiping Lake, Beijing, and was a cousin of Emperor Tongzhi.

The stone is in the middle of the Luliang Mountains, the gorges, the loess beams. The whole area is east, west, high, low, mountainous and hilly. In the eastern mountain ranges, there are Mt. Yunding, Mt. Hu, and Mt. Chenjiajie, all above 2,000 meters; in the southeastern mountain ranges, the main peaks are Mt. Tianding, Mt. Qiyun, and so on, between 1900 and 2000 meters; and in the northeastern part of the border, Mt. Boneridge, at 2,535 meters, is the highest peak in the city. The central and eastern regions are hilly, fractured, heavily loess-covered; there are many valleys between the hills; the land is fertile, water is plentiful, and the population is dense, making it a major agricultural area. The main rivers are the North River, the Great East River, the Little East River, etc., flow into the Three Rivers after crossing the castle, and into the Yellow River through Yulin County.

Shi Kai-yan (Chinese: 施启揚; May 5, 1935 – May 5, 2019) was a Taiwanese lawyer, a member of the Communist Party of China, who served as the President of the Judiciary, Deputy President of the Executive Council, Secretary-General of the National Security Council, and a member of the Continental Committee. He is married to Li Zhonggui. After graduating from the Law Department of Taiwan University in 1958, he worked as an assistant professor on the one hand, master's degree on the other hand, obtained a master's degree in law in 1962, went abroad to Germany to study for a doctorate, and obtained a doctorate in law from Heidelberg University in 1967. After returning to Taiwan, he worked as an associate professor in the Department of Law at Taiwan University, as an assistant researcher at the Center for International Relations at the University of Political Science, and as a researcher, and from 1971 to 1984 he was also a professor in the Department of Law at Taiwan University. After returning to China, he joined the Communist Party of China and entered politics in 1976. He served as Deputy Minister of Education, Deputy Minister of Political Affairs and Deputy Minister of Justice, Minister of Justice in 1984, Deputy Director of the Executive Yuan in 1988, and served as Director of the Executive Yuan under Yu Guohua, Lee Hwan, and Ho Bermuda. In 1993, after the war, he became the President of the Executive Council, the Secretary-General of the National Security Council, the next year the President of the Judiciary Lin Yanggang resigned, and Sch Kai-yan took the position of Deputy President. In 1999, he was appointed to the post of President of the Republic, after which he was appointed to the post of Deputy Prime Minister. On 19 March 2004, the day before the 2004 presidential election, 319 gunshots were fired, which had a huge political impact on both the election and the political scene.

The First Battle of Changsha (also known as the First Battle of Changsha, the First Battle of Xiangbei, or the Battle of Xianggan) was a defensive campaign conducted by the Chinese Army of the Ninth War Area against the Japanese Army in the areas bordering Hunan, Hubei, and Jiangxi provinces from September to October 1939 during the Second Sino-Japanese War. The battle was the first major frontal assault by the Japanese on the battlefield in China since the outbreak of World War II in Europe. Japan launched an offensive against Changsha in three directions: northern Gansu, southern Oman, and northern Xiangbei, concentrating 100,000 troops to strike and overthrow the national government. The 9th Division's deputy commander, Xue Yue (officially appointed as commander on October 1, 1939), defended Changsha, adopted a defensive focus on Xiangbei, "resistance to the war, for the outer wing", mobilized more than 30 divisions and three forward columns, and about 240,000 people participated in the battle. By 9 October, the 195th Division of the Chinese army had returned to the line of Occupation of Deer Point, Xinhua, and Yanglin Street, and the Japanese retreated north of the Xinhua River; by 14 October, the two sides had resumed their pre-war positions. Japan's Operational Objective: "The operational objective is the same as that of the Xiangdong Campaign, namely, to urgently and thoroughly crush the increasingly active enemy forces in southern Jiangsu, in order to guarantee the security of our army, the so-called Self-Defense Battle." On 15 August, the Japanese 11th Army's "Guidelines for Operations in Jiangnan" clearly stated the operational guidelines as follows: "This operation will be conducted primarily by surprise attacks, ending the battle as soon as possible, and then resuming roughly the original situation." (Recently, the enemy fled quickly, so the secrecy of tactics and preparations is of great importance.)"The deputy commander-in-chief of the 9th War Area, Xue Yue, used the so-called "Heaven's furnace method" to eliminate the mobility of the Japanese mechanized troops, according to the terrain of Hunan, left to Dongting Lake, right to Mt.

From January to March 1946, the National Army occupied the camp and stationed it in Shenyang, in order to ensure the security of this largest city in the northeast, the authorities immediately launched military operations to capture Liaoning; on March 18, they attacked Liaoning Central, on March 21, they stationed it in Liaoning, on March 22, they stationed it in Puxiang, on March 24, they attacked Iron Ridge, on March 29, they attacked Kuanshan, on April 1, they recaptured Kaijo and the camp, on April 2, they resumed the occupation of Daishi Bridge, the National Army swept through the Liaoning Southern Communist Army, the force was like bamboo, only ten days left in Liaoning was finally determined, and Shenyang was no longer concerned. The army returned to Shenyang as the center, swept northward and eastward, and on May 3 entered Hongxi, Hongxi Lake, Fushun and other industrial areas in succession. Formerly the Northeast Camp in Jinzhou, the Security Command, Liaoning Provincial Government were successively stationed in Shenyang; the heads of the other provinces and cities in the Northeast, delegates from the central ministries and heads of other institutions all received personnel at different rates from Beiping to Shenyang, preparing to receive them with the army.

County is the administrative divisional unit name used by the Chinese character culture circle, has a long history. It has been used as a place name since the pre-Qin period in China, and evolved into an administrative district unit in the Spring and Autumn Warring States period, and is still used today as a local administrative unit in the traditional sense and legal status of the Chinese character cultural circle, expanding the concept of county-level administrative districts. In today's Chinese-speaking world, 縣 exists mainly as a sub-district, but in Japan it is a first-class administrative district. As an administrative unit with a long history in China, modern Chinese scholars believe that counties are the watersheds of local administration in China's feudal dynasties. Its view is that the administration of the central government only affects the administrative districts above the county, and below the county is in a state of "local autonomy". In China, "county" became the name of administrative units in the spring and autumn period. Prior to this, the Zhou Dynasty was politically divided. There are different usages for this class of administrative units in the pre-Qin Dynasty, and the usages of warring states are particularly mixed. In the Western Zhou period, it was written "han." In the late Qing Dynasty, Tang Degang believed that the origin of "county" was when Zhou Wu divided the princes, because he did not want to give the princes too large a fiefdom, and did not want to divide too many foreign princes, leading to "many places that are neither Wangki nor suitable people can be sealed", these lands "hanged undecided", only temporarily dispatched people to manage, waiting for suitable people to seal, called "hanging", and later evolved into "county". However, it is doubtful that the word "kan" was used in the pre-Qin Dynasty except in the Warring States Qin Dynasty, whereas the word "kan" was used in the Western Zhou Dynasty, whereas the word "kan" was used in the Eastern Zhou Dynasty. In the spring and autumn periods, the lords were annexed, and after the great powers destroyed the small states, if they did not want to divide the land to the nobility, they were also set up as counties. Thus, the kingdoms of Chu, Chen, and Cai were eliminated from the counties.

The Chadam Basin consists of five geomorphological types: high mountains, hills, gorges, plains and lakes from the edge to the center. It has a belt-like distribution, northwest high-east-south-low, southern salty-water lakes, salt marshes, and a large area of crescent-shaped sand dunes and chains of sand dunes. The northern part of the basin is intermittently distributed by mountains such as Mt. Sishen, Mt. Greenbeam, Mt. Sitai, and Mt. Yakushi. People of Huangpi County, Hubei Province, Hanyang Prefecture. He is a social scientist, political activist, and one of the leaders of the People's Republic of China Youth Party. He was a nationalist thinker, the founder of modern neo-fascism. Chen Kei-tian is the son of a landowner who runs an oil refinery. Early learning. In 1905, he began to receive a new-style education, and entered the Hubei Higher Agricultural School attached to the Higher Primary School in Wuchang. The following year, he transferred to the newly established Dongming Primary School in Huangpi County. In the spring of 1910, he was promoted to the Hubei Higher Agricultural College Affiliated Secondary School. The following year, when the Xinhai Revolution broke out, Chen joined the revolutionary faction and became a member of the 2nd Army Chartered Corps of the Northern Expeditionary Army. In the autumn of 1912, Chen entered a private Wuchang Chinese University, specialized in political economy, studied under Liu Wenqing, and graduated in the summer of 1915. In 1917, he became a faculty member of Wuchang Chinese University Middle School. In 1919, he enrolled in Nanjing Higher Normal School, but did not enter due to a lack of specialization; in the autumn of the same year, he joined the Young Chinese Society together with Jiao Ying and Yujia Qiu. Between 1923 and 1924, he was chairman of the board of directors. In the aftermath of the May Fourth Movement of the Young Chinese Academy, there was a confrontation between the left and the right, and Chen Kei-tian belonged to the right, which advocated nationalism and opposed Marxism, and he engaged in fierce arguments with the left, such as Deng Zhongxia. In 1920, Chen attended Nanjing Higher Normal School (later renamed National Southeast University and National Central University), where he studied at the Department of Education.

Ba Jin (Chinese: 巴金; pinyin: Bǎjing; November 25, 1904 – October 17, 2005) was a Chinese modernist writer, publisher, and translator. He is also regarded as one of the most influential writers of the "Fifty-Fourth" New Cultural Movement, a master of Chinese literature of the 20th century, and a master of contemporary Chinese literature. It has been translated into many languages, but has not been published since 1949. His wife, Susan, married Barkin in May 1944 in Huaxi. In March 1983, Bakin was elected Vice-Chairman of the CPPCC five times in a row, serving until his death. Tulips describes Baking as "the conscience of the nation" The original name and words of Baking derive from the first sentence of the Song of Songs, "Call South Gantang" (Chinese: 蔽甘tang). He took one word from each of these names, and it became his pen name. The asteroid 8 315 is named after him. Since many Malay, Portuguese, and Japanese mercenaries were involved, the Dutch had no firepower, and the Dutch strongholds themselves had no strong defenses, making it difficult to sustain the siege for long. The Cambodians also blockaded the Mekong River with floating bridges, and set out in a heap of boats to take control of two Dutch warships, capturing all 60 of their sailors. Meanwhile, a third Dutch warship was patrolling the waters south of Phnom Penh. The captain and his men had no idea what was going on upstream, but they found the craftsmen who were delivering supplies to them behaving strangely. So he extracted the truth by means of torture, and decided to force his way out of the harbor without restraint, under fire from a large number of chasing boats, and successfully returned from the sea to Batavia. And so the news of my colleagues' tragic experiences came to be known to the outside world. The top executives of the Dutch East India Company were outraged, and immediately set about forming the Second Support and Rescue Corps. In the spring of 1644, a small company of Pierre de Rogemortes sailed from Batavia, intending to use the three warships they had assembled to force the Cambodian king to release the people. But tropical disease along the way left half of the Dutch soldiers unable to fight until they arrived. When they drove down the Mekong from Phnom Penh, they found Cambodian army pontoon bridges blocking the entire waterway. Although the Dutch managed to break through the first blockade line, they were jammed in front of the second defensive line behind them. Subsequently, large numbers of Cambodian armed boats launched attacks from the rear, and shore batteries fired repeatedly at the grounded Dutch warships. The commander-in-chief, Pierre de Rogemortes, was killed in action, while the Dutch suffered 156 casualties from 432 soldiers, and several Dutch warships fell into Cambodian hands.

Apparently, among the northeastern population of Song Dynasty O, Jiangxi immigrants accounted for a significant proportion. This should be the beginning of Jiangxi migrants' systematic influence on the Odong region. During the Song and Jin War, the southern and northern sides of the Song and Jin Lines suffered heavy casualties. During the Song and Yuan Dynasties, peasant uprisings in the eastern and northern parts of the country also caused enormous losses. Against this backdrop, the migration of Hongwu from the late Yuan Dynasty to the early Ming Dynasty was a demographic restructuring of the Huangxia region, radically changing the population and language composition. In the first year of the Qing dynasty, De'an fell into the state, and belonged to Huangzhou Prefecture, while only Yunmen County was not abolished, until the 13th year of the Qing dynasty, De'an Prefecture was reestablished, and the counties under its jurisdiction were reestablished. Thus, "in the early years of the Han Dynasty, most of Dean's counties no longer existed, owing to overpopulation." This area is "almost a no man's land, a vast area, with less than 20,000 indigenous people." At the beginning of the Ming Dynasty, Dean Prefecture received immigrants from two main directions, one from the eastern neighboring areas of Huangzhou Prefecture, such as Macheng and Huangdong; the other major immigrants came from Razhou, Nanchang, and Jiangxi. "Immigrants from Jiangxi and nearby Huangzhou relocated in large numbers, so that on the population map of Hongwu in 26 years, there were about 5 people per square kilometer, the foreign population accounted for 80 percent of the total population." The level at which Dean received immigrants was also more complicated. "Because there is a large number of so-called indigenous people in Asagi County who are old immigrants from Jiangxi in the Song Dynasty, they have a larger population than the old indigenous people, and they are also indigenous people compared to the Hongwu immigrants, we call them the new indigenous people. When the Aztecs moved to Dean's Palace during the Flood, there would be a large number of such populations mixed in, and they could be said to be the main part of the Aztecs who moved to Dean's Palace."

Chiang Kai-shek was very concerned that the Soviet Union would come up with proposals in favor of the Communist Party, and that the U.S. and Soviet Union would reach an agreement to restore peace in China. In order to gain American support, Chiang Kai-shek secretly ordered President Hu to launch an offensive on March 10, quickly seizing Yan'an and destroying the central organs of the Communist Party. On 1 March, Hu and his chief of staff, General Sheng Wen, went to Nanjing to discuss the battle plan, and on the morning of 3 March, they returned to Xi'an by airplane. On March 7, Chiang Kai-shek delayed the attack by three days because the U.S. military observers in Yan'an had not yet withdrawn, but ordered Hu to quickly capture Yan'an during the Moscow Conference and destroy the main force of the Northern Shaanxi Communist Army. On March 8, Hu Zongnam went to Luochuan. At 10 o'clock in the evening of March 10, Hu convened a meeting in the hall of Luochuan Primary School of the heads of the army, divisions and brigades of the 1st and 29th Armies, instructed Chiang Kai-shek's approved plan for the capture of Yan'an, issued a war order, ordered all the armies, divisions and brigades and assigned to their regiments, battalions and companies to prepare for the attack before 6 o'clock in the evening of March 12, and advanced at dawn on March 13.

Thus, even though they share similar habitats, they differ greatly from one another. Traditionally, blue algae are morphologically divided into five parts, denoted by the numbers I-V. The first three — the chromosomes, the pleurocapsales and the fibrils — have not been supported in the study of the species history of plants and animals. The latter two — Stigonematales and Stigonematales — are monophyletic, they're isocysts. The members of Chroococales are unicellular and usually aggregate in colonies. The classic taxonomic criterion has been the cell morphology and the plane of cell division. In Pleurocapsales, the cells have the ability to form internal spores (baeocytes). The name Hoch (high) refers to the high German-speaking area, from the Alps northwards to the central German mountains, where the terrain is relatively high. Accordingly, Lower (Nieder) in Low German refers to the relatively low level of the North German Plains, which is spoken in Low German. Hoch (high) does not have any equivalent meaning in standard German to that of other German dialects. To avoid confusion between "Standard German" and "High German", "Standard German" is also called Standarddeutsch (Standard German) or Deutsche Standardsprache (German Standard Language), shortened to Standardsprache (Standard Language) if the context is clear enough. However, such names were strongly opposed by the German-speaking regions of Switzerland because they only recognised the universal status of Standard German and did not want to replace it with Standard. Standard German differs geographically, particularly between German-speaking countries, and linguistically, especially in terms of vocabulary (also in some examples of pronunciation and even grammar). The regional variant of Standard German should not be confused with the variant of the German dialect, although the former is influenced to some extent by the dialect, but the two are after all quite different. In most regions, depending on the specific situation, the German language used by German speakers belongs to a continuum, which is a mixture, from more dialectal variants to more standard German variants. In the German-speaking part of Switzerland, there is no such continuum between dialects and (Swiss) Standard German.

According to the media, the intention of the Mainland Commission of the Republic of China (hereinafter referred to as the Land Commission) and the Strait Exchange Foundation (hereinafter referred to as the Sea Foundation) to send Taiwanese aircraft to take back Taiwanese residents was rejected by the Mainland. On the afternoon of January 27, the Ocean Society of Mainland China received a letter from the Sea Foundation. On January 28, a spokesman for the Taiwan Broadcasting Corporation, Ma Xiaoguang, responded that Wuhan had been properly cared for, and that there was no need for a Taiwanese plane to pick it up. He stated, "In recent days, Taiwanese media reports and Taiwanese officials have claimed that they have entered into communications agreements on various pipelines and coordination on the other side, including with the Association of the Seas, which are inconsistent with the actual situation. In response, Tsai Zhiju, the director of the Land Commission's legal affairs department, said that the Taiwanese people in distress were mainly short-term residents on business trips, tourism, visits to relatives, and non-long-term residents of Hubei. On 1 February, Taiwanese businessman and then KMT Central Committee member Xu Zhengwen held a press conference, claiming that more than 500 Taiwanese "stayers" were returning home. Meanwhile, media outlets in Taiwan reported that Mr. Wuhan had been suffering from high fever for seven days for lack of medical care, and the two incidents were seen by Taiwanese media as contributing to a change in official attitudes in mainland China. On 27 January (the first day of the Chinese Lunar New Year), before the airplane's departure on 3 February, the Kuomintang Central Committee and the Taiwan Enterprise Union formed the "Group of Seven" of which Lin Rongde, the acting party chairman, was a member. On 2 February, Taiwanese residents of Wuhan received a notice of the next day's return to Taiwan. On February 3, the charter flight was operated by China Eastern Airlines, carrying 247 passengers. Later, the Hubei Provincial Bureau of Transportation (台办 Hubei Province) estimated the number of passengers to be 250, and three people were excluded from pre-board screening. In the early hours of February 4th, the task force completed the quarantine process. We found one with a fever, two with a sore throat. On the evening of February 4, the Supreme Commander of the Department of Health, Chen Zhongzhong, announced that one of the three passengers admitted to the isolation ward had been diagnosed with Wuhan pneumonia, the 11th case in Taiwan, and that the two sides had lost mutual trust.

Phosphate (symbol: PO3−4), the salt of phosphate, is a very important substance in inorganic chemistry, biochemistry and biogeochemistry. The phosphate ion is a polyatomic ion with the experimental formula PO43− and a molecular weight of 94.97. It contains one phosphorus atom, and is surrounded by four oxygen atoms, forming a tetrahedron. Phosphate ions have a 3-form charge, and are covalent bases of hydrogen phosphate ions (HPO42−); hydrogen phosphate ions are covalent bases of hydrogen phosphate ions (H2PO4−); and hydrogen phosphate ions are covalent bases of phosphate (H3PO4). It is a supervalent molecule (a phosphorus atom has 10 electrons in its electron layer). If a phosphate is an organic phosphorus compound it is called a phosphate ester, and its chemical formula is OP(OR)3. In addition to some alkali metals, most phosphates, in their standard state, are insoluble in water. In dilute water solutions, phosphates exist in four forms. In strong bases, the phosphate ions (PO43−) are more abundant; in weak bases, the hydrogen phosphate ions (HPO42−) are more abundant. In a weak acid environment, dihydrogen phosphate ions (H2PO4−) are more common; in a strong acid environment, water-soluble phosphate (H3PO4) is the predominant form. More precisely, there are three equilibrium reactions: at 25 °C, with various different acidity coefficients (mol/L): at pH values of strong bases (pH=13), [H2PO4−][H3PO4] 7.5×1010, [HPO42−][H2PO4−] 6.2×105, [PO43−][HPO42−] 2.14 {\displaystyle {\frac {}}\simeq 2.14} where only phosphate (PO43−) and hydrogen phosphate (HPO42−) are visible as major components.

Parents of children who have purchased a real-life rapid screening test can still get a free test kit. Newborns who have not yet obtained a health insurance card, or who have subsequently been born, can still obtain a health insurance card once the policy has been implemented. It is estimated that there are around 5,000 households in the United States who use this method of self-care and self-care services. Furthermore, infants 0–6 years of age receive free five-dose family-controlled antigen rapid screening test kits, which are dispensed on a one-to-two basis based on ID numbers; one-to-one on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays; two-to-two on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays; and all on Sundays. Parents are reminded that household rapid screening should only be used by children over the age of two, rapid screening reagents obtained from children under the age of two should be used by parents of children under the age of two, and should not be used by children under the age of two. On June 1, the "first round" 0–6 year olds (children) will receive a free five-dose household rapid screening test kit, even if they have already purchased the first round of rapid screening. On June 6, the implementation of the "second round" of home antigen rapid screening trials was introduced, increasing the number of trials from 78 to 117. On 13 June, restrictions on double purchases were lifted. On July 1, the "Third Round" of domestic antigen rapid screening reagents were put on sale under the real name system. On August 15, the "fourth round" of home antigen rapid screening trials was implemented, with the original purchase of one dose (5 doses) being increased to a maximum of two doses (10 doses), divided into one or two purchases (discountable), the price remaining at 500 yuan per dose (5 doses), informing people in need and eligible to have health insurance cards purchased/received from the health insurance bureaus and health clinics that sell real-name home antigen rapid screening trials; and the "third round" of 0–6 year olds (children) receiving one dose (5 doses) of home rapid screening trials free of charge.

The Battle of Zhengzhou was a major battle fought between the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) led by the Communist Party of China (CPC) and the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) led by the National Government in Zhengzhou, Henan Province, China in 1948. During the 1948 Jinan Campaign, the army of Jinan and Xuzhou was tightened, and in late September Zhengzhou's Sun Yuanliang Corps was relocated to Xuzhou. Zhengzhou's defenses were replaced by the 106th and 268th Divisions of the National Army in Anyang and Xinxiang, and the 12th District Command of the Xinxiang National Army was moved south to Zhengzhou. Zhengzhou was then called Zheng County, and the entire county was under the jurisdiction of Vi Xin Town, Datong Town and Dehua Town, with an area of only 2.4 square kilometers. On September 24, 1948, just before the end of the Jinan Campaign, the deputy commander of the East China Field Army, Awa Yu, sent a telegram to the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and reported to the East China Bureau and the Central Plains Bureau, proposing to launch the Huaihai Campaign. In order to attract the reinforcements of Sun Yuan Liang's regiment, to cooperate with the Eastern Front of the Chinese Eastern Campaign, and to ensure the smooth conduct of the Huaihai Campaign, on October 11, the Central Military Commission sent a telegram to the Central Bureau: "Sun Yuan Liang's three divisions, Dongjin, Wang Liu, Chen, and Deng, immediately deploy to attack the Zheng Xu Line, intercept Sun's regiment. Zhengzhou is located at the junction of Longhai Railway and Beijing-Hanhai Railway, and its strategic position is extremely important. In order for the PLA to transport heavy weapons and large quantities of heavy military equipment to the Huaihai battlefield, railways were an important means of transport. After receiving the telegram, Liu Beicheng, Chen Yi, Deng Xiaoping, 1, 3, 4, 9, column commander Chen Gang, Chen Xilian, Yang Yong, Qin Qiwei, etc., in U County, in accordance with the instructions of the Central Military Commission, formulated a battle plan to attack Zhengzhou. On 13 October, the Central Military Commission gave its approval, agreeing to "attack Zhengzhou and deploy reinforcements in accordance with your timetable".

After World War II, this trend developed into a neoclassical synthesis. The problems that dominated economic hypotheses and theories at the time were becoming increasingly apparent, and John Maynard Keynes was one of the early thinkers to recognize these problems. When physics began to question the necessity of absolute time, writers began to question narrative structure, composers began to question the necessity of harmonious tonal harmony, Keynes began to question the two pillars of economics at the time: first, whether money had to have a firm foundation, usually the gold standard, and second, that if demand decreased, supply or price would decrease accordingly, thereby rebalancing. Keynes himself was closely associated with London's Bloomsbury district, and was fascinated by the atmosphere that changed people's minds. It was this experience and the signing of the Treaty of Versailles that ultimately led him to break with traditional theories. In 1920 he wrote The Economic Consequences of Peace, in which he not only elaborated on the overall economic consequences of the Treaty of Versailles as he saw it, but also established his position as an economist with practical political experience that could influence national decision-making. In the 1930s, Keynes published a series of articles on the effects of national power and overall economic trends, developed a theory that monetary policy was not just a fixed reference, and he became increasingly convinced that economic systems did not automatically follow a curve that economics called the productivity curve. But he didn't find any evidence, and he didn't find any form of expression for these ideas. In the late 1930s, the globalized economic system began to hit the United Kingdom — the central country at the time.

In order to compensate for the shortage of existing international ports, the Taiwanese government first opened Suo Port in the 1970s (under the jurisdiction of the Keelung Port Authority), then built Taipei Port (also known as Freshwater New Port; under the jurisdiction of the Keelung Port Authority) and Anping New Port (under the jurisdiction of the Kaohsiung Port Authority) in the 1990s. In 1999, the Ministry of Transportation of the Republic of China changed its name to the Ministry of Transportation of the Republic of China. Due to Taiwan's economic boom, and the rapid development of commercial ports, especially located in both the north and south of Kaohsiung and Keelung, it was the third and seventh largest container ports in the world, respectively, in its heyday, and contributed greatly to Taiwan's economy; however, since the 1990s, the rapid development of ports in mainland China and neighboring countries, which affected the competitiveness of the various commercial ports in Taiwan, passenger traffic throughput could not grow. In order to improve competitiveness, the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of China has implemented the "separation of government enterprises" measures since March 1, 2012, to incorporate the port offices and establish the Taiwan Port Authority to be responsible for the actual operation of the trading port, the original four port offices were respectively reorganized into the "port branch" of the Taiwan Port Authority, and the shipping and port supervision was established another port office as the competent authority. On the island, the Ministry of Transport commissioned the Kinmen Prefecture Government and the Linjiang Prefecture Government to set up a port authority to manage the domestic ports in the prefecture, not affected by the establishment of the Taiwan Port Authority. There are currently seven international ports in Taiwan, including four major ports and three auxiliary ports. There are five domestic merchant ports: Pubang Port in Chiayi County and Ma Kung Port in Penghu County (one of the two largest port districts in Penghu) are mainly used for offshore transportation and tourism, Shenzhen Port is mainly used for oil and gas discharge and tourism sea fishing by Taiwan Central Oil Company, while Kinmen Port (three port districts below) and Mazu Port (five port districts below) are used for direct trade with mainland China through the Small Three-way Mode, and for informal trade activities.

Admiral of the Fleet John Arbuthnot "Jacky" Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher (25 January 1841 – 10 July 1920) was a British admiral. During his 60-year career in the army, he exerted enormous influence on the Royal Navy. By the time he was commissioned, the Navy was still using pre-armored wooden sailing ships, and by the time he retired, the Navy was already using steel battlecruisers, submarines, and aircraft carriers. An argumentative, energetic, forward-thinking man, Fisher is often cited as the second most important figure in the history of the British navy after Lord Nelson. Although he had extensive combat experience, he was remembered as an innovator, strategist, and promoter of naval development, rather than a naval commander involved in major naval battles. In 1904, he was appointed First Minister of the Navy. He decommissioned the next 150 obsolete warships, and began building replacements for modern warships. Fisher felt that the navy needed to improve the range, accuracy, and speed of the guns. He was also one of the first to advocate the use of torpedoes, which he believed would eventually replace heavy artillery as the main anti-ship weapon. During his tenure as naval governor, he introduced the torpedo boat destroyer class to the navy. After serving as First Secretary of the Navy, he was responsible for the construction of the first "All-Big-Gun" in 1911, when he officially resigned from the Navy Headquarters on his 70th birthday, but he again served as First Secretary of the Navy in November 1914.

Engineering is broad in scope, and is generally subdivided into several subfields, which are different areas of engineering. Initially, engineers are trained in a particular field, but may be exposed to other fields in their careers. General engineering can be divided into four main categories: In addition, there are other engineering fields, formerly classified as mining engineering and marine engineering, and now classified as industrial engineering and materials engineering. The British Engineering Commission covers many of these areas of engineering. Occasionally, special applications integrate these traditional fields into a new one, such as Earth Systems Engineering and Management, which includes philosophy, ethics, anthropology, environmental sciences, and engineering studies. Some new fields are temporarily defined as a combination of some existing fields, so there are still many grey areas as to whether a particular application is considered a field, a major indicator being whether a major university has a department, institute, or course in the field. There is considerable overlap in these areas, especially in the applied sciences, such as mathematics, physics, and chemistry. The most critical and unique task of an engineer is to discover, understand and combine practical limitations to achieve satisfactory results. In many cases, the product doesn't just have to meet the technical requirements, it has to meet other requirements as well. These conditions include material source, physical or technological limitations, feasibility of future improvements and other factors such as cost, marketability, productivity and suitability.
