Because any important resolution must be decided by more than 85 percent of the vote, a single country in the United States can veto any reform. The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are the same organization that was decided at the Bretton Woods Conference, but they are two different organizations. The World Bank Group consists of five institutions: the term "World Bank" generally refers only to the IBRD and IDA, while the World Bank Group or WBG generally refers to all five. The World Bank Institute is the World Bank's capacity development department, providing learning and other capacity-building training to member countries. A government can decide for itself which organizations it wants to be a member of. At present, the IBRD is composed of 188 member states of the United Nations, as well as Kosovo; the other institutions have 153 to 184 members, notwithstanding that all the institutions of the World Bank Group adhere to the terms of their agreements, which form the legal and institutional basis for all their work. The World Bank is also the executing agency of the United Nations Global Environment Facility (GEF). 188 members of the United Nations and Kosovo are members of the WBG, at least in the IBRD. So far, all the members have also participated in some of the other four institutions (IDA, IFC, MIGA, ICSID). As of May 2016, according to the number of participating agencies, the WBG members: the five UN member states that have not yet joined: Andorra, Cuba, Liechtenstein, Monaco, North Korea. Since the United States is the largest shareholder in the World Bank, the President of the World Bank, also known as the "President of the World Bank," has always been an American, while the President of the International Monetary Fund is a European Union person.

According to the current hypothesis, Planet Nine orbits the Sun with a very high eccentricity and has an inclination of up to 30 degrees (6999523598775598300♠30°±10°). For observers on Earth, when Planet Nine is at its farthest point from the Sun, it will appear in either Orion or Taurus. According to Brown's conjecture, assuming the existence of Planet Nine, it would take at least 20 years to reach the planet if a spacecraft were to be launched from Earth, using the gravitational pull to navigate its orbit around the Sun. The planet's mass is estimated to be 10 times that of Earth, and its diameter is between 2 and 4 times that of Earth. Brown argues that if the ninth planet existed, its mass would be sufficient to clear its orbit of large objects within 4.6 billion years (with the possible exception of certain combinations of semi-major axes and mass) and its gravity-driven outer edge of the Solar System would be, by current definition, sufficient to make it a planet. Brown speculated that Planet Nine might be an ejected ice giant, similar in composition to Uranus and Neptune: a mixture of rock and ice and a portion of gas. In fact, if it had once flown between Jupiter and Neptune, the planet might have contained hydrogen and helium. Chad Cherkyro and Scott Shepherd were the first to describe the orbital classification of extreme trans-Neptunian objects, pointing to similarities in the orbits of asteroids 90377 and 2012 VP113. In the absence of a ninth planet, the orbits of these objects should be randomly distributed, not biased in any direction.

In 1820, under the Missouri Compromise, Maine separated from Massachusetts to become the 23rd U.S. state. In the 19th century, Massachusetts was the leader of the American Industrial Revolution, and there were a number of textile and shoe factories near Boston and Laurel, and a number of toolmaking, papermaking, and textile factories near Springfield. Although Massachusetts established its first slave colony as early as the 17th century, before the American Civil War, Massachusetts was the center of the American abolitionist and progressive movements. Thanks to the efforts of Horace Mann, the state's educational standards are among the highest in the United States. Although there was an early outcry against the abolition of slavery in Massachusetts, and even more riots against the abolition between 1835 and 1837, Massachusetts's manufacturing economy began to decline in the early 20th century as several manufacturing firms relocated. By the 1920s, with the rise of manufacturing in the Midwest and South, combined with the effects of the Great Depression, Massachusetts' textile, shoe and precision machinery industries were inevitably in decline. During World War II, Massachusetts produced 3.4 percent of all U.S. armaments, making it the 10th-largest U.S. state. In 1987, Massachusetts received federal funding for the Central artery tunnel project, the "" Big Digging "" project, the largest federal engineering project of its time. The Kennedy family played a very important role in 20th-century Massachusetts politics. U.S. President John F. Kennedy, Massachusetts Senator Ted Kennedy On May 17, 2004, Massachusetts became the first state in the United States to legalize same-sex marriage.

Hong Kong's legal system is based on the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary, along with the common law system. After the transfer of sovereignty in 1997, the Basic Law of Hong Kong was adopted as the constitutional document of the legal system. Under the principle of one country, two systems, Hong Kong's legal system was able to continue the original common law system, supplemented by the written law. Therefore, the legal system of Hong Kong is quite different from that of mainland China, and even from that of Macau. It is currently used in Hong Kong law, and is compiled in the form of written Hong Kong legislation. Currently implemented laws include: the Basic Law, other Chinese laws listed in Annex III of the Basic Law, the original laws before the transfer of sovereignty to Hong Kong (including the Common Law and the Equity Law), and laws enacted by the Hong Kong legislature. National laws of the People's Republic of China relating to defence, diplomacy and other matters outside the scope of Hong Kong autonomy must first be incorporated into Annex III of the Basic Law by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China, and promulgated or enacted by the Chief Executive directly in Hong Kong. After the arrival of Charles I of England on Hong Kong Island in 1841, it was announced that the Chinese were still governed by local customs, and that British customary laws had been introduced. For example, for the same crime of murder, if the perpetrator was a European, he would be hanged under English law at the time, but if the perpetrator was a Chinese, he would be beheaded. In order to maintain the administrative status of the New Territories at the time and to respect the customs and interests of the New Territories residents, the Hong Kong Government decided that the New Territories would be administered by the local squires of the New Territories.

Traditional religious rituals: God the Great Secret Society: God, also known as God the Great, God the Grand Duke, God the Old, God the Goddess, God the Bodhisattva, is said to have evolved from the "wall" and "protect the city river", later evolved into the "personality god", and has the duties of a secret administrator, a magistrate. The city is named for the city walls, and God for the waterless moats of the city. The origin of the worship of the city god is said to date back to the Zhou Dynasty, when it was one of the eight gods worshipped on New Year's Eve — Sui Yong. According to the Book of Rites, the ancient gods worshipped "Water Yong" in the "Eight Waxes", interpreted as "Water God and Yong City", so it is generally believed that this is the beginning of worshipping God, but the worship of the eight waxes at this time should be performed only by the angels, and the situation of worshipping God in later times is not the same. From the Han Dynasty onwards, the worship activities of the gods continued to rise, and people everywhere honored the deceased vassals or heroes as the gods, including Kishin and Hoko. It is said that in the Three Kingdoms period, Wu Guo built the Temple of God; also in the Book of Bei Qi Muyong Yan, the Northern Qi general Muyong Yan visited the Temple of God in Yingcheng and defeated the Southern Liang enemy army, for the earliest clear description of the orthodox history. According to the Book of Sui, the Five Pilgrims: "The King of Liangwuling sacrificed to the god of the city, he cooked the ox, and suddenly there was a red snake around the ox's mouth. It is known that in the Northern and Southern Dynasties, the city gods were widely regarded as folk religions. It is believed that the temples were built to pray for rain, blessings, and disaster relief. There are many famous authors, including: Han Yu, Du Mak, and Li Shang-yin, among which the earliest is Zhang's "Sacred City God's Word" written in 717. During the Song Dynasty, the worship of the city god was included in the national rites, and the temple of the city god spread to all provinces, states, and counties.

This indicates that the inhabitants of India were also called Paladins (i.e., Brahmins) in ancient times. Some scholars have suggested that Paledi refers to the indigenous peoples of the region before the arrival of the Aryans in India, whose civilizational remains were found in Harappa and Mohenzo-Daro. There is some controversy, however, as to whether the Paladins were descendants of the King of Borodino. India existed both in the Paleolithic and the Neolithic. The ancient Indian civilization of the Indus River in Pakistan is one of the earliest ancient civilizations in the world, and at least 2500 B.C., there was an ancient Indian-created civilization in the Indus Valley in Pakistan, and because the earliest known sites of this civilization are located in what is now Pakistan's Harappa and Mohenzo-Daro, so this civilization is also called the Indus Valley civilization or the Harappa civilization. The ancient Indians established a strict social hierarchy, but the civilization collapsed suddenly around 2000 B.C., the river basin civilization collapsed, and the carrier languages and scripts of the culture collapsed, and no one understood them. The reasons for the breakdown of ancient Indian civilization are still unclear in the archaeological world. Around 1500 BC, the Aryans from northwestern India invaded the Indian and northern Ganges river basins of northwestern India, and gradually settled and engaged in agricultural activities over the following centuries. The foreign languages brought in by the Aryans replaced the local languages, culturally integrated with the locals, creating the classical Vedic culture. And this civilization is several centuries later than the Indus civilization of the Indus Valley, so relatively, it's commonly called the Ganges civilization.

For the first time, Vietnam declared a state of epidemic prevention, including the inclusion of new forms of pneumonia as a zoonotic disease. On February 3, a further 1 confirmed case was reported, bringing the total to 8 cases. A 29-year-old woman, who had worked in Wuhan, China, traveled to China on the 17th by China Southern Airlines CZ8315, and three of her eight colleagues had been diagnosed with the disease. On February 4, the number of confirmed cases increased to nine. In addition, a 30-year-old man, who had worked in Wuhan, China, traveled to China on the 17th by China Southern Airlines CZ8315, four of the eight colleagues with him had been diagnosed with the disease. On the same night, another confirmed case was reported, bringing the total to 10. Additionally, a woman from Yongfu Province was a relative of an infected person who had previously returned to Vietnam from Wuhan, China. On February 6, two more confirmed cases were reported, bringing the total to 12. Additionally, Vietnamese from Yongfu Province were closely associated with the previously diagnosed patients. On 7 February, the number of confirmed cases increased to 13. A 29-year-old woman, who had worked in Wuhan, China, traveled to China on the 17th on China Southern Airlines CZ8315, and five of her eight colleagues had been diagnosed with the disease. On February 11th, Vietnam added one new case, bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 15. The latest case is a three-month-old baby, infected by a grandmother, who was diagnosed with a new type of coronavirus on February 9. On February 13, the father of the fifth case was tested positive, and the number of confirmed cases in Vietnam increased to 16. On February 25th, the 16th case was released from the hospital after being negatively tested for COVID-19, which temporarily released Vietnam from the outbreak of COVID-19, and all confirmed cases have been discharged.

Idi Amin Dada (17 May 1925 – 16 August 2003) was the third President of Uganda from 1971 to 1979. In 1946, Amin joined the British colonial unit King's African Rifles and deployed to Kenya and Uganda. Following Uganda's independence, Amin was promoted to at least the rank of general in the Ugandan Army, became its commander-in-chief, and deposed Milton Obote in the January 1971 military coup d'état, seizing power. As head of state, Amin further upgraded his rank to Marshal. Human rights abuses, political persecution, ethnic persecution, summary executions, extrajudicial executions, nepotism, political corruption, and economic mismanagement under Amin's rule were all serious problems in Uganda. International observers and human rights organizations estimate the number of people killed under his rule at 100,000. Initially, Amin's policy was more pro-Western and gained support from Israel, but later shifted to Libya (Mu'anmar Gaddafi), Zaire (Mobutu Sese Seko), the Soviet Union and the East German Front. Discontent within Uganda and Amin's covetousness of the Kagera district of Tanzania led to the outbreak of the U Than War in 1978. The war ended Amin's eight-year reign, and Amin himself fled Libya, then moved to Saudi Arabia where he lived for the rest of his life, dying on 16 August 2003. Amin's year of birth is disputed: he claims to have been born in 1926 in a small village near Koboko in northwestern Uganda, but is also reported to have been born in Kampala in 1925.

In response, the government of the Republic of China pointed out that the British version was inconsistent with reality. On 21 September 1999, a major earthquake struck Taiwan, and the United Kingdom sent six search and rescue teams to rescue the people. In September 2003, the European Parliament and a group of MEPs from the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain jointly launched the Marco Polo Club.

Zhang An-Lao (Chinese: 張安樂; pinyin: Zhang An-Lao; born March 13, 1948), nicknamed "White Wolf", was born in Hongdong County, Linfen City, Shanxi Province, and moved to Taiwan with his parents as a child. He is the current Chairman of the China Unification Promotion Party and Honorary Director of the Democratic Progressive Party of China. Zhang Anlu is one of Taiwan's famous gangster bamboo gangsters. After returning to Taiwan in 2013 after being found not guilty of organized crime, he began actively engaged in political activities on both sides, and advocated the unification of the two sides, one country, two systems, etc. Born in 1948 in Nanjing City, Zhang's parents moved to Taiwan the following year when he was a baby, and as a child he and his mother lived in Taoyuan Taoyuan National Primary School, and after graduating from elementary school, moved to Zhonghe Anle Road in Taipei Prefecture. His father was a university professor, his mother was a female teacher, and when he was a junior high school student in Taipei, he attended the Taipei Provincial Taipei Jianchuan Gaku Junior High School, while in school, he contacted campus gang members, joined the local "Nankai Road Gang" and was active in Jianchuan Gaku and Taipei Botanical Garden. During his high school years, he became acquainted with Chen Kai-rei and others, and gradually became a prominent figure in the gang under the nickname "white wolf", and was arrested by the police for attempted murder and imprisoned for 28 days for allegedly shooting and wounding a police constable in Yonghe Township. After graduating from high school, he went on to study at the National Taiwan Normal University Affiliated Secondary School Day School, and after graduating from high school, he studied at the History Department of the Tanjiang College of Arts and Sciences.

According to the guidelines of the Inter-Agency Standing Committee on Mental Health and Psychosocial Support, the COVID-19 outbreak could have some long-term consequences. As anticipated by the Inter-Agency Standing Committee on Standards of Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (IASC), some long-term consequences include: deterioration of social networks and the economy, discrimination against COVID-19 healers, potentially deepening hostility towards frontline workers and the government, potentially deepening anger and aggression against children, and potential mistrust of information provided by official authorities. United Nations: Universal Postal Union Japan: Ministry of Posts State Council Central Committee of the Communist Party of China Central Military Commission Survey and Mapping Agency National Post Office, is a sub-ministerial state bureau administered by the Ministry of Transportation of the People's Republic of China, responsible for postal administration. The National Post Office is responsible for the formulation of postal industry policies and planning, as well as for the supervision of postal services (including express services). In 1948, the Central Committee of the People's Government of the People's Republic of China established the General Administration of Posts and Telecommunications, which was responsible for postal and telecommunications affairs. In 1949, the People's Government of the People's Republic of China reorganized the Department of Transportation of the People's Government of the People's Republic of China into the Department of Postal Administration of the People's Republic of China. On November 1, 1949, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the Central People's Government was established, and in December of the same year, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications convened the National Postal Conference, which accepted the industry of the former Postal Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation of the Republic of China, and assigned it to the People's Postal Administration; on December 27, the Ninth Meeting of the Central Postal Economic Committee decided to establish the Postal Bureau. In 1954, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the People's Republic of China was established. In 1970, the former Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications was merged into the Ministry of Transportation of the People's Republic of China, known as the "General Administration of Posts and Telecommunications of the Ministry of Transportation". In 1973, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the People's Republic of China was restored. On March 1, 1994, the State Council approved the Ministry of Postal and Telecommunications' institutional reform program, separating the Postal General Bureau from the administrative hierarchy of institutions, becoming a professionally accounted enterprise bureau. On October 4, 1995, the Postal Bureau registered with the State Administration of Commerce and Industry of the People's Republic of China a business license as a legal entity, and the company was named "China Postal and E-mail Administration Bureau" (Chinese: 中国郵政總局).

At the beginning of the Ming Dynasty, the Yuan Dynasty still followed the provincial system, until the abolition of provincialism in 1376, the first administrative district "in line with the Song Dynasty code", the establishment of the Chen announcement ministry, the punishment according to the inspection ministry, the command ministry, the division of civil affairs, supervision, military. In the latter half of the Ming Dynasty, the power of the three departments was gradually taken over by the Chubu system, and Chubu often became the supreme commander of the unified power of the provinces. In the first year of the Han Dynasty, military guards were established throughout the country, and one guard headed by Du Wei was established, until 1375, when Du Wei was changed to Du Commander-in-Chief, commonly referred to as Duxi, who administered the military affairs of the guards under his command, the Ministry of Military Affairs, and the Five Military Governor-General's Office. In 1376, he abolished the Bureau of Central Affairs, and instead established the Ministry of Envoys, commonly referred to as Buseishi or Hanshi, which administered local civil affairs and was directly linked to the six central ministries. In addition, there is also the Office of the Attorney General, which is responsible for supervising the administration of justice, and the Attorney General's Office, which is responsible for supervising the administration of justice. In 1406, the Ming army overthrew the Vietnamese Hu dynasty and established the Kutian tribe in its homeland, but the Vietnamese civilians never ceased to revolt until 1427, when the Ming army was defeated in the Blue Mountain uprising, and the Kutian tribe was established by the Later Han dynasty. The districts of the Ming Dynasty were mainly divided into bureaucratic divisions, prefectural divisions, state divisions, and county divisions.

On January 1, 1912, the provisional government of the Republic of China was established in Nanjing, where Sun Yat-sen was sworn in as the provisional president. On January 9, Jiangsu Governor's Office was relocated to Suzhou. After that, he abolished Jiangsu Governor's Office, established Jiangsu North Governor's Office, Xuzhou Military Governor's Office, and became the military branch of Jiangsu Governor's Office. The House of Representatives was reorganized into the House of Representatives. After the temporary government moved north, Jiangsu Governor's Office was relocated to Nanjing. On 19 November, he was appointed Governor of Guangdong Province. In December, the military and civilian governments were dissolved, and the Ministry of Administration was established. On February 15, Yuan was elected by the Senate as the Provisional President, followed by Sun Yat-sen's official announcement of his resignation as the Provisional President, the Provisional Senate's decision to move the government to Beijing, and in March, after the Provisional Government moved north, Yuan's military conference in April, formulated a national disarmament plan, demanding that the first step be to cut the national army by half. Yuan appointed Huang Xing to stay in Nanjing, the main purpose of which was to use Huang Xing to demobilize the army, but Huang thought that the time for construction had come and that the Yuan clan could be promised through democracy, so he aggressively disbanded the Jiangnan region, which was occupied by the Allied forces, such as the revolutionary army near Nanjing, in just two months' time by three divisions instead of two. Thus, by the time Yuan was preparing to kill the revolutionaries by force, the revolutionaries were in an extremely unfavorable position. In the first two years of the People's Republic (1913), the Kuomintang, composed of the Allies and other groups, won an overwhelming majority of seats in the first parliamentary elections, and when the Kuomintang deputy chairman Song Kyoren was preparing to organize a cabinet, he was assassinated on March 25 at Shanghai Railway Station. Sun Yat-sen returned from Japan to Shanghai, discussed countermeasures, firmly insisted on the suppression of Yuan Shikai, but the opinion within the party was extremely unified, Huang Xing and others believed that it was militarily inadequate to counter Yuan Shikai, and therefore advocated a legal solution, only a minority of the party, including Li Rujun, supported Sun Yat-sen's opinion, and in April and May, the Kuomintang held two secret meetings in Shanghai, but failed to unite opinions and make a decision.

However, after a month of court hearings in February and March 1953, the charges were dropped. Around 1954, VOA's headquarters moved from New York City to Washington, D.C. The advent of inexpensive, low-cost transistors has led to a significant increase in the number of shortwave radio listeners. During the Hungarian Revolution of 1956, the broadcasting of VOA was considered controversial, as the continued hints of VOA made it possible for many Hungarian refugees and revolutionaries to receive Western aid, but ultimately did not. Throughout the Cold War, many governments targeting VOA interfered with its broadcasts. In the early 1980s, Voice of America began a $1.3-billion reconstruction program to improve its broadcasting capabilities. During the period of martial law in Poland from 1981 to 1983, VOA's Polish programming was expanded to seven hours a day. In 1985, VOA Europe was founded, a satellite-broadcasting arm of AM, FM and cable television throughout Europe. The network uses a modern format, broadcasting popular music songs, VOA news, and locally interesting topics 24 hours a day. In January 1997, as a cost-cutting measure, Voice of America Europe was shut down without prior notice. In 1989, U.S. Voice expanded its Mandarin and Cantonese broadcasts to promote the democratic movement in China, including demonstrations in Tiananmen Square. In 1993, the Clinton administration proposed cutting funding for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, arguing that post-Cold War Europe no longer needed political propaganda, but this was not accepted by Congress.

According to anthropological linguistics, Taiwan is the origin of the South Pacific South Island language family, i.e. the majority of the South Island people migrated from Taiwan, which can be said to be the starting point of Taiwan's foreign relations. In the Three Kingdoms Chronicle, Wu Guo appointed an army to land on the Isle of Wight, but it is disputed whether the Isle of Wight belonged to Taiwan. In the early days of the Yuan Dynasty, the Penghuzhai Prosecutor's Office was established, and it was intended to invade Taiwan. In 1593, the Nagon Incident in Taiwan occurred, in which a Japanese vassal of the Toyotomi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), Masashige Harada (原田孫七郎, Harada Masashige). In 1670, the Zheng dynasty of the Tainan region of Taiwan signed a trade treaty with the United Kingdom, the first formal diplomatic treaty in Taiwan. Taiwan was subsequently ruled by the Qing dynasty and Japan, and its foreign relations were integrated into the Qing and Japanese diplomacy. In 1945, when Japan surrendered, the Republic of China took over Taiwan. In 1949, the Republic of China government was defeated in the Civil War and subsequently seized Taiwan, declaring itself the only legitimate government representing "all of China" internationally, after the Battle of Kinmen, withdrew from the United Nations, and the United States severed ties with it. After the United States enacted the Taiwan Relations Act, the establishment of the U.S. Seventh Fleet remained a major mission to defend Taiwan, and Taiwan's identity began to rise. In 1984, Taipei participated for the first time in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles under the name of China Taipei, and began to use the plum blossom flag instead of the blue sky, white sun and full red, after which foreign relations began to be based on the Olympic model, no longer insisting on itself as the only legitimate government representing "all of China", and actively participated in international related activities, maintained to this day. The political connection between Taiwan and ancient China has been interpreted differently by scholars, but the inclusion of the Great Qing Dynasty map after 1684 is more uncontroversial, but in fact the so-called map refers to the western part of Taiwan, the last Nan Hall was added in 1875, only 20 years away from the actual date, and the Qing Dynasty still did not rule most of the indigenous people of the high mountains.

The Taiwanese Sociological Association (Taiwanese: 臺灣社会学会) is a social science organization in Taiwan. It was founded in 1930 in Shanghai, China, as the "Chinese Society of Social Sciences" (Chinese: 中國社会学社), founded on the initiative of Sun Yat-sen, Xu Shilian and other scholars, was the first "national legal academic group" established in the Chinese academic community, and in 1971 published the "Chinese Journal of Social Sciences" as an academic journal of the institution. It was not until the 1980s that the organization began to organize regular, larger-scale academic activities. In 1995, after more than forty years of publication, the Taiwan Sociological Society changed its name to "Taiwan Sociological Society", and the institutional publication was renamed "Taiwan Sociological Journal". In 2000, the name of the society was changed again to "Taiwan Society of Social Sciences" until now. The Society's mission is to study the theory of sociology, social problems, and social administration. The main functions of the association are divided into: individual members, group members, honorary members, sponsored members. Pierre de Fermat also independently discovered this coordinate system, including the three-dimensional coordinate system, but it was not published. Both Descartes and Fermat had a single coordinate axis. When Frans van Schooten and his students translated Geometry into Latin in 1649, they introduced concepts to explain some of its ideas, including the second coordinate axis. The Cartesian coordinate system underpins the calculus invented by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Leibniz. After the Cartesian coordinate system, people created more coordinate systems, like the polar coordinate system in the plane, and the sphere coordinate system and the cylindrical coordinate system in three-dimensional space. A two-dimensional orthogonal coordinate system is usually defined by two mutually perpendicular coordinate axes, usually called the x-axis and the y-axis, respectively; the intersection of the two coordinate axes, called the origin, is usually denoted by O, both meaning "zero" and the French initial "Origine". Each axis points in a particular direction. The coordinate axis of these two different lines determines a plane, called the xy-plane, also known as the Cartesian plane. Normally, as long as the two coordinate axes are perpendicular to each other, their direction is not affected by the analytic problem, but habitually, the x-axis is horizontally pendulous, called the horizontal axis, usually pointing to the right; the y-axis is vertically pendulous, called the vertical axis, usually pointing upwards. Such a positional relationship between two coordinate axes is called a two-dimensional right-hand coordinate system, or right-hand system. If you draw this right-handed system on a transparent piece of paper, and you rotate it in the plane no matter how, the result is called the right-handed system; but if you rotate the piece of paper, the coordinate system that you see on the back is called the left-handed system.

From August 21 to October 7, 1944, representatives of the United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union, and China met at the Dunbarton Oaks, an ancient manor near Washington. The meeting laid out the basic outline of the UN Charter, and resolved the main issues surrounding the establishment of the United Nations. When discussing the composition of the Security Council, the United States initially proposed four permanent and seven non-permanent members, later proposed that France be admitted as the fifth permanent member, and added that it might later propose adding a Latin American member as the sixth. The Affiliated Senior High School of National Taiwan Normal University (HSNU) (Chinese: 国立臺灣師範大學附屬高級中學; pinyin: Zhu Zhong; pinyin: Zhu Zhong) is a full-time secondary school located in Xinyi Road, Da'an District, Taipei, Taiwan. Established in 1947, it is the oldest secondary school in Taiwan, and one of the most commonly referred to as "sub-secondary" schools. It is a traditional boys' school, and since 1980 it has been accepting girls in music classes and the newly established Kuninaku Department, and in 1983 it has been accepting a small number of girls in ordinary classes. In addition to regular classes, special classes such as science classes, mathematics classes, information science classes, language classes, music classes, and art classes are also offered. It is the largest high school in Taipei, with 84,251 square meters, and is conveniently located within the campus. As a result of the university's affiliation, it is known for its liberal arts culture, its rich community and student activities, and its students' advocacy that they can "play". Prior to the establishment of the Secondary School, on April 1, 1937, the then Governor-General of Taiwan established the Taipei State Third Secondary School on the site of the present-day Secondary School. At the end of World War II, on December 5, 1945, under the orders of the Taiwan Provincial Chief Executive Office, Taipei State Taipei Third Secondary School was renamed "Taiwan Provincial Taipei Third Secondary School".

The Nanzhuang Conference (Chinese: 城南庄会议) was an expanded meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) held in Nanzhuang, Fuping County, Hebei Province, China from April 30 to May 7, 1948. The five secretaries of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) Mao Zedong, Liu Shaochi, Zhou Enlai, Zhu De, Ren Bitian and Li Xianning, Zhang Jichun, Chen Yi, Awa Yu, Peng Zhen, Nie Rongzhen, Huang Jing, Lori Qing, Bo Wai, and others attended. On March 20, 1948, the former Central Committee from northeastern Shaanxi crossed the Yellow River and the Central Post-Committee meeting, led the Central Organ to Jinzhao Jiaofang District, arrived on April 13, Zhengnanzhuang and the Central Works Committee meeting. On April 25, Mao Zedong sent a telegram to Awa Yu asking him to attend a meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) to study whether the three Huano columns would cross the southern Yangtze River to fight on the outer front. On 29 April, Awayu and others arrived in Jingnanzhuang. An extended meeting of the Registry was held on 30 April in the southern town of Chengnanzhuang, Jinzhao Military District. The meeting discussed the adoption of three aspects of the "Army forward, production one inch, strengthening discipline." It also adopted the slogan of the CPC Central Committee commemorating the "Fifty-first" Labor Day, as modified by Mao Zedong. The meeting decided to merge Jinchahe and Jinhe Luyuan into the North China Liberation Zone, establishing the Central Plains Party Military Organ. Mao Zedong said, "When we arrived in Jinchai, just as when we arrived in Xingguo in Jiangxi, the crowd saw us all smiling. On May 18, 1948, Mao Zedong's residence in Zhengnanzhuang was heavily bombed by the National Army Air Force. The Chengnanzhuang Revolutionary Memorial Museum, built in 1972, completely preserved the former sites of the Jiangsu Military District Command and Mao Zedong and other central leaders of comrades' work and life, was designated by the provincial government as a key cultural heritage protection unit in 1982; since 1994, it has been listed by the provincial city as a demonstration base for patriotism education; in 1996, it was designated as a national cultural heritage protection unit.

Andromeda is the northern constellation, named after the Greek mythological hero Perseus, and was one of the 48 constellations listed by the 2nd-century astronomer Claudius Ptolemy. The Milky Way's galactic plane crosses the constellation Perseus, which is the brightest of the three yellow-white supergiants at 1.79 magnitudes. Many of the surrounding stars are members of the Alpha Persei open cluster, the most famous of which is the visible eclipsing binary, Uranus, a variable star associated with a mysterious legend. There are a lot of famous objects in Perseus, X Perseus is a binary star with neutron stars, GK Perseus is a nova with an apparent magnitude of 0.2 that peaked in 1901. In ancient China, it was discovered in the constellation Andromeda that two very closely spaced open clusters formed a double cluster. The Andromeda Cluster, 250 million light-years from Earth, is a very large cluster of galaxies, named after the constellation Andromeda. The annual Perseus meteor shower is a very significant meteor shower, and the radiation point is in the constellation Perseus. According to Greek mythology, Perseus was the son of Danaeus, who was ordered by King Polytheus to take the head of Gorkon Medusa. With the acceleration of the pace of life brought about by modernization and the fusion of world cultures, today's Chinese funerals are a mixture of various religions (Buddhism, Taoism), local cultures, ethnic cultures (such as Japan), etc., the main process of traditional funeral rites has been preserved, but such traditions as funeral rites, funeral dress, filial piety, etc. have been "simplified", and the complete conformity to the old Confucian system is rarely seen. Its main processes are as follows: Funeral is a Chinese funeral form, in which a lively funeral atmosphere is used to replace the previous heavy funeral atmosphere, funerals are held for the elderly who have attained the age of eighty or more, and gongs are played to praise their longevity. The five virtues are merit, wealth, longevity, health, and good fortune. According to tradition, Han people generally allow relatives who are "one hundred years old" (one hundred years old dead) or called "high" (the "high" tradition refers to those over 90 years old, but the folk generally relax to 80 years old) to mourn, because it is believed that it is not easy to live to 80 years old (even one hundred years old) and it is worth celebrating for the deceased (there are various reasons for this, this is one), and the color of the hall and the funeral should be chosen, such as pink or pink orange, not too much white dots. The function of this mode of burial is to divert the attention of the deceased's immediate relatives from grief through elaborate ethical procedures, and to foster collective unity through community gatherings. Many owners perform funerals and burials for their animals and pets. Funeral arrangements are generally similar to those of human beings. Burial methods include soil burial, cremation, gene burial, grass burial, flower burial, water burial, celestial burial, and pet owners plasticizing their pets' bodies, or making mummies for long-term preservation, or undergoing ultra-low-temperature cryogenic preservation.

China Petroleum University (East China) is a national key university under the Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, is a national "211 Engineering" and "predominant academic innovation platform project" key construction institutions, is an engineering-oriented, multi-disciplinary coordinated development of teaching and research-type university, China's first established and the largest oil high school. Nowadays, it has developed into a national key university that combines engineering as the main subject and engineering management. Former predecessor of China Petroleum University Beijing Petroleum College was founded in 1953, through four important development stages of Beijing Petroleum College, East China Petroleum College, Petroleum University, and China Petroleum University, the running system was changed from industry institutions to universities directly under the Ministry of Education. In November 1951, the first National Conference of Higher Industrial Institutions was held in Beijing. The representative of the Ministry of Fuel Industry in charge of the petroleum industry attended the meeting, calling for the cultivation of petroleum technological talents, recommending learning from the experience of the Soviet Union, establishing China's petroleum education system, not only petroleum secondary technical schools, but also formal higher petroleum institutions. It's suggested that when the conditions are ripe, we organize an oil academy in time. This was the first proposal to set up an oil academy. The General Administration of Petroleum of the Ministry of Fuel Industry of the Central People's Government first established contact with Beiyang University in Tianjin. At the request of the Fuel Industry Department, the Chemistry and Geology Departments of Beiyang University were converted into the Petroleum Refining Department and the Petroleum Geology Department, with the Petroleum Mechanical Section in the Mechanical Department, and the Mining Department was essentially converted to serve the Fuel Industry Department. The Fuel Industry Department, in cooperation with Tsinghua University's Department of Chemistry, established the Tsinghua University Fuel Laboratory. In May 1951, on the basis of the Fuel Laboratory, the Petroleum Refining Group was formed.

Unlike other Eastern European socialist states influenced by Stalinism after World War II, Yugoslavia remained independent from Moscow. This was partly because of Tito's strong leadership, and partly because, when the Communist Party of Yugoslavia liberated Yugoslavia, the Red Army provided only limited assistance. All of this made Yugoslavia the only Eastern European socialist state to remain under pressure, independent of Moscow, until the late 1980s and early 1990s, when Tito made Yugoslavia proud of its independence. What the Yugoslav legislature did was a graphic decision made by the Politburo. The National Security Agency (NSA) of the Yugoslav secret police operates much more strictly than those in other parts of Eastern Europe, but is still regarded as a formidable tool of government control. The media in Yugoslavia is still severely constrained by Western standards, but it still enjoys greater freedom. Nationalist groups are a special target in the eyes of the authorities. The secret police, the National Security Agency, assassinated "enemies of the state" in exile abroad. The Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries often accused Yugoslavia of practicing Trotskyism and social democracy. At the same time, the non-aligned countries failed to form a third group, especially after the 1973 oil crisis led to a split. Despite this, the Soviet Union's attitude changed during the course of Fascism. Brezhnev cooled relations once again (though they never deteriorated to the point of conflict with Stalin). Yugoslavia supported Czechoslovak leader Alexander Dubček during the Prague Spring of 1968, and then established a special relationship (not all the time) with outspoken Romanian President Nicolae Ceausescu.

A territorial sea, also known as territorial water, is an area of water extending 3 to 12 nautical miles from the baseline of the territorial sea, that is, from the land territory of a coastal state beyond its inland waters, or from the territorial waters of an archipelago state beyond its territorial waters. However, the actual situation may differ from country to country. The sovereignty of a State over its territorial sea, its airspace and its continental shelf, as a part of its territory, is inviolable, but his State may exercise the right of passage over its territorial sea. The territorial sea was established on the basis of three principles: the state must occupy its coast for security purposes and protect its coast from offshore waters; the state must inspect and control ships in and out of its coastal harbours for commercial, financial or political purposes; and the state must possess the resources in its coastal waters in order to maintain the livelihoods of its inhabitants. The width of the territorial sea was at the heart of the controversy. From the 16th to the 17th centuries, the concepts were ambiguous. Initially, it was believed that this was due to the proximity of the sea. Later Dutch international jurists, such as Grotius, used the "cannon shot" as the area of control of the sea. Countries in the Mediterranean have also adopted the "shore range" argument. The Scandinavian countries of northern Europe define their territorial sea as a fixed distance along the coast. In the aforementioned claims, the "shore gun range" was generally accepted, and since the average 18th-century gun range did not exceed 3 nautical miles (5.6 km), some nations set their territorial sea width at 3 nautical miles. By 1945, the custom was gradually being changed to 12 miles (22 km) or even 200 miles (370 km). The 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea defined the limit as 12 nautical miles.
