The center of the Milky Way is marked as a strong radio source called Ursa Major A* (remarkable Ursa Major A star). Centered on A* Centauri, the orbital motion of the object indicates that there is a massive dense object there.

After the March 1965 general elections, Mobutu and Casabuba returned to a political stalemate. Mobutu launched his second coup d'état in November 1965, taking control of the country. Under Mobutu, the Congo (renamed Saï in 1971) was transformed into a dictatorship until Mobutu was overthrown in 1997. Congolese colonial rule began in the late 19th century. Since Belgium's independence from the Netherlands in 1830, the kingdom's lack of international power and prestige frustrated King Leopold II of Belgium, who sought to persuade the government to support expansion around the then undeveloped colonies of the Congo Basin. The idea was so controversial with the government that Leopold eventually founded his own colony. Many supportive Western countries viewed Rio de Janeiro as an effective buffer against power struggles between the colonies, so Rio de Janeiro's private colony, the Free State of the Congo, was recognized internationally in 1885. Belgium's rule in the Congo was based on the so-called "colonial trinity" of state, missionaries and private companies. During the 1940s and 1950s, Congo experienced unprecedented levels of urbanization, and the colonial government launched various development programs aimed at making the territory a "model colony." The African nationalism movement developed in the 1950s outside of the Congo, mainly in the "évolués". The movement split several ethnically and geographically divergent political parties and groups. The greatest enemy of the Congolese national movement was the Abako League, led by Joseph Kasawubu. Despite being Africa's largest nationalist party, the National Movement has many different factions and positions on many issues.

Zhang Zhaodong (Chinese: 簡肇棟; pinyin: Zhang Zhaodong; born 18 August 1955) is a Taiwanese politician, doctor, and a member of the Democratic Progressive Party. He was elected to the Fifth Legislative Council at the end of 2001 and was re-elected at the end of 2004, but was defeated again at the beginning of 2008. He is a former member of the New York City Legislative Assembly. In September 2011, he resigned from the Legislative Council, resigned from the next Legislative Council election, and resigned from politics. On 18 December 2007, during the parliamentary elections, it was announced that Jiang was alleged to have bribed a Chinese nationalist candidate, Jiang Lianfu, during the parliamentary elections in mid-November 2007, when he visited Chen Lianji (Taiping City representative) and handed over 50,000 yuan in advance cash to Chen Lianji, asking Chen Lianji to help "pull people" and "vote" during the parliamentary elections, which was interpreted as "an attempt to tie up and solidify votes". On October 9, 2009, the Taiwan High Court of Justice ruled that Jiang's nomination was invalid, and he was re-elected by the People's Party of China. On January 9, 2010, he defeated Yu Wenqin, the current mayor of Taipei, who had been nominated by the Kuomintang, and was elected to the 7th Legislative Council. On September 11, 2011, in the middle of the night, Jin Zhao drove a car into Taichung City's Dalijiajie Road and killed a man who was drunk and fell on the road.

Initially, the Luming armies killed numerous enemies and prisoners, and were victorious. However, Yan Sui Zhen Ming's army was defeated in a brave attack by the enemy, and Liu Yu was besieged. Mao Tse-tung's army attacked the northwestern mountains of Ise-jo Castle, almost defeating it, but was killed in a sudden mid-air battle. All the Ming armies wanted to retreat, they were furious, they would retreat, one thousand households would be beheaded as a warning, the Ming army would only stop the footsteps, they would do their best to kill, and Liu Yu would be rescued. The Ming court heard about the defeat and death of Mao Tse-tung, negotiated with the military commanders, such as Xuan Shu Cheng-shin, Shuning Hou Zhu Yong, Ding Xiang Count Guo-dong, and threatened the four rebels of the Northern Mongolian Army, sent Zhu Yong with 40,000 troops to Beijing. Zhu Yong demanded to be rewarded before going on the expedition. During the cabinet negotiations, Peng Zhen, a university student, dismissed Zhu Yong because he believed that the current strength of the Manchu rebels was sufficient to stabilize the situation; in a military report, he said, "The Ming army has besieged the Manchu rebels, will soon be victorious, why send more troops?" After hearing this, the army commander, Shang Shu Chengxin, expressed his resentment, claiming that if the loyalists were defeated, he would kill his general and send his troops out again. Afterwards, the rebels surrounded and persuaded all four rebels to surrender, and the rebels invited them to meet with them. KMT and Liu Yu rode on horseback to the rendezvous, and Ma Wensheng and dozens of his cavalry arrived, shouting for the surrender of Manchuria. In the meantime, the Mongolian army was reported to have entered the Ko River valley, so he led the main part of the Ming army back to Kugen, leaving 3,000 elite soldiers to fight the rebels. The Ming army captured more than 1,000 people, except for the 4th of March, fire, etc., and all the criminals were sent to the Beijing division (the next year the 4th of March was delayed to be executed in Beijing), the remaining 800 people were beheaded in the army.

In March 1951, Zhang was appointed Chief of Staff of the East China Military District. In July 1951, Chen Yi asked Zhang to investigate a plan to capture the coastal islands of Fujian and Zhejiang, and Zhang proposed a "fight from north to south". On 29 April 1952, Zhang Zhen, the Minister of Warfare of the Central Military Commission, was commissioned by the East China Military Region to report to the Central Military Commission and Mao Zedong that two divisions of the 21st Army, then stationed in eastern Zhejiang and northeastern Minchuan, would attack and liberate the other coastal islands of eastern Zhejiang with the support of the Navy and Air Force. Mao Zedong's advice was to wait until after the Korean Armistice to renegotiate. The 21st Army then went on to battle in the morning. In January 1953, Zhang Aiping led a team to the Fujian front line, concluding that the north-south occupation of the islands of Fujian and Zhejiang was to be replaced by the south-north occupation, that is, the first to occupy Dai, Xiao Jinmen, Non-War or Small War to occupy the other islands of Fujian and Zhejiang. The military commission approved the plan, and prepared to carry out the campaign by land and sea with 200,000 troops, first repairing airports in coastal areas of Fuqing, Dong'an, and Zhangzhou, and constructing railway embankments between Xiamen Island and mainland China. After the Korean War ended, in August 1953, the United States and the United States Army conducted the first joint military exercise in the Taiwan Strait, publicly declaring their determination to defend Taiwan militarily. At the end of 1953, Mao Zedong, at a meeting of the Military Commission in Hangzhou, suggested that the Taiwan question could be resolved. In early 1954, the Treaty of Mutual Defense between the United States and China began to be drafted. Against this backdrop, it was difficult for the PLA to strike large and small, and it could only try to find the bottom line for the U.S. military's involvement in the near-sea warfare of mainland China by attacking islands from the north to the south, in small- and medium-scale battles. Mao Zedong said: "The situation has changed, we are ready to fight Da Chen, settle the coastal islands of Zhejiang first, we expect the emperor will not intervene much.

She said: The nomination of Comrade Li Junyi is mainly based on his extensive experience, as a member of the Legislative Council since the fifth session, he has performed very well, while in each observation, he is very explosive and combative comrade from politics, and the ability of basic integration is very strong. Among the "must vote" items in the poll, the people of Tainan County had the highest support for Lee. Since then, he has continued to rise in local support, and is often nominated for Tainan County Governor today. At the end of the same year, the Ministry of Internal Affairs announced the merger of Tainan City and the elevation of Tainan County, and the election of Tainan County Governor was cancelled at the same time. As a result, he lost the opportunity to run for governor of Tainan, and the following year, Lee was declared eligible to run for the first-ever mayoral election in Tainan. In addition to Li, the first-time mayoral candidate of Tainan, he was also a colleague of Lai Qing-de, Yee-jin, and then-Chief of Tainan, Xu Xie-fai, and then-Chief of Tainan County, Su Hwan-chi. On May 7, 2010, a press conference was held in Tainan City to announce the results of the first round of the People's Party of China (PPC) mayoral election, with the five candidates receiving 44.28%, 32.60%, 18.98%, 2.35%, and 1.79% of the votes, respectively. He was elected as the first mayor of Tainan on behalf of the Communist Party of China. During his tenure as a member of the Legislative Council, Li was accused of bribery in a Chinese pharmaceutical business, sentenced to seven years and six months in the second instance of the High Court, and the Supreme Court dismissed the prosecutor's appeal in the second instance, confirming his innocence. Lee said that he was willing to forgive the High Court Judge Chen Xiaofei, the accompanying Judge Sun Huilin and the appointed Judge Chen Yuyun, as long as they were able to apologize publicly, and if he did not apologize a week later, he would take legal action, accusing the three of misconduct.

Huang Jie (Chinese: 黃杰; November 2, 1902 – January 14, 1995) was a general, politician, and poet, who was awarded the Order of the Blue Sky, the Order of the Cloud, and other decorations.He was the Commander-in-Chief of the Army, the Chief of the Presidential Staff, the Commander-in-Chief of the Security Bureau, the President of Taiwan Province, the Minister of Defense, the Executive Council and the Strategic Advisor of the Presidential Office, the Commander-in-Chief of the Second Division of the National Army, the Commander-in-Chief of the Tax Police, the Commander-in-Chief of the Eighth Army of the National Revolutionary Army, the Director of the Chengdu Central Military School Education Department, the Director of the Sixth Branch School, the Commander-in-Chief of the Eleventh Army Group, the Director of the Central Training Group, the Commander-in-Chief of the Fifth Training Command, the Commander-in-Chief of the First Army, and the Commander-in-Chief of the Taip He graduated from Changsha High School in Hunan Province. In 1924, he entered the First Infantry Division of Huangpu Military School. In January 1925, he was appointed a lieutenant colonel of the 1st Regiment of Reconnaissance and participated in the First and Second Eastern Expeditions and the Battles of Guangzhou. In September 1926, he was promoted to commanding major of the 3rd Battalion, 1st Regiment, garrisoned in Chaozhou. Between 1927 and 1928, he participated in the Northern Expedition of the National Revolutionary Army, the Battles of Longtan, Fengyang, Bengbu, Xuzhou, Teng County and Jinan. After completing the Northern Expedition, he participated in the Western Expedition. In 1930, he participated in the Second Sino-Japanese War, serving as the brigade commander of the 2nd brigade of the 1st Division. At midnight on July 11, enemy forces broke through the line, the situation was urgent, Chiang Kai-shek insisted on commanding Yanagawa Station. Huang Jie, under Chiang Kai-shek's command, led three regiments of the Department of Light and Rapid Assault, recaptured Li Dam Shu, saved danger, and achieved great success, which is written in Chiang Kai-shek's Diary and the history of the National Revolutionary Army.

It is usually divided into "near the Qing Ming" and "near the Little Qing Ming": "The third day of the first month of March, in ancient times it was called the first day of the month, Zhangzhou people called it the third day of the month, dedicated to the ancestor's tomb." And the people of Quanzhou called the tomb of Qingming, which is called the tomb of Yeoming. The custom in Quanzhou is to sweep graves for a few days before and after the Ming Dynasty. The first tomb, called the "New Tomb," is usually laid on the second day of February. In the second and third years, the cemetery is usually cleaned for one day between the Spring Festival and the day before the Ming Dynasty. From the fourth year onwards, the cemetery can be visited on the day before or after the Ming Dynasty. According to the customs of Quanzhou, it is absolutely permissible to sweep graves on clear days, and it is not necessary to choose the day to be avoided. In Zhangzhou, more than half of the people choose to sweep graves near the small Qingming at the beginning of March, but due to the Republic of China government's designation of Qingming Festival as a national holiday, to coincide with the holiday, the day of Qingming Festival gradually became the main day of sweeping graves in southern Taiwan. It is customary in Hokkien to step on the grave of another person while walking along the way and say "borrowed" without regard to guilt. When they found the tomb, the ancestors prayed, telling the land gods and the ancestors to start sweeping the graves. It can also be used to repair the cracks in the cemetery, or to paint the gravestones, and when it is done, press grave paper on the grave, representing the repair of the ancestors' chambers. The tomb does not carry offerings, but only hammer sickles, paint, incense, paper money, and wine; if it does carry offerings, it is called a tomb; if it is a tomb, it is called a tomb; or if it has prepared boiled eggs or salted duck eggs, the ancestors of the ancestors throw egg shells on the tombstone or tomb mound, symbolizing the resurrection of the shells, the resurrection of life, other grenadier shells, clam shells, clam shells, shrimp shells, etc., for the same allegory.

After Zheng Shilong, Zheng Hongkui, and Zhou Zhuang were appointed as emperors by the Tang dynasty, the year Longwu, was for Emperor Shaozong Xiang. When the emperor of Shao Zongxiang first became the king of Tang Dynasty, he served in the domain of Nanyang, and when he became the governor of Nanyang County, he often referred to him as "the son of Nanyang, the son of the fish, the son of the water, and we all have a reason." In the spring of 1646, the Qing army led by Leqde Khan invaded Jiangxi, and the Tang troops left Changsha. On April 14, the Qing army attacked Ganzhou, Yang Tinglin died in custody for half a year, and Ho Teng-kao sat unable to save himself, only dispatched the Count of Nan'an Hao Yongzhong with more than 10,000 horses to enter Longquan (present-day Suichuan County, Jiangxi Province), Hao Yongzhong left Changsha, passed through Hengzhou, and from September 2 to Chenzhou, i.e., Guangxi. On the third day of October, the Qing army attacked the city, until late on the fourth day, the Qing army entered the city to lay siege, the bees invaded the city, the city and the streets were destroyed, Yang Tinglin threw himself into the pond, and at dawn, the Qing army occupied Ganzhou City. After the defeat of the Qing army in Yuezhou, Fujianxi, he resisted the Qing army. Early in 1647, Confucius, Shang Keqi, and Geng Zhongming led the Qing army to attack Hunan, and in March they captured Yuezhou, Xiangyin, and Changsha. The anti-seizure line split. The governor of Hunan, He Dang-jao, and the general of the army retreated. In the year 1648, Emperor Yongle resided in Guilin, and Gafu Dangzhao was appointed Grand Master, and Jinzhao was appointed Marquis, and his descendants succeeded him. In March, the Ming surrendered Jin Xianghuan, Li Chengmun, and others in Jiangxi, Guangdong to overthrow the Qing, the Qing army retreated from Hunan to consolidate Wuchang, and the anti-Qing situation recovered. He surrendered, taking Quanzhou, Yongzhou, Hengzhou. The remainder of the Daesun army, led by Tadachika, occupied a large number of prefectures in Hunan Province and besieged Changsha. He then orders his men to leave the camp and prepare to attack Changsha, but they are unable to do so for a long time.

At the time, the most prominent figures in the political scene were the City Council Secretary Lai Dai-nong, in addition to Zhang Liao Guiyang, the Mayor of Zhouzhi National Secondary School, and Zhang Ziyuan, a lawyer, who actively campaigned for the nomination. However, due to the high level of tension in Zhang's territory, a clash broke out between Lai Dai-nong and Zhang Liao-kyo, which resulted in the greatest possible counterattack. :82–83, the final local powers voted for Lin Baiyan, and Lin Baiyan was elected mayor with the support of the Kuomintang by 137,174 votes, defeating the more than 60,000 votes of Tsang Wenpo. On December 20, 1981, Lin became the ninth mayor of Taichung City. At the beginning of the administration, Lin Bairong also proposed a new reform, "One Hundred City Councillors", with the aim of recruiting experts from all walks of life in the city and promoting the city. However, at the time of the job advertisement, there were objections that the city executive was the head of the mayor's office, and that the councillors did not comply with the city's organizational rules. We sent the banyan tree back and forth through the valley, and then we shouted a stop. This led to a lack of perseverance on the part of the deputies at the tenth first congress of the City Council in May 1981. :93-94 On the local budget issue, before compiling the 72nd annual budget, Lin Bairong declared to solve the actual local problems, especially to hold construction talks in each district, which was originally welcomed by local representatives, and made a number of speeches. However, in the municipality's membership council deliberation stage, the local demands were put on hold due to the positional opinions of the various units. During the first session of the 10th City Council, the issue also became a matter of district councillors attacking Lin Bairong for not paying attention to his proposals, criticizing Lin Bairong for failing to control city units, councillor Li Yuhua more criticized and suggested Lin Bairong should reduce unnecessary remuneration, spend more time in municipal construction.

The modern art of wine pairing is based on the idea that the characteristics of wine and food (such as taste and texture) are different, that some characteristics can be harmoniously combined, and that some characteristics conflict with each other. Finding the harmonious elements to enjoy at the same time can make the whole eating experience more enjoyable. In expensive restaurants, waitresses recommend food-cooked wines to their guests. Most wines are packaged in glass bottles and sold after being sealed with corkscrews, but traditional corkscrew production is low and has aging problems, and the quality of the packaging is not perfect, and in recent years the number of metal bottle caps and synthetic corkscrews has been increasing. But traditional wooden stoppers are much more environmentally friendly. Wine is a natural and fragile beverage, vulnerable to light, heat, vibration, and excessive humidity. Traditionally, wine cellars have provided a lightless and warm environment for wine, in addition to protecting it from damage from unstable external environments, and also providing it with a good shelf life. Therefore, the current home-use of thermal wine cellar, its setting conditions mostly refer to the environment of the wine cellar, temperature about 14 °C ± 2 °C, humidity maintained 65% ± 10%. However, this is only according to the conservation conditions obtained by traditional wisdom, and has not been rigorously scientifically investigated. The flavor of the wine depends on the grape variety. Because different grapes produce different aromas, drink differently, and collect differently, the flavors can be very different. The varieties of grapes vary widely, and the geographical location, latitude, soil and climate of different regions all have suitable varieties for cultivation. Despite centuries of strict laws that have been handed down, each region has clearly defined the grape varieties that can be grown.

After the end of the war in 1945, the conflict between the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) on issues such as disarmament, constitutional reform, and a unified government was again highlighted, leading to a series of military conflicts between the two sides. The Communist Party named the armed forces it controlled the People's Liberation Army (PLA); after the three major battles, the Battle of Liao Shen, the Battle of Huaihai, and the Battle of Pingjin, the Communist Party gained absolute military dominance in the northeast and northern China. On the other hand, the Kuomintang ended its dictatorship in 1947, reorganized the party-led National Government into a constitutional Government of the Republic of China, reorganized the National Revolutionary Army into the National Army of the Republic of China, issued a counterinsurgency order, and implemented financial reform measures such as gold coins to revive the weakened Chinese economy after the war. In April 1949, the two sides negotiated a ceasefire in Beiping but failed, and the Chinese People's Liberation Army launched the Battle of the Changjiang River, occupied the Republic of China's capital Nanjing, the first major city of Shanghai, and gradually seized most of China's territory, and in 1987 opened an unofficial mechanism for exchanges. The root cause of the Communist Civil War was ideological differences between the two parties. In China, where democracy has not yet been built, no political party can elevate its claims to national policy by attracting votes. The KMT's political assertion developed from the founding of the People's Republic of China to the 1920s, and was formed during the Northern Expeditionary War, with Sun Yat-sen's "Three-People'sism, Five-Power Constitution" as the main guiding ideology, striving to achieve China's unity, democracy, and prosperity through three stages: military, educational, and constitutional. Its ultimate goal was to establish a republic based on the Western model of democracy, with the nationalization of the army and the political realization of democracy.

The Battle of Zhuqing, from June to March 1356, Zhu Yuanzhang captured Zhuqing Road (now Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province) to establish the foundations of the war. Shortly after Zhu Yuanzhang occupied Chuzhou (now Chuzhou City, Anhui Province) and Wazhou (now Wa County, Anhui Province), the leader of the Red Scarf Army, Guo Zi Xing, died of illness, and Zhu Yuanzhang led his troops. Zhu Yuanzhang's Ministry of Mines, on the advice of Feng Guozhi and others, decided to cross the river to seek a festival, to establish a base, and decided to mine the stone first. In the spring and autumn, the leader of the insurrection, Yu Tong Hai, was attached to Zhu Yuanzhang. Zhu Yuanzhang actively trained the navy, first defeating the Yuan Dynasty's troops in the Hague, occupying the mouth of Yuxi (now the northern bank of the southeastern Yangtze River in Chao County, Anhui Province). In June, the admiral crossed the river, attacked the Ox Islands, captured the stone, led the army along the river, and the winds returned. Afterwards, Zhu Yuanzhang sent men to cut the cables and let the boat go east to the river, so that it did not return. He then attacked Taiping Road (present-day Dantou County, Anhui Province), and in the Yuan Dynasty, the Emperor Zhuangzhao and his troops refused to surrender, Zhuangzhao hurriedly attacked, destroyed Taiping, the Emperor Zhuangzhao fled, and Zhuangzhao occupied Taiping. The Yuan army counterattacked, and the Yuan Dynasty commander Zhongzhao Banzi led a naval force to Zhejiang, blockaded Gu Yuekou, and cut off Zhu Yuanzhang's main line of communications with Wa Prefecture. The Chinese commander of the Yuan Dynasty militia, Chen No-shin, led tens of thousands of troops to attack Taiping, Zhu Yuanzhang sent Xu Da, Deng Yu, and Tang Wei led the army to meet the enemy, then sent another general around the road to the rear of the Yuan army, both sides crushed the Yuan army, the Yuan army was defeated, Chen No-shin was captured and surrendered. In July, Zhu Yuanzhang's commander, Zhang Tianyu, led an army and surrendered General Chen No to attack Zhuqing, but was unsuccessful. In August, Zhu Yuanzhang ordered Xu Da's army to attack Lishui, Liyang, and other places near Qingcheng.

Yongzhou, also known as Yongling, is a city in southwestern Hunan province of the People's Republic of China. It lies northwest of Shaoyang City, northeast of Lin Hengyang City, east of Chenzhou City, southeast of Qingyuan City in Guangdong Province, south of Hezhou City in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, west of Guilin City in Guangxi. It is located at the northern foot of the Nanling Mountains, with a north-south elevation, three-sided mountains, the north-west of which are the Du Pong Mountains, the Yuecheng Mountains, the south-east of which are the Mengzhu Mountains, the Jiuzhu Mountains, and the middle of which are the Yangming Mountains, dividing the city into two parts, north and south. The Xiangjiang River flows through the northern part of the city, and Xiaoshui flows from the south to the north, and it joins the Xiangjiang River in the city. The city has a total area of 22,259 square kilometers, a population of 542.97 million, and the city's people's government is located in the Coldwater Beach District. On November 25, 2015, Yongzhou was approved as a National Forest City. On December 16, 2016, Yongzhou was designated as a National Historic and Cultural Landmark by the State Council. Yongzhou ancient times called Zero Ling, because Sun Tzu's southern crusade collapsed in Ningyuan Jiuzhu Mountain, the Empress, the wife of Ying Qianli, the sad and tearful story (zero Ling's "zero" word, is "tears" means tears). According to the Book of Chronicles of the Five Emperors, Shun was "a hunter-gatherer from the south, who died in the wilderness, and was buried in Jiangnan nine times, and was buried in the tomb of Zero." At the time of the Spring and Autumn War, it belonged to the southern border of Chu Province, and at the time of the Qin Dynasty it belonged to Changsha County. In the year 111 BC, Emperor Wu of Han established Jialing County. At the beginning of the Sui Dynasty, Yongzhou was established as the headquarters, and Yongzhou and Zeroling were named thereafter. Also because Xiaoshui and Xiangjiang meet in the city, Yongzhou calls itself Xiaoxiang in ancient times. After the reunification of China, the Sui dynasty abolished the state, county, and county system in accordance with the principle of "save for leisure, and small for large".

Yang Nenju (Chinese: 楊念祖; born May 15, 1955) is a Taiwanese military strategist and politician, born in Danyang County, Gansu Province, who served as the Minister of Defense and a professor at National Sun Yat-sen University. He holds a bachelor's degree in sociology from the Catholic University of Zurich. He holds a master's degree in sociology from the University of Reading and a master's degree in political science from the Institute of Political and Economic Studies, London. Yang's research papers include: New Century Chinese Communist Liberation Army and the security of the Taiwan Sea, the evolution and future development of the Chinese Communist Party's military strategy, the latest U.S. defense assessment and relations between the two sides, the defense environment of the Republic of China and the direction of military build-up, Taiwan should fight asymmetric warfare, and the recent development of the Liberation Army Air Force. He has participated in academic conferences in Hong Kong and the United States. He was appointed Deputy Minister of Defence on 16 September 2009 by Prime Minister Ma Ying-jeou, but resigned on 6 August 2013 due to the collapse of the Hong Chung-kyu incident, and was promoted to Minister of Defence on 1 August 2013. He is an Assistant Researcher at National Sun Yat-sen University Research Center, a Lecturer at National Sun Yat-sen University Research Institute, Secretary-General of the Taiwan Association for Higher Policy Studies, Visiting Scholar at the United States News Agency (USIA), Director of the National Sun Yat-sen University Academic Research Center, Advisory Committee on Foreign Affairs, Advisory Committee on Land Commission, Advisory Committee on Defense Report of the Ministry of Defense, Lecturer at National Sun Yat-sen University, Senior Strategic Studies Course of the Ministry of Defense, Special Professor at National Sun Yat-sen University Center for Educational Understanding.

Eventually, 543 people were rescued and brought back to Shanghai, surpassing the total number of other rescue ships. Three hours after the disaster, the Maori and Jiangxian ships, as well as several sailing boats, were also involved in the rescue effort. In the end, the entire Ganga ship was rescued by just over 900 people. The Marine Corps dispatched divers to the area and recovered more than 1,000 bodies, with an estimated death toll of over 3,000, most of them from Ningbo. It was also China's largest naval disaster at the time. Jiang's shipwreck shocked both Shanghai and Ningbo. The Shanghai Declaration continues to cover this issue. On the issue of compensation, there was a dispute between Ningbo Travel Association and China Merchants Bureau. In the opinion of the Ningbo Travel and Tourism Association, the overloading of ships should be the responsibility of the Merchant Marine Bureau. However, the Mergers and Acquisitions Bureau insists that it must be able to compensate on the premise that it can verify the facts. A petition was also filed for compensation, but it was denied and the case was eventually dismissed. There are all kinds of theories about the cause of the Jiangyao explosion, including boiler explosions, rocket hits, time bombs, bomblets, torpedo attacks, water mines, etc., but they have not been proven. It's also said that a bomb dropped by an army bomber accidentally sank the Jiangya River, and it's also said that a communist agent planted the bomb to create panic in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, but there's no evidence of that. The boiler explosion is said to be the earliest explanation of the Jiangyao explosion, proposed by the Ningbo Brigade and Shanghai Township Association's Good Aftermath Legal Group. According to various signs (e.g., the body was found to have been blown up, the hull was torn open), and survivors testified that the boiler operators "were dismissed from their duties and gambled with the crowd every time they left Wu Songkou". However, there is ample evidence to deny this, as the boiler connections are complete and the most critical chimneys are still standing.

Feng Jicai (Chinese: 冯 Jicai; born February 9, 1942) is a Chinese contemporary writer and painter. Early in his career, he worked as a painter in Tianjin, and later devoted himself to literary creation and folk culture research. It promotes a lot of folk culture protection propaganda work. He has written a great deal of poetry, novels and paintings. He also wrote several articles for primary and secondary schools and university textbooks, such as the essay "Pearl Bird". It is also used by the Ministry of Education of the Republic of China as the language of instruction in the sixth and fourth grades of elementary schools. He currently holds the following positions: Executive Vice-President of the Chinese Federation of Arts and Letters, President of the Chinese Society of Fiction, President of the Chinese Association of Folk Artists, Vice-President of the International Organization of Folk Arts (IOV), Vice-President of the Central Committee of the China Association for the Promotion of Democracy, Standing Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, and Counsellor of the State Council. Feng Jicai (Chinese: 冯 Jicai; pinyin: Fǔ Jicai; pinyin: Fǔ Jicai; pinyin: Fǔ Jicai; pinyin: Fǔ Jicai; pinyin: Fǔ Jicai) was born in Tianjin on February 9, 1942, and lived in Tianjin until about 1982. After graduating from high school in 1960, he worked at a book and painting company. In 1974, he moved to Tianjin Arts and Crafts Workers Amateur University to teach painting and art theory. He began writing fiction in the late 1970s, and in 1977 he published a historical novel, Yoshikazu Ken (義和拳), with Li Dingxing. Afterwards, he wrote about the subjects of the Cultural Revolution, such as "The Smoke Bucket," "The Path of Laying Flowers," "Ah!," "The Tall Woman and Her Dwarf Husband," and "One Hundred Years of One Hundred Persons," and became one of the representative writers of scar fiction. In the 1980s, he became a member of the Chinese Writers' Association, and was the editor-in-chief of Literary Freedom Talk magazine and Artist magazine. After seeing the rapid development of Tianjin and the disappearance of a large number of historically valuable buildings and cultures, in the late 1990s, efforts began to protect Tianjin's original culture.

Tsai Ing-wen (Chinese: Tsai Ing-wen; born 31 August 1956) is a Chinese politician, lawyer, and lawyer, and the current President of the Republic of China. In 1986, she participated in international negotiations such as the World Trade Organization and received a government award. In the 2008 presidential election, she was elected as the party's first female party president. In 2014, she was re-elected as the party's chairwoman, winning nine of the 13 seats in the local mayoral elections. In 2022, after the defeat of the Communist Party of China in the Nine-Party Elections, she resigned as chairwoman of the Communist Party of China. On August 31, 1956, Tsai was born at Ma Kai Memorial Hospital in Taipei City, China. His father, Tsai Jie-sheng, had been drafted into the South to escape the Japanese army, and at the time in Manchuria (now northeastern China), he was studying at a mechanical school to repair fixed-wing aircraft. As a child, Tsai was loved by her parents and brothers and sisters. In 1963, he attended Chang'an National Primary School in the middle mountains of northern Taipei. In 1966, when she was in fourth grade, she transferred to the newly established Jilin National Primary School in the Mid-mountains of Taipei City. In 1971, she graduated from the first year of Bei'an National High School in Taipei. In high school, I attended Taipei Sun Yat-sen Women's High School. With former president's wife Zeng Wenhui (the third high-ranking lady), the daughter of the famous sculptor Yang Yingfeng, Yang Hanhong, and Xu Guan Qianfashi are all Zhongshan Women's Middle School alumni. In 1974, after graduating from high school, the family business needed a legal background. He graduated from Cornell University in 1980. She studied law at the London School of Economics under the title Unfair trade practices and safeguard actions.

The law of the Republic of China is divided into three levels: the Constitution, the Law, and the Order, based on the Constitution of the Republic of China, and the Standard Law of the Republic of China, based on the Standard Law of the Republic of China. Legislation is enacted, amended, and repealed by the Legislative Assembly of the Republic of China, and is then promulgated by the President of the Republic of China. The Six Laws of the Republic of China (Chinese: 六法全書) are the most common laws of the Republic of China, including the Constitution, the Administrative Law, the Civil Law, the Criminal Law, the Civil Procedure Law and the Criminal Procedure Law. More than 80% of the legal provisions of the Republic of China are subject to German and Swiss inheritance, especially civil law, so that many legal scholars go to Germany to study for law degrees. The Republic of China is a continental legal system, based on statute law, unlike the United Kingdom and the United States, which are based on case law. According to Article 2 of the Standard Law of Central Regulations, the names of laws are divided into four categories: laws, laws, ordinances, and general rules. Legislation is enacted by the Legislative Assembly and enforced by the President. The order is a specific measure issued by an administrative body, and must not violate the provisions of the Constitution and laws. By their very nature, they are called rules, regulations, sub-rules, procedures, guidelines, standards, or norms (Article 3 of the Standard Law of Central Regulations), and the above-mentioned names are for illustrative purposes only, without prejudice to the validity of their orders if any other names are adopted. In addition, local governments may, within their sphere of autonomy or under the authority of central laws and regulations, formulate autonomous regulations, divided into two types of autonomous regulations and autonomous regulations.

The Jinshu, written in 648 AD, is one of the twenty-four histories of China, compiled by Genling Tang Fang and others, with twenty-one authors. It is recorded in the history of the Three Kingdoms period from the early years of Shima Yi, down to the Eastern Jin Dynasty of Emperor Gong of Yuanxi II (420), Liu Yu abolished the Jin emperor's independence, taking the name of Song Dynasty of Jin. The book also describes the situation of the Sixteen Kingdoms in the form of a chronicle. There were original narratives, one volume for each catalogue, ten volumes for the Chronicles, twenty volumes for the Chronicles, seventy volumes for the Epistles, thirty volumes for the Chronicles, a total of one hundred and thirty-two volumes. Later narratives and catalogues were lost, and there are now one hundred and thirty volumes. Twenty-one authors have contributed to Jinshu. The Tang dynasty attached great importance to the study of history, and China began to establish museums of history in the Tang Dynasty, the Jinsho being the first of them. There are six historical books of the Twenty-fourth Dynasty: Jinsho, Liangsho, Chensho, Beizisho, Zhousho, and Suisho, which were completed during the Tang Dynasty. Prior to the Tang Dynasty, there were eighteen Jin dynasties, and in fact there were more than twenty, of which Shen Yao, Zheng Zhong, and Yu Mei three have died, and the rest still exist. At that time, the Tang Dynasty considered these Jin histories to be flawed, and "although they were made, they were not perfect", so in 646, the Emperor issued a decree to repair Jinsho, and the Tang Dynasty said in the Decree to repair Jinsho: "Great, it is also useful to repair historical books." The book was edited by a group of historians and scholars under the supervision of Fang Xuanling and others, and was based on the book of Jin written by Zang Rongxu of the Southern Dynasty, while referring to other scholars of Jin history and related works, "taking dozens of canons and anecdotes," and citing the historical books compiled by the Sixteen Kingdoms, and began to be written from 646 to 648.

At the end of the Eastern Han Dynasty, the department of cross-sectional history was changed to the department of cross-state. During the Three Kingdoms period, the province was divided into Guangdong Province and Guangdong Province to the north. In the Tang Dynasty, the excavation of the Meiguan ancient road facilitated the transportation between the Central Plains and the Lingnan region, and Guangzhou became the main port of overseas trade in the country. In 862, Lingnan Province was divided into two provinces, East and West, and Guangdong Province was divided into Lingnan Province and East Province. At the end of the Tang Dynasty, it was occupied by the Southern Han Dynasty. After the defeat of the Southern Han dynasty by the Song dynasty, the Lingnan Road was rebuilt and the Guangnan East Road was divided into three sections in 997. In the Yuan Dynasty, Guangdong Province was divided into Guangdong Province and Haibei Hainan Province, divided into Jiangxi Province and Guangdong Province. In 1369, Guangdong Province was renamed Guangdong Province, and Hainan Province was merged with Haibei Province. In the Qing Dynasty, there were two governors of Guangdong and Guangxi provinces. During the Ming and Qing dynasties, Guangdong's economic and cultural development had leapt to the forefront of the nation. After the Opium War, Guangdong became a source of democratic revolutionary measures to overthrow the Qing dynasty and establish a republic. On November 9, 1911, representatives from all walks of life in Guangdong held a meeting at the Guangdong Consultative Bureau to proclaim the independence of the Republic of Guangdong. After Yuan Shi Kai's reign, Guangdong entered the era of warlord rule. Sun Yat-sen established a revolutionary regime in Guangdong three times, and Guangdong became the center of the national revolutionary movement. In 1925, the National Government of the Republic of China was established in Guangzhou. In October 1938, the Japanese occupied Guangzhou, and the Guangdong government withdrew to northern Guangdong. After the founding of the People's Republic of China, the Guangdong Provincial People's Government was officially established on November 6, 1949. In 1952, Beihai City and Qinzhou District were annexed to Guangxi, and Guangxi's Huaicheng County was annexed to Guangdong. In 1955, Guangdong Province was divided into Guangdong Province (Guangdong Province) and Guangdong Province (Guangdong Province), and was renamed Guangdong Province (Guangdong Province) and Guangdong Province (Guangdong Province).

Despite the conflict, the leaders of post-reunification Vietnam and Cambodia conducted several open diplomatic exchanges during 1976 to underline the so-called strong relationship between them. However, cross-border attacks occurred again on 15–18 March 1977 in Jiangjiang Province and on 25–28 March 1977 in Anjiang Province. Further attacks occurred on 30 April, 17 May and 19 May 1977, killing 222 civilians. In a raid on 17 May, Khmer Rouge artillery shelled the provincial capital of Anjiang, Zhuatsu City. On 25 September 1977, during the Mid-Autumn Festival, the Pol Pot army launched an attack across the Cambodian-Vietnamese border, penetrating about 10 kilometers into Xining Province, killing 592 local residents. At the end of 1978, Pol Pot mobilized ten divisions to prepare for the invasion of Vietnam, and in December 1978, the Politburo of the Communist Party of Vietnam and the Central Military Commission adopted a decision to suppress the Pol Pot group. On December 25, 1978, the Vietnamese Army launched an all-out offensive against Cambodia with a combined force of 18 army divisions, 15 brigades, and one aviation division. The Commander-in-Chief of Military Operations is Lieutenant General Lai Chung Xun, Deputy Minister of Defense and Chief of the General Staff of the Vietnam People's Army. The Vietnamese army deployed seven military-level ground units, north to south as follows: 24 divisions of the Khmer Rouge, 2,000 to 4,000 men per division, deployed along the border. There are 1 division on Highway 19, 3 divisions on Highway 13, 5 divisions on Highway 7, 5 divisions on Highway 1, 8 divisions on Highway 1, 2 divisions on Highway 2, and 5 new divisions on Highway 3.

In August 1921, he enrolled at the University College London School of Art, Synod College, where he met Fourth Years, who was studying at the University of London. In 1922, he joined the Communist Party of China under the introduction of Liu Kiwen and Shao Yuanqiu. In 1923, he participated in the restoration of the London branch of the Kuomintang. In September 1924, after graduating from the University of London, he was admitted to the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris for further studies, having previously moved to France from the United Kingdom with Shaw and Fournier. He also joined Xie Jukang, Xu Xianghong, and other Chinese student organizations such as "The Dog Association". In 1926, Zhang Daohan was once selected for the Salon des Beaux-Arts in Paris for three works of art; in late June, after returning from Europe, he was invited by Liu Haiwu to lecture in Shanghai. On August 1, Zhang Daohan was appointed secretary of Guangdong Provincial Agricultural and Industrial Department, headed by Liu Kiwen. At the invitation of the mayor of Nanjing Special City, Liu Kiwen, he became secretary-general of Nanjing Municipal Government in September 1928. In May 1928, he participated in the founding of the National Qingdao University, later serving as its president. In December 1930, he was appointed a member of the Zhejiang Provincial Government and head of the Department of Education. In June 1931, he was appointed Deputy Director of the Central Organization Department, and the following year he was appointed Permanent Deputy Director of the Ministry of Transport. On November 12, 1933, Zhang Daohan, along with dozens of artists from Nanjing, Shanghai, and Beiping, founded the China Art Society in Nanjing, serving as its president. And we organized theater troupes, improvisational theater troupes. On October 18, 1935, he founded the National Drama School in Nanjing. In January 1938, the National Government was reorganized, Chen Lifu was appointed as the head of the Ministry of Education, Zhang Daohan as the deputy head of the Ministry of Education, and the editor-in-chief of the compendium of textbooks. In September 1939, he became the headmaster of the Central Political School.

Malaysia is a federation of 13 states, with a parliamentary democracy and an elected monarchy. The Malaysian parliamentary system follows the Westminster parliamentary system of the British Parliament, and is also classified as a representative democracy. Malaysia's legal system is an Anglo-American system, with common law jurisdiction. The Prime Minister of Malaysia is the elected head of state of Malaysia, and is also the Commander-in-Chief of the Malaysian Army, Navy and Air Force. Although the Supreme Head has nominal supreme legislative, judicial, and administrative powers, may exercise his or her functions and royal prerogatives on his or her own, in practice, the Constitution also limits his or her powers. The Supreme Head must take into account the views of the Prime Minister and the Cabinet in exercising his executive powers, as well as in exercising his legislative powers in accordance with the decisions of Parliament. Although the Supreme Head is considered the "symbolic" head of state, the federal government operates strictly in the name of the Supreme Head. In nominal terms, the Supreme Head "delegates power to the Prime Minister through the Constitution," and the federal government governs the country in the name of the Supreme Head. Therefore, the federal government is also known as the "His Majesty's Government" (Malay: Kerajaan Seri Paduka Baginda; English: His Majesty's Government), the supreme head of state, although a constitutional monarch, must consider the views of the prime minister and cabinet when exercising his powers. However, the Federal Constitution grants the Supreme Head three discretionary powers, which can be exercised without regard to the views of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, namely: The Federal Government of Malaysia is headed by the Prime Minister of Malaysia, who is also known as the Head of Government. According to the Constitution of Malaysia, the Parliament of Malaysia is the federal legislature of Malaysia.

Taiwanese cinema refers to the production and production of films in Taiwan, which began in the Heian period, and is closely related to the social development of each era. Contemporary Taiwanese society is multicultural, free and creative, so it can give filmmakers a good stretching stage, and has a certain influence on the Chinese film graphics. Taiwanese films are often referred to as "national films", but this term is only used to refer to films made in Taiwan after the National Government took over the territory in 1945 or after the partition of the two sides in 1949. In 1898, the Japanese Buddhist Shinshu Shonen Church held a "Shonen Education Projection Illumination" outside Taipei's North Gate, which was the first time a film was shown in Taiwan until the last Taiwanese film, "Chen San Gong Musume" in 1981, Taiwan experienced more than two decades of Taiwanese film era. According to statistics, the total production of Taiwanese films is nearly 2,000, with a maximum annual production of 120 films. In the 1960s, the Central Film Company hired Lee to shoot two films, Oyster Girl and Duck House, and Bai Jing Rui's Home in Taipei, both of which were well-received, from which martial arts, kung fu, and martial arts films became the mainstream of Taiwanese cinema until the 1980s. In the mid-1970s, due to Taiwan's withdrawal from the United Nations and other adverse factors, a number of patriotic propaganda films were shot to stabilize the population. In 1982, the Central Film Company made a four-part documentary film, The Story of Light and Shadow, which is considered to be the first Taiwanese New Wave film. In the mid-1980s, Taiwanese films began to focus on taboo subjects, reflecting on and exploring contemporary Taiwanese society, history, and personal memories, the most striking of which was Hou Xiaoxian's City of Sorrows.

On 16 November, Zeng Qingdao and John Gibson negotiated with the British, but the British failed to achieve their objective and decided to use force to force Qing to surrender. In October 1868, the British commander in Hong Kong, Sir Halley Keppel, after receiving the request of the British Consul General, ordered Lieutenant Gurdon and his two ships, Algrine and Bustard, to attack Hong Kong. On 25 November, two British ships opened fire on Anping, intending to capture the city, and Vice Admiral Jiang Guozhen of the Qing Dynasty's Marine Corps was stationed in Anping, while Liang Yuangui and Taiwanese General Liu Mingtongmen immediately sent troops to support the city. The British attacked during the night. Defeated by the Qing army, the Jiang kingdom feared the punishment, the situation was in turmoil. Soon, peace fell. After the occupation of Anping, the British declared that if the Qing court did not renegotiate, they would seize all of Taiwan. Zeng was forced to reopen negotiations, and on 29 November signed the Camphor Treaty: the Governor-General of Ho Chi Minh City sent Zeng to Taiwan, consulted with the British Consul General, Sir Richard Thompson, and obtained the consent of the British Ambassador to Beijing, Sir Rutherford Alcook, to conclude the Camphor Treaty: it was signed at the end of December of the same year, and Man Qing abandoned the camphor administration under foreign interference. All of the officers of Taiwan's Taoyuan Gui (梁元桂) and Fengshan County (鳳山知縣) and Shigang County (鹿港同知) were dismissed from their posts. The British ambassador to the United States, James T. Simpson, was also recalled by the British government to face disciplinary action for armed robbery. This dispute was referred to by foreigners as the Camphor War or Camphor Conflict, and after the signing of the Camphor Treaty, the export of camphor to Taiwan fell into British hands.

Liu Jian-gun (劉健群, Liu Jian-gun; 1902 – March 17, 1972) was a Chinese poet and novelist. He was the first member of the Legislative Council of the Republic of China and the third chairman of the Legislative Council of the People's Republic of China. Born in April 1928, he dropped out of the Guizhou Provincial Specialized School. Early in his career, he served as Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces and Commander-in-Chief of the Air Force. In 1925, any necessary secretary. He was appointed as the Commander-in-Chief of Wuhan Camp, Nanchang Camp, and Liu Jianjun as the Commander-in-Chief of Camp Office respectively. In March 1930, he moved to Nanjing to live in Hongwu Road. Chiang Kai-shek sent people to examine him. Chiang then invited him several times to talk to him, and he was very understanding of him. Chiang Kai-shek said to Hsin-chung, "Liu Jian-guang is five years ahead of Chen Guo-fu, ten years ahead of you. He was subsequently appointed as Commander-in-Chief of the Military Committee (General) (the former Commander-in-Chief had been appointed Commander-in-Chief of the General Command for Combating Banditry in the Three Provinces of Yuan and Anhui). In 1931, he wrote a pamphlet for Chiang Kai-shek entitled "The Rethinking of the Kuomintang", suggesting that "the Kuomintang, imitating Mussolini's Brownshirts, should follow the orders of its leaders, and its members should wear blue shirts". In March 1932, Chiang Kai-shek, Kang Zeng, and others founded the Rikkensha in Nanjing, and Liu's suggestion played a catalytic role. The non-Huangpu students were appointed as the core cadre, only Liu Jian group. Afterwards, he was appointed head of the Political Training Department of the Military Commission, presided over the National Military Political Workers, and was ordered to set up a "political training course" in Nanjing. Around 1,000 high school students were trained in the "One Party, One Ideology, One Leader, One Enemy" program, and after graduation, all graduated as Huangpu students, all of whom were recruited as reconstruction workers and cadres of the reserve army's political workers.

On 3 March, Pakistan accused India of violating the two treaties and filed a complaint with the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) Council. India initially objected to the Council's jurisdiction, but on 29 July the Council ruled that it had jurisdiction. Accordingly, India appealed the ruling on 30 August of the same year, arguing that its right of appeal and the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice to entertain appeals also derive from the two treaties. Pakistan objected that the International Court of Justice had no jurisdiction to hear the appeal. Iceland did not participate in any stage of the proceedings, nor did it accept any statement of facts, allegations or legal arguments made by the United Kingdom. Iceland did not participate in any stage of the proceedings, nor did it accept any statement of facts or legal arguments or justifications put forward by Germany. Furthermore, on 14 January 1974, the Court voted not to merge the case with the United Kingdom v. Iceland case, because the positions and opinions of the two claimants differed and the merger would not meet its wishes. The main controversy is as follows: The main controversy is as follows: Malta had submitted an application to join the proceedings in 1981, but the court failed to approve it in view of the fact that both parties had expressed their disagreement with Malta's accession. Iran did not participate in the proceedings, but its Foreign Minister sent a letter saying that the case could not and should not be accepted by the International Court of Justice. Italy had submitted an application to join the proceedings in 1984, but the court failed to approve it, as both parties had expressed their disagreement with Italy's accession. But the court assured Italy that it would protect the interests of Italy in participating in the proceedings, without prejudice to the territory in which Italy sought the continental shelf. El Salvador submitted an application to join the proceedings in 1984, but the court failed to approve its immediate participation.

The British coronavirus vaccination program began in December 2020, and with rapid vaccination, the British government eased its restrictive controls. Meanwhile, Scotland first implemented the Second All-Scotland Blockade on 22 September. Northern Ireland, Wales and England imposed their second national blockades on 14, 23 and 31 October, respectively. A third national blockade was imposed by the constituent nations during the Christmas holidays. In July 2021, a new strain of Delta virus, first discovered in the Republic of India, spread to the United Kingdom, triggering a third epidemic that continues to this day. As the British government lifted all mandatory control measures, except for house arrest, from July 19, 2021, until December 2021, a new variant of Omicronium was introduced into the UK from South Africa, causing record-breaking numbers of new cases. Meanwhile, the British government had briefly reintroduced measures to prevent epidemics such as wearing indoor masks. As of January 4, 2022, more than 13.64 million people in the United Kingdom had been infected with the virus, with 217,724 new cases, the highest number of new cases per day in the United Kingdom to date. Because the UK had achieved basic population immunization in the second half of 2021 with vaccination, the third wave of the Delta virus, which was more infectious and less symptomatic than the previous two outbreaks, and which was dominated by Omicron, had little impact on British society. On 21 February 2022, epidemic control measures, including house arrest, were lifted in England. The median age of death after exposure to the virus was 83 years. In January 2020, Heathrow Airport tightened its surveillance of three direct flights a week from Wuhan; everyone would be subject to a customs health inspection.

The Chinese Civil War (Chinese: 中内戰; pinyin: Zhōngzhōngzhōn; pinyin: Zhōngzhōngzhōn; Chinese: 中内戰; pinyin: Zhōngzhōngzhōn; pinyin: Zhōngzhōngzhōn) was a civil war fought in China in the first half of the 20th century, and was the largest and most profoundly affected civil war of the 20th century. The Communist Party of China (CPC) gained control of mainland China during the Civil War and established the People's Republic of China to replace the original Republic of China state system, while the KMT and the government of the Republic of China moved to Taiwan, resulting in political separation and military confrontation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The meeting adopted Zhang Qi's China Youth Party Program, China Youth Party Charter, and issued the China Youth Party Founding Party Declaration. According to Lee, the party's founding aim was "to see international communism, party-owned organizations, both at home and abroad, infiltrated by young intellectuals, who, if they did not get up early and confronted, would make it easier for Stalin to defeat the Chinese conspiracy." The party's aim is "to strive for the independence and freedom of the Republic of China as the flag" and "to overthrow the warlords who do evil to the country and its people, and to realize national politics." Due to the small number of members at the meeting, the party did not elect the chairman and the executive committee according to the party charter, but decided to establish two groups, the Party Affairs and Propaganda, and assumed Tsang Qi as the chairman of the Party Affairs Group and Zhang Zhizhu as the chairman of the Propaganda Group. Due to the weakness of the Youth Party, the organization's name was kept secret for a long time, only appearing under the name "China Nationalist Youth League". It was not until the Fourth Congress in September 1929 that the party's name was made public. On April 20–21, 1924, Li Huang attended the First Party Congress of the Chinese Youth Party in Paris, where he delivered a speech entitled "The Meaning of Nationalism". The General Assembly elected a central leader, and a central leadership body was formed. Lee was elected Minister of Foreign Affairs. In September 1924, Li Juan and Zeng Qi returned to the country. Li Juan said that the reason for this was that Zhou Enlai and other members of the Communist Brigade were returning home, "expecting increasing communist activity in the country, believing that it is impossible to pursue without following". He also said that he wanted to "embrace the brave in the face of adversity, prepare to return home and fight the International Communist Party to the end." On 10 October, together with Tsang Qi, Li Juan, Zhang Mengjun, Sa Sun-sheng, Chen Kai-tian, Yu Jia-kiu, and others, he founded the Zhou Zhuang newspaper in Shanghai, opposed the strategy of the Kuomintang-Russian Communist Party, insisting on "nationalism" as the center, striving to propagate nationalism.

On 8 September 1943, Italy surrendered and was divided into two parts due to political differences in the northern and southern regions; the north was formed by Fascists as the Italian Social Republic, and the south was restored as the democratic Kingdom of Italy before the seizure of power by Mussolini. The Carabinieri Command for Liberated Italy was formed in Bari in the south and recruited new recruits to join the Italian Liberation Movement, as well as the Italian Co-Belligerent Army, which had already entered Italy, to fight the remaining Fascist parties in the north with the help of Nazi Germany. After the rescue of Mussolini, the remnants of the Fascists organized themselves in the north, remaining loyal to Mussolini's cavalry, and some of the surviving members of the Blackshirts, to form a "Blackshirts Brigade", which retaliated fiercely against Fascist opponents in its areas of control, and fought against the Liberation Army and Allied forces in the south. Although at its peak, the Blackshirts once claimed to have more than 49 brigade-level units, each "brigade" was only a small regiment, with no more than 1,2000 men. Due to the role of the Cavalry in the fall of Mussolini and the fact that one of the only two teams to fight the Germans during the Nazi occupation of Rome was a student battalion from the Second Cavalry School, the Germans became extremely distrustful of the Cavalry. After the German occupation of northern Italy in October 1943 and the formation of the Italian Social Republic, all cavalry units in the occupation zone were disbanded, many officers and men were arrested and deported to Germany as forced labor.

Phoenix is a minor constellation in the southern sky, named after the mythical bird of immortality, first delineated by Peter Keizer and Frederick Houtman, the astronomical instrument on the Peter Francis sign, published by John Byrne in 1603. The French explorer and astronomer Nicolas Louis Lacaille charted the brightest stars in the constellation in 1756, and assigned the Greek letters to them using the Bayer nomenclature. The constellation's declination is between −39° and −57°, and its declination is between 23.5 and 2.5 hours. Phoenix, Crane, Peacock, and Tucana are the four birds of the Southern Hemisphere. It's the brightest star in the constellation, and it's a bright orange giant with a magnitude of 2.37. The second-brightest Mars Nine is composed of two orange giants, a binary star with a combined apparent magnitude of 3.31. Phoenix has a disk of debris. We've discovered planets in 10 of the Phoenix constellations, and in the 21st century we've discovered the Phoenix Cluster and the Elgordo Cluster, two of the largest observable galaxies in the universe, 5.7 and 7.2 billion light-years away from Earth, respectively. There are two meteor showers in Phoenix, in July and December, respectively, and the latest research suggests that there may be seven more. The Dutch navigators and explorers Pieter Keyser and Frederick de Houtman, who accompanied the first Dutch expedition to the East Indies with the Indonesian fleet, charted twelve constellations in the southern sky, the largest of which was Phoenix. Astronomy historian Richard Allen notes that the Phoenix constellation was formed in ancient astronomy, unlike other constellations such as Pluto or Nicolas Louis Lacaille, which Arabs viewed as hummingbirds, vultures or eagles.

A brown dwarf is a secondary star between the heaviest gas giant and the lightest star, typically between 13 and 75 or 80 Jupiter masses. Unlike stars in the main sequence, brown dwarfs are not massive enough to sustain a nuclear fusion reaction of hydrogen (1H) into helium in the core. However, they range between 13 MJ and 65 MJ. All stars are classified according to their spectra, and brown dwarfs are classified as M, L, T, and Y-type stars. Within the visible wavelength range, brown dwarfs are very faint. The brown dwarfs known to have planets around them are 2M1207b, MOA-2007-BLG-192Lb, and J044144b. The nearest brown dwarf to Earth is Luman 16, discovered in 2013, which is a pair of binary stars 6.5 light-years away. As of December 2017, the largest extrasolar planet in NASA's archives is HR 2562 b, estimated to have a mass of 7001300000000000000♠30±15 MJ, more than twice the mass boundary of planets and brown dwarfs (13 MJ). In the 1960s, the existence of brown dwarfs was theoretically postulated. At the time of the discovery of the theory by Hiv Kumar in the 1960s, what is now known as a brown dwarf was known as a black dwarf. The term "black dwarf" now refers to white dwarfs that have cooled to the point where they no longer emit visible light. However, it has been calculated that even the least massive white dwarfs take much longer to cool to this temperature than the present age of the universe, so it is not expected that such objects will exist.

The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) designates the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council as "nuclear-weapon states", with the United States, Russia (inheriting the Soviet Union), the United Kingdom, France, and China being the first to have successfully acquired nuclear weapons. At the height of the Cold War in 1986, there were 70,300 nuclear weapons in the world that could be deployed immediately, and in 2019, there are only 3,750 nuclear weapons that could be deployed immediately, while the total number of nuclear weapons in the world is still over 13,890. The following is a list of sovereign states that have recognized nuclear weapons, including the number of warheads they currently possess and the dates of their first tests: During World War II, the United States began working with the United Kingdom and Canada on a classified Manhattan Project in the 1940s, in response to the possibility that Nazi Germany would develop nuclear weapons earlier than its allies. In August 1945, the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan, making it the only country in the world to actually use nuclear weapons against enemy forces, with two bomb blasts estimated to have killed more than 200,000 people and injured more than 130,000. At this time, nuclear weapons weighed about 5 tons, and the troops had to use heavy bombers to transport the bombs over their targets. The Soviet Union also began to develop its own nuclear weapons program. On November 1, 1952, the United States successfully detonated the first hydrogen bomb designed in accordance with the Teller-Ulam design program at the Changchun Fuji Mak nuclear test site on Enewetak Atoll, becoming the first country in the world to develop a hydrogen bomb.

The Shanghai People's Groups Federation (Shanghai: 上海人民团体联合会; pinyin: Zhōngzhōngzhōngzhōngǎn; pinyin: Zhōngzhōngǎngzhōngǎn) is a Shanghai People's Groups Federation founded in 1946. On May 5, 1946, under the leadership of the Shanghai Underground Party of the Communist Party of China, 52 Shanghai People's Groups formed the Shanghai People's Group Federation (Chinese: 上海人民团体联合会). All the people's groups unanimously recommended that China Democracy Promotion Association take the lead in the preparation of the joint body. In mid-June 1946, the Shanghai People's Organization Federation and the Shanghai Students' Peace Promotion Association jointly launched the Shanghai People's Peace Petitions League to oppose the civil war, and on 23 June 1946 they went to the capital Nanjing to petition. As soon as the petitioners arrived at Nanjing Shimonoseki Station, they were beaten by Kuomintang agents and thugs, resulting in the Shimonoseki Massacre. Between 23 and 28 September 1946, ten groups, including the Shanghai People's Coalition for the Promotion of Democracy in China and the Shanghai People's Coalition for the Promotion of Democracy in the People's Republic of China, called for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from China. On November 4, 1946, the Nanjing National Government and the U.S. Government signed the Sino-American Trade Treaty, which was referred to by Chinese public opinion as the "New Twenty-first", and November 4 was called National Shame Day. On November 13, 1946, the Shanghai People's Group Union issued a Statement on the Sino-American Trade Treaty, opposing the National Government's signing of this new unequal treaty. On 29 December 1946, 11 political parties, including the China Democratic Progressive Party and the Shanghai People's Group Union, issued a joint statement protesting the U.S. atrocities, strongly demanding that the U.S. withdraw from China "immediately and with the indignation of the civilian population".

A Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) is a string used in computer terminology to identify an Internet resource name. The logo allows users to interact with resources in the network (generally referred to as the World Wide Web) through specific protocols. The most common form of a URI is the Uniform Resource Locator (URL), often designated as an informal URL. A more rare use is the Uniform Resource Name (URN), which aims to provide a pathway. Used to mark a resource in a particular namespace, to complement a URL. URIs can be viewed as locators (URLs), names (URNs), or both. A Uniform Resource Name (URN) is like a person's name, and a Uniform Resource Locator (URL) is like a person's address. In other words, the URN defines the identity of something, and the URL provides a way to find that thing. An ISBN system used to identify a unique bibliographical object is a typical URN usage example. For example, ISBN 0-486-27557-4 uniquely marks a particular version of Shakespeare's play Romeo and Juliet. In order to access the resource and read the book, people need its location, which is a URL address. In a Unix-like operating system, a typical URL address may be a file directory, such as file:///home/username/RomeoAndJuliet.pdf. The URL indicates an e-book file stored on your local hard drive. So URLs and URNs are complementary.

The so-called provincial status issue refers to the ethnic conflict that occurred in Taiwan after the National Government took over in 1945. The government of the Republic of China records the nationality of each person on the identity card. People who are registered as Taiwanese are called Taiwanese citizens. The term "foreign provinces" refers to those provinces of mainland China (which were formerly under the administration of the Republic of China) and non-Taiwan provinces registered as such before 1945, usually after the end of World War II, when the Chinese arrived in Taiwan with the government of the Republic of China and their descendants. Due to the differences in lifestyles, the two groups have often been marginalized, and have been deeply influenced to this day. In 1945, after the Japanese surrender of the Second World War, the National Government took control of Taiwan, and the Taiwanese people initially adopted a positive attitude towards it. On April 2, 1946, Taiwan's Chief Executive Chen Yi established the Taiwan Provincial Language Promotion Committee (國語会) to promote the national language movement, with the main goal of replacing Japanese with the Republic of China's language within a year, many professionals and intellectuals temporarily disapproved. In 1947, Taiwan's economy was severely damaged by the corruption and corruption of the Taiwanese army and civil servants, as well as by the National Government's collection of Taiwanese biological resources for use in the Chinese Civil War. There was a rise in malnutrition, unemployment, destitution, and growing resentment, culminating in the murder of twenty-eight people. After the suppression of the National Government, many intellectuals and people from all walks of life were killed, and the people were angry and did not dare to speak. In 1949, the government of the Republic of China withdrew from Taiwan. The Taiwanese martial law was enacted, and the White Terror began. The provincial government of Taiwan, based on the household data of the Heiji period, conducted a household survey, and everyone received an identity card, and the household and identity card were marked with the province's name.

John I had five children, the third of whom was the famous seafaring prince Enric. The 15th and 16th centuries were the heyday of Portugal, which had large colonies in Africa, Asia and the United States, and was a maritime power. Famous historical figures of this period included Prince Enrique, Bartholomew Díaz, Vasco da Gama, Ferdinand Magellan, and many others, including the first expedition to the Cape of Good Hope in Africa, the opening of a new route to India, and Magellan's first circumnavigation of the Earth. However, with the rise of other European powers overseas, Portugal's power declined. In the battles of the Triple Alliance with Morocco and Ottoman Turkey, the young Sebastian I was killed, and the royal family was annexed to Spain in 1580. In 1755, a devastating earthquake on the Richter scale struck the Portuguese capital of Lisbon, killing 100,000 people and seriously weakening the Portuguese Empire. It was invaded by the French in 1807 and occupied by the French in 1808, causing the Portuguese dynasty of Bragança to relocate its capital to the South American colony of Brazil until the end of the War of 1812. During this period, in order to gain the support of the Brazilian people, Portugal declared its equality with Brazil and changed its name to the United Kingdom of Portugal-Brazil-Algarve. In 1822 Brazil gained its independence, and in 1825 Portugal recognized Brazil's independence. On October 5, 1910, the Portuguese Revolution overthrew the monarchy, and King Manuel II fled abroad.

The Vice-Chairman ranks second only to the Chairman of the Central Committee, above the Standing Committee of other non-Party Vice-Chairmen. The Twelfth Congress of the Communist Party of China abolished the positions of President and Vice-President of the Party, and stipulated that the three positions of Chairman of the Military Committee of the CPC Central Committee, Chairman of the Advisory Committee of the CPC Central Committee, and First Secretary of the CPC Central Committee of the Communist Party of China must be held by members of the Standing Committee of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. This rule was abolished after the 13th Deng Xiaoping and others withdrew from the Politburo Standing Committee. The Standing Committee of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China is the highest-ranking body of the Communist Party of China and the Government of the People's Republic of China at the "State level". The list of members of the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the People's Republic of China after the founding of the People's Republic of China is usually arranged according to qualifications and positions, reflecting their status in the Party and the government, the list of attendance at official events, etc. However, the ranking of the Standing Committee is generally determined by the party's history and status, so sometimes it is not necessarily linked to the level of the official positions held, and the number of members is not necessarily single, for example, the six Standing Committee members elected at the 1st Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China ranked first as General Secretary of the CPC Hu Yaobang, second as Vice Chairman of the Central Military Commission Ye Jianying, third as Chairman of the Central Military Commission Deng Xiaoping, fourth as Premier of the State Council Zhao Ziyang, fifth as President Li Shen-ming, and sixth as First Secretary of the Central Military Commission Chen Yun. The meetings of the Standing Committee of the Politburo are usually held once a week. The sixteenth and seventeenth Politburo Standing Committees increased from seven members at the fourteenth and fifteenth sessions to nine, and the eighteenth resumed to seven.
